Collision of Worlds 
Invasion
Part 1
By Michael DeBuse
What do Gods fear?

An unexpected force appeared, a creation of one not divine,
An infestation of worlds.
Some vanquished the plague, but many worlds fell.
Only one world endured and remained infected, Whinhlem.
A proposition came from the God of Whinhlem.
Interference between worlds was banned.
No God shall harm another God, nor their world.
All agreed, so that none could repeat the disaster.

A law of isolation was passed, a dire punishment affixed,
For a taboo that should never be broken.
What caused the Gods such fear?
The Lurr.

Chapter 1
“The more complicated the formula, the more unexpected the results.”
Emer
Dim orange light illuminated a cluttered desk covered in wrinkled and torn parchment and intricate brass measuring instruments.
Faintly glowing, polychromatic gemstones showered specks of color on two pocket watches whose times were ever so slightly off from each other.
The only sounds in the room were the scratching of a quill and the low mumbling of the room’s owner, Emer.
Tearing another sheet of vellum in half and tossing it to the side, he exhaled his frustration.
The amount of wasted vellum on the floor was enough to make even the least frugal onlooker angry, especially his personal maid, Dyas, who would have to clean it in the morning.
She had already given him a few choice words with a weary yet understanding smile as she delivered a small cup of tea before retiring for the evening.
After pecking him lightly on the cheek, of course.
Emer was used to her flirtatious nature, so he was not startled by the sudden sign of affection, unfitting for a maid.
If anything, she made the cold, gray-marble room feel a bit warmer.
The other palace servants saw Dyas as a necessary contrast to Emer’s habitual pessimism, something she claimed she would remedy one day.
Emer retrieved a large, corked vial from the bottom drawer of his desk.
He unstopped the hole and poured the black liquid into the small inkwell that had run low.
This was his second refill of the night.
“I am a scholar, not an instructor,” Emer mumbled to himself as he returned the vial to the drawer.
He felt a tightness in his temples each time he looked at a new blank page, gripping ever heavier as the evening drew late.
Emer leaned back in his wooden chair intricately carved from the trunk of a tree and took a sip of the sour tea.
The herbs used in the brew were a special arrangement created by Dyas to help keep him awake and focused while he worked.
Having an apothecary’s daughter for a maid came with simple benefits like this.
He looked up at the extravagant etched-glass windows behind his desk as he exhaled his self-doubt with the warmth of the tea.
The etchings depicted the movement of the stars, moons, and planets.
Another exhale passed his thin lips, this time to release his feelings of inadequacy.
The windows were a creation of his superior and former master, Evhial, a High Elf and gravity specialist who served as the court magician for Emperor Yuro Amel until her abrupt passing two years ago.
Years on Whinhlem were already long—long enough for an infant to reach adulthood after only experiencing three summers—but those years felt even longer in Evhial’s absence.
Every thought of Emer’s superior was another reminder of just how superior she was to him in every conceivable way.

Evhial built the windows as a replacement for the sky that would have otherwise been visible if not for the poorly placed and grandiose bastion obstructing any and all view from her office, now his office.

So long as he periodically recharged the etched glass with raw ven, the natural energy that fueled magic, the etchings would react directly to the minute shifts in the unique gravitational pulls of each heavenly body, tracking and following them as they moved across the sky with utmost precision.
It was a complex magical technology that had never existed before Evhial’s time.
Superior…
Emer observed the etchings on the glass hoping that somehow the brilliance of his late master would inspire a similar brilliance in him.
He often doubted himself, and there were many who shared in those doubts due to his lineage and inexperience.
He recalled when he received candidacy for the position of court magician, the highest magical position in the Amelian Empire.

When his appointment came to council discussion after Evhial’s death, he was not able to raise his voice in defense against the dissenting opinions speaking of tradition and pure heritage, let alone he being sixteen years of age, well into adulthood but still far too young for anyone to see him as experienced in magic, or at least experienced enough to hold such an esteemed position.
Plus, the position of court magician had traditionally been held only by High Elves.
Emer was High Elf in appearance, but only half by blood.
He was much shorter.
His father was a fairy.

Fairies tended to have a strong affinity to only a single element, which would have eliminated his chance of being court magician, a position that required at least an affinity to the four basic elements and one rare element.

The fortune of his birth gave him the affinities of both his mother and father which when combined totaled not only the four basic elements of water, earth, fire, and wind, but also the rare affinities of spatial and life magic, life magic being a common affinity for High Elves.
His sudden call to candidacy, the only candidate, came as a surprise.
Candidates were always selected after years of investigation and assessment, but Emperor Yuro ordered the selection be made immediately after Evhial’s death.
His reason?
He did not want to delay the magic education of First Princess Eydis FeAmel, a task given to none other than the court magician.
Emer recalled the unspoken urgency hidden behind his emperor’s eyes.
Emperor Yuro’s reasoning felt shallow to the royal council, and many demanded the call be postponed for another four years at the least until a more suitable body of candidates could be cultivated.
“Appoint him.”
A crisp but young voice echoed across the hall of Emer’s memory.

Eydis FeAmel, who would eventually become the empress of the Amelian Empire, then only an adolescent of two and a half years old but far enough in her education to sit in council, silenced the dissenters.
Emer’s appointment was ratified by only a slight margin.
Slight, but slight was enough.
He would spend his life serving her, so her blessing was all the convincing that the council needed.
Shortly after his appointment was ratified, Emer learned that the first princess had an affinity to spatial magic, his specialization.
Evhial had made the discovery shortly before her passing during a clandestine trip on the princess’s order to visit Evhial’s associate, a trow geneticist, on some matter of secrecy.
Princess Eydis’s spatial affinity had been kept secret from the council, including that it was Emperor Yuro himself who had given Emer the candidacy while rejecting all others.
Even now, the number of people who knew was few.
In Emer’s opinion, such a discovery should be celebrated.
Spatial magic was a rare affinity.
Much of Emer’s time over the following two years until this evening was devoted to teaching Eydis, more out of gratitude for her support in his appointment than any obligation of his position.
Eydis was a bright youth whose intelligence shone even more brilliantly as she grew to adulthood over those two years.
She had mastered both wind and life magic under Evhial.
She finished her academics in one year, half the expected time.
All the while, she was forced by Emperor Yuro to train with the palace guards until her martial instructor, Symra, demanded that the grueling conditioning end.
No longer required to train with the soldiers, Eydis spent her meager free time learning every language and dialect of the empire, numbering over one hundred in total, solely out of boredom.
Now she was learning spatial magic faster than Emer could create lessons for her.
The lesson he gave her earlier that morning was insufficient.
Although she did not voice a complaint, her face spoke volumes.
Boredom.
Her thoughts were elsewhere.
His lessons were not challenging enough for her.
The first few lessons caused Eydis to bubble with joy.
Her face radiated in cheery youthful beauty with each new discovery.
She would grab him by his hands and plead for him to teach her more.
Emer tore another sheet of vellum and tossed it to the floor; another lesson plan Emer felt was inadequate.
She was the first person who ever made Emer feel adequate, and he chased that fleeting feeling every day.
That was why he struggled so.
So long as he had something to teach her, he could spend time with her.
So long as she found him useful, he could support her.
Everything that Emer was, he wanted to give to Eydis FeAmel.
CRASH!
A pane of glass shattered in Emer’s mind and the recoil of ven numbed his body.
This feeling…
Something or someone had forcefully broken the anti-teleportation barrier Emer set around the palace.
Springing to his feet with enough force to knock his heavy chair prone, Emer readied a warm thermal energy in his hand.
Feeding it two separate yet similar compositions of fire ven, his hand burst into two distinct flames.
Once the two flames were formulated to alternate in intensities, Emer flipped the latch, opened the window, and launched the flare into the sky.
The combined flames pulsated between subdued yellow and vibrant orange: the signal that there was an intruder in the palace.
Before the flare could reach the apex of its climb, another flare ascended pulsating red and purple.
“Protect the royal family.”
This was an assassination.
The red and purple flare was only used when danger directly targeting Emperor Yuro or his family was discovered.
There was a high likelihood that someone in the palace had already died.
The door to Emer’s office burst open.
“Hostile intruder,” the guard yelled.
“Go to the emperor!”
Spatial magic was a purely defensive and powerful support element.

From barriers to escape, the school of magic was vital to the protection of the royal family, and those within the palace who were charged with providing this protection were the Namie, an order of spatial magic specialists.
Emer’s position as the court magician and being a spatial magic expert made him not only a Namie but also their leader and magic instructor.
His role was to head directly to the emperor and evacuate him at the first sign of threat.
Emer recalled at lightning speed his memorized teleportation formula targeting the Emperor’s personal chambers.
He thrust his fingers into the air in front of him.
The tips vanished, or more accurately penetrated the space in front of him, leaving translucent cracks from where his fingers disappeared.
He pulled his hand to the side, tearing the space away in front of him, and threw himself into the rift-like portal cracking vertically through the air.
He landed in an extravagant but dimly lit lounge.
A sword rested its edge against his throat but was promptly removed.
“You’re too late,” the captain of the royal guard growled.
“Too late?” Emer repeated.
Only a few seconds had passed between the destruction of the barrier surrounding the palace and Emer’s arrival in the emperor’s chambers.
The captain’s teeth squeaked under grinding pressure that could crack them at any moment.
The glare of the captain’s grey, bloodshot eyes drew Emer to attention, their intimidation worsening the worming tension Emer felt coiling in his stomach.
“We are dealing with a spatial mage.
There was no break-in.
He must have teleported directly here.”
The captain ordered his men to rally the Namie and hasten to ensure the safety of the remaining two wives of the emperor, the first princess, and the two young princes.
He then pulled Emer by the arm through a long corridor towards the emperor’s bedchamber.
“No physical weapon could do this.
What do you make of it?”
On the bed rested the severed bodies of Emperor Yuro and his first and second wife braided together in what had been a passionate evening.
There was no spray of blood from the strike of any weapon.
What blood flowed from their bodies avoided a thin line running through the severed trio.
Emer’s stomach knotted, not from the brutality of the scene but because he had failed in the most important task demanded of him by his position.
He reached for the space between the severed bodies and felt solid resistance although no obstruction was visible in the dark.
Drawing ven into his hand, he made it resonate at a high frequency.
Touching the invisible object again weakened and dissipated it.
“A barrier?
Impossible.”
Barriers made from spatial magic prevented passage or entry.
They could move and push and potentially bludgeon if the mage was skilled enough, but they could never hold a form sharp enough to cut.
Even if placed through someone, the barrier would only hold them bound.
Emer had never heard of such magic.
Cold sweat ran down past Emer's thin brow, stinging his eyes.
His heart raced and threatened to beat out of his chest.
Emer was the strongest spatial mage in the Amelian Empire.
Once he became court magician, his first task was to replace the outdated encryption methods to strengthen the palace’s anti-teleportation barrier.
It had taken him a large portion of his first year as court magician to complete, and the resulting barrier became multiple magnitudes harder to breach.
Brute forcing the encryption would take centuries, yet someone had managed it in less than a year.
Now having seen a barrier used as a weapon, there was no doubt in Emer’s mind.
This mage had a mastery of spatial magic incomparably superior to his.

Ignoring the captain’s questions about what weapon killed the emperor or how barriers were involved, Emer strung together another teleportation formula in his mind and tore open a portal to the first princess’s chambers.
He had to make sure she was safe.
He had to protect her.
Instead of the portal creating a direct window to the location, the destination clouded over.
Emer tried to enter the rift, but it forced him back.
The first princess’s bedchamber was surrounded by a teleportation barrier.
The signature of the ven was different than what he would recognize as hers.
Emer placed his hand on the rift to read the flow of the foreign ven for clues about the barrier’s nature.
Constructing a strong teleportation barrier took a long time, so one created in seconds should be weak.
At least he hoped it would be weak.
Superior.
The haunting thought would not leave his mind.
Sure enough, the encryption was one Emer could decrypt in a minute at most, but it was not one an average Namie could break easily.
Emer was the only one who could reach her.
“Princess Eydis is in trouble,” he told the captain.
“Guards should be there.”
“They will not be able to enter.”
Working the decryption in his mind, Emer forced spatial ven of the correct intensity and frequency pattern to disrupt the barrier.
The barrier was too complex to remove, but he only needed to weaken it enough to allow passage.
Even so, it would still take time.
He could only pray for Eydis’s safety as he worked.
What madness would drive someone to directly target the Amelian royal family?
They were personally favored by the titan Bydrofe, the Guardian of Whinhlem.

Emperor Yuro had yet to present his heir to Bydrofe--traditionally done when the heir reached three years of age, becoming an adult, wherein Bydrofe would impart his wisdom and a blessing--but a delay in the first princess’s presentation would not remove his favor.
To attack the royal line was the same as making an enemy of the greatest entity on Whinhlem.
As the barrier waned, the struggle on the other side grew visible.
The first princess’s room crumbled as near-invisible planar projectiles struck the white-marble walls and exquisite wooden furniture.
They cut through with no resistance and sent broken shrapnel falling to the white, wool-carpeted floor.
Not a single piece of furniture remained undamaged, and the outward-facing wall had already fallen revealing the cold night sky.
At the center of the destruction stood First Princess Eydis FeAmel.
She wore only her night skirt, now tattered from her frantic defense against an assailant not visible from the portal’s angle.
Heavy bruising coated her torso, arms, and legs.
A cloudy film was amassed on her arms and legs and blurred the details of her body.
The princess understood the nature of her assailant’s attacks and coated her body in spatial magic vibrating at high frequencies.
She punched and kicked the planar projectiles that she could not avoid, the perfect combination of Emer’s spatial magic instruction and Symra’s martial training in full display.
The barriers her unseen assailant flung at her weakened from contact with her vibrating spatial defenses, but her magic only removed the edge.
The impact still had a visible effect, knocking her back and adding to her countless welts and bruises.
Emer felt great pride in his pupil’s ingenuity and insight, but if he did not hurry, she would not last.
The princess was on defense doing all she could to keep herself from being cut.
Having seen the effect these barrier weapons had on the emperor and now the stone walls cut through effortlessly, Emer knew only one would be enough to end her life.
“That should be enough.”
The captain drew his sword with Emer’s consent and charged into the rift.
Emer followed behind.

The sensation of passing through the weakened barrier was akin to trudging through thick mud that clung to his robe as if trying to hold him back when he exited the portal into the princess’s chambers.
A human dressed in a simple brown robe tied with a thin black sash stood in the air.
He looked more like a monk or scholar than an assassin, but having already seen the effects of this assassin’s magic, Emer knew he was a master of his craft.
The captain charged the assassin while Emer ran for the princess.
Surprised by their sudden appearance, that someone had infiltrated his barrier so quickly, the assassin’s barrage ended.
The princess quickly utilized the small moment of opportunity to release a wind spear at the intruder with a swing of her arm.
Emer felt the distinct sensation of spatial magic use just before the wind spear hit.
It dissipated before reaching its target.
The assassin set up a defensive barrier around himself.
Even with his help, Emer knew they would be unable to fight the assassin.
He lacked confidence that he could penetrate any defensive barrier created by this human.
“Princess, this way!”
Emer grabbed the princess’s arm and ran towards the collapsed wall.
The captain stood between them and their attacker to delay the assassin as much as was possible.
With a swipe of the attacker’s hand, a barrier cut through the captain’s sword and severed him in half diagonally from shoulder to hip.
It continued towards Emer and the princess unobstructed.
Emer pulled the princess through the rubble and out her bedchamber into a freefall.
Quickly formulating a simple, short-distance teleportation formula, Emer tore open the air below them.
They landed hard on the lightly domed roof of the Temple of the Gods across the east courtyard from the princess’s chambers.
The princess rubbed her side and shoulder, aching terribly from the hard impact on her many bruises, but her attention quickly drew away from her own injuries.
“Your arm!”
“Ignore it.”
Crimson ran in a constant stream from what had been Emer’s left arm.
He gripped the bloody stub with his hand just above where his elbow once attached and forced life magic into it.
The veins fused closed, stopping the deep red fountain, and the searing pain numbed until it became bearable.
The brief seconds of rapid blood loss made his head light and his body cold.
He blinked a few times to fight past the pain but noticed the princess shivering in the cold winter air.
He removed his robe and placed it on the princess’s shoulders.

Eydis was a whole head and a half taller than Emer, so the robe was not long enough to reach any further than her knees, about the length of her shimmering brown, silken night skirt, but it would provide some warmth.
“We must seek time for me to prepare the long-distance teleportation for your escape.”

The emergency escape teleportation formula was deliberately overcomplicated to prevent others from following the ven trace left behind by the portal, and he needed time to ensure whether his memory of the complicated formula, recalled while fighting back the haunting ache of his missing arm and the onset of shock, had any errors.
Mistakes in teleportation could be fatal.
While Emer recalled the formula, a portal opened behind them, and the assassin appeared.
Instead of casting the escape spell as he recalled it, he formulated another quick, short-distance teleportation and pulled the princess through before their assailant could attack.
After landing on the grounds on the opposite side of the temple annex, Emer grasped her wrist.
They bolted into a sprint over the tightly cobbled path as fast as their legs could carry them.
Emer had no destination in mind.
He only needed a short window of time.
The palace guards who saw them ran to catch up and aid in the princess’s protection.
Emer once again began checking over the escape formula and already found one mistake that he promptly remedied, but he made little further progress when another portal opened in front of them.
“Slow him down!” Emer shouted to the guards.
He stomped his heel into the ground, and a wall of rock and earth shot up between him and the portal to stall their pursuer, if stalling was even possible against such a mage.
He then created another short-distance teleportation formula and pulled the princess through to the central courtyard of the palace.
Eydis shrieked.
Her younger twin brothers lay severed in half in their own gore, murdered while still in the prime of their childhood.
Eydis’s hardened expression from her martial training vanished, replaced by creeping fear.
She had never witnessed the death of a loved family member, especially a death so violent.
As hard as her conditioning under Symra was, little could prepare her for such a sight.
Emer chastised himself internally for his lack of forethought.
The twin princes always dueled in the courtyard in the evening, and there would certainly have been a chance that the assassin would notice them.
They may have been the first to die, being out in the open.
The emergency flare that was launched shortly after his came from the direction of this courtyard.
Numerous guards and servants observed the bodies while medical staff futilely investigated them.
Nothing could be done for the dead in such a state, even with life magic.
Emer continued checking over his escape formula and almost finished before a portal opened right where they had exited.
The assassin appeared to the astonishment and screams of those in the courtyard, so Emer pulled the princess through another portal.
They exited inside the palace’s great hall.
Emer pulled Eydis in the direction of one of the many entryways lining its breadth.
Once again, the stationed guards joined them in their flight.
The patter of bare feet and clacking of hardened boots echoed over the carved marbled walls where the deep redwood accents did little to dampen the sound.
Emer now knew he could no longer use his escape formula, not as he had memorized it.
“He said I brought this upon myself… that I was the last one,” Princess Eydis said in shock.
“My brothers… Are… You are supposed to evacuate my father.
How is my father?
My mother?”

The swiftness and lethality of the offensive barrier magic meant there was a high chance that the assassin could have finished off the remaining wives of the emperor in the time it took for Emer to investigate the emperor’s corpse.
“Your father and his first two wives, your mother… are dead.
If that is what he said, we can trust the others are as well.”
Color slowly drained from Eydis’s face.
“What about Ceil?
Her marriage to my father has not been made public.
He could not have known about her.”
Emer did not know.
Ceil’s maid was a Namie.
She was the only member of the royal family ordered to have a Namie in her presence at all times, so perhaps she alone escaped.
Just as they exited the hall, a portal appeared, and the assassin saw the direction of their flight.
Emer pulled the princess through another quickly formed portal, leaving the guards of the hall to sacrifice themselves as the others likely had.
Emer’s fears were correct.
The assassin was tracing his teleportation far too easily.
Even though a trace of the formula was left behind by every portal at its source location, it was not so easy to read.
The assassin was reading them as if they were nothing more than a brief memo.
If he used the escape formula, with his assessment of the assassin’s competence in spatial magic, again being reminded how superior it was to his own, Emer knew the assassin would simply follow.
Perhaps if he stayed behind to erase the trace… But then he would not likely have time to fully erase it before the assassin killed him.
Even partially erased, the assassin could glean the destination coordinates and create his own formula.
However, that was the best and only option.
For the plan to work, his escape formula would need to change further.
Emer altered the formula he had just finished checking over.
He added another few layers of complexity including destination randomization.
Next, he removed distance limitations so he could send her as far away as was possible within his power.
At the same time, he set destination restrictions, including one to force the location to a populated city that was non-aggressive.
Such detailed restrictions for a randomized portal were not simple to infuse into a formula.
Emer’s pace slowed as they ran down a corridor on the upper levels of the palace.
Constructing such a complicated formula while simultaneously creating smaller formulas to aid them in their flight caused extreme mental strain.
This was only compounded by the disorientation from his mind slowly succumbing to shock and the perpetual lightheadedness from loss of blood.
“H… how,” Princess Eydis stuttered.
“How can a human be that powerful?
Their ven levels and affinities are far too weak to keep up an attack that long.
Along with all the teleportation…
If he was a minum, it might be plausible, but--”
Another portal opened in front of them, not at the destination of his last portal like before.
The assassin knew the layout of the corridor and that it did not branch.
With how quickly the assassin killed the rest of the royal family, he likely knew the layout of the entire palace.
Emer’s last portal had placed Eydis on a path the assassin could intercept.
This was a grave mistake.
The assassin exited the portal and immediately launched his barrier attack, only this time it was not sharp but wide and blunt with intense, pulsating energy.
Emer set up a barrier, but it shattered the moment the pulse touched it.
He coated his arm and shoulder in vibrating spatial ven, but the barrier did not dissipate on impact.
It continued with force and knocked Emer into the princess.
They both flew back to the floor.
Emer grabbed the princess to keep her from sliding away from him over the smooth marble.
“Thought that might work,” the human said in a relaxed but playful tone in perfect Elven.
“I should look into making a stronger version.”
There were no guards to delay the assassin.
He and the princess were alone, but Emer did not panic.
A rare, confident smile grew on his face.
He finished the formula.
Emer prayed to the memory of his late master that he had not made an error in its construction.
So long as the princess exited somewhere unhostile to the elves, someone would lend her aid.
Emer grabbed the princess and pulled her close.
“I don’t know where you will exit.
I will stay behind and scramble the trace so he cannot follow.
If I die first, he should still find it difficult to pursue you.
Wherever you appear, find help quickly.”
Emer activated the finished escape formula and tore the rift open below the princess, forcing her to fall into the portal.
His ven levels plummeted faster than he had ever experienced before.
Something about the black portal he created drained the majority of his ven, leaving only what was necessary to keep his body functioning.
The dregs of Emer’s remaining ven would only be sufficient to scramble and erase the portal.
Afterwards, he would have none left to protect himself, not that he had any confidence in his ability to survive.
In haste, Emer channeled ven into the rift which began to warp, crack, and then collapse like shattered glass.
Expecting to be quickly executed by the superior spatial mage before him, Emer instead saw wide, bewildered eyes.
The portal vanished, and soon after, so did the trace.
An exhausted smile spread across Emer’s face.
I won.
A spatial mage of the attacker’s mastery would know that following the princess was impossible now.
“To think there is someone in this world capable of that level of teleportation.
Is it not taboo on Whinhlem?
You had better pray that you did not send her to some inhospitable world.
Although if you did, my job would be finished here and now.”
The assassin praised Emer.
Emer’s joy twisted into confusion.
He did not know what the human meant by him sending the princess to an inhospitable world.
The destination was randomized, but he placed restrictions on where the exit could appear.
“But, I assume you are not so incompetent.
I will only have to trace where you sent her to make certain she is dead.”
This man was a skilled spatial mage, far more skilled than Emer, but the thought that this human could still trace the princess’s destination after the portal and trace were erased was absurd.
The assassin replied as if he knew the cause of Emer’s confusion.
“The lingering trace may be gone, but the formula trace can still be found in you.
I will have you come with me.”
The trace remains in the caster?
This concept was unknown to every spatial scholar Emer had ever met, both inside and outside the empire.
How could that be possible?
Even if it was, how could one extract the trace?
Just how much more advanced was this human’s knowledge of spatial magic than the Amelian Empire’s leading spatial magic expert?
What have the humans of Tolmyur been hiding during their decade of ceasefire with the Empire?
No matter the answer to these questions, Emer realized that he only had one option.
When someone died, ven in the body dissipated.
The trace had to be remnants of ven used for the spell somewhere inside the body.
There could be no other option.
He had to do something, but his ven was too low for his body to draw from.
Emer forced his ven below the critical levels, drawing from the reserves of ven his body needed to sustain itself, and channeled it into his hand.
He only needed a little, and a little was all his body would give him.
The small pulse of electric energy in his hand crackled like static.
The princess would be safe.
The assassin would not reach her.
Now at the end of Emer’s short life, amid mistakes and struggles, he finally felt for the very first time that he performed his duty well.
Emer’s body shuddered and fell to its side.
His left eye rolled back into his head from the shock he sent through his body.

Chapter 2
“The Hidden Princess”
Eydis
Lies.
Eydis tapped an annoyed finger on the arm of her padded lounge chair as she watched her maid leave, the sullen palace guards closing the door behind her.
She never understood this odd ability she had, but she knew when people were lying.
Something about their scent or heartrate betrayed secrets her few caretakers desired to keep hidden.
They spoke to her with calm demeanor after she awoke, when they bathed her, and when they brought her morning meal, but something about their expressions felt off.
The maid who cleaned Eydis’s quarters just now was particularly troubled, but when Eydis asked with genuine concern what was the matter, her maid simply replied, “All is well with me.”
That statement was truth, suggesting the problem that kept her retainers on edge or depressed existed elsewhere.
Eydis had her suspicions.
Something happened yesterday in the palace.
She faintly saw the glow of an orange and yellow flare from her window.
She heard shouts and wails and hastened padded footsteps of servants and the clanking metal of guards.
An officer of the guard reached the door to her quarters after the height of the commotion had passed but was called back before he opened.
She heard but a single brief exchange in a subdued voice her keen ears could easily snatch from the other side of the cold marble.
“Should we bring her out?”
“No, it’s too late now.
But we might need her later.”
For as long as Eydis could remember, she had never left her quarters.
Every regality was provided to her in the confines of her living space.
She was well educated in language and etiquette and magic, fed the highest quality cuisine, and given the most elegant of dresses.
She was taught a deep love and responsibility for her country and people whom she would eventually lead and protect.
She had servants on call for all her needs.
She had everything she could ever want as First Princess of the Amelian Empire, everything except the freedom to walk out her guarded door.
Eydis was taught that the First Princess was forbidden to show herself until the day she wed or took her position as empress.
That was one of the first lies her retainers taught her.

When she grew the courage to challenge the claim to her instructor whom she thought would delight in her desire to seek the truth, the grizzled old High Elf simply shook his head and replied, “Emperor Yuro has ordered that you remain here until your time.” That was not a lie.
Eydis could not deny she felt excited when the guard spoke of taking her from her room, but what purpose would she have if what happened last night was indeed an emergency?
Perhaps they planned to evacuate her.

But then why was it “too late” once the trouble passed instead of “safe” or “unnecessary?” What did the officer of the guard mean by saying they “might need her later?” She had so many questions, and each she asked throughout the morning was returned either with a lie or a well-constructed truth that deflected away from the actual truth.
She could do little about the deflections.
She had grown accustomed to such things but loathed them all the same.
Why couldn’t people be honest?
Eydis stood to walk off the unease in her stomach.
The commotion last night and the sullen demeanor of her caretakers was part the cause, but it was not the only cause.
Despite having eaten after her morning bath, she still hungered.
Or perhaps it was not quite hunger.
She craved something.

She leaned against the side of the single crystalline window of her lounge to look out into the back corner of the palace’s east garden while she pieced apart her typical morning routine to find out what was missed.
Her craving led to food, which in turn led to her breakfast.
There the missing piece was found.
Perhaps due to last night’s commotion, the chef staff chose to pair with her meal the most exquisite of fine wine.
A rare treat indeed, since she had never before imbibed.
However, the wine replaced her usual morning beverage, and the more she thought on it, the stronger the unease in her stomach grew.
That was what she craved.
Perhaps in the unease of last night’s events, her body wanted the comfort of habit.
Eydis walked to her door to address the guards on the other side.
“Afen, summon one of the chef staff for me.”
“Certainly, your Highness,” the guard replied.
Eydis returned to her padded lounge chair and eagerly awaited the usual servant.
He barely made it through the door before Eydis addressed him.
“I am most grateful for the wine you provided with my morning meal, but I would still like my usual drink.
Can you bring it to me?”
The slender man’s face grew pale enough to match the color of his antler-like horns that sprouted near his temples and circled the sides of his head like half-crowns.
Eydis heard his heartrate increase and noticed the near-imperceptible odor of his sweat grow in the air.
She knew another lie would follow.
“I apologize, your Highness, but we have run out of stock.”
Surprisingly, that was not a lie, but it was not the entire truth either.
How could a beverage that Eydis received every morning without fail since as long ago as she could remember suddenly now run out of stock?
The suppliers of the palace should always keep excess of all foods to meet the sudden whims of the fickle royalty.
She had a hunch.
“Is the shortage due to the events of yesterday night?” she asked.
“No, your Highness,” he replied promptly, almost afraid.
That was a lie, as clear as if he admitted it himself, but Eydis could not antagonize the terrified man who had served her so perfectly until now.
Whatever the reason may be, the circumstances were clearly not under his control.
“So, your stock vanished last night.
That is a pity,” Eydis replied with a light smile to show she held no ill will towards the man.
Perhaps the source of the drink was such a rare and valuable substance that made obtaining it worth burglarizing the palace, an improbable explanation yet possible nonetheless.
“Please make every effort to resupply.
It is my favorite drink.”
“Certainly, your Highness.
However… it may take time before we can procure more.”
Truth.
“Understood.
You may be on your…”
Eydis’s words trailed off.
She rushed to her window and peered up over the trees of the garden to smoke growing in the distance, first as whisps in the light breeze then into columns and billowing plumes.
As the sky greyed, faint howls of terror crept into her keen ears.
“We’re under attack!” a palace guard called from the hall outside her door.
“Humans in the city!”
“In the city?
How?” Eydis called back, rushing to her door.
Now the events of last night made sense.
Amel might have been under attack last night, but her caretakers kept this a secret to not worry her.
They held confidence in their ability to repel the attack, but now the enemy neared the palace.
“We must act!
We must protect the people!” she ordered.
As future empress, her duty was first and foremost the safety and prosperity of her people.
She reached for the handle of her door but hesitated to open it.
Her father, the emperor, had forbade her from leaving this room.
Did his decree hold in an emergency such as this?
The ongoing cries of her people that she knew only she could hear grew louder and louder in her mind.
Innocent people were dying at this very moment.
This was not the time for hesitation.
Eydis pulled her door open, ripping it from the tight grip of her guard.
“We cannot stand here and do nothing,” she said to her stunned guard.
The two guards exchanged glances and reached an unspoken agreement.
“Follow me,” Afen said, leading Eydis down the marble hallway.
Turning right led to a window-lined corridor with a pointed arch ceiling.
The marble shimmered with veins of red copper from the light filtering in through the crystal windows.
The palace’s east garden was in full view, blooming with winter flowers and full trees that never minded the mild winter climate.
The palace surrounding the garden was grand.
Only now that she left her room did she realize that her room was far smaller than what she thought the heir to the empire should have, but she did not have the leisure to dwell on that thought.
The rising smoke was far more visible here than from her single window looking into the back corner of the garden.

Eydis had thought, or at least hoped, that the smoke was only isolated to what little sky she could see from her window, but black smoke billowed from every direction she could see as she ran down the windowed corridor.
The humans had not breached a single location along the city’s wall.
They were already throughout the city.
“Was there no advanced warning?” Eydis asked.
“What of the villages they had to attack along the way?
The outposts throughout the land?
Has this battle been raging for so long, and no one thought to inform me?!”
Eydis was livid.
As heir to the Amelian throne, she should have been one of the first to be informed, and yet her caretakers failed to inform her until the enemy was already in the city.
How could they be so incompetent?
“The invasion began today, just now,” Afen said as he pushed open the heavy wooden doors at the end of the corridor.
The doors opened to a grand hall with arched columns supporting the high ceiling.
Large yellow and blue banners with gold trim hung down the columns to the pristine white-marble floors.
In the center, an insignia of ears of wheat arrayed in arborescence glimmered with gold.
Eydis realized only now that she had never known the insignia of the Amelian Empire.
Soldiers, palace guards, and servants rushed about in preparation to defend the palace.
“Your Highness!” A maid ran over and bowed briefly.
Many of the soldiers, servants, and guards noticed Eydis’s presence and showed a similar surprise.
The palace guards understood something immediately and urged the servants and soldiers to return to their preparations, ordering them to pay Eydis no mind.
“Why did you return?
Amel is not safe,” the first maid continued.
“Return?” Eydis repeated, perplexed.
Afen grabbed the aged woman’s shoulder, but before he could push her away, the hall erupted in countless flashes of white light.
In the place of every brief flash stood a Tolmyurin soldier in leather or half-chain armor.
Flashes of magic and steel filled the grand hall.
Eydis quickly erected a barrier to shield the maid from a stone spike and had to turn immediately to erect another to protect Afen’s back from an arrow.
The palace guards were the first to recover from the surprise assault and retaliate.
The soldiers soon followed.
The Tolmyurin invaders scattered in odd patterns as they attacked.
This not only threw off the organization of the hall’s counteroffensive, but it also cleared the precise locations the soldiers had first appeared.
Not a minute later, Eydis understood why.
Another eruption of quick flashes followed, and the number of Tolmyurin soldiers in the hall doubled, now outnumbering the defenders of the hall.
There was no way to defend against it.
This was only the east hall of the palace, one of the smaller.
If so many invaders had come here, there had to be countless more throughout the palace.
Eydis now understood how the city could so suddenly be under attack from within.

She was never taught the teleportation school of spatial magic, but something told her that such an invasion utilizing teleportation to this degree should be impossible, or else the entire world would be in chaos as all nations feared spatial magic.
What spatial magic master had Tolmyur cultivated to enable such a feat?
Eydis immediately searched for an escape route to save the noncombatants from being slaughtered in the battle.
The doorway back to the windowed corridor was the nearest route.
She conjured a wind spear in each hand and flung them at the two enemy soldiers between her and the exit.
Her attacks hit the unaware targets.
Two palace guards and three soldiers followed up immediately to secure the exit.
“Go!” Eydis ordered the maid she continued protecting.
“Your Highness must flee first,” the maid protested.
“Find a Namie and escape before it’s too late.”
Eydis erected another barrier to block an explosion of fire that quickly enveloped her and the maid before dispersing.
Afen was without her barrier and crumbled to the ground in a burning heap.
“No, I will not abandon my people,” Eydis said, mourning in her heart for the guard of her chambers she had known her entire life.
What ruler would flee in the height of her nation’s greatest crisis?
“Find any servants you can and flee the palace or board yourself inside a room.”
“But your Highness—”
“GO!” Eydis screamed at the maid.
The maid looked into Eydis’s eyes and grew terrified.
She no longer questioned the order and followed the few servants who made it to the protection of the soldiers guarding the exit to the corridor.
The Tolmyurin soldiers shifted positions in near unison, once again clearing the precise locations where they had arrived.
Having seen it twice already, Eydis and a small number of the palace guards who were not otherwise occupied readied attacks.
The moment the flashes appeared, Eydis released two wind spears with an outward swing of both her arms.
The first struck the arriving target, but the second flew over her other target’s head.
The middle-aged man was far shorter than most humans, a minum.
He turned and noticed Eydis, staring into her eyes with a sudden realization.
Eydis knew she had been recognized as the First Princess of the Amelian Empire.
This man, a commander by the insignia on his leather breastplate, knew her description.
Eydis glanced around her and saw that most of the palace guards and soldiers were now being felled by superior numbers.
Her barriers alone had enabled her to survive for so long.
The hall was lost.

The moment she was about to flee to find a better location for defense or to rally with any other soldiers or guards she might find, an inverted geyser hit her from above and flattened her into the marble floor.
The commander stamped his foot forward, and the marble beneath her crumbled into powder.
The geyser pressed her into the thick marble mud.
Eydis grew terrified deep in the mud unable to see or breathe, but she soon realized that she had the strength to resist the geyser’s force.
It was not as strong as she thought.
Eydis pushed her head up out of the mud, but the moment she met eyes with the commander from beneath his geyser’s torrent, the geyser vanished and all the water within the mud with it.
The commander pressed his hands into the ground.
Eydis felt all the marble around her constrict to crush her.
Her voice cried out, and she felt as if her head would burst from the pressure.
There he left her unable to move or speak, her body in terrible pain and her head pounding.
Eydis could only watch as the remaining defenders of the hall fell one after the next.
She listened until the battles throughout the palace slowly ceased.
In a manner of two or three hours, the palace grew silent.
Once again, only the faint screams of the city reached Eydis’s ears.
Amel had lost.
In less than a single day, the palace fell, and no doubt the city would soon follow.

* * *
Eydis slowly grew accustomed to the immense pressure of the marble floor crushing her as she waited under the watchful guard of the commander who had imprisoned her and the invaders that remained in the hall.
The hall grew dark, and the torches and braziers were lit.
All the while, Eydis had no other choice but to listen to the banter of the soldiers praising their Commanding General and their swift victory.
Some discussed and questioned her identity as the First Princess of the Amelian Empire.
She bore the insults and perverse conversations of those who wanted to have their way with her.
Eydis feared what her fate would be.
“Commanding General present!” one of the soldiers called.
All Tolmyur soldiers stood at attention.
An unarmored man in a simple brown robe tied with a thin black sash walked into the hall.
The commander who imprisoned Eydis was the first to greet him.
“Commanding General Jethro, I have a gift.” He lowered his hand to Eydis whose head and only part of her right shoulder stuck out of the marble cement.
“Well done, Captain Byurk,” Jethro praised.
“The entombment should have killed her.
I am positive that she is a—”
Jethro raised his hand to silence the captain.
He knelt in front of Eydis and brushed the hair from in front of her eyes.
“What is your name?”
Eydis glared at him.
She took the deepest breath she could manage in her constricting prison.
“I will not trade words with the man who assaulted my city.” Her voice was little more than a rasp.
“Amel is mine now,” Jethro replied with a cheerful smile.
“I cannot say that it has anymore use for its… princess.”
“Then kill me, butcher, and be done.”
Eydis wrenched her neck, and the marble at her back cracked.
The soldiers guarding her brandished their spears, pointing them at her.
Jethro raised his hand for his men to stand down.
“She can do nothing against you with me here.
Now,” he continued, returning his attention to Eydis, “killing you would be a terrible waste.
You are quite useful to me alive.
How about a deal, a trade?
If you become my prisoner, I will not raze your city.
Do not worry.
I am quite kind to those who cooperate with me.”
There was no deception in his words.
He spoke the complete truth.
Eydis’s only choice was to accept.
If she could spare her people, she did not care what else Tolmyur would do to her.
That was her duty as princess.

Chapter 3
“Watch that first step.”
Kimmel
Kimmel stood on a chair in front of his stone-polished darkwood desk.
The room was dim out of habit due to the rationing of fuel in the Tolmyur kingdom, although the freshly conquered Amelian palace in which he currently resided had no need for any rationing.
The dim light was hardly sufficient to accomplish any sort of work, but he preferred the nights to be dim, having grown up in the far less affluent deserts of Tolmyur.
Despite being born a nobleman’s son, he was often forced to work in the dark while his eldest brothers were provided fuel for lighting at night, so Kimmel was accustomed to such conditions.
A bright night simply felt… unnatural.

Bending over the desk and supporting his body with his forearm, he finished writing his report on a perfectly executed assassination of the three grandmatriarchs of the dryads, the hamadryads, and started a new report on the capture of two other dryads.

The Tolmyur Kingdom kept detailed records in massive archives, and Kimmel wanted this success to be beautifully told, not to solidify his place in history but to add to the many achievements glorifying his Commanding General, Jethro.
The dryad forests of Dhuillir were a vassal territory of the elven-ruled empire.
Dryads specialized in life magic and guerrilla warfare, a troubling combination.
The unified dryad clans under the hamadryads were a terrifying power, and by eliminating the core of that unity, Dhuillir should crumble into its sixteen individual tribes.
Kimmel was proud to have taken part in such a vital mission.
Including his success, over 500 political and military officials had been assassinated last night.
Only six attempts ended in failure.
The grandest of the assassinations was performed by Commanding General Jethro, who personally volunteered to eliminate the Amelian Empire’s royal family.
The emperor, his three wives, and two of his children were successfully eliminated.
A mighty feat, indeed, as expected of the Commanding General, and a long-held dream of anyone who lived in Tolmyur.
Kimmel was giddy just thinking about it.
Regrettably, the tyrant princess was among the failed attempts.
Her death was what all of Tolmyur hoped for the most.
They received word that the emperor had taken a fourth wife, but no one outside the palace knew who she was, so she never became a target.
By the time they learned of her existence, she had already escaped.
The Commanding General accepted full responsibility for his failures and never passed blame to someone else as any other lesser general likely would have.
His humility was inspirational.
The hamadryads that Kimmel was ordered to assassinate, on the other hand, could not escape.
They were a rare form of dryad that lived long enough to take root in the ground and grow like trees, so they never moved.
Dryads had a cultural or religious custom that once one aged enough to take root, they pilgrimage to introduce themselves to the sixteen dryad tribes and end the pilgrimage in some sacred grove.
This meant all the hamadryads were in one place.
How fortunate.

There was no limit to the number of hamadryads and so no limit to the number of grandmatriarchs, but the probability for a dryad to live long enough to become a hamadryad without succumbing to rot, disease, or any other ailment common to aged plants was extremely low.

Such ailments should be simple to heal since dryads were some of the strongest of life mages, but they treated age and death as sacred, so they never interfered with that natural process, at least among their own kind.
Luck was the only factor that determined if a dryad would live long enough to become a hamadryad.
Essentially, Kimmel only had to locate the three luckiest of dryads who were rooted in place in a single location and make use of his fire magic to burn them all to the ground.
He could still hear the screams, and what a joyous sound they were.
Even greater than the hamadryads’ screams were the wails of the dryads who could only watch as the ageless living monuments of dryad unity burned to ashes.
Kimmel could only laugh.
The task was almost too easy.
A special use of fire magic taught to him personally by his Commanding General enabled him to move unseen in a cloak of thermal ven.

Combined with his own self-developed specialization that could set a fire inside the hamadryad from a distance, he never needed to produce an external flame that would give away his position or touch the hamadryad, which would place him at risk to some of the strongest life magic on Whinhlem.
Any other fire mage his Commanding General could have sent may have been able to complete the mission, but they would have undoubtedly died in the immediate retaliation.
Kimmel was never caught, let alone seen.
He took great pride in his abilities and knew his Commanding General did as well.
He was one of only a few who received personal tutelage.
How could he not be special?

Once he eliminated the grandmatriarchs, he expected to be involved in the invasion of Amel the next morning, but he found a piece of parchment at the planned retrieval point that detailed a second mission.
The Commanding General needed two dryads, one shaman and the other a sister or daughter of the shaman, someone emotionally close.
Kimmel was charged with capturing both.

He did not understand the reason for the additional order until the Commanding General himself arrived after the successful conquering of the Amelian Empire’s capital city--another miraculous feat--and personally teleported both Kimmel and the two captured dryads back to the palace.
The Commanding General had a lead on finding the location of the escaped princess but needed a highly adept life mage to extract a teleportation trace from a seemingly dead half-elf.
The Commanding General’s knowledge of magic far surpassed anything Kimmel or the Tolmyur Kingdom had ever known.
The ability to extract the spell trace from the body of the caster was only one of many examples, the ability to teleport an entire invading army into a city being another.
His Commanding General was exceptionally talented in magic for a sotnum, a human.
The only problem with obtaining the trace was that such extraction took a level of life magic that surpassed the abilities of the captured High Elves in the palace.
They needed a dryad.
Dryads were troublesome negotiation partners.
They were difficult to threaten because their long lives often made them shrewd.
Despite their race being completely female, concepts like sexual assault were foreign to most due to reproduction being caused by the pollen of other plants in the air, not intercourse.
Physical torture was just as pointless.
Dryads only resembled elves in appearance but were nearer of kin to plants.

Damage from weathering, force, or other physical causes were no reason for concern to dryads due to their few pain receptors and ability to rapidly repair or even regrow any lost or damaged part of their body.
The only exception to their regenerative abilities was fire.
Fire damage could not be healed.

The life sap that ran through their body in place of blood was flammable, not as much as oil or alcohol but enough to make every dryad fear an open flame, making it the only threat that could be used against a dryad besides a premature death.
But if their dryad guest was willing, there would be no need to resort to such measures.
The Commanding General was well-known in Tolmyur for his kindness and hospitality to those who helped him.
Ever generous, and Kimmel was saved by that generosity once.
Even now, the Commanding General was currently making his dryad guest feel welcome and explaining that he would set them free if the Shaman performed one task.
Whether or not that promise would be kept depended on how cooperative she was from the start.
Generous and ruthless.
Kimmel loved even more how ruthless his Commanding General could be.
Kimmel’s report to the king on the captured dryads ended abruptly with a tiny flash of light like a white spark.
A small piece of parchment appeared in front of him.
It was an order for Kimmel to join the Commanding General.
Negotiations had failed.
Kimmel jumped off his chair.
This was an expected and exciting development, but he took a quick breath to calm himself.
If he was too excited, he would not be able to perform his role as ordered.
The two dryads would have known about the death of the three Grandmatriarchs.
Fire was hard to hide once it spread after all, and now his fire would be of use again, or more specifically his ability to manipulate heat.
He reached up to grab the door handle and kicked off the wall to open the heavy wooden door.
If negotiations were successful and the trace was obtained, Kimmel wanted to request his quarters be changed to one better sized for minums, perhaps a room meant for fairy dignitaries.
His Commanding General would surely be willing.
Kimmel walked down the cold marble hall and up a short flight of steps to a small room with no more than a table and counters lining the wall on one side.
It served as a small prep kitchen for the meeting room beside it.
Two soldiers stood in the narrow space, each holding an arm of one young dryad woman.
Their hands were gloved to prevent any potential harm from life magic.
The dryad had the appearance of an adult elven woman of three to four years in age, or if he compared her to the shorter-lived human races, perhaps a woman of a year and a half to two years.
The green-brown hue of her perfectly proportioned body combined with her green eyes and long, grass-like hair with plentiful white, long-petalled flowers gave her a bizarre, sylvan beauty.
She glared back at Kimmel with open animosity.
Kimmel smiled.
If circumstances were different, he would have preferred to have some fun with her first.
Breaking that rebellious glint in her eyes would bring him no shortage of entertainment.

After all, torture was his life’s calling and the only reason he avoided beheading or rotting in a jail cell somewhere in Tolmyur after his plans to usurp the kingdom was leaked by his sister to his Commanding General.
The soldiers pulled the dryad after Kimmel and released her in front of the meeting room.
Kimmel opened the door.
The dryad gasped in relief seeing her mother unharmed and sitting on a red leather chair across from another man.
The seemingly dead half-elf on the low table between them did not draw her attention.
The shaman was just as happy to see her daughter safe, but her expression quickly changed to dread.
She knew what this was.
The dread spread to the dryad beside Kimmel, but before she could react, her neck was constricted by an invisible force that prevented her from screaming.
Her feet were then restrained by a similar invisible force and rose.
The dryad lost her balance in the air and fell back, but her feet did not follow, locked upright by the barrier.
Her ankles broke in an audible crack from the dryad’s weight, and she hung upside down.
The Commanding General raised his hand and directed the woman to the back of the room against the wall next to an unlit fireplace.
Kimmel followed the levitating body, amazed as always at his Commanding General’s manipulation of barriers to do things he had never seen.
The girl lowered enough that her shoulders were level with Kimmel’s, and her long, grass-like hair slid along the ground.
“L-leave her alone.
We want nothing to do with this war!” the Shaman pleaded.
The dryad beside Kimmel glared at the Commanding General, but there was fear in the shaman’s eyes.
Kimmel now understood why his Commanding General chose to negotiate with the mother instead of the daughter.
“You are a member of the Amelian Empire, are you not?
And you have been wholly uncooperative.” The Commanding General’s face showed neither frustration nor anger.
“And… and I can’t do what you want of me.
I have never heard of such magic!”
“Take the hair.”
Kimmel removed a small wolfram knife and cut the dryad’s long hair just short of where the flowers bloomed.
Dryad hair regrew quickly, but the trauma of being cut prevented it from blooming for about a year.
The flowers that bloom collected pollen.
In other words, dryad hair was directly tied to reproduction, and cutting it was one of the greatest forms of humiliation.
The dryad did not mourn the loss of her hair.
What was one year to a race that could outlive even the elves?
She did, however, understand her position as the target her captors could openly harm to force her mother into submission.
Her eyes burned with indignation, but the Commanding General’s expression did not change.
“Even if you could find a spell trace from a dead man, what would you do with it?” the shaman asked.
“What concern is it to you?” The Commanding General leaned back in his identical red leather chair and rested his hands behind his disheveled head.
“Is it because we are at war with the Amelian Empire?
I thought you had no connection with it?”
The shaman bit her lip.
“But if you must know, I can tell you.
I already mentioned that I was curious about the spell being something that I did not think anyone of this world capable of performing, but that was only part of the truth.
The spell was a special form of teleportation.”
“If you tell her too much, she is going to catch on to what that means,” Kimmel said while tossing the cut hair into the cold fireplace.
Kimmel’s words were not meant to undermine his Commanding General’s negotiations.
They were a prearranged act calculated to make the dryad shaman think about why they would want a teleportation trace.
Both Kimmel and his Commanding General wanted her to discover their aims.
As expected, the dryad shaman was not so foolish that she would miss their meaning.
Because Kimmel captured the two dryads near the grandmatriarch’s grove, she knew about the assassination of the hamadryads.
The grandmatriarchs would be lesser assassination targets.
Without a doubt there would have been more, and these men wanted to find one who got away.
“Who?
Who are you after?”
“I want to get information on a spell for my own curiosity,” the Commanding General replied with a pleased smile that accentuated his deep dimples.
“Will you help?”
The shaman remained silent.
She was weighing the risk of helping against the lives of her and her daughter.
If the target was one of grave importance, their sacrifice for the protection of the Amelian Empire would be the wisest decision.
But, Tolmyur had already conquered the capital city and palace, so what other high-profile targets could there be?

If the target was smaller, even on the level of her own grandmatriarchs, a mother could find reason to choose the safety of her daughter over another who would mean no more to the safety of the empire than a government official who could be replaced, especially since the target was most likely not a dryad.
However, telling her that it was someone of lesser importance would sound like an obvious deflection and further make her believe it was a target of grave importance, causing her to refuse outright.
Besides, his Commanding General was always honest.
He would never lie even if it was advantageous to do so.
The key was that the shaman could not know and had to keep guessing.
For now, further persuasion was needed.
With a nod from his Commanding General, Kimmel began channeling heat into the knife in his hand.
Wolfram had an incredibly high melting point.
Unlike iron, it could withstand and retain heat that even the best fire mages would have difficulty protecting themselves against.
Kimmel agitated the fire ven in his hand to move at faster and faster speeds, and the knife began to glow with such intense white heat that smoke rose from his sleeves.
“Please!
Stop!”
The shaman stretched her hand out and tried to leave her chair but was bound in place by another of the Commanding General’s barriers.
The suspended dryad looked at the knife with wide eyes, unable to cry out in fear due to the barrier restricting her voice.
Kimmel plunged the knife into the dryad’s arm just past her shoulder and cut down.
Despite appearing and feeling no different than skin, the dryad’s flesh burned like wood.
Fascinating.
Orange embers grew on the edges of the knife’s path and fractured inward as they followed the veins of flammable life sap.
The woman writhed in silent agony far surpassing what even a dryad pain tolerance could withstand.
Kimmel finished the downward cut and continued upward, slowly this time to watch the peculiar way the knife burned the wood-flesh as he fully severed the arm.
Any human would have passed out or died from the trauma alone, but the dryad remained conscious.
Her hair would grow back, but the burnt stub of her shoulder could never regrow her arm.
Kimmel grew an overeager smile and aimed at the next arm.
“Stop!
Stop!” The shaman pleaded for her daughter with tearful eyes, but her daughter looked back with a pained expression that begged her not to give in.
“I’ll do it!
I’ll do it…”
“Good to hear.”
The Commanding General’s teeth peeked from between his grinning lips.

He waved his hand at Kimmel who slowed down the agitated fire ven in his hand to cool the knife and placed his hand above the dryad’s shoulder to chill the embers slowly eating away at her from the inside.
The rebellion in her eyes was gone, replaced by sobs of defeat.
Kimmel felt a rise in his chest that broke into a pleased smile across his face.
This was not how he wanted to break her, but he was enjoying it all the same.
Seeing the knife dim to a blackened coating of scale and soot, the mother of the tortured woman cried in relief.
The Commanding General began his explanation to the dryad shaman with an odd interpretation of ven theory.
Ven was not a fuel for magic, like wood that would burn to create fire, as Kimmel had always imagined.
It was more like the breath you inhale to speak a command or parchment you would write the command upon.
One’s affinity determined their authority over the elements--whether the elements would obey the command given--and ven transmitted that command.

When a spell was cast, an imprint was left in the parchment that could be read, or an echo of what was spoken that could be heard, which the dryad shaman understood better being from an oral culture rather than literate.
The grander the spell, the grander the command, and so the harder the imprint in the parchment would be to obfuscate.
Or the louder the echo.
It was only now that Kimmel realized his Commanding General was providing dual analogies so that he too could learn from the explanation.
This remnant of the command was the resident trace Commanding General Jethro desired.

Once the shaman understood the target, Jethro began explaining the procedure in excruciating detail, something about biological connections in the mind that determined thought and how this imprint or echo remained on them.
The complexity was so far beyond Kimmel’s understanding, but the shaman, a life mage who best understood the intricacies of biology, followed without issue or even question.
Clearly, Kimmel’s lesson had ended, but he had to wonder, where did all his Commanding General’s knowledge come from?
All of this was unheard of.

If a magic scholar published such findings, he would be numbered among the greatest magicians in history, yet his Commanding General kept this knowledge and more hidden and only revealed it as needed.
Once the explanation finished, the Commanding General gave the dryad shaman freedom of motion.
“Can you do it?” he asked, more as an ultimatum than for confirmation.
“It will be difficult, but I think it is possible with how you explained it.”
“Remember, I do not just need his ven but the remnants of the command lingering on the ven.
And please be careful.
I will be casting the spell once you give me the trace, and if it is not what I saw before, well, I do not think I need to say, do I?”
“Understood…” The shaman placed her hand on the half-elf’s forehead.
Small, white root-fibers grew from her hand and penetrated the skin of the half-elf.
She knelt with eyes closed in concentration long enough to bore Kimmel who decided to lean against the fireplace and examine the odd contrast of the wood-like embers on the severed human-like arm.
The skin of the arm felt no different than the skin of any other target Kimmel had entertained himself with in the past, but the charred stub did not resemble burnt flesh.
The cracks and white ash from the embers looked no different than a stick that had been pulled from a fire.
It even smelled of wood smoke.
He soon grew bored of this too and returned to the hanging dryad.
He wiped the tears from the corners of her eyes with her own hand and caressed her cheek as if comforting her in her sorrow.
All the while, he did not notice Jethro eying him from behind in disappointment.
Kimmel felt another rise.
The rebellious glint in the dryad’s eyes returned in a furious glare.
He so desperately wanted to break her, permanently.
She had that special kind of stubbornness that he loved.
His father and eight older brothers were the same.
Killing them slowly was the greatest joy of his childhood.
With enough pain, people will agree to anything, even giving up succession rights or promising to be blind to the other siblings he’d killed.
This was most effective when the injuries were not visible, so there would be no evidence.
For fire magic, there was only one option: no surface burns.
The trick then was that too strong of an internal flame would kill them too quickly.
Precision and control were key, and his control, practiced to perfection, was the reason his Commanding General took interest in him.
His Commanding General would always caution him that tempering his mind and emotions was just as important as tempering his flame.
This proved to be the greatest advice.
It made people less cautious of him, which created even more brilliant reactions when he revealed his true self to the people he’d hunt for practice.
When his Commanding General ordered him to stop targeting those who had done no harm, Kimmel instead hunted people who were willing to commit crimes.
What powerful insight!
Those were just the type of people who were harder to break and so provided even better practice.
His Commanding General’s wisdom was incomparable to anyone else on Whinhlem.
The shaman requested the Commanding General to extend his hand, pulling Kimmel from his reflections.
Kimmel thought he should warn her not to harm him because life magic worked by touch--she could easily poison him or do other harm--but in the end decided against it.
Any damage done would mean death for her, her daughter, and likely her people.
The Commanding General was also the only person who would be able to understand the trace, so he had no choice but to receive it personally.
Sending the trace took far less time than reading it.
The shaman let go of the Commanding General’s hand and was ordered to sit back in her chair.

Kimmel watched in anticipation of this never-before-seen teleportation that his Commanding General seemed to be more excited about than even finding the tyrant princess, although the two were directly connected.
The Commanding General cast the spell by tearing open the space beside him.
Unlike other teleportation spells, the destination was not visible on the other side of the portal.
There was only darkness.
Even if the location was protected by a teleportation barrier, the location would simply be blurred or clouded over.
Kimmel wondered if the teleportation failed.
That same worry showed on the face of the dryad shaman who nervously began pleading to the Commanding General that she did everything she could, but he demanded her silence.
“This is it.
It has been so long since… I suppose I did see it yesterday as well, but still.
This is perfect!
Kimmel, come here.”
Kimmel tossed the arm into the fireplace and stood beside his Commanding General.
“I would like you to go through, assess the location quickly, and then immediately return.”
The portal was nothing more than an abyss that stretched out into infinite darkness.
The light of the room did not penetrate it.
It appeared to have infinite depth but at the same time no depth as if it had been painted in the air in front of him.
He would never admit it vocally, but it scared him.
However, orders were absolute.
He walked to the strange abyss and touched it.
There was a little resistance but no pain.
Taking a deep breath, he stepped through the strange membrane.
The bizarre blackness wrapped around him and pulled him through with the sensation of being dragged upstream through a viscous fluid.
Kimmel found himself on a deserted, peculiar, black paved road on the slope of a stony hill at the foot of some snow-dusted mountains.
Vegetation was scarce.
The air was frigid and bitter and hard to breathe, and his body felt as if it might float up into the sky if he jumped.
In the distance down the mountain was a monumental city of impossible design.
Unbelievably tall structures that sparkled with light rose from the center on the far side of a bisecting river.
He could not begin to think how they remained standing without wide and expanding supports at the base.
They were just as thin at the bottom as they were at the top.
Red and white lights moved uniformly along what may be roads, but in the dark, he could not make sense of any of it.
It was as if some master had grasped the stars, arranged them in lines and boxes, and then sent them flowing like water along their paths.
The land was like a strange dream that Kimmel doubted his mind could ever conjure.
The city was within walking distance, but Kimmel did not have the luxury to investigate.
He had to return.
“Was it like another world, different from this one,” his Commanding General asked once Kimmel returned and the portal was closed.

The world Kimmel lived in was vast, and there was little way that anyone could ever fully explore it on one’s own, but everything about the strange location on the other side of the portal told Kimmel that it was different.
“Yes, sir.
I cannot imagine that place being somewhere we could find through travel alone.
Another world is the only way I could describe it.”
“It was a success?”
The shaman let out a sigh of relief.
The Commanding General closed the portal and sat back down in his seat.
Kimmel also moved next to the wroth, hanging dryad.
“I would like to thank you for your cooperation.
But, I do have some concerns.
You called this elf a dead man, and I am sure you assumed I would know a body’s ven disperses when someone dies.
Being such a powerful life mage as you are, you would know he is very much alive, even without touching him.
I can only assume that you asserted he was dead to prevent me from retrieving the trace.
Why would that be?”
“I promise you that was not my intent!
I only thought your request impossible to grant and was begging for your reason.”
“So I am unreasonable, then?
I tend to find myself very reasonable if someone agrees to cooperate from the start.
I would have even rewarded you for your efforts.
Regrettably, you fought me all the way.
You realized that we are trying to chase down a failed assassination target.
Am I correct?”
“No, I was not thinking that!”
Tears streamed down the shaman’s cheeks.
With a nod from his Commanding General, Kimmel reached up and placed his hand near the stomach of the hanging dryad.
Ven converted to fire but not on the surface of his hand.
To the onlooking shaman, Kimmel’s actions appeared like a threat, but it was the final order of a failed negotiation.
“Yes!
Yes!
I realized that was your aim, but I still helped you, didn’t I?
I did what you asked!” The shaman pleaded even more earnestly for the life of her daughter.
“You did, and you far outperformed my expectations.
However, I applied a barrier to block out any converted ven and to only accept the raw ven from the trace.
When you touched me, my barrier felt some resistance.
What were you trying to do?”
That was why he was given the final order, Kimmel realized.
The dryad shaman’s face grew dry with fear, forming faint wrinkles and chapping her lips.
“Nothing.
I was only sending you the trace.
Dryads can only use life magic.
You have to expect some excess life ven to be mixed in.”
“Knowing my expertise in magic, do you think I am foolish enough to believe that?
Raw ven remains raw until you willingly convert it.
There would have been nothing but raw ven from the trace if that is all you desired it to be.
I can only assume you meant me harm.”
The hanging dryad screamed.
The barrier that restricted her voice had been removed.
Kimmel leaned against the fireplace away from the woman.
Glowing orange cracks appeared in the dryad’s stomach extending outward, and flames grew from the cracks as the life sap fueled their growth like burning veins.
The shaman watched in horror as the fires spread and engulfed her daughter from the inside out.
The woman’s stomach became a hollow cage of embers.
Before the fire grew too large, Kimmel grabbed the flaming body and dragged it into the fireplace.
The shaman looked back at the Commanding General, unable to form any words of anger, hatred, or spite.
The Commanding General’s expression never changed.
It remained the same pleased smile.
“As a bonus, I thought you should know that you have committed the ultimate act of treason against the Amelian Empire.
The target you just gave me the location of is none other than the heir of the royal family, the First Princess, now Empress, Eydis FeAmel.”
The figure across from the Commanding General sat lifeless in her chair, her mind now broken from the realization that she had not only lost her daughter but also caused the end of the Amel Dynasty.
Kimmel was in awe.
Breaking people was his hobby and profession, but he felt inferior to Commanding General Jethro.
He was confident that he could have broken a dryad in a day or two, but his Commanding General accomplished the same in the span of a single negotiation.
Kimmel only acted as an assistant playing his part as instructed.
This man was a god in Kimmel’s eyes.
“In that state I do not think she will be a problem any longer, but we cannot return her with knowledge of resident traces or trans-world teleportation,” his Commanding General said.
Kimmel grabbed the dryad shaman by the leg and pulled her off the chair.
Without any resistance or movement on her part, he rolled her into the now roaring fireplace.
“It seems dryads are just wood after all,” Kimmel jested.
“Weren’t you telling the truth when you said you would reward her?”
“Of course, if she agreed without me needing to summon you.
While I would not have allowed her to return with the knowledge I gave her, I would have sent her daughter home if that was her choice.
I was prepared to give her the whole of the palace’s royal gardens as her personal grove.
