I doubt she would find such a stunning array of flora anywhere in Dhuillir.”
“I’m glad she didn’t agree.
It would have been boring for me otherwise.
What should we do about the half-elf?” Kimmel asked.
“I will keep him alive.
This portal that he designed is far more stable than… than what I expected.
He is quite the competent spatial mage.
Although I hate to admit it, if he had the knowledge of spatial magic that I possess, I do not feel that I could have defeated him in combat.
There is no doubt in my mind that I would have died the moment he appeared to rescue the princess.”
“All the more reason to kill him,” Kimmel spat.
There was no way any elf could be his Commanding General’s equal.
“No.
There may be more that I could learn from him.
I will have the life mages ensure he makes a full recovery but stays sedated.
We will keep him in prison for the time being.
But first, I would like to send you after the princess.”
“Me?” Kimmel was genuinely surprised that the Commanding General would trust him with such an important mission.
He was even more excited to be able to search the mystical city up close.
“I am honored.
When do I depart?”
His Commanding General called in a guard who carried a bag of provisions and Kimmel’s equipment.
Kimmel’s participation had been planned from the start.
Once Kimmel was prepared and after confirming that the location the portal had opened was safe and where few would notice, his Commanding General gave final instructions.
“Your mission is to scout out the land, and if possible, find the princess.
You are one of the few fire mages I taught who has been able to master the use of thermal energy and light to conceal your presence.
Use that to stay hidden, and do not engage her unless you are sure you can kill or capture her cleanly without resistance.
I will open the portal once more three days from this time.
Report to me then.”
His Commanding General tore open the black portal.
Kimmel peered into the abyss.
He jumped through and the portal quickly vanished behind him.
Jethro sat back in his leather chair and rubbed his temples with his thumb and forefinger.
He had invested far too much effort into Kimmel to not make use of him, but the truth remained that Kimmel was a danger.
Such genius in magical control was an exceptional find, but at what point was a personality so twisted that no amount of genius could compensate?
Jethro had tried to fix Kimmel.
He had tried for so long, but everything he taught was misunderstood and twisted and only made Kimmel worse.

Jethro had two other covert specialists he had personally trained, fire mages like Kimmel with enough control to bend light to conceal themselves, but for the first mission to an unknown world with untested inhabitants, Kimmel was the only one of the three he felt comfortable testing the unknown risk.

* * *
Kimmel passed through the nauseating portal and landed on the odd, black road.
The loud roar of a horn blared behind him, and before he could turn around, he was struck by a large, fast-moving object.

The long-haul trucker floored his brakes, thinking he had just struck a lost child wandering the road in the dark, but this only ground the minum under the tires, leaving nothing more than a red streak on the pavement.

Chapter 4
“Gestures may not be universal, but goodwill is.”
Eydis
The night of the assassinations.
The view of Emer vanished through the black void of the portal.
The sensation of a cold membrane enveloped Eydis’s body.
It layered pressure on her but at the same time sucked her through.
She was choked by perfect blackness, void of light and life, for what felt like an eternity within her troubled mind.
Tears welled in her unseeing eyes.
It was unlike any portal she had ever passed through.
Never once had Eydis been involved in an emergency evacuation, so she did not know if these escape portals were all this way.
When she was about to cry, the sensation ended with the impact of Eydis’s back on wet and cold, solid stone ground.
Air erupted from her lungs, and haggard gasps struggled to bring them back to life.
The air above Eydis spun and swirled like a stirred pot, but at least there was faint light.
She blinked her eyes to regain their focus, but the black portal continued to bend and contort.
The tension created cracks, and it began to break.
Her eyes worked fine.
The distortion she saw was the rift collapsing.
A moment later, it evaporated.
Emer did not follow her through this time.
“I will stay behind…”
Emer’s last words haunted her.
There was no chance that the assassin would spare Emer, especially after helping her escape.
Emer was her tutor, but over the nearly two years she spent learning from him, he had become a dear friend.
She wanted to curse him for not following but understood his conviction.
Although a portal could only permit passage for the number of people it was formulated to allow, someone with skill could read the ven trace to determine the destination.
Emer had to stay behind and prevent the assassin, an exceptional spatial mage, from reading it.
He fulfilled his sworn role as a Namie and guaranteed her safety.
Her father, her mother, her brothers, her father’s other wives, and now Emer.
Eydis lost everyone.
They were all taken from her in one night by a single human assassin.
Eydis tried to cry out in anger, frustration, and sorrow, but any sounds that broke through her lips were cut by her lungs crying for air.
She could not breathe and was slowly growing lightheaded.
Sitting up and placing her hand on her chest, she channeled life magic to ease the spasming of her diaphragm.
The gasps stopped, and her breathing regulated, but even when inhaling normally, the air she breathed was extremely thin like she was sitting at the summit of a mountain.
The impure air tasted bitter, and a deep breath led to an uncontrollable fit of coughing.
The bitter, cold air and the snow falling from the night sky suggested a volcanic mountain top, but she was sitting between two wide buildings.
Did Emer send me to the northern wilderlands?
The strange alleyway in which Eydis landed stretched out far to her left and right.
Although it was paved like a road, no one traveled it, and the black paving that resembled a rough matte glaze was unlike anything she had seen before.
The falling snow was wet but fell heavy enough to gather on the road, dampening her skirt and chilling her legs.
The odd rectangular structures had many sets of paved stoops with two to three steps leading to doors lining the full width of the alley.
There were no signboards, no markings to tell the purpose of these structures.
At even intervals between each door, large openings in the structures were covered with horizontally ribbed, green metal.
Next to a few of the doors sat large green, blue, or black metal bins.

The wilderlands to the north of the Amelian Empire were mountainous and had frequent snowfall in winter, but the architecture of the plain rectangular structures and the alleyway was far too dissimilar from the typical northern buildings built from stacked layers of thin stones or those repurposed from ruins of an ancient civilization that inhabited the northern continent in ages past.
The biting breeze and falling snow sent a chill down Eydis’s back.
Her legs on the ground stung, and her toes were quickly growing numb.
She could not yet spare the time to determine where Emer sent her or mourn the loss of her family.
She needed to find help or shelter, preferably both.
A lantern lit behind Eydis.
She startled and turned to face it but was puzzled by what she saw.
There was no visible fire in the lamp.
It did not appear to be fueled by oil or candle, and no one was there to light it.
It only held a strange glowing orb, some form of magical lighting unknown to her.

The door sitting atop three stone steps opened, and a scruffy looking middle-aged man wearing a soiled black apron and strange, dark blue clothing walked out carrying a large black sack that had an oddly reflective sheen.
He was human.
Eydis stopped breathing.
Fear crawled like insects down her back, and she dared not move.
Her martial training fought her instinct to flee, and in her traumatized mind, flight was slowly winning.
The man did not notice her when he turned to toss the sack into a metallic green bin on the side of the door.
She began the construction of a teleportation formula in her mind while her heart raced at the sight of a potential enemy.
The man produced a small white box and even smaller orange cylinder from his coat pocket.
Removing a thin white stick from the box and placing it in his mouth, he turned his back to the wind and magically produced a tiny flame with the orange cylinder.
His eyes met Eydis’s, and fear overcame her, freezing her in place.
The man called to her in a loud accusatory tone, but she did not understand his words.
It was not the human language or any of the over one hundred others she knew.
He leaned forward for a better look.
In reaction, Eydis shuffled backward but slipped on the frozen slush and fell to her back.
While scrambling back to a sitting position, Emer’s robe parted to reveal the heavily bruised skin of her chest.
The man’s eyes stared at her chest and then found the cut sleeve stained red with Emer’s blood.
He eyed the countless bruises on her arms and legs and called out loudly to her once more before descending one step.
Again, Eydis shifted further away from him with a reflexive light yelp in spite of all her past conditioning under Symra.
The man extended his hand, elbow bent, and his palm facing towards her while replacing the small white stick, cylinder, and box in his pocket with his other hand.
Magic?
Eydis could not tell the nature of the ven the man used.
It was skillfully withheld to prevent any sign of what attack might come.
All she knew was that this gesture was a sign of aggression.
Eydis made no hostile actions, but this man was threatening her nonetheless.
She now felt her shameful, trauma-fueled fear justified.
This was an enemy.
She could attack him first, but she also knew that would give the humans of this land more reason to hunt her.
Any movement forward by the man reflexively caused Eydis to recede further back.
Seeing this, the man pulled another small rectangular object from his pocket with his free hand, and after touching it three times with his thumb, he placed it against his ear.
He spoke to it without removing his gaze from Eydis or dropping his extended hand.
The tone of the man changed from explanatory, to annoyed, and to calmed, directing words both at something unseen and Eydis.
Even if she could understand his words, Eydis was too scared to respond, fearing this man might be just as powerful as the assassin, however unlikely that may be.
The man placed the object back in his pocket and continued staring at Eydis, never once dropping his hand.
Frantic questions sped through Eydis’s mind.
Should she run?
Should she attack?
If she tried to use teleportation magic, he could strike before she could enter the portal.
Should she set a barrier first?
If she did that, he might sense it and have reason to attack or call for help.
She might still be protected then, but if he was as strong as the assassin… But, no sign of magic was appearing on his hand.
Was it a bluff?
Many humans could not use magic, or so she was taught.
Then again, that assassin was human.
Neither she nor the man made any movements for the longest time as the snow fell enough to coat most of the matte road in grey.
The tension of the standoff choked her in the already thin air.
The sound of grinding gravel reached Eydis’s ears.
It grew to a low growl, and blue and red light became visible from around the corner of the building.
The man’s face relaxed, but he did not move.
Eydis’s fear became terror when a large beast rumbled around the corner.
Its voice was an incessant purr that never paused for air.
The dual-colored flare affixed to a bar across the top of its back flashed alternating, piercing blues and reds.
Its eyes beamed with blinding yellow light as it appeared to slide towards them along the ground.
Wincing from the light of its eyes, Eydis could not make out the form of the beast.
The man who threatened her to keep her from running had summoned something terrifying.
I should have risked it.
I should have run.
The man lowered his hand and faced the beast.
A wing extended from its side, and another human appeared from behind it, or perhaps from within it.
Someone had been riding the beast.
She could not tell if it was a town guard or knight.
He wore no armor and wielded no visible weapon, but he was wearing dark clothing of much higher quality than the other man, showing some unknown difference in role or status between them.
And she could not rule out the possibility of him being a magic expert like the assassin who had no need for physical weaponry.
The new arrival looked Eydis in the eyes and then turned to speak with the man.
Both their attention was off her.
Taking advantage of the opening, Eydis released pure and uncontrolled wind from her hand into the ground causing the accumulated snow and slush to fly in all directions.
Both the humans shielded their faces.
Eydis activated her prepared teleportation formula and entered the portal, closing it behind her.
Eydis exited forcefully into a bush.
The impact broke small branches while the thicker ones scraped and punctured her arm and side.
“Ahh…” Eydis moaned as she rolled off the damaged shrub into snow-dusted leaves.
Her teleportation had no predetermined destination.
She knew nothing of this land.
Her only choice was to set a requirement for the exit, somewhere with foliage where she could hide.
Such a simple teleportation formula would have led to an intense scolding from Emer.
He had taught her that a lack of restrictions on a randomized destination portal could spell disaster--a lesson well learned.
Eydis whimpered again from the pain of her imperfect teleportation.
She was free from the two humans, but that did not ease her mind.
The portal was gone, but if either of those humans were spatial mages like the assassin, they could still read the lingering trace because no one was there to erase it.
That should not be possible in the first place!
Eydis screamed in her mind.
A human using spatial magic was unheard of.
It was a rare affinity that only races with strong innate magical ability could even possess.
And that assassin far surpassed her spatial magic mentor, the court magician, the spatial prodigy, the best spatial mage in the entire Amelian Empire.
Not only her family, but now her entire reasoning left her.
This night was one painful absurdity after another.
Eydis curled into a ball, wanting this terrible nightmare to end.
She wanted to wake up.
She wanted to greet the cheerful smiles of her maids in the morning.
She wanted to spend the day laughing and playing with Ceil.
She wanted her life to return to normal, but the strong wind that blew over her chilled her to the bone and emphasized the reality of her situation.
Symra’s survival training took over.
Eydis was outside in the snow in a land controlled by humans, and she needed to create shelter before she weakened any further.
All Eydis saw near her in the dark were plants.
While most had lost their leaves, there were many that remained lush despite the cold.
The sound of running water told her a river was right beside her down the bank.
The flowing water only added to the chill in the air.
Lights of a city glimmered across the water from the other side of the river.
Strangely tall buildings dotted the horizon.
Both up and down river, more lights could be seen.
Behind her, a long wall of lush, thin trees blocked the view of anything past them.
She had found an isolated, lightly forested location just separate from the city across the river.
The surrounding bushes and wall of trees would provide cover, and with the river at her back, there was little chance of anyone seeing her from that direction if she hid among the bushes.
So long as she did not leave here, Eydis felt there was little chance of anyone finding her until the light of daybreak.
Channeling life magic into her hand, she applied it to the small bleeding punctures and scrapes from the bush.
The magic sterilized the wound, sewed the damaged tissue together, and accelerated the healing of her skin.
The repairs were imperfect in such little light, but any visible scars could be remedied in the morning.
She ran her hands across the aching welts and bruises all over her body from her desperate defense against the assassin.
Life magic repaired the damaged blood vessels and tissue underneath.
The inflammation and swelling decreased, but the blood that caused the discoloration of her skin would have to fade naturally.
It was a painful process, but if the bruising was not treated, her body would be in terrible shape after the next magic she would cast.
Next, she surged life ven through her body to accelerate her metabolic rate and blood flow slightly to increase and better regulate her body temperature.

This method of hypothermia prevention was dangerous over long periods of time due to the increase of her body’s resource consumption and constant drain on her ven, but a single night would not be a problem.
Any physical shelter made from the shrubs and trees would be easily spotted.
Until Eydis could better ascertain her situation, she made the decision to forgo a physical shelter.
The effects of the cold could be mitigated this way, but as an extra precaution, Eydis placed a thin, two-restriction barrier around herself.
The first restriction slowed any entering wind to prevent wind chill, and the second regulated the escape of heat.

The fight with the assassin had consumed the majority of her ven, but such a weak barrier and her metabolic regulations should last through the night on her remaining reserves and what ven replenished as she slept.
Eydis cleared the snow beneath her and curled up on the dead leaves, praying that when she wakes, she would be back in her bed in the palace.
Eydis woke with a haze in her eyes and her mind muddy.
She could not move her arms or legs.
She could not even feel if they were there.
Dark blue and green blurs shook with every jolt or sway of her body.
The sensation was akin to sea-drunkenness.
The faint pressure of an arm on her back told her she was being carried.
The riverside plants changed immediately to some structure, and then she was inside.
Whoever carried her placed her on a soft bed and ran around frantically gathering items which were placed in her armpits and between her legs.
The touch of the objects was painful, but their radiant heat slowly crept through her body.
The person then disappeared into a hallway to return with a large pile of something that was then layered on top of her, blankets.
This person knelt next to Eydis and looked into her clouded eyes.
At this distance, she was able to see the features of his round face.
He was a young human man with short blond hair and deep blue eyes like sapphires.
The man spoke some words in a soft tone and smiled with his faint pink lips.
He then went to the far wall and tapped an object affixed to it.
Warm air blew in the room.
Eydis’s clouded mind could not find reason to worry about or be fearful of the human, so she nestled into the warmth of the blankets and let sleep take her again.
Deep slumber was interrupted by angry voices.
In her drowsy haze, Eydis saw the man who took her in engaged in a heated argument with a second, taller man near the small wooden table at the far end of the room.
Once her eyes found focus, she saw the taller man grasping a familiar small rectangular object in his hand.
Unease rose in her stomach when remembering the terrifying beast that could be summoned by that same object.
As the argument continued, her rescuer seemed to convince the other man to return it to his pocket.
The tall man then pointed at her rescuer, shouted, and departed out the door to the left, slamming it behind him.
The man who took her in sat on a wooden chair of similar make to the table and wiped his hands down his face before letting out a frustrated moan.
After sitting for a time, he produced the same small object from his own pocket and proceeded to tap it with his thumb.
Eydis thought he had convinced the taller man, but the opposite was true.
His actions showed his reluctance to summon whatever that monster was, but he must summon it nonetheless, possibly out of duty or obligation.
She had to stop him.
Eydis scrambled out from under the many blankets, stumbling in frantic motions, her feet slick with sweat and slipping over the polished wood flooring.
Her martial training told her to strike him down before he raised alarm, but in her heart she couldn’t.
He was human, but she knew he helped her.
Kneeling before her rescuer, she placed one hand atop the object and grasped his pant leg with the other.
She bowed her head as far as she could without tugging on his clothing and pleaded in the human language she knew.
“Please, do not.
I beseech you…”
Eydis did not know if he understood her words, so she remained in her supplicant posture.
The man removed her hand from the object.
Fearing that he would not listen, Eydis placed her hand back on top.
“Please!” she pleaded again.
This time his hand gently grasped hers.
She looked up and saw him place the object back in his pocket.
Relief filled her heart, and she felt as if she would cry.
He pulled Eydis to her feet and sat her down on his chair.
He then walked over and folded up the damaged robe that was caught under the blankets on the couch.
Placing the robe aside, he grabbed one of the top blankets, and after saying a few words, wrapped it around Eydis’s exposed shoulders.
His consideration for her warmth and even the care he showed for Emer’s robe was not what Eydis expected from a human.
Humans were supposed to be crass and unruly.
They were a barbaric race that had settled the inhospitable deserts on the east side of the continent and would launch unprovoked attacks against the Amelian Empire every decade or so.
This man’s consideration was what she expected from the elves or other more civilized races.
Once Eydis was comfortable, the man walked over to the corner of the room that appeared to be for storage or perhaps food preparation.
Counter space covered most of the length of the back wall.
Cupboards were mounted on the wall above the counter, and a wash basin sunk into the counter on the left.
A tall white cabinet stood in the far corner on the right from which he removed a few eggs and a wrapped orange block, holding them up for Eydis to see.
He then grabbed a pan and lit a fire atop a strange looking range in the center of the counterspace without magic, oil, or kindling.
Who was he?
Perhaps he was not human and only appeared as one.
Nymphs in the Amelian Empire were nearly identical to humans aside from the nymphs’ vibrant hair colors.
There could be other races unknown to Eydis that looked like humans but were not.
Eydis ruled out that possibility quickly.
In her education, she had learned about all the peoples of her world.
She was taught every race on Whinhlem in her accelerated education and could identify them immediately by appearance.
This man was human.
Her eyes told her so even if her reasoning denied it.
In a few short minutes a plate was set on the table beside Eydis.
Her rescuer coaxed her to eat after handing her a fork and knife.
The egg had been broken, lightly fried, and folded over an orange, mildly salted cheese.
It was a crude and simple meal that only a commoner would eat, but the savory aroma was enticing.
She had been consoling Ceil all afternoon and into the evening until just before the attack.
She had forgone dinner.
The knotting of her empty stomach caused her mouth to water.
Eydis opened and closed her hand to check if her fine motor control had returned to her fingers.
Holding the simple egg and cheese meal stationary with the fork, she cut off and placed a small piece in her mouth using the tip of the knife.
The welling tears finally fell.
Kind humans did exist.

Chapter 5
“Language Barriers.”
Justin
7a.m. classes were the reason Justin Hapfeld woke earlier than most, and especially earlier than his roommate, Sean.

This morning followed the usual routine of struggling to get out of bed, trudging down the short hall to the bathroom just beside his room, taking a quick burning hot shower to wake up, and then throwing on clothes before heading out the door to walk to campus.
His apartment sat at the edge of a residential district next to the river bisecting Gullivan, and his door was on the first floor right next to a gate that led to the river’s park pathway.
Each morning, Justin took the river path north about half a mile until it intersected with the Main Street Bridge, and then he followed Main Street another mile to the university he attended.
This routine continued every other weekday in mind-numbing monotony for the entire three and a half years he had attended.
He could make the trip blindfolded if need be.

Every minute detail, every bush, tree, and rock along the river was so engrained in his memory that he could even tell what branches on the trees had snapped in the wind or what rocks had been kicked aside from people walking off the thin, paved path.
This morning was to be just another thoughtless trek down the river in the first snow of November, just the same as every other day.
Only, it was not the same.
Out of the corner of Justin’s eyes, there was a strange mound of snow barely visible in the bushes only a few yards down the path from his gate.
Any other passerby would have missed it or not cared enough to notice, especially this early on a freezing cold morning.
Someone had likely dumped trash, which was not all that uncommon.
Because it was so close to his apartment, he figured he would deal with it after returning from his classes.
As he walked past, his eyes remained drawn to the mound, and the more he looked, the more unusual it appeared.
Something pulled his curiosity.
The mound of snow held an S shape bent around itself almost as if someone was curled up underneath.
Justin’s breath caught in his throat.
He rushed over, forced his way through the thick bushes, and knelt next to the mound.
Brushing away the few inches of snow revealed a woman about his age with a deathly pallor.
He shook her lightly, but she did not respond.
The very slow rise and fall of her chest showed she was still breathing, but her breath was faint.
He picked her up, surprised by how light she was despite the woman being far taller than him, and carried her into his apartment.
The peculiar robe she wore repelled water, so she was not soaked save a few places on her skirt.
Thankfully, this meant he wouldn’t have to undress her.
Justin laid her on his fabric-upholstered couch against the back wall and grabbed spare bottles to fill with hot tap water.
He placed them in her armpits and between her legs.
He then grabbed all the blankets off his bed and spread them over her, making sure even her head was covered except her face.
The woman’s teal-colored eyes followed him, and he felt himself unconsciously pulled in by them.
Justin knelt in front of her and smiled.
“Everything will be okay.”
Once he turned on the auxiliary heat in the combined kitchen living room, she quickly fell asleep.
Over the next few hours, Justin checked up on her to make sure that she was warming.
Color slowly returned to her face, but her breathing remained weak and strained.
At about 9a.m., Sean came out and saw the woman sleeping on the couch.
After Justin explained the situation, Sean raved at him for not calling the police or an ambulance.
Justin had thought of doing so but decided against it, which he realized after was terribly foolish, because not doing so could have endangered her life further.
His naïve reasoning was that he felt calling the police would cause more trouble for her, as if the threat of her dying of hypothermia would somehow be less trouble.
His excuse was based on something that he felt was completely absurd but still found difficult to ignore.
He did not think this woman was human.

She was a foot or more taller than him, making her about six and a half feet tall, but she weighed no more than 80 lbs., probably less, and yet appeared a healthy enough size that should weigh twice as much, being rather lithe.
The pupils of her teal eyes were oval.
The final trait that could not be ignored was her ears that pointed outward about three and a half inches and narrowed to a point.
She looked in every way like a fantasy elf.
The ears could be faked.
There were surgeries that people could get to give themselves elf ears.
Oval pupils can be caused by a rare eye defect, mutation, or due to some form of trauma and so were possible.
Maybe.
However, there was no way someone could fake their weight.
Why would an elf be near frozen outside in the bushes?
The only reason he came to was her hiding from something or someone.
How did she get there in the first place?
Elves shouldn’t be real, but she was real and sleeping on the couch to warm up.
If he had not found her, there was a high possibility of her freezing to death.
There was a chance that the cold already caused serious damage.
Thinking further, her low weight could be caused by prolonged malnutrition or illness causing low bone density.
Add severe dehydration and lack of eating for several days and her weight could almost be explained.
Perhaps she was so lithe because she was malnourished.
Deep down, Justin knew this.
Sean’s words restored his reason, and he decided to call the police, but she stopped him in fear and panic.
Justin looked at the pitiful woman futilely trying to hold back tears as she ate the omelet in front of her.
He was not able to get a good look at her condition in his haste to warm her, but when she hurried over to stop his call, the peculiar robe she wore came off.
The woman’s arms, legs, stomach, chest, all over her body were covered in long bruises as if someone had beaten her mercilessly with a broom handle or metal pipe.
Seeing the bruises, he had even more reason to call the police or an ambulance, but she stopped him again.
What had she gone through that would make her not want to be found?
What caused all her injuries?
To answer these questions, Justin first needed to find the means to communicate.
Her plea had been in a language he did not recognize.
When she finished her omelet, Justin set the plate and utensils in the sink.
He grabbed her hand and prompted her to stand to lead her to the couch.
When she sat, he wrapped another blanket around her.
After kneeling on the floor in front of her, he tried introducing himself.
“I am Justin Hapfeld.
What is your name?” Justin asked slowly, pointing at himself and then at her.
He made sure to emphasize the diction of each word.

The woman remained silent for a while and then replied in what sounded like the same language she pleaded to him before but this time just as slowly and with the same emphasis on pronunciation and diction.
At least she understood that he was trying to communicate, but he still could not recognize the language.
At the very least, it was not any of the major world languages he would be able to recognize even if he could not understand it.
Justin tried again in his terribly broken Spanish and French but received no reaction from her.
He then fell silent in thought.
Noticing Justin’s silence, she spoke again but in a different, more fluid and melodic language that lacked hard consonants.
Even when slowing down and emphasizing pronunciation, he could not tell when one word started or ended or if there even were defined breaks between words.
Again, seeing Justin’s silence and confusion, she spoke in another language that was jarring and full of guttural sounds.
He needed to start from something far more basic.
Justin pointed at himself.
“Justin.” He then pointed at her.
Repeating the gesture and his name once more, she replied.
“Eydis,” she said.
Justin then repeated the gesture but with more words.
“I am Justin.”
Pointing at Eydis, he said “You are Eydis.”
Eydis’s eyes lit up having come to some realization.
She repeated the same gestures.
“Thu eart Justin… Ic eom Eydis…”
The words Eydis spoke sounded strangely familiar.
Justin stood up and paced while biting the middle knuckle of the forefinger on his right hand.
If he modified what she said a little, the meaning was clear.
“Thou art Justin.
I am Eydis.
Old English!
Anglo-Saxon!”
Justin rushed to his room and emptied the contents of his backpack.
He grabbed a small and worn paperback book, Beowulf.
He handed the book to Eydis, who had her hands raised in defense after his sudden outburst, and pointed at the right-side page that contained the original Old English text.
Eydis relaxed.
She held the book and stared at the page.
Seemingly getting nowhere, she handed the book back to him pointing at the same page.
“Read?” he asked.
Could Eydis not read?
Or was the written version of Old English in the book different than what she knew?
Justin’s English professor was an Old English fanatic, but he did not expect his students to be able to understand Old English.
He only hoped the students would catch the similarities that made up the origins of English, similarities that Justin struggled to notice but his professor assured were there.
Justin was only filling a general elective requirement by taking a course that focused on ancient literature.
He was not an English major taking some course where the students were required to study Old English in depth.
However, when starting the section of the class focusing on Beowulf, they had a quiz over the pronunciations of the strange letters and accented vowels.
He could at least attempt to read it.
Starting from the first page, Justin read a few stanzas of the ancient epic, fumbling a bit on pronunciation.
As he progressed down the first page, Eydis grew visibly excited, bordering desperation.
She immediately rattled off Old English far more fluent than he had ever heard his English professor speak.
Regrettably, Justin had no idea what Eydis was saying; however, his English professor might.
Justin looked at the clock on the wall above the table to check if his professor was in office hours and took out his phone.
Eydis’s excitement changed to fear.
She began speaking Old English again in a frantic, pleading tone.
Justin knelt in front of Eydis once again.
Grabbing her hand, he reassured her using the softest voice he could.
“It’s okay.”
He held the phone face up in front of her and turned it on speaker so she could hear the dial tone and any subsequent conversation.
He never released his gentle grip on her hand.
After a brief moment, a receptionist picked up.
Justin did not know the number he needed, but he knew the department office could connect him.
“Can you connect me to Dr. Shuman’s office?
I am one of his English 212 students.”
After a brief wait, a raspy voice came over the phone.
“Ryan Shuman speaking.”
“Hello professor.
This is Justin Hapfeld from your 212 class.”
“Hello Justin.
What can I do for you?”
“I have someone in front of me who does not speak English, well, modern English anyway, but she does speak Anglo-Saxon, Old English, quite fluently from the sound of it.
This is a bit of an emergency situation, so I was hoping you could help.”
“An emergency?
Is everything alright?”
Justin explained in brief what happened that morning but carefully worded it to sound like Eydis was fine and that there was no need for police or ambulance.
Whether or not the authorities needed to be involved depended on what Eydis told them.
Eydis listened all the while with unease on her face and her quivering hand in Justin’s grasp.
After the conversation finished, Dr. Shuman introduced himself in Old English.
The worry melted from Eydis’s face.
Their conversation was brief and only so Dr. Shuman could say that he wanted to meet with her.
Home visits by instructors were not permitted, so they would need to go to his office.
There were parts of this situation that would make more sense in person anyway, namely Eydis herself.
After Dr. Shuman received confirmation from Eydis that she was fit enough to travel, Justin set a time for later that afternoon.
The tattered, silken brown, knee-length skirt that Eydis wore and the damaged robe with the blood-stained sleeve were the only clothing she had.
Gesturing Eydis to stand, Justin tightened the blanket around her hips to gauge her size.
His pants would fit around her thin waist with a belt, but they would obviously be too short.
Justin ran down the hallway to Sean’s room and grabbed a pair of his skinnier jeans.
Sean was about Eydis’s height.
He then went to his own room to look for a shirt.
Eydis’s breasts were on the smaller side, so any one of Justin’s shirts would work and be slightly baggy.
He would give her a sweater and coat to wear over it anyway.
All that was left was shoes.
Justin placed the clothes he had retrieved on the table and lined up his foot next to Eydis’s.
His feet were bigger, but not by much.
If he gave her thick socks, there would be little discomfort.
Seeing Justin collect clothing for her, Eydis removed the blankets and looked at her arms and chest.
She ran her fingers through her long golden hair and removed a small piece of dead leaf.
Justin took notice of Eydis’s actions, trying his best not to stare.
“Do you want to take a shower?”
Justin grabbed Eydis’s hand and led her into the short hallway between the table and couch and to the first door on the right.
Inside the bathroom, he brought her to the tub in the back.
He turned the left nob and let her feel the heat of the water leaving the faucet.
He then turned the right nob so she could notice the water growing colder.
Lifting the stop on the faucet made water rain from the showerhead.
Eydis’s face glowed in amazement at the simple plumbing of an old shower.
The idea that a shower was foreign to her made him worry further.
How could anyone not know about showers?
Or perhaps she never had access to indoor plumbing.
Realizing that there was a possibility that Eydis knew nothing of western toilets, he showed her how the toilet worked as well.
Better to be safe, he thought.
Eydis seemed grateful for the explanation, so his concern was well placed.

Justin retrieved a clean towel and placed it along with the change of clothes on the counter before closing the door to give Eydis her privacy, not that she had any problems exposing herself in front of him.
If Justin was being honest with himself, this whole situation was a bit overwhelming for him.
His emotions were in a tumult.
He wanted to be helpful and reassuring after whatever it was Eydis went through, but he felt he could not do that if he kept shifting his eyes away from her.

Either exposure was not seen as an issue wherever Eydis came from, or the situation Eydis was in before he found her was one where she was forced to expose herself in front of others, making her lose any care for the privacy of her own body.
Justin hoped it was the former, but given the horrible state that she was in, he feared it may be the latter or similar circumstances.
Whatever the reason, it could not have been good.
She was beaten and in hiding, not wanting to be found, even to the point of sleeping outside in a snowstorm that very well could have killed her.
What if she was dumped there by some eccentric who no longer had use for her?
Justin’s mind weaved through crazy idea after crazy idea while he waited patiently for Eydis to finish her shower.
Some thoughts disturbed him while others aroused him.
When he realized where his mind was wandering, he grew appalled at himself.
Eydis had obviously gone through some horrible ordeal, and here he was sexualizing her part in that ordeal.
“You are better than this,” Justin mumbled to himself.
He made the commitment right then that no matter her exposure, no matter what she went through, he would view her as a person in need of help, nothing less.
He would learn her situation when he met Dr. Shuman, or at least he hoped.
The police could be contacted then if necessary.
After 45 minutes, the sound of the shower continued, and Justin began to worry.
At an hour, Eydis had yet to finish.
Soon their hot water would run out if it had not already.
Justin placed his ear to the door.
He could not hear any movement or sounds that would suggest Eydis was washing or that she finished bathing but left the water running.
He feared the worst.
Justin knocked on the door.
“Eydis?”
The sound of someone stirring came from inside, much to his relief.
After a few more minutes, the shower stopped.
With the noise of the shower gone, Justin could hear Eydis’s strained and erratic breathing.
It sounded like a severe asthma attack.
“Eydis, are you okay?” Justin rapped on the door again.
The sound of rustling clothes could be heard, but it was clear that Eydis was having trouble on the other side of the door.
Justin fought within himself whether to open it.
Something collided into the door, and the knob turned.
Heavy steam wafted from the bathroom, and Eydis collapsed to her knees in front of Justin.
He was grateful she managed to dress herself.
Her gasping breath sounded as if her throat was shredding.
Her head hung low, and her fingers gripped the carpet.
She looked exactly like the height of a severe asthma attack.
Justin lifted Eydis and carried her to the couch, sitting her straight.

He tilted her head back to prevent the obstruction of her airway and motioned her to take in deep breaths through her nose and exhale through her mouth, emergency treatment for an asthma attack he had learned due to his younger sister having asthma.
He did not know if asthma was the reason for Eydis’s condition, but he thought the same process could help.
After a few minutes, Eydis’s breathing began to stabilize, but she continued breathing heavy.
Once Eydis was calm enough to communicate, she placed her hand on her chest and nodded at him, stating something he could not understand but assumed was either an apology or words of gratitude.
Eydis moved her hand slowly in a waving motion that looked like water or perhaps air.
She then placed her hand on her chest, and after saying something Justin could not understand, she moved it up and down in motion with her breathing.
“Is it becoming harder to breathe?” he asked.
Eydis then repeated the same air-like hand motions but much slower.
She moved her hand to her chest and repeated the breathing motions but far more exaggerated.
Slower air and harder breathing?
The speed of the air should not be a problem.
If not slow, then what?
Justin then realized what Eydis was trying to explain.
“The air is too thin?”
Gullivan was against the foothills of the Rocky Mountains, high in elevation.
Justin also found himself short of breath when he first moved here, having lived along the southwest coast of California at sea level for most of his life.
Eydis’s case may have been an extreme version of what he experienced.
She possibly had trouble breathing normally and the elevation only made matters worse.
The events in the bathroom now made sense.
Justin had neglected to open the thin window above the shower or turn on the fan.
Eydis must have used the hottest water she could tolerate to bathe.
The increase in steam without any ventilation may have raised humidity to a level that tipped the non-breathable scale for her.
She may have been drowning in the air, if that was even possible.
“I’m sorry,” Justin said, kneeling in front of Eydis with his head down, mimicking her earlier posture.
Eydis spoke in frantic words and coaxed Justin to stand back up.
She did not seem to blame him, but he still felt terrible for his ignorance of her situation.
Justin returned to the bathroom and retrieved the towel.
He then dried her hair for her and combed it.
Her golden hair was extremely fine but strong, full, and surprisingly light for its volume.
Even when the comb caught, none of the hairs broke.
Justin added this to the list of things that made Eydis inhuman.
Justin pulled Eydis to her feet, and using the pants he was wearing as an example, he showed her how to zip up and fasten the button.
The pants sagged at the waist, so Justin retrieved one of his belts and began threading it through the belt loops.
When threading it through the center back loop, he noticed something peculiar.
There was a small bump in the pants at the base of her back.
Did she have a tail?
He had not noticed it when she wore her knee-length skirt, and it did not show below it, so if it was a tail, it would be short.
There was no visible bulge other than the potential tail’s origin, so if it was longer than an inch or so, it would be hidden between her cheeks.
Eydis’s nervous voice pulled Justin away from his contemplation of her possible tail, and he finished threading and fastening the belt.
Eydis gave him a grateful smile and gentle words with her fist pressed lightly against her chest.
Even when wearing men’s clothing, or possibly because she was, she radiated a bizarre yet beautiful charm.
Justin reminded himself that she was simply someone who needed his help, but he wished even more that he could understand her and she him.

The strange woman must have felt the same about their inability to communicate, because in the few hours before they had to leave, Eydis handed him Beowulf and urged him to read the Old English text followed by the English text stanza by stanza.
Justin continued reading to Eydis as the hours passed, only taking a brief break to eat lunch, but Eydis declined the offer for a meal.
Eydis quickly picked up on the similarities between the two languages that eluded him, much to Justin’s surprise.
She recognized that the language of the original text derived the language he spoke and soon began stringing simple words together in English.
Eydis was incredibly intelligent.

Chapter 6
“Emer was truly the greatest spatial mage of his time.”
Eydis
The time for departure arrived.
“Thank you,” Eydis told Justin, who closed and placed Beowulf on the arm of the couch.
Expressing gratitude was something Eydis wanted to learn first and foremost, and Justin had been able to explain the phrase to her during the language lesson she requested of him.
There was much she had to thank him for, so much that it worried her.
Eydis understood that she may have died if Justin had not found her.

Something about this strange land drastically slowed her body’s natural ven regeneration to the point where sustaining the barrier and the life magic regulating her body temperature drained ven far faster than her body could replenish it.
The ven freely present in nature was all around her, even in this room, but she could not absorb it as well as she could back in the Amelian Empire or anywhere else she had previously visited.
The composition felt foreign, different.
Using it was like adding wet fuel to a fire.
The flames would decrease until the wood dried, eventually becoming something that would burn.
Her body was being forced to process the ven first before taking it in.
Even now, she had only restored about a tenth of what she had used the previous day despite the resting she had done.
She had an affinity to wind, so her connection with the natural ven in the air was strongest.
It was from the air that she recovered most of her ven, at least normally.
Eydis wondered if the strange bitter air of this land was somehow related.
Justin provided her clothing and let her bathe in his home, but she troubled him further by collapsing.
The air was too thin and too hard to breathe.
The steam from the hot water filled the air and suffocated her.
Eydis tolerated it to finish bathing, but the longer she spent, the worse she grew.
Before she realized how bad she had become, it was too late.
Her eyes no longer focused, and her lightheadedness prevented her from moving and cutting off the water.
Justin called out to her in concern, but Eydis could not let him come in on her, even if he meant well.
Using what ven she could convert to wind and gather in her weakened state, she forced the steam away long enough to take deep breaths.
She managed to find the energy to cut off the water and exit the tub, but using wind magic further worsened her condition.
It stole the air her body so desperately needed.
Her head felt as if it would float away, and nothing in the small room held shape in her vision.
Once Justin called again, Eydis knew he would soon enter.
She had endured mock death-matches as an advancement requirement in her martial training.

Her last advancement match involved fighting for her life when depleted of all stamina, ven, breath, and more that was required to function normally let alone protect herself in a fight or even defeat her far more skilled instructor, Symra.
Eydis had barely won at significant cost, leading Symra to request Emperor Yuro to stop her training.
Eydis could function without breath while being lightheaded.
She frantically pulled the pants over her wet legs and pulled them up as far as she could, making sure to tuck her tail inside.
She stood and pulled the shirt over her head, but the motion in her lightheadedness made her black out, and she fell forward into the door.
The moment of blackness was brief, her trained body pulling her back to consciousness almost immediately.
She turned the knob in desperation for the air on the other side and collapsed in front of her rescuer.
He quickly understood the cause of her agony and helped her breathe, saving her again.

Saving her life, giving her food, providing clothing, arranging a meeting with someone with whom she could communicate, providing a bath--Eydis felt she was becoming more and more indebted to this man.
Out of her own curiosity and desire to communicate, she even asked him to help her learn his language.

Emer’s original plan was for Eydis to exit the portal somewhere in the Amelian Empire or the neighboring allied countries where she would immediately be recognized and taken to local officials whose responsibility it would be to give her shelter and provide for her safety.
Instead, she was transported into enemy territory and had to rely on the kindness of a civilian to help and conceal her.

Justin’s exchange with the taller man was proof that she was unwelcome or that her presence would cause Justin and him trouble, especially with humans breaking their ceasefire in the most heinous manner possible.
Despite these risks, Justin continued helping her, and she had nothing to give him in return.
If any guards discovered that Justin sheltered Eydis instead of reporting her immediately, that would be grounds for immediate execution.
What could she offer him that would balance out the risk he was taking?
Eydis’s mind circled around the rewards the empire would give him, sanctuary and monetary compensation among others.
But the current state of the Amelian Empire was unknown.
By now, the news of the death of her family would have spread through various information channels.
There was no telling what panic or chaos could be ensuing right now or if the assassinations were just the precursor to a far grander scheme.

The kingdom of the humans, Tolmyur, almost evenly matched the Amelian Empire’s strength; the magical superiority being on the empire’s side, but the physical strength and sheer numbers being on the human’s side.

However, fighting that human assassin that surpassed even her mentor in spatial magic and seeing the magical communication device that each human here seemed to possess, Eydis could no longer say with any certainty that the empire held magical superiority over the humans.
If there were others with the same strength in magic as that assassin, if there were many more like him, the empire would fall.
How then would she be able to repay Justin?
She could make all the promises in the world, but they would fall empty depending on the outcome of the war.
The possibility even existed that the two men would not accept a promise with no guarantee of fulfillment and instead expected to be paid outright.
What could she offer then?
She had nothing.
Eydis’s heart sank as the chilling caress of unease ran its fingers down her spine.
She hated herself for realizing it, but there was something she could offer, as a woman.
She did not want such an arrangement and could not make such an arrangement given her status, but what if Justin or that other man requested or demanded it of her?
The very thought made her legs tremble.
The heir to the Amelian Empire being taken by human commoners would bring shame to the empire no different than losing the war.
Eydis would have to turn them down and leave, but what would happen to her then?
Would someone being sheltered in enemy territory at the risk of the death of her saviors have the right to refuse?
While Eydis worried over the nature of her situation, Justin returned carrying a blue knitted cap and matching scarf, a grey sweater, and a brown coat.
He looked at her shaking frame and coaxed her to sit back down.
Her trepidation had been mistaken for physical weakness.
Eydis tried to assure him that she was alright and donned the sweater.
Justin then wrapped the scarf around Eydis’s neck and placed the cap over her head, tucking her pointed ears inside.
Placing his hands over her concealed ears, Justin looked Eydis in the eyes and spoke to her in a serious tone, his gaze unshaken.
Although Eydis did not understand his words, she knew the meaning.
“Keep your ears hidden.”
Eydis’s situation was exactly as she had feared: other humans discovering that she was an elf was dangerous for them both.
Justin led Eydis out the door and locked it behind him.
Eydis looked around at the building.
It was a tenement at the edge of a residential district.
He lived on the bottom floor with what appeared to be two more residences to the left.

If the second floor held the same number, there were six in total for the tenement, all much smaller in size compared to the shingle-roofed residences she could see from the walled-in, paved pathway in front of his door.
The paving was cracked and crumbling in disrepair at the edges.
The metal columns supporting the walk of the second floor were chipping and rusted in places.

In direct contrast to the amazing machinery and technology, the appliances and heated water his home provided--his abundant wealth compared to the poverty she expected of the average human--a dark worry struck her that Justin might be a lower-class citizen, at least lower than those who lived in the quality structures surrounding the tenement.
No government at war would hesitate to kill a lower-class citizen for harboring the enemy.
She doubted humans would even hesitate to kill a noble for helping her.
Eydis’s hands rose subconsciously to cover her ears under the woven cap as if its thick weave was not sufficient to hide the soft cartilage underneath.
Justin led Eydis the opposite direction from the other houses and through a gate that opened to a path along the riverside.
After only walking a short distance, Eydis noticed a patch of disturbed leaves and snow partially concealed in bushes.

Eydis had thought that she was far enough separate from civilization in some wooded area, but the truth was that there were homes on the other side of the wall of trees just across the path from where she slept.
There was little choice but for her to be discovered; however, being discovered by Justin saved her life.
Eydis and Justin continued walking down the river path towards a large metal and stone bridge.
Similar beings to the one she had seen the night before crossed at incredible speeds.
They were many different shapes, sizes, and colors.
The diversity of the monsters was astounding.
As they neared the bridge, Eydis realized they were not monsters but closer to fast-moving metal carriages.

She felt terribly embarrassed by the assumptions caused by her fears, but the contraptions were unlike anything she had ever seen before, so she had to remind herself that such misunderstandings were normal.
Or should be normal.
She had never been in a situation like this, and she did not doubt that anyone else from Amel would have made the same mistake had they never been to the human territory.

None of the carriages had flares or the means to produce them on top like the one she encountered the night before, so the one summoned by that man had been special, possibly meant solely for the town guard or whatever the role of that man was.
She couldn’t even begin to guess.
Everything in this city was too foreign, too different.
The river path continued under the bridge.
Justin led Eydis up cobblestone steps on the other side to the road.
Eydis had been enduring their brief trek, but after climbing the steps, she needed to rest.
Her lungs pleaded for air, but it was in such short supply.
She had to wonder how Justin was so unaffected by the thin air.
His breath was so light that he almost looked as if he wasn’t breathing at all.
Eydis pulled on Justin’s sleeve and motioned that she wanted to sit down.
She could push through, but she did not want to end up in a state that would trouble Justin even more than a short rest.
Thankfully, Justin understood her silent gesticulation and led her a short distance away from the bridge to a blue bench with a sign attached to the corner.
Eydis leaned her head back on the bench like Justin had shown her before and noticed again that she could breathe a little easier.
Once she felt better, Eydis spent her rest looking around at the peculiar buildings and people along the road.
As expected of the human kingdom, it was highly populated.
The buildings were all simple rectangles in shape, but the colors and expensive, clear glass windows advertised their exquisite quality.
The number of automated metal carriages was astounding.
The empire could never hope to craft such machines, and this city alone had so many.
What would happen if the humans were to use metal carriages specialized in combat in the war?
Even the carriages used by the civilians appeared impervious to arrows, blades, and other martial weaponry.
They looked as if they could withstand weaker magic.
Given the offensive capabilities of the assassin, there was no doubt in Eydis’s mind that the humans had the ability to make carriages capable of withstanding advanced magic.
Eydis knew.
The empire would lose this war.
While eyeing the carriages and people, another strange realization came to Eydis.
There were no giants, dwarves, or minums among the populous.
Humans came in four breeds.
Minums were the ruling race of Tolmyur and lived north of the deserts in more fertile lands along the largest river on the continent.
The ‘mi’ in their name meant river in their tongue, ‘num’ meaning people.
They appeared in every way the same as general humans aside from being half the height.
They were the magical power of the human races, usually having affinities to multiple elements.
General humans, or sotnum in the minum tongue, the primary language of Tolmyur, were the most populous due to their high proliferation.
‘Sot’ meant ‘west’ since the humans originated from the same lands as the elves before migrating east to the deserts.
They had minor magical capabilities and average athleticism, a well-rounded race.
Dwarves, the mountain-folk or doknum, were short and stout and usually specialized in a single magical affinity.
While stronger than the general humans, they were slower than both humans and giants, and so dwarves would often lose to them and other athletic races in physical combat.
This led them to combine magic with martial skill to terrifying results.
They had once been a longstanding ally of the elves before the creation of the Amelian Empire, but regrettably they joined under Tolmyur’s banner.

Giants, called seknum in Tolmyur since they were a seafaring people who lived along the coasts of the deserts, stood up to one and a half times the height of general humans and possessed no magic ability, but their physical ability far surpassed any of the elfkind, even the large-bodied male Mountain Elves.
Even in a city with a high population of general humans, Eydis assumed there should still be at least a few of the other breeds mixed in.
Eydis had seen one short, stout woman that could have been a dwarf, but she lacked the other physical markers of the race.
Any minum Eydis thought she saw was only a child, and there were no giants to be seen anywhere.
A tap on Eydis’s shoulder woke her from her contemplation.
Justin pointed down the road at a rather large, blue, rectangular carriage.
It pulled to a stop in front of them filled with people.
Justin waited for a few to exit and then pulled Eydis inside.
He placed the communication device he carried on a small pedestal by the entrance until the color at the top changed from blue to green.
He then repeated the motion a second time and led Eydis to the back where she could sit down in the only unoccupied seat.
Justin stood next to her and held onto a rod that extended down from the ceiling and attached to the corner of her seat.

Eydis watched out the window in amazement as the carriage crossed the bridge at an incredible speed but grew disappointed when it slowed to a stop so soon to let off more passengers and take on others.
This carriage, or perhaps a passenger wagon might be a closer analogy, served the purpose of transportation for those who lacked access to carriages of their own.
The infrastructure of human society was amazing.
There was no equal to it in the empire.
After a few more stops, Justin pulled on a wire above him.
The carriage stopped once again, and Justin led Eydis out its door.
The scenery where they exited was different from along the river.
The buildings were far larger and more spread out.
The architecture changed from building to building, some even resembling simple red-brick fortresses lacking external walls or other defensive fortifications.
One had pillars at its entrance atop some twenty or thirty steps.
Another was a simple rectangle in shape covered in nothing but pristine glass with a green tint.
Long cement paths led to and from buildings with wide grass clearings between, decorated with sparse trees and shrubbery that were well cultivated.
Benches lined some paths, but none were in use.
Most of those walking outside preferred to get to their destinations and out of the cold quickly.
Eydis began to worry about whether this was a government facility.
What else could explain the apparent affluence?
In the end she could only trust Justin.
Justin led Eydis along paths between the structures.
Eydis found that the vast majority of people here were young adults, many with packs on their backs or books in their hands.
The packs would suggest this was a destination for travelers, which might explain why there was someone who understood foreign languages.
Perhaps it was affiliated with city customs.
Then again, wouldn’t customs be better located near points of entry?
There was also little evidence that the buildings were inns or taverns where travelers would congregate.
The truth had to relate to the books and documents many carried.
Perhaps this was a large archival complex, but what purpose would a city have for one so grand?
She had learned that minums traditionally were adept recordkeepers, but this was clearly a human city, not minum.

When Eydis noticed two men younger than Justin near the entrance of one of the structures conversing with a much older woman as she explained and pointed at some document atop a book one of the men carried, Eydis found her answer.
This was an educational institution.
Did Justin have connections here?
If so, did that mean that even lower-class citizens of the Tolmyur Kingdom had access to education?
Eydis watched in amazement the students passing by.
The number suggested that most young adults in this city attended here, if her estimation of the city’s size during her brief travel was anywhere near correct.
The humans were not only far more technologically advanced, but they might also treat their people better than her empire treated her own.
Everything Eydis had learned about the human Kingdom of Tolmyur was being turned on its tail with each new revelation.

Due to the large population of humans, insufficient resources created widespread poverty with only the merchant and upper class being able to live comfortably, and even their affluence would be poor by the Amelian Empire’s standards.
Humans bore many children from very young ages due to the high mortality rate of youth and to supply more workhands.
Organized education was non-existent, and most humans were either taught the trade of their parents or were conscripted into the army.
The lucky ones who avoided conscription ended up becoming hunter mercenaries, farmhands, or apprentices of craftsmen without children of their own.
The unlucky joined bandit groups, became slaves, or starved to death.
The Tolmyur Kingdom was supposed to be an oppressive absolute monarchy.
Eydis had to wonder if she was taught lies.
The advanced infrastructure, well-dressed appearances, high quality shops, public education, and cheerful demeanor of the people all shattered Eydis’s mental perception of human life.
Justin brought Eydis into one of the plainer looking, but rather tall, structures that had interchanging layers of glass windows and red brick at every floor.
Taking her to a small room off from the entrance, he pressed a small, upward-facing arrow symbol on the wall next to a metal door.
The symbol promptly lit up.
After a moment, the metal door opened leading to an even smaller room that could fit no more than ten people if packed tight.
The only adornment was a simple handrail that ran along the breadth of each wall.
Eydis followed him inside with no shortage of unease.
There were no doors other than the one they entered, and there were no windows.
She could not understand the purpose of this tiny room.
Justin pressed one of many circular symbols beside the door, and the doors closed, trapping them in.
Eydis grabbed the sleeve of Justin’s coat.
He looked up at her with an assuring smile that almost looked amused.
Without saying a word, he pointed upward.
Gravity in the room increased, causing Eydis to yelp lightly in surprise at first, but the increase was pleasant and a little closer to what it felt like in the empire.
Beside her, Justin fought to hold in a snicker, making Eydis feel a little self-conscious.
The sensation soon ended, and the doors opened.
The windows showed they were now on the top floor of the building.
The reason for the increase in gravity was the room raising upwards--an automated pulley system, perhaps.
This was another fascinating human technology.
Eydis followed Justin down a mostly deserted hallway to a row of wooden doors.
Justin knocked on one near the end, and a familiar raspy voice answered.
Justin opened the door and led Eydis inside.
The small room had an outward facing window in the back covered in vertical and evenly spaced slats.
The window revealed the campus, city, and mountains not far in the distance.
A bookshelf was mounted on the wall to the left, and a desk wrapped around below the window and along the right wall.
An elderly human man who appeared to be about five years old sat in a black leather chair.
His disheveled white hair and chin-strap beard gave the look of an academic.

Eydis found this assumption reasonable if this was an institute of learning, and only a scholar would invest his brief human lifespan to learn the language of the sprites who were an extreme minority even in the Amelian Empire.
After a word of greeting to Justin, the elderly man turned to Eydis.
“I am pleased to meet you,” he said in the familiar tongue of the sprites.
“Please sit in the chair beside you.”
Eydis sat down as instructed, but there were only two chairs, so Justin leaned back against the wall beside the door.
His relaxed posture in front of his elder and superior struck Eydis as bizarre, and she feared there might be repercussions, but Shuman did not seem to mind.
Perhaps he was mild-mannered or forgiving of such benign insults, but to be safe, Eydis sat straight with her hands clasped in her lap, legs close together, and her ankles politely crossed.
She was a princess, but in her current situation, Shuman was the highest authority and deserving of respect.
Shuman spoke with Justin and asked a few questions to which Justin gave concise replies.
Satisfied, Shuman faced Eydis once again.
“Justin tells me that you do not speak English, but you know other tongues that he has not heard.
How many do you speak?”
Shuman’s knowledge of the language was what Eydis had expected.
He spoke in the slow and simple words of one who knew the language of the sprites but was not fluent.
Although most people spoke multiple languages, those with enough education to speak many languages fluently were few and far between.
Telling the truth about how many languages she spoke may raise suspicion against her or at least hint her social status.
However, Justin would not have brought her to this man if he did not trust him at some level.
After careful contemplation, she decided to answer.
Being a polyglot did not immediately mean she was royalty.
“I speak one hundred and thirteen languages and dialects.”
Shuman’s eyes widened and he leaned back in his chair.
“Does that mean you speak most of the major tongues in the world?”
Shuman’s statement surprised Eydis.
The languages and dialects in the Amelian Empire alone numbered nearly one hundred.
If she included the neighboring countries and territories, they increased to multiple thousands, and that was just one of the smaller continents of Whinhlem.
Including the beastkin who populated the rest of Whinhlem, the world had hundreds of thousands of languages if their various dialects were included.

There were, of course, the major political and commerce languages that most people of every country knew or could at least understand, but each race and society strongly held onto the language of their origin, and that practice was widely accepted all over the world.
The only way a language would die out would be the extinction of the race that spoke it.
Even the humans, giants, dwarves, and minums had their own separate languages and accompanying dialects with Common Minum being used universally throughout Tolmyur.
Was Shuman not educated after all, or was their education suppressed to include only what was needed within human society?
If that was the case, having only one hundred languages made sense.
Eydis had to make certain.
“How many languages are there in the world?”
Shuman thought for a moment.
“From what I know, there are about eight thousand.”
“Do you understand this language,” Eydis asked in the Common Minum dialect she had learned.
“I am sorry,” Shuman replied.
“I do not know what you said.”
How could a human scholar not even know the common tongue of the humans?
There was an obvious answer, and Eydis felt a fool that she had not realized sooner.
“What is the name of this nation?”
Shuman looked visibly perplexed.
“I do not know how to say it.
Please wait.” He pulled a book from a shelf above his desk and flipped through the pages.
After jumping from location to location, page to page, he inserted it back on the shelf and sat down.
“I could not find a good way to say it.
In English, we call it ‘The United States of America’.”
“This is not the Tolmyur Kingdom?
Can you show me a map?”
Shuman did not react to the mention of Tolmyur.
He turned around to the large black slate mounted on a stand sitting atop his desk.
Moving a small object on the desk lit the slate.
It was a larger version of the communication device that all humans carried.
Soon what resembled a map appeared.
Shuman turned the slate towards Eydis and moved away.

It was then that Eydis realized the chairs in which she and Shuman sat had small wheels attached to the bottom, so she slid her chair in front of the map mimicking the light motions of Shuman’s legs to take caution against any uncouth movements.
The land masses and bodies of water looked nothing like anything she had formerly seen on maps at the palace.
There was the possibility that these were only small islands that she would not have noticed when looking at the full world map.
“Where are these islands located?” she asked.
“I do not know what you mean.”
“Can you show me the whole world map?”
“This is the world map,” Shuman replied, perplexed.
“Where are we?”
Shuman rolled his chair next to Eydis and requested access to the small hand device.
Moving it also moved a small white arrow on the slate.
Shuman motioned the arrow in a circle around the center of the northwestern landmass.
“Here.”
The map then expanded to focus on the area Shuman had circled.
Map details were added and became more visible.
Eydis gasped in astonishment despite herself.
Rivers, lakes, and mountains formed.
What looked like cities dotted the landscape, and their size was easily visible.
These were not small islands but small continents.
The entire Amelian Empire would almost fit inside the continent Shuman highlighted.
Out the window behind the desk, Eydis noticed that the sun was already setting when it should still be midday.
She sat slack in her chair, too dumbstruck to worry about keeping appearances.
Is this real?
Is this world not Whinhlem?
Where am I?
Seeing Eydis’s reaction, Shuman spoke with Justin.
Their conversation lasted for some time.
“Justin says there is a lot about you that is not…”
Shuman paused for a moment like he was trying to find the right way to express what he wanted to say.
Justin intervened.
He made the motions of removing her woven cap, suggesting that Eydis should be up front to Shuman about who she was.
Eydis was apprehensive.
Justin knew she was an elf and had taken precautions so that this truth would not be revealed.
Was it safe to reveal the truth to Shuman as well?
Again, Eydis’s training told her to abstain from any action that could endanger her, and again Eydis had to suppress its impulse.
She was taught to survive in many varying situations, but in all her training, she had never been told how to act when brought to another world.
How could Evhial, Symra, or Emer ever predict such an event occurring?
Although, Emer was the one who sent her to this world.
If he had such ability, he should have taught her how to interact with the natives of a new world.
In the end, she had little choice but to trust Justin, and therefore trust Shuman.
She removed her woven hat.
Her pointed ears sprung outwards flicking out strands of hair with them.
This time it was Shuman who sat back in his chair dumbstruck.
He asked some worried question to Justin who in turn replied with a serious answer.
Justin pointed at his eyes, ears, and lower back in his explanation and then held out his arms as if carrying something.
After hearing Justin’s explanation, Shuman leaned forward to get a better look at Eydis’s eyes and ears.
“Are you an elf?” He asked.
Eydis held back her answer.

If these humans were as hostile to elves as those in the Tolmyur Kingdom, even if they were not at war, or especially if they had connections with the Tolmyur Kingdom, confessing herself a High Elf would be the end of her freedom and possibly result in execution.
Then again, Shuman did not react to her mention of Tolmyur.
Eydis looked back at Justin with worry pained in her face.
Justin replied with a reassuring smile and nodding head.
Eydis lowered her head and tensed.
Every emotion within her was telling her to remain silent or lie.
Humans killed her family, a reality that she was constantly trying to push to the back of her mind to focus on what was happening at this moment.
Everything Shuman had shown her could have been fabricated.
She may still be in danger.
But… Justin would not have taken her here if he did not trust Shuman.
He had already done so much for her, too much to reason off as a means to some convoluted deception ploy to earn her trust to capture her.
If it was all a lie, then she could not fault herself for believing it.
Taking a deep breath, Eydis spoke.
“I am a High Elf of the Amelian Empire.” Eydis’s ears drooped slightly after her confession.
She readied an emergency teleportation formula in case the worst occurred.
She set the destination to the far side of one of the mountains she could see in the distance from the small room’s window.
Shuman exhaled loudly and leaned back in his chair.
“Now I know why you speak Anglo-Saxon,” he said with his hand still covering his mouth as if it had somehow grown attached.
Sitting upright, he continued.
“Elves are from old Germanic stories and were known as the white spirits of the forests.
You said you were from the Amelian Empire.
I do not know it.
How did you come here?”
Eydis could sense no deception in Shuman’s words.
Perhaps these humans had no connection with the Tolmyur Kingdom.
The fear welling up within her abated, albeit only slightly, but she felt safe enough to explain what happened the night before.
“I escaped an assassin.”

Shuman and Justin listened awestruck as Eydis recited the calamity that had befallen her family, but she left out the details about humans being the perpetrators, fearing that it might cause some misunderstanding or make them think there was a condemning reason the humans of her world were hostile towards elfkind.
Shuman translated each statement for Justin as she spoke, looking up words in his book that he was unsure of and filling in guesses where no translation could be found.
By the end, Justin sat on the floor.
Her tale overwhelmed him.
“So…” Shuman spoke up after a moment of silence.
“If this is all true, you are the princess and next queen of the Amelian Empire?”
“Next empress, yes,” Eydis replied.
“I do not want to doubt you, but things like magic and elves do not exist in this world.
They are only stories.
If it is not too much to ask, could you show your story is true by using some magic?
True magic?”
Eydis understood that Shuman’s emphasis on the word “true” meant he desired proof that could not be seen as a trick or illusion or explained through other means.
The request was trivial, and she was more than willing to comply.
“It is more difficult for me to use the ven here, but I can.”
Shuman had a very small, leafy plant in a pot in the windowsill behind his desk.
It was in the peak of health, suggesting that Shuman took great care of it.
“May I see that plant?”
Shuman handed Eydis the small ceramic planter.
“Do not hurt it.”
Eydis gathered life ven in her hand and touched the stem of the small plant between her thumb and forefinger.
Fresh branches and leaves grew before their eyes.
The growth was small but very noticeable.
Eydis stopped at the point where going further might endanger the plant with its current nutrient levels.
She then handed back the planter.
Shuman examined and touched the fresh leaves.
“In all my fifty-eight years, I never thought I would see true magic.”
Eydis was stunned.
Shuman looked no older than five.
Humans had a lifespan of about five to six years, but some lived to seven.
Members of elfkind lived to be about 80 with High Elves commonly reaching 90 to 100 years of age.
How could a human live so long?
“Can you ask Justin his age?”
After a brief exchange, Shuman responded.
“He is 23.”
This broke all knowledge Eydis had on human biology.
Eydis was only halfway through her fourth year of life, yet Justin looked no older than she.
Were these people not human?
This was another world, so humans might be different here.
Eydis reached another realization.
This world was different.
This was no better proven than by the map she had seen.
The map suggested that this world was smaller than hers.
