Her first instructor, Evhial, had taught her that the larger the body, the larger the gravitational pull.
The opposite would then be true.
The reason she felt lighter, and possibly why the air was thinner, was because this world was small.
The days were also about half the length of those from her world.
None of the knowledge about her world would apply here.
If the measurement of years was also different, then the ages of Justin and Shuman could be explained.
They might still be human.
“How many days are in your year?” Eydis asked.
“365 and one fourth part,” Shuman replied.
Eydis was puzzled about the fraction of a day that was included but thought it best to ignore.
However, the number alone meant little.
Eydis could no longer make any assumptions.
“How do you measure your numbers?”
Shuman looked puzzled and then asked Justin, possibly for clarification or an idea of what she meant.
Coming to a conclusion, Justin held up all ten digits of his hands.

Eydis understood that this meant their number system was likely base ten, something she felt was rather primitive, but she could understand the ease it made simple calculations although at the cost of complicating division due to the lack of divisors the base allowed.
The common folk of Whinhlem often measured their numbers the same.
Eydis requested something to write on.
Shuman handed her a high-quality piece of parchment and an odd-looking writing instrument.
It was transparent, and the ink appeared to be held in a tube inside of it removing the need for an inkwell.
Or perhaps it could be better stated that the inkwell was inside the pen.
It was fascinating.
She worked out the conversion of 365 from base ten.
She then used her observed length of the day in this world to estimate how many days their year would be in hers.
Finishing the math, she was ready to report her findings, or rough estimates at least.
“A year in my world would be just under twelve in yours.
This would make me about fifty-five in your years.”
“You age well,” Shuman jested, visibly trying to hold back his surprise.
“Elves do age much slower than humans in my world, so perhaps it is the same here.
I am physically an adult, but I am also still considered to be in my youth because I have not become independent.
High Elves like myself live to be…” Eydis paused to mentally calculate the years, having already grown accustomed to the simple base conversion, “We live for about one thousand years in your time.”
Shuman explained to Justin the reason for Eydis’s out-of-place questions along with her age, but Justin did not appear surprised.
Instead, he spoke some serious words back at Shuman who nodded in agreement.
“Justin wants us to return to topic.”
Eydis realized that she had moved their conversation in an unimportant direction, overcome by her curiosity.
“Your family was killed, and your teacher sent you to this world, correct?” Shuman asked.
Eydis nodded.
“Do you think there is a way to send you back to your world?”
“I do not know.
I am an amateur in that school of magic and nowhere close to the abilities of Emer.
Sending someone to another world is magic I cannot begin to understand.
Emer must have done it because my assassin was another mage of equal or higher ability.
He had easily traced our attempted escapes until this one.
I did not even know Emer was capable of such grand magic.”
Shuman grew troubled.
“You said your assassin was the same or stronger than Emer.
Is there a chance that he could still come for you?”
“My destination was randomized, and Emer stayed behind to scramble the trace… the remnants of the magic left behind after its casting,” she explained quickly.
“My assassin has not followed, so I want to believe that Emer succeeded.
I cannot say for certain, but I do not think it would be possible for the assassin to follow me.”
“Are you sure?”
Eydis considered all the theories and laws of teleportation she had learned from Emer.
Emer would never lie to her about the capabilities of his own magical specialty, especially considering she would become empress.
Doing so would be tantamount to occupational suicide leaning on the side of treason.
“Yes, everything I have learned says it is impossible, but… I also thought teleporting to another world was impossible.
The assassin used magic I had never seen before too, so for him… I cannot guess.”

Chapter 7
“Friends are those with whom you can confide.”
Eydis
Eydis sat at the back of a small lecture hall.
She grew fascinated by the angular table that rose from between her seat and the one next to it and folded down over her lap.
She spent a few minutes in an inquisitive fever repeating the raising and folding motions and admiring the peculiar hinge that made such movements possible.
The few occupants sitting among the tiered seating of the hall watched her in confusion.
Each student in the room was not skilled in the language of this country, English.
Eydis received special permission from Dr. Shuman after their meeting yesterday to attend an English course designed for foreign students.
The timing of the course near-perfectly coincided with the time Justin was earning money, making it quite advantageous.

When Eydis asked about Justin’s job, he simply replied, “I answer questions.” Eydis was curious to what kind of occupation such a cryptic answer could apply and landed on the only possibility on Whinhlem, an information broker.
The lower class of many large cities was often the priviest to the rumors and secrets of the city.
The most knowledgeable among them would sell this information to others, if the price was good enough.
Perhaps Justin leveraged his tutelage within the institution to gain access to broader information channels.
It was a dangerous profession that paid poorly for most information but held the potential for great reward for rare and dangerous knowledge.

The more difficult to obtain and dangerous the information, the higher the risk to the broker’s life, especially considering the greatest of rumors were often detrimental to the person who was the topic of the rumor, and so they would want to silence the spread as a matter of course.
If Justin lived with that kind of risk daily, she better understood why he would be willing to house an unknown person who was the target of a very powerful assassin.
After the meeting with Dr. Shuman ended, the topic arose of where Eydis would stay.
Dr. Shuman raised concern about having a young woman stay in an apartment with two other men but was unable to provide her shelter himself.
He was willing, but his relationship with his wife was currently strained, and she rejected the idea of him bringing home a younger woman without giving him a chance to explain the situation.
Allegedly, he had affairs in the past.
Eydis could understand the feelings of a wife who would easily mistake this act of kindness as taking in a much younger mistress.
Their relationship would only worsen if his wife would not accept Eydis’s presence in his home.
In the end, Justin agreed to take care of Eydis until something more permanent could be set up.
The only hurdle was the other resident, Sean.
Justin talked to Sean that evening and explained the situation but made sure to leave out the information about Eydis’s origin and the assassin targeting her.
Persuading Sean was difficult, but he agreed under strict terms.
Eydis had to find some way to earn money, and when possible, she would find her own place to live.
Their home only had two personal rooms with a single bed each.
For the time being, Justin agreed to sleep on the couch, giving Eydis his bed.
Eydis refused such generosity at first, but Justin would not budge, so she had little choice but to give in to his kindness with an unspoken promise to herself to repay him when able.
Finding a way to earn money was difficult for Eydis in her current situation.
She was an illegal resident of this country and did not know the language.
Eydis was at least grateful that Sean had not requested her to repay them outright, and she sought every opportunity to gain his favor after seeing how angry he became when Justin saved her.
She wanted to find work so that she would not be pressured into unfavorable methods of repayment.
Her request to be taught the English language was a means to this end and led to her seat in this lecture.
By the end of the lecture, Eydis was relieved at the similarities between English and the sprite tongue, more so than she previously thought.
Understanding the lecture was extremely difficult, but reading with Justin on her first day helped immensely.
Her conversations with Dr. Shuman and this lecture from one of his associates built Eydis’s confidence in her understanding of the basic grammatical structure of the language.

She would only need to learn the vocabulary, their conjugations, and practice as much as possible to grow accustomed to the pragmatics; however, this was the cause for frustration due to the number of conflicting rules and exceptions in English.
Eydis understood that many languages absorbed parts of others to develop.
She only wished that English had picked the rules of the languages it assimilated and incorporated those rules universally throughout instead of using haphazard combinations of conflicting rules.
Eydis closed the small pocket-sized grammar book Dr. Shuman had given her and let out a sigh.
The more she read, the more annoyed she became.
Of all the languages she had studied, this was the first language she felt was not worth learning, and yet it was the only one she needed to learn for the sake of her own survival.
Eydis slouched in a padded chair of an empty foyer where Justin had instructed her to wait.
It was only about 200 square feet in size and contained a single couch and chair.
The double doors between the chair and sofa led to the second-floor balcony seats of an old lecture hall.

When she peaked in the doors out of curiosity, the room almost reminded her of a much, much smaller version of the grand council chamber of the Amelian palace, except everything was fashioned of wood instead of marble.
It could fit maybe two hundred students on the first floor and half that on the balcony seats.

The foyer only had two entrances, and Justin chose it for their meetup location due to how few people passed through the connected stairs to the hall’s first floor and the hallway that extended about ten yards opposite the double doors before turning corner out of sight.
A little time remained before Justin would return.
She tried to keep occupied to prevent herself from mourning the death of her family or drowning in worry over what was happening in the empire with her family gone.

The sight of her brothers severed in half lying in their own gore flashed in her mind the moment she let her mind wander, and the mere thought of her parents, brothers, and Ceil caused her heart to ache with an acute pain.
But, she also felt that any further study into the English language would only lead to frustration.
Tilting her head back, Eydis decided to practice her deep breathing and focus on her ven regeneration to help her body better process the unfamiliar ven of this world.
Eydis closed her eyes and fell into a trance.
“Do you think I am not aware you were stalking me?”
“I wasn’t stalking you.
I just wanted to apologize for last night.”
Eydis woke abruptly from her trance because of the angry voice of a girl.
Eydis quickly corrected her assumption.
It was a woman, not a young girl, though she was quite short.
The woman had shoulder-length brown hair with a mild wave that made the ends curl out in random directions.

Her face was round but well enough proportioned to accentuate her doll-like cheeks and subtle jawline that would have made Eydis immediately think of young nobility if not for her crass tone of speech.
She walked beside another much taller man with hair colored a slightly darker shade of brown.
He talked back to her in a stern tone while rubbing the stubble on his chin.
Upon closer inspection, they were not walking together.
When he jumped ahead a pace, she briskly stepped further ahead.
When he placed his hand on her shoulder to turn her to face him, she swatted it away.
She wanted him to leave, but he wouldn’t.
When they reached the foyer, the woman turned to face him and started jamming her finger into his chest which was at the level of her face.
“I’m not some cheap whore who can be bought off with a meal!”
When she tried to walk away, the man walked in front of her pleading with outstretched arms for her to wait and hear him out.
Eydis did not understand the full nature of their conversation but felt that the woman could use help.
She stood and walked between her and the man.
“Leave alone.”
“This has nothing to do with you,” the man replied, but he then froze with a creeping smile.
“Leave alone,” Eydis repeated.
“He’s not worth the trouble,” the woman spat.
The man stepped back to look Eydis in the eyes.
His gaze then wandered down to her chest, then hips and waist, looking mildly disappointed that her form was hidden under her thick clothing.
“You want to hang out some time?
I know the best clubs in the city.”
Eydis did not understand the man, but she knew he had changed his target.
His overconfident grin that said she would be his made her skin crawl.
When he stepped closer, Eydis’s training instinct triggered.
She pushed the man in the chest while simultaneously expelling wind with force, barely managing to catch herself to avoid using any magic that would be harmful.
The man flew back to the other side of the small foyer and rolled once when he hit the ground.
“You go!” Eydis shouted.
The man used the wall to stand and stumbled away down the stairs without looking back.
It was then that Eydis realized what she had just done.
In her disgust, she reflexively used magic in front of two unknown people when Justin was making every effort to hide her identity.
This was a grave mistake caused by the harsh training and conditioning her father forced upon her.
Would Justin be angry?
Would he scold her?
If word spread that she was capable of magic in a world that supposedly had no magic, she would draw undesired attention, and that would trouble her rescuer.
And worse, in the rare chance that the assassin did arrive in this world, he would be able to locate her much easier.
She could no longer rely on the instincts engrained in her since childhood.
They were detrimental to her survival on this world.
In addition to learning English and meditating to become accustomed to the strange ven, she now had to actively repress her training.
Eydis turned to the woman still standing in the foyer with these worries spiraling in her mind.
The short woman bounded in front of Eydis with pure excitement lit like a spark in her eyes, now looking more like the young girl she had initially assumed.
“Was that some kind of Chinese one-inch-punch?
That was incredible!”
Eydis thought for a moment but could not make any sense of what she said.
If she could do nothing about the man who saw her use magic, she could at least find out who he was and inform Justin with an apology and promise to be more careful.
“Who was he?” Eydis asked.
“A mistake,” the short woman replied.
“He is Mistake?”
“He asked me on a date last night, and I went.
It was a very nice restaurant, and I immediately knew what he was after.
I asked him to take me home right afterwards, but he wanted me to come back to his place.
I said no.
Then he had the gall to go after me in his own car!
God… Why do men think that you can buy sex with dinner?
Every guy I meet either thinks hello means I’m wet and ready or dates me forever without ever wanting sex.
There is no in-between!”
Eydis stood in silence.
Again, she could not make sense of her.
“Oh, I’m sorry.
You don’t speak English, do you.”
Eydis paused to string together a simple reply.
“I do not speak English good… no, well?”
“Where are you from?”
Again, Eydis thought carefully about her answer but not just because she had to figure out how to say it.
She could not tell her she was from another world, and there was no Amelian Empire in this world.
There was only one answer she could give.
“I am from house of Justin Hapfeld.”
“Justin?” The girl’s eyes wandered around the foyer and lingered on the sofa.
Her expression grew rather irritated for a moment but then calmed down.
“Are you his sister?
No, you are too tall, too old, and his sister obviously speaks English.
Don’t tell me you are his girlfriend.” The irritation returned.
This woman seemed to know Justin, which was a cause for some relief, although the irritation in her expression was troubling.
Eydis felt it best to explain further and show Justin’s sincerity.
“Justin help me.”
“God, of all people… Of course he would.
And here of all places, too.” The irritation faded but not completely.
“Well, at least you don’t have to worry about him trying to sleep with you.
I dated him for a year, and he wouldn’t even spoon.
He still living with Sean?”
“Sean?
Yes, house of Sean.”
“Sean’s an ass.”
Eydis did not know what an ass was, but from her tone, it could not have been a positive moniker.
Eydis rekindled her conviction to do whatever she could to not break Sean’s terms for letting her stay in his home.
“Hold on, isn’t that Justin’s sweater?
And that is Sean’s coat.
Those are men’s jeans too.
Are they Sean’s?
What kind of situation are you in?”
Eydis grew nervous when the woman picked at her clothing stating the names of the owners.
She realized that Eydis did not understand her question and rephrased it in simple words.
“Why are you with Sean and Justin?”
Eydis could not tell the woman her situation.
She may know Justin, but she was uninvolved.
The woman did not look like she would accept Eydis’s plea to remain silent, especially because she was acquainted with Justin.
Eydis took a deep breath and was about to speak when another voice spoke first.
“Sammy?”
It was Justin.
The woman named Sammy walked past Eydis into the hall and began firing questions.
“Who is this girl?
Why is she wearing you and Sean’s clothes?
Why is she staying at your apartment?
Why did she say you were helping her?”
Justin stepped backwards from the barrage of questions from someone that was even shorter than him, but he was not cowering.
He grew a confident smile.
“She’s an elven princess who was sent to our world using teleportation magic in order to escape an assassin who murdered her family.”
Eydis placed her hand on the woven cap, asking Justin with her eyes if she should take it off.
Justin shook his head lightly.
Sammy did not notice the exchange and grew more irritated.
“I’m being serious here!” she shouted.
Justin shrugged his shoulders and walked over to Eydis.
He asked to see her arm and pulled up her sleeve to reveal many long and crossing bruises on her forearm.
Justin recited the explanation that he, Dr. Shuman, and Eydis had agreed upon.
“Eydis was brought into the country illegally in an abusive situation we don’t know the full details about.
She escaped and collapsed on the river path just outside my apartment.
I found her in the morning practically naked and almost frozen to death.
I took her in and warmed her up.
School faculty knows about the situation.
We asked, but Eydis absolutely refuses to let us contact the police.
Happy?”
Sammy’s eyes widened.
“Was it sex trafficking or something?!
Is that what happened?” Sammy looked back and forth between Eydis and Justin.
“I already said we don’t know the full details.”
Sammy walked over to Eydis and grasped her hands.
“You poor thing.
Whatever happened to you, you are safe with me!
I’ll see if I can talk to my dorm manager to set you up with a bed.
For now, you can share my bed.
There is a limit of 3 days for visitors, but I’ll make something happen before then.”
Sammy again spoke far too fast for Eydis to follow.
Seeing Eydis’s confusion, Sammy slowed down.
“You. Stay. With. Me.”
Eydis was surprised by Sammy’s offer.
“What is your work?”
“Where do I work?
I am a librarian at the university here.”
“Librarian?” Eydis was not familiar with the word.
Sammy turned to Justin.
Her brows narrowed in annoyance.
“What language does she speak?”
“A lot of them, just none that I know.
Think central to northeast Europe.”
“God, you are useless.”
While Justin and Sammy argued about how to explain the word Eydis did not know, Eydis pulled out a small dictionary Dr. Shuman gave her.
The book was little help.

The word it used was a loan word of a different language than this Anglo-Saxon that Justin and Dr. Shuman claimed she spoke, or perhaps the language of the sprites was not entirely the same as what was once spoken on this world.
She was left to look up the other words in its description and piece the meaning together.
When Eydis thought she had come to some understanding, Sammy pulled the book from Eydis’s hands.
“This,” Sammy said, pointing at the book.
“Lots of this.”
Sammy worked in this school’s archives.
She was a bookkeeper.
Eydis felt she could not rely on her.
Given Justin’s profession as an information broker, he would be accustomed to the dangers and risks of his profession.
There was no doubt in Eydis’s mind that Justin had plans already set for defense, escape, and hiding if someone sought to silence him for the information he sold.
Justin also knew the truth of her situation and that powerful people were targeting her.
There was little chance that the assassin could follow her to this world, but the possibility remained, however improbable it might be.
Someone who was used to such risks and had plans prepared for emergencies would provide far better shelter than an uninvolved bookkeeper who was unable to send away one man just moments before.
Eydis was grateful for Sammy’s offer, but she could not accept.
“Sorry.
I stay at home of Justin.”
“Wait, what?
Is that what your question was about?
How can me working at a library make you decide to live with him?” Sammy noticed Eydis’s confusion.
“Whhyyyy?”
Eydis knew Sammy was asking the reason for her decision.
She looked up the single word that would describe her situation.
“Danger.
Danger for Sammy.”
“Danger?
Are those sex trafficking tards still looking for you?
I can see why you would worry about staying with another girl, and I admit I wouldn’t want to run into them either, but… Gahhhh!” Sammy ruffled her hand through her wavy hair.
“Fine.

Sean won’t do anything to you, and his police connections might help, and I’m not even sure Justin has a penis, so you will probably be safe there, but I want you to stay in contact with me.” Sammy turned to Justin who looked troubled by something Sammy said.
“She doesn’t have a phone, right?”
“What do you think?” Justin replied.
“Okay.
Eydis was it?
Come with me.”
Sammy grabbed Eydis’s wrist and began pulling her down the hallway.
Eydis stopped before turning the corner and looked back at Justin.
“Yes, you come too,” Sammy ordered.
“You are going to help me pay for everything.”
Justin ran to the other side of Eydis.
“You aren’t seriously going to get her a phone, are you?”
“How long have you known me?
What do you think?
Just think of it as me paying forward the favor.”

* * *
Eydis was excited to ride on the bus again.
There were far fewer people than there had been in the morning and the day before, so Eydis and her two companions each had seats in the center near the doors.

The bus ride was far longer than the trip from the bridge to the university, and they got off at what looked like a large fortress, but like all the other grand structures of the city, it lacked any defensive fortifications.
The huge field surrounding it was paved and filled with those automated carriages except for a few lines of small trees sectioning off parts of the field.
“What is this?” Eydis asked, unable to make sense of the massive structure.
“Have you never seen a mall before?
What kind of hole did they keep you in?
Please don’t tell me they captured you as a child and kept you hid away.”
Eydis resigned herself to being unable to understand Sammy’s quick speech until her proficiency with English improved.
She turned to Justin with the hope that he might explain, but Justin only shook his head.
“Ignore her.”
Eydis did not know the word “ignore” and so stayed silent.
Once inside, the purpose of the structure became clear.
Numerous stores lined the walls and showed their wares through crystal-clear glass.
The entire building was a covered market filled with extravagant shops selling exquisite items that even the nobility of the empire would pay fortunes to obtain.
Eydis wondered how someone of supposedly low class like Justin could afford to shop in such a marketplace.
The only possible reason Eydis could think of was Sammy who accompanied them.
Sammy’s noble features aside, a bookkeeper was an educated profession, and to be one for a large institution of learning would imply that Sammy was at least middle class but probably merchant class.
Her clothing was of a far higher quality than Justin’s, so Eydis felt her assumption was correct.
They walked along the long hallway filled with plants, kiosks, and small shops with the merchants peddling wares to passing shoppers.
On the sides, large banners and displays decorated the perfectly transparent glass.
White and black golems modeled clothing merchandise in the windows, but on closer inspection, the golems were not real but fabrications made from some glossy material.
Eydis could not deny that the display figures looked uncannily similar to the delegates from the golem nation of Stollmuk along the empire’s eastern border.
Golems could fashion their appearance however they pleased, but the delegates kept bipedal forms nearly identical to elves for ease of communication and interaction.
Sammy stopped at a smaller store with familiar hand-held communication devices on display.
She pulled Eydis inside and to one of the shop attendants.
She then snagged the attendant by the sleeve and pulled him and Eydis over to a specific device, ordering him to retrieve it.
He returned a moment later and walked with them to the counter.
The man displayed the usual tenacity of a peddler, but Sammy surprised Eydis by how well she controlled negotiations.
Definitely a merchant’s daughter.
Soon Sammy pulled Justin in and made him pay for the device, screeching Eydis’s thoughts to a halt.
Why would Sammy force a lower class to pay?
Were these communication devices actually rather inexpensive?
Or was she abusing her superior social status?
“I can’t believe I had to buy it.
Wasn’t it your idea to get her a phone?” Justin moaned.
“She’s on my plan.
You only made the down payment, but I’ll be getting the monthly bill.
In the end, I’ll be paying more.
Besides, it’s only until she gets herself situated.
You’ll make up for the difference by buying her clothes.”
“Clothes?” Justin stopped walking.
“What, you don’t expect her to keep using you and Sean’s, do you?” Sammy stopped walking and turned to look with suspect at Eydis’s chest and hips.
“You said that she was practically naked.
I probably should ask.
Did she have any underwear?”
Justin stiffened.
“No, she didn’t.”
Sammy took two tense steps toward Justin with a scowl.
He recoiled slightly but did not move.
“Is she wearing any now?” Her eyes were daggers piercing into Justin’s moral center preventing him from lying.
Justin shook his head, and Sammy punched him in the stomach.
Or she would have if Eydis had not reacted so quickly to catch Sammy’s hand before it hit.
Eydis did not understand the exchange.
She only understood that Sammy’s aggression grew quickly.
Sammy’s sudden attack surprised her.
Her training instinct moved her arm, and she had to restrain herself to not repeat her mistake with “Mistake” and retaliate by instinct.
“Don’t you think that getting her something proper to wear would be the first thing you should do?
God!” Sammy ignored that Eydis had stopped her punch and grabbed her extended wrist.
“He’s such an idiot!” she spat.
She pulled Eydis down a few shops to an undergarment vendor.
The undergarments ranged from mildly titillating to blatantly seductive and caused blood to rush to Eydis’s cheeks.
She was more than comfortable without any breast support, and she doubted that they would have any underskirts meant to conceal a tail.
From the look of all the displays and the fake white and black golems that modeled the wares, the lower undergarments were tight fit and hid nothing.
Some of them were even transparent lace or so thin that the owner would be better off naked because somehow the teasing fabric felt even more erotic.
Disregarding Eydis’s apprehensions, Sammy pulled her through the displays to an attendant.
“Can we do a bra fitting for her?”
They followed the attendant to a back room with multiple smaller booths that each had their own separate door.
Eydis and Sammy entered one while the attendant waited outside.
Sammy ordered Eydis to remove her coat, sweater, and shirt.
Eydis followed Sammy’s instructions but took great care to not pull off her woven cap with the shirt to keep her ears hidden.
Sammy grew silent, the sight before her robbing her of breath.
She slowly moved her hand towards one of the many bruises that were now larger and growing green and yellow in color.
A finger hovered above the horrid mark but hesitated to touch, stopping just above the skin.
Sammy’s hand retracted slightly and attempted to touch again.
The longer Sammy stared, the more her face contorted in distress.
Her voice quivered, and angry tears welled in her eyes.
“Who would do such a thing?”
Eydis knew how grave her injuries would appear to others.

Such excessive bruising would incapacitate most, and she could only endure it during the assassination attempt due to her experience with her advancement matches which were often just as brutal, but now the actual damage was healed.
The bruising only looked severe.
She smiled and grabbed Sammy’s extended hand.
“I am no hurt.”
Eydis wiped a falling tear from Sammy’s cheek and urged Sammy to start measuring.
Sammy hesitated.
There was no way Eydis would not be hurting.
How could she not?
Sammy felt her own arm unconsciously as if imagining the pain such damage would cause her.
Her vexed expression hinted that she felt Eydis was only showing a strong front in an attempt to ease her worries.
Eydis gently grasped Sammy’s hand and moved it to one of the larger bruises that covered most of the top of her right breast to near her collarbone.
The bruise was as large as Sammy’s hand and would hurt terribly if touched had she not healed it three nights before.
Sammy tried to retract her hand, but Eydis shook her head.
She applied pressure to Sammy’s hand atop the bruise and smiled.
“No hurt,” she repeated.
Sammy gently palpated some of the other bruises, and a tear fell from her eyes for each one she touched.
“Is everything alright?
Do you need any assistance?”
The voice of the attendant on the other side of the door reminded Sammy why they were there.
Sammy nodded, wiped her face with her sleeve, and measured Eydis’s rib circumference and her breasts.
Confirming with the attendant outside, they settled on a size.
“I’ll go retrieve a 32-B sample bra to confirm the match.”
Upon the attendant’s return, Sammy had Eydis don the bra and confirmed the size.
Sammy spent the remaining time in the store finding bras that Eydis liked.
She focused on sets that not only came with a matching bottom but multiple bottoms and bras, which was cheaper than selecting individual pairs.
They were also nowhere near as provocative as those on display, much to Eydis’s relief.
After picking out enough for daily use, Sammy paid for them.
Eydis returned to the booths to change into a pair.
She had no choice but to wear the human style and let her tail hang over the back because when she tucked it inside, the underwear held it between her legs, and it would rub when she walked.
They returned to Justin who was sitting in a padded chair in the large corridor outside the shop.
Sammy walked directly to him.
Her hands shook, and twice she tried to speak, but her voice fell silent.
She took a deep breath and collected herself.
“Her bruises… Have you seen her…”
“As clearly as you likely did.
They were pretty bad when I found her.
They probably all happened the day before.”
Sammy’s hands tightened into fists.
She stared into Justin’s reassuring eyes, but this only fueled her anger.
“You know more about this than you are telling me, don’t you.”
Justin’s eyes remained firm.
“I told you what I know.
It’ll be up to Eydis if she wants to tell you more.” He stood from his seat and walked over to Eydis.
“Let’s finish shopping.”
Justin walked away, so Eydis quickly followed.
Sammy hurried after them and jumped in front of Justin, forcing him to a halt.
“Just so you know, you are paying for all her clothes because I got her underwear.” Sammy began walking but stopped after a few steps.
“If I find out that you have been lying to me about any of this, I’ll kill you.”
“Noted,” Justin replied with a shrug.
Sammy’s open hostility towards Justin worried Eydis, especially because she was of a higher social status, but Justin did not seem to reflect the same worry.
He shrugged it off with a shake of his head and a smile as if this kind of exchange was normal for them.

From what Eydis could glean from Sammy’s earlier conversation, they had known each other for one of this world’s years, but Eydis could not pin down what the nature of their relationship could have been.
Eydis played around with the possibilities in her mind while she followed Justin and Sammy to a clothing vendor that specialized in tall and slender styles.

Sammy ran with eager fervor from wall to wall, rack to rack, grabbing clothes that she assured would accentuate Eydis’s “natural beauty,” exclaiming that, “when you look great, you feel even better.” Soon Eydis had no time to worry over Justin, at least concerning Sammy’s hostility towards him.
A new worry quickly emerged.
Eydis had to stop Sammy from piling on more and more clothes for the sake of Justin’s purse.
He had already done so much for her, and Eydis felt terrible that he was being made to pay even more for her support, especially with something as superficial as stylish clothing.
She was more than happy wearing Sean and Justin’s extras, given her situation.
Justin urged Eydis to follow Sammy so she could at least have some say in what she wore, but Eydis let Sammy make the selection and agreed to turn down anything that she did not care for.
She outright rejected warm tones as well as blacks and greys.
Eydis enjoyed the subtle blues and greens despite her family’s tendency to wear vibrant colors as a status symbol.
She chuckled silently when inspecting a simple looking, bright purple, one-piece dress that Ceil, her father’s most recent wife, would have loved.
Seeing Eydis’s reaction to the dress, Justin found the size Sammy had told him and added it to the pile of outfits for Eydis to try.
Sammy led Eydis to the entrance of a hallway filled with dressing rooms where they learned that there was a ten-item limit.
Over half the pile was handed to Justin who had to wait outside the hallway.
She received a large tag with the number ten on it from the attendant standing guard and pulled Eydis inside.
Sammy urged Eydis to undress, but Eydis was apprehensive.

She knew that Justin was trying to keep her elven identity hidden from Sammy, and if she undressed to her underwear, even if she could keep her woven cap on to hide her ears, the surrounding mirrors made hiding her tail impossible.
“Please alone,” Eydis requested.
“You didn’t mind when you got measured for your underwear.
And with me here, you won’t have to open the door every time to show me how it looks.”
Sammy’s smile was radiant.
Eydis did not know how to make her understand and could not understand Sammy’s reply well enough to offer a rebuttal, so she repeated her humble request.
“Please alone, Sammy.”
Sammy exhaled and then smiled.
“Okay.
No biggie.” She then left the small room and closed the door behind her.
Eydis locked the door in the same manner she saw Sammy lock it just moments before and undressed completely.
She had a full view of the bruises on her body in the surrounding mirrors.
She had forgotten to erase the scars of the three small punctures from teleporting into the bush, so she took a moment to kill and replace the damaged skin using life magic.
The result was fresh and smooth skin that no longer bore a scar.
It was pinker than the surrounding skin, but as the skin died naturally, the color would blend to match.

Pleased with the results, Eydis picked out a set of blue pants made of thick fabric, a simple white shirt with a mildly pleated pattern in the front that even Eydis felt matched her modest chest well, and a light green blouse that Sammy claimed would look appealing if worn over the shirt.
The shirt and blouse fit perfectly, but the pants were tight against her tail, causing quite a bit of discomfort.
Sammy said she wanted to see the clothes, so Eydis placed on her woven cap, tucked her ears inside, and opened the door.
“That looks great!
Turn around.” Sammy motioned her hand in a circle, so Eydis turned slowly.
“Yup, looks good.
Everything fit okay?”
Eydis’s tail ached from the pressure, so she tried pulling the back of her pants up so that they did not rest on her tail.
Sammy moved around to investigate the issue.
“Something seems bunched up here.
Hold on.”
Before Eydis could stop Sammy, a strong pressure on her tail caused a tight pain in Eydis’s lower abdomen.
“Hii!”
“Wha?!”
Two voices screamed out in unison.
Before Eydis could recover from the pain and shock that nearly made her knees buckle, Sammy pulled her into the changing room.
“What is that?
Do you have a tail?” Sammy’s voice was hushed so that others who may be in nearby stalls could not hear.
Eydis looked at the mirror on the door and saw in the reflection of the mirror behind her that Sammy had pulled her tail out of the pants.
The smooth and hairless tail no thicker than two of her fingers hung down and rested in the crease of her cheeks, only extending a little below them.
Eydis tried to hide it with her hands, but just as she thought, the surrounding mirrors made her efforts futile.
Sammy looked at the tail’s reflection and then into Eydis’s eyes.
With a single quick motion, she pulled off the woven cap.
Eydis did not try to stop her.
What good would that do now?
Released from their captor, Eydis’s pointed ears sprung out sideways.
Looking at Eydis’s ears, then eyes, then ears again, Sammy dropped the hat and sat back onto the bench lining the mirror on her side.
“Are you an… an elf?” Sammy’s tone showed her disbelief in her own words.
Eydis’s ears drooped slightly.
“I am an elf.”
“No, it couldn’t be.
A princess?
Are you a princess?”
“Yes, princess.” Eydis’s ears drooped lower.
“Then what Justin first said about you… Stay here.
Don’t go anywhere.”
Sammy left Eydis to wait in the room on the bench.
Eydis was angry at herself for letting her identity slip out because of her tail.
The pain from her tail being pulled had not fully subsided, but instead of using life magic to alleviate the ache, Eydis let it remain as punishment for her own carelessness.
She wished that she could freely flaunt her tail like men instead of keeping it hidden, but female tails were special.
They contained far more nerves than male tails, and Eydis’s was very sensitive even when compared to other women.
Symra always taught Eydis that her tail was one of her greatest weaknesses in combat, because whenever Symra would strike Eydis’s tail, Eydis would buckle.
Eydis never expected it would also become detrimental to hiding her identity, because normally, it would never be seen.
Female tails became even more sensitive during arousal which made them associated with sex, so elven society dictated that female tails should be kept hidden and only shown to one’s spouse.
Eydis never thought that her tail might be seen by another.
Although, she would often let her tail hang out and play with it when no one was around, something that was viewed as inappropriate and childish.
Living among others in a land where her identity should remain secret, her tail habits might become another danger to her identity.
The risk of her tail was something she had never considered.
At least she could think of this mistake with Sammy as a learning opportunity.
She rubbed the smooth skin of the tip of her tail in her depressed state while thinking about how she would apologize to Justin.
Breathing deep, Eydis locked the door and donned the purple dress.
The comfort it provided far surpassed the pants she had tried before.
Looking in the reflection behind her, the bulge of her tail was not visible.
Eydis suspected dresses were the only human clothing she would be able to wear with comfort.
Skirts would have been nice, but she had not seen them when perusing the clothing.
She sat silently in the dress until Sammy returned.
Eydis expected Sammy to come with more questions or accusations, but Sammy entered silently, grabbed all the pants, and then left again.
After another span of time, she returned and locked herself inside the room with Eydis.
In Sammy’s arms were some more pants as well as the elusive skirts.
“I like that dress.”
Something was different in how Sammy spoke and acted.
Her words were slower and more cleanly pronounced.
Her smile was still radiant, but instead of the heat of the noonday sun, it held the subtle warmth of a sunset.
“But, it really conflicts with your golden hair.
If you like it, that’s fine.
Try this on with the blouse you wore before.”
Sammy handed Eydis pants that looked nearly identical to the uncomfortable pair.

Eydis no longer needed to hide her identity from Sammy, so she no longer had reservations about undressing in front of her, although she did feel a little self-conscious about Sammy staring at her tail.
Eydis’s tail was on the short side.
Most men preferred women with longer tails.
Eydis understood that Sammy had no way of knowing this about elves due to there being no elves in this world, but she felt ashamed of her length just the same.
When she told Sammy, Sammy only chuckled and said her tail was cute and not to worry.
Humans normally did not have tails, so they wouldn’t care about length, but Sammy’s reply did little to comfort Eydis.
Eydis had felt inferior over her length ever since Ceil first started living at the palace.
Ceil’s was always far longer than Eydis’s despite Ceil being a year younger.

Ceil also had two tails of perfectly even length, a sign of extreme fertility and luck among elves and so incredibly rare that there were only nine recorded cases of someone being born with this trait, the most recent being a little over 100 years ago.
It was because of Ceil’s tails that Eydis’s father had taken such a young girl to wife, claiming her before anyone else could.
The more Eydis thought about Ceil, the more she missed the close sister she had found in the girl and the more she hoped that Ceil had been able to escape.
Eydis ceased her reminiscing, pulled up the pants, and tucked her tail inside.
The feeling was unlike the other pair.
They were soft and elastic.
Instead of resting low on her hip and putting pressure on her tail, the elastic band on the top held at her waist.
The soft fabric hugged her tail like a blanket.
Eydis looked at Sammy with amazement.
“Sorry I hurt you.
Your tail seemed sensitive, so I thought some jeggings would work.
I also got some skirts if they didn’t.”
Eydis leaned forward and embraced Sammy.
“Thank you.”
Sammy separated and flashed her sunset smile.
“No need to thank me.
Now put on that blouse and let’s see how it looks together.”
Eydis tried on all the outfits that Sammy put together.
Each of the so-called jeggings that Sammy brought was very comfortable, so Eydis opted for them over the skirts.

The bump from her tail was slightly visible until her tail snuggled into the crease of her cheeks, but someone would only see it if they were looking directly at it, and her blouse covered the bump when standing.
Sammy did not seem to think it would be an issue, so Eydis pushed the worry from her thoughts.
Once finished, six full outfits were chosen with an extra skirt and shirt on the side.
Eydis also selected three pairs of fleece sweatpants for sleepwear, fascinated by the soft fabric.
When Sammy suggested shirts to go with them, Eydis declined.
She only wore her night skirt to bed in her world and would sleep better or at least more comfortably without.
Sammy protested, but the language barrier complicated creating any sound argument that Eydis could fully agree with.
In an unknown world and after all that happened, Eydis had trouble sleeping, so she wanted to be as comfortable as possible to hopefully alleviate the issue.
And the fewer clothes she bought, the less Justin would have to pay.
Given that reasoning, and knowing the truth about what happened to Eydis, Sammy finally conceded defeat.
“Then make sure to put a shirt on whenever you leave your room,” Sammy ordered as she added the shirts to the ‘keep’ pile anyway.
Eydis apologized to Justin in her heart for the extra unnecessary expense.
They placed the undesired clothing on the table at the entrance to the hallway, and Sammy thanked the attendant.
Justin sat on a bench off to the side seemingly deep in thought but stood and joined Eydis and Sammy once they exited.
Anxiety grew in Eydis’s stomach as they approached the register.
She was about to say that she did not need the extra clothing, but then Sammy stood in front of Justin and paid for it all.
“I just wanted that idiot to learn some responsibility and grow up a little,” Sammy admitted with a smile, “but he seems to be doing a lot for you already.
My family has lots of money anyway.”
Relief washed over Eydis.
She took some pride in hearing that her assumption of the class difference between Sammy and Justin was correct, so Sammy paying would not weaken her purse.
And Justin was providing for Eydis, so Eydis found that Sammy’s reasoning was honorable.
The last stop was the shoe store.
Sammy also paid for the two pairs of shoes.
The first was not unlike Justin’s pair that she was wearing called tennis shoes.
The second resembled boots and had short heels, a must for winter according to Sammy.
Gullivan apparently received a lot of snow every year.
“Now that shopping is done, let’s have dinner!” Sammy exclaimed.
Eydis followed Sammy and Justin to a large hall with tables in the center and food stalls lining the edges.
The single meal Eydis ate the day before had been enough to last her into this one.
The food of this world was far denser and more filling than the food of her world, heavy enough to mildly upset her stomach.
This time, Eydis wanted to try something much lighter, so she requested a simple salad.
Sammy followed Eydis but ordered a salad with some type of grilled white meat on it, possibly avian.
Justin chose a salad wrapped in very thin flatbread and added the same meat.
He then paid for all three meals before Sammy could, mildly annoying Sammy.
They found a table and ate as Sammy fiddled with Eydis’s smartphone and instructed Eydis how to use it.
“Justin, have you seen this?” Sammy handed the phone over to Justin.
“It says some child got hit by a truck outside of town last night.
What’s weird is that a witness claims it was not a child but some tiny man.
A midget or something.”
Eydis wondered if she had heard correctly.
“Not a child?
Tiny man?”
From what Eydis had seen and heard from Dr. Shuman and Justin, minums did not exist in this world.

Chapter 8
“The Start of the Hunt”
Jethro
Jethro admired the view of the grand council chamber from in front of the throne of the former Amelian Emperor.

The faint smell of blood lingered in the great hall, but the odor did not distract from the elegant tapestries and masonry that put to shame anything that Jethro had seen since his arrival in the Kingdom of Tolmyur.
Like most of the palace, the walls were carved white marble with wood accents fashioned into natural geometry.
Tall crystalline windows rose in the back to light the hall with rainbow sparks from the sun.
Pillars rose along the sides of the hall’s length to support an upper balcony.
What he found odd about the orientation of the seating was that the emperor’s throne was the lowest seat in the hall.
The tiered council chairs that were finely crafted and unique to the needs and comfort of the individual races that used them sat on the balcony and looked down on the throne.
The slightly elevated platform for those seeking audience with the emperor or council stood at level with the throne itself.
Jethro could not understand how such a self-righteous emperor could bear sitting below those who served him or took audience with him.
Then again, the elves were not the original architects of this palace.
In the ancient ruins of the northern wilderlands, there were several halls with similar seating orientations.
In truth, Jethro knew little about the internal dealings of the Amelian Empire’s government, its emperor, and its people.
What he did know came from the military and government officials of the Tolmyur Kingdom as well as historical documents preserved in Tolmyur’s archives.

On the surface, the elves did not appear as the barbaric and ruthless race that the humans and records made them out to be, but the truth written in the records and what he had experienced personally was undeniable proof of their cold-hearted treachery, especially towards the humans.
The catastrophic state of the Tolmyur Kingdom was a topic close to Jethro’s heart.
He had lost much in his time there due to war and the terrible living conditions of the country.
One loss stacked on top of another leading him to devote himself completely to his military career.
Jethro proved to not only be far more educated than any of the officers but also far more skilled with magic than even the minums.

After only half a year, he rose in ranks to the highest commanding office of the Tolmyur military, but only after he killed the former Commanding General who had tried to assassinate Jethro to stop his rapid rise to power.

When the King awarded Jethro the position of Commanding General, he gave Jethro the task of improving their military might and granted Jethro’s request to let him finalize a generations-old plan to enact retribution upon the Amelian Empire.
Half a year of preparation led to the triumphant victory that gave Jethro the ability to stand in this hall.
The crushing defeat of the allied armies of the sovereign states of the Amelian Empire who tried to retake Amel had crippled many of the races’ military power.
Jethro did not doubt he would win.
The Amelian Empire was far inferior to his knowledge.
There was no challenge.
Instead, the battle was orchestrated as a display of power designed specifically to terrorize the hearts of every sovereign state allied under the empire’s banner.
None would dare retaliate for fear of leaving their home territories defenseless.
Jethro could strike instantly anywhere at any time, and now all nations feared that power.
The victory had only cost the Tolmyur Kingdom a small percent of their total army.
The king was so pleased with Jethro’s success that he granted him nobility and charge over Amel.
“Pleased…”
Jethro could only smile to himself.
When personally giving the report of the victory to the King, masked in the high praise and jovial demeanor Jethro saw the same animosity that the former Commanding General had shown.
Giving Jethro charge over land in the center of enemy territory was an obvious attempt to keep him away.
Yes, even the King of Tolmyur now feared him.
But Jethro did not care.
What the King thought of him was a trivial matter that did nothing more than distract him from the task at hand.
Even if the king wanted to target Jethro, he lacked the means to threaten him.
Jethro was the strongest in the kingdom, and he no longer had any family that the king could target.
Jethro sat on the throne with both arms and legs crossed in a rather lazy fashion unbefitting someone of his status.
Trying to control the rowdy resistances scattered all over the territory provided some entertainment.
Witnessing the demoralizing one-sided defeat within the streets of their own capital had doused the fires of resistance in Amel before it could spread.
All that was left was to bury the embers.
Those who still clung to hope spoke of the survival of the royal family.
They claimed the royal bloodline had not ended.

Were these humans and not elves, Jethro would have understood the concept of cousins or other distant relatives of the emperor being able to inherit the throne, but for elves, only the spouses and children could inherit.
This was a product of elven longevity and inter-breeding.
Living as long as elves do, there was ample time to produce offspring who also lived long lives.
With such enormous families whose children married into many other families, most elves were rather closely related.
This interconnectedness was even stronger in the pure-breed High Elves that held claim to the throne of the empire.
The royal bloodline was considered the purest of all, and most High Elves had some royal blood in them by human familial standards.
Once an emperor was crowned, the brothers and sisters were relegated to nothing more than nobility with no connection to the throne.

For the resistance to say that the royal bloodline had survived, there were only two possibilities: they believed that the missing princess was still alive, or they spoke of the one wife of the emperor who had escaped.
True enough, Jethro had been unable to present to the masses the corpse of the princess or the wife as he had the rest of the royal family.
In such dire times, no evidence meant there was hope.
If Jethro wanted to seal the fate of the empire and stamp out the remaining resistance, he needed to remove both these obstacles, especially if the surviving wife was with child.
The whereabouts of the escaped wife was unknown, but Jethro was sure she was being protected in one of the many nations within the empire.
The first princess hiding in another world was a far more difficult--and personal--matter.
Jethro removed a pocket watch from his coat.
Confirming the time, he opened the black portal that gave access to the mysterious world hiding the first princess.
No sooner had the portal opened than a man wearing a crude traveler’s robe appeared.
In his hand was an identical pocket watch.
“You were wise to send this with me,” the freckled and disheveled scout spoke.
“The days pass far faster there.
Without this, I would not have known when to wait.”
“Were you able to contact Kimmel?”
Jethro had suspected something was amiss when Kimmel did not return through the portal Jethro made at the agreed time.
Of the possible reasons, difference in time was one that Jethro had personally experienced.
Providing the pocket watch he found in the palace, the first of any kind of watch he had seen in all the wilderlands, Tolmyur, and Amel, was a countermeasure for this.
“Regrettably, I could not find him.
There is a possibility he was captured or killed,” the scout replied.
“Are the inhabitants hostile?”
Dangerous inhabitants were a double-edged sword.

While his goal was the death of the princess, something that the inhabitants of the other world could accomplish unknowingly for him, he would need her body as proof, or the resistance would not believe him.
“The inhabitants were the most peculiar part,” the scout continued.
“They were all sotnum.
Not minum, doknum, or seknum.
Just sotnum.”
“Not surprising.
There are also humans here, after all.”
“Sir?”
“Continue.”
“I was able to freely walk among them in their city.
They saw me as a foreigner due to my dress and language, but most were kind and gave me no trouble.”
“What of the princess?”
“No sign of her.
The city is vast and has a large population.
I feel that only one or two scouts would be insufficient to locate her, especially when we do not know the language.”
“If they are human, we may be able to convince one to help.
Does their language seem difficult?”
The scout removed a scrap of flimsy grey paper with black lettering and handed it to Jethro.
Jethro scanned it over but could not make any sense of it, as expected.
While auditory language translated automatically within his mind, written forms were left to his own study to interpret.
“Did you glean any phrases from what you heard?
How does their language sound?”
“Pronunciation did not seem as complex as common Minum nor was it as simple as Elven.”
‘Ifhee complainstoomee won moor time aimgonnasnap.’
‘Oh god heeneedza bath.’
‘No you havta waiduntil weget home.’
“Do you need more, sir?” the scout asked after he saw Jethro’s brow knot further for every line that he repeated from what he heard in that world.
“No, that is enough.” Jethro rubbed his chin.
High-ranked scouts were trained to echo what they heard in order to pass along information even if they did not know the language.
Jethro trusted that his scout was not far off in his pronunciation, but it did not translate in his mind.
It seemed his gift only extended to languages on Whinhlem.
Jethro reached into the space beside him, his hand vanishing through a small vertical crack in the air.
He removed a small piece of parchment, a quill, a thin corked vial, and a small bag of sand.
Uncorking the vial, he dipped the quill in the ink and penned a message.
After spreading sand on the ink to speed the drying so it would not run, the message disappeared with a light pop.
A minute later, he opened a portal, and a second scout walked through.
This scout was short and of a thick build, a dwarf with a refined posture befitting his leadership position as scout captain.
“Mordok, I would like you two to find someone educated.
Male or female, it does not matter.
If we can find someone who can either learn our language or teach us the language of that world, our search will become easier.
Feel free to promise any reward they ask if it is within my power to grant.
I will open the portal for your return in nine days.”
“About the portal,” the first scout cut in, “can we move it to a different location?
The exit is on a paved road.
It is far from the city, but it is regularly traveled.
My sudden disappearance may have been witnessed.”
Jethro searched through the formula in his mind and reactivated the section regarding destination randomization but modified the restrictions so that the destination would remain near the city.
He then opened the black portal and had the scout enter, return and report, and then enter a new portal.
This repeated multiple times, and Jethro was quickly running low on ven.
Finally, the scout returned with an elderly man in his arms, a human, as the scout had said.
This was indeed another world of humans.
The man’s neck was freshly cut and bleeding.
The scout dumped him on the floor, and after flipping the knife around in his hand, he wiped the red stain off on his robe as he spoke.
“It was a residence separate from the main city.
The only occupant was this man.
I think this location is optimal.”
Jethro memorized the newly modified trace.
He then wrote out another three messages and sent them out with light pops.
After waiting a moment, he opened up three more portals.
The demeanor of the three men differed from the two scouts.
These were soldiers trained for covert work and assassination.
Two were human and the third was a young minum.
Each bore stern expressions in anticipation of their orders, having already been informed of and awaiting their possible mission to some unknown, strange world.
“You three will be sent to the other world to continue looking for the princess.
Because the inhabitants are human, sotnum, do what you must to blend in with the population and gather information on all government, management, and city security facilities.
Fect, because there are no minums in that world, stay hidden and observe.
There will likely be places you can go that the others cannot.
Use your high sensitivity to spatial ven to try and detect when the princess might use spatial magic.
You have no time limit, and I will not contact you directly.
Leave a message with those at the portal exit if you must contact me.”
Once the men had their orders, Jethro opened the black portal and sent them through.
Jethro then vanished with the sound of a loud snap.
There was a princess to entertain.
Now that the hunt in the other world had moved to the next stage, he needed to refine the weapon the emperor had left him so that she too might join the hunt.

Chapter 9
“Lesson Preparations”
Eydis
Not long after capture, one of Eydis’s suspicions was answered.
Larger rooms than her quarters in the east wing did exist.

Instead of confining Eydis in some guard post’s dungeon, Jethro reserved the grandest of the guest rooms in the second-floor west wing of the palace for her, twice the size of her former accommodations that her father, the emperor, forbade her from leaving.
The spacious, carpeted room functioned as a bed chamber, study, and a furnished lounge all combined into a single room.
The floral furniture was extravagant and unspoiled from the fighting that had emptied the palace.
Here Jethro met with her daily to discuss the nature of her imprisonment and the treatment of her people within and without the city.
Other than the scheduled meetings, she had freedom to do what she wanted, aside from leave the room.
Again.
Strangely, though, her accommodations in this room provided by Jethro were better than what her father had given her.
She only lacked servants.

She dearly missed the maid who woke her every morning, the chef staff who brough her meals, her elderly instructor who enjoyed battling Eydis in contests of wit, and the guards who would engage her with light banter from the other side of her door whenever she felt the urge.
Despite the grander accommodations, Eydis felt more isolated, lonely.
Even though Jethro visited her daily, she found no joy in his company.
He was her captor, and although he promised not to raze the city and to spare the citizens from slaughter, she knew they suffered greatly from the Tolmyur occupation.
But that was her agreement, to stay slaughter in return for her cooperation.
Jethro never went back on his word.
That was something she learned quickly about him during his daily visits.
Never once in their hours of discussion did he lie.
Despite how busy she assumed he was as Commanding General of Tolmyur, he made the time for her.
He brought her meals when they talked.
He resupplied her provisions as needed with his spatial magic.
He was her only contact.
No one else was permitted to see her.

When she questioned his teleportation magic, he spent an entire day to teach her how to create standard teleportation formulas and shortcut the reading of teleportation traces with the warning that she would be unable to escape the teleportation barrier he placed around her room.
Only he held the key to the encryption.
Other than her imprisonment, Jethro treated her exceptionally well, and she knew why.
He was trying to gain her favor, and the realization sickened her.
He wanted her cooperation, and her people were hostages to that end.
How could she ever think to cooperate with the man who butchered her people?
The more Eydis dwelled on this, the more she began to loath their meetings.
She watched the sun move in the sky from her window and counted down the time until Jethro’s scheduled appearance.
Her feet felt heavy as she walked to the floral-stitched sofa of the lounge as if thick shackles bound her ankles.
She sat and waited, a little longer than usual.
Jethro appeared in a flash of light beside the settee across from her.
“Sorry to keep you waiting, Princess Eydis FeAmel.”
He took a seat on the settee beside him and opened a small portal.
He pulled out two plain ceramic cups and saucers and then retrieved a similarly plain kettle piping hot with tea.
“I apologize that this is all I have to offer at the moment.
I was held up with planning and did not have time to run by the kitchen before coming here.
I am a poor host.” Jethro smirked.
He filled Eydis’s cup and handed it to her.
“Hosting me in my own palace?
What a farce.” Eydis replied.
“But it is my palace now, correct?”
Eydis closed her eyes with mild irritation.
She rested the cup and saucer on her lap and crossed one foot behind the other in a minor expression of humility as a woman who was a formal guest in another’s home.
“Indeed.”
Each visit, Eydis’s posture reverted from a subservient guest to the upright, straight posture of a host presenting herself before a guest of lower status.
Each visit Jethro subtly reminded her she no longer held the same status she once had.
She could do little against him, so the gesture was her sole rebellion.
Eydis took a sip of the murky brown liquid.
Its strong bitter flavor left her coughing.
This was the first time he had given her such a drink, and it was foul.
Jethro poured his own cup and took a long draft.
“Not to your liking?
It took me forever to copy the taste, but it is still a little off.
The beans I want can’t be found, it seems.
At least the palace stores have a bark with a similar flavor.
I am quite proud of the discovery, actually.”
Not wanting to insult her host, Eydis continued drinking the hot, bitter liquid.
The saucers were small, so etiquette demanded she empty the cup once at her own pace, and then her host would pour a second.

Discussions would then continue, and she could decide whether to continue drinking, but a single sip of the second cup was usually taken out of gratitude for the host’s hospitality, even if she had no further desire to partake.
The speed in which she drained her first cup showed her desire to end their meeting quickly.
Her brooding at the window before Jethro’s arrival left her with little patience for him.
When she finished, tears budding in the corners of her eyes from the immense effort required to keep a refined expression after downing such a bitter drink, Jethro retrieved the cup and saucer.
Opening another small portal, he removed a different pitcher and poured its contents into the cup before handing it back.
Eydis was about to take a light sip out of courtesy but wretched at the smell.
She looked at the contents and dropped the cup on the white carpet, staining it dark red.
“So it seems that you are far enough along that only the princess’s blood would be appetizing.
Perfect.” A crooked grin grew across Jethro’s face.
Eydis stood and backed away from the red stain.
“You insult me!
What is the meaning of this?” Considering the comfortable treatment Jethro had given her, she never expected that he would so suddenly try and trick her into drinking blood.
Where did the blood come from?
A shiver ran down her spine.
Who did the blood come from?
“Just a test.
I hope you will not take offence.” Jethro picked up the cup and saucer, and using a barrier that only rejected blood, he pulled the stain from the carpet and placed it back in the cup.
The carpet returned to its pristine white with no signs of any blood having been spilt.
At Jethro’s coaxing, Eydis sat back down.
“That was a foul trick.
I hope you are satisfied.” Eydis crossed her arms and glared in irritation.
“Is this what passes as entertainment in that barbaric kingdom of yours?”
“While your reaction was better than I expected, the real entertainment is yet to come, but some preparations must be made first.”
Eydis grew wary of what Jethro was insinuating.
“What do you mean?”
Jethro sat the cups, saucers, and pitchers on the small table beside his settee.
“Do you believe you are the First Princess?” he asked, leaning forward with his hands clasped and elbows resting atop his knees.
Eydis’s eyes narrowed in an accusatory glare.
“You were only allowed to stay in the lower levels in the southeast wing of the palace and could never visit the halls, council, or any of the upper floors.
Is that true?”
“The princess is not to reveal herself until she is wed or is crowned the new empress.
Even your barbaric country should know this,” Eydis replied, knowing well that it was a lie.
Her father ordered her confined to her room, but she did not know the true reason.

“I still lived in luxury, had servants wait on me, and received proper education befitting nobility as one who would live by presenting herself in front of others, that is, until you besieged the palace.”
“Education in keeping a royal appearance.” Jethro’s crooked grin grew wider.
“Among others,” Eydis retorted quickly.
“I would have you know there is one vital piece of information that was neglected in your education.”
Truth, Eydis’s senses told her.

“Obviously there is much in the world that I have yet to learn and much more that I have no need to learn,” Eydis replied quickly, mirroring what her past instructor often stated to silence some of her piercing questions.
“What I am referring to affects you directly and is something your caretakers did not wish for you to know.
And it is most likely the reason you were confined to your room.”
Truth.
Jethro retrieved a small burlap bag from a portal.
“Open it.”
Eydis loosed the string and removed a small jar.
Inside sat a blood-colored, leach-like creature about the size of her hand.
It pulsated slightly but appeared almost dead.
“What is this?”
Eydis brought the jar to her face to examine it closer.
The leach took notice and attacked the side of the jar facing Eydis.
Eydis startled and dropped the jar on the floor, but it was sturdy enough to remain intact.
She picked up the rattled creature and inspected it again.
Its circular mouth filled with rows of tiny spined teeth scraped at the side of the glass near her face.
The creature soon lost energy and rolled back onto the bottom of the jar.
“I would like you to take care of that.
Think of it as a pet.”
Jethro walked over to the wall on the far side from Eydis’s bed and created a portal on the floor.
When he pulled it upwards, a metal crate large enough to fit a person appeared.
It lacked any windows with the only visible openings being a small latch door on the top and an even smaller metal funnel in one corner.
“Place it in here.”
Eydis continued observing the odd creature while she walked over.
Jethro opened the latch.
She unstopped the jar and shook out the leach into the large crate.
The latch was then closed and the metal around the latch heated, welding the latch to the crate.
This surprised Eydis.
Objects could be infused with magic, but she had never seen an infusion with an activation trigger.
She did not know such magic was possible.
Jethro retrieved the cup of blood and poured it into the funnel.
“I will place a similar cup on your bedside table each morning.
All you need to do is pour it in as I have and return the cup to the table.
I have affixed a detection barrier on the surface, so I will know when you place something on it.”
Eydis looked at the bloody cup in Jethro’s hand with disgust.
“How long must I care for this thing?”
“Twenty, maybe thirty days.
Leave a message with the cup if you have any concerns.
Remember, there is something very important that you need to know, and taking care of this creature is the best way to teach you.”
Another truth.
Jethro held the cup out to Eydis.
After a moment of hesitation, she grabbed it.
“I will be upfront that I do not trust you.
However, if this secret affects me, as future empress I will go through with it.”
“You are wise to do so, but you should abandon becoming empress.”
Jethro’s jovial tone only served to increase the suspicion in Eydis’s glare.
“One more thing before I leave.
In a few days, it will likely start making noises or rattle in its cage.
Pay it no mind.
Just feed it as instructed.”
Jethro vanished in a loud snap, a different, more advanced form of teleportation than what he taught her, one that lacked the need for a physical portal.
Eydis was left staring at the crate with a bloody cup in her hands.

Chapter 10
“Crossing Paths”
Austin
There was something bewitching about her beauty, something otherworldly that Austin found difficult to place into words.
She was taller than most, even taller than Rebecca and possibly a little taller than him.
She was also thinner than most, but not anorexic like Suzie.
The first day he saw her, she wore baggy clothing like Kaitlyn.
Men’s clothing.
But now she wore fitted clothes that proclaimed her femininity to all, femininity that Austin wanted to be revealed to him alone.
Her hair was too golden to be called blond, and if it had a brilliant sheen, he would not doubt that it was truly made of gold.
More golden than Amy, or even Chrystal whom Austin was convinced dyed her hair to retain such a tone.
But most bewitching of all was her eyes.
They were a deep sea-green and shone with authority that knew from the very core of her being that she was superior to all.
She glared at him with those eyes on that day.
She made him feel beneath her, and that only made him want her more.
Amy and Vanessa flaunted that same aura of superiority, but like all the others they sung his tune before long.
Amy in particular turned into a submissive moaning kitten after only a little foreplay.
Austin wanted to tame that superiority, to prove to both her and himself that he was the superior one.
Sammy slipped through his fingers as if she had a sixth sense against his coercion.
There were a few like Sammy in the past--he never cared to remember their names--but he would not let that happen again.
Not with her.
Eydis FeAmel.
He would claim her for himself.
The bus jolted.
A hip slammed into Austin’s shoulder as he sat on the padded seat by the bus’s folding door, jostling his mind away from admiration of his mental image of Eydis.
The morning buses were always crowded, and normally he would not mind, but Austin’s frustration leaked into a faint scowl.
The bus was far more crowded than he expected.
A crowded bus was beneficial, because it meant that people who were packed next to each other could not easily separate.
He could strike a conversation with Eydis, and her only choices were to reply or ignore, but Eydis was too kind to ignore him.

She was learning English and was more than happy to talk with anyone, even him after he apologized for what happened the day they met, prompting a quick and heartfelt apology from her for pushing him.
If the bus was too crowded, people could stand between, complicating any conversation he would initiate.
At least by catching Eydis on her morning commute to campus, Sammy would not be there to interfere again.
“Next stop, Main Street Bridge,” the electronic voice announced, muffled by the mass of bodies and the sound of grinding asphalt.
Austin learned yesterday that Eydis lived in a small apartment half a mile or so south of the bridge on the east side of the river.
She lived with another man, but their relationship did not appear to be romantic.
They acted as no more than acquaintances, lacking even the most basic signs of platonic affection.
Even if that was her boyfriend, Austin wasn’t worried.
Vanessa also had a boyfriend, as did Karen.

Austin was confident that if he asked any girl to pick between him and that man of short stature with some excess weight, she would pick him, but he was not so foolish to believe that appearance was all that mattered in attraction or that all women viewed physical attraction the same.
The bus merged to the right lane and slowed, shifting the mass of bodies forward like reeds in light wind.
Austin peered out the window beside him and saw few people at the stop, relieving some of his worry.
Eydis stood out towering over the other four who awaited the bus.
She and her friend or roommate or lover stood in the back of the group.
They would board last, placing them by the door next to him.
The bus was crowded.
There was nowhere else to stand.
Only three passengers exited the bus, creating a net gain in the already crowded space.
Eydis boarded last so that she could stare out the window as the bus moved.
She tended to be fascinated by such simple things, which was rather charming.
A small smile grew across her lips when the bus pulled away from the curb back into morning traffic.
“You must really like busses,” Austin said, tapping Eydis lightly on the leg by her knee.
Eydis started in surprise and looked down beside her.
“Austin?” She had initially thought his name was “Mistake,” something that was likely Sammy’s doing to mock him.
Eydis’s embarrassment when he told her his real name was adorable, so in truth he was a bit thankful to Sammy.
“Good morning.”
“Good morning,” Eydis replied with a smile less authentic than when she gazed out the window.
Her friend seemed far less pleased to see him but did not speak up.
Instead, he shifted Eydis around in the crowded space, swapping places with her with his back facing Austin.
“I was just saying hello,” Austin replied to the wordless rejection, but he found it almost comical.
The man blocked nothing.
Eydis was tall enough and the man short enough that Austin could see Eydis’s face over his shoulder.
Austin could continue the conversation if he wanted, but that would make him appear too desperate.
Eydis’s expression was mildly apologetic, so clearly, she understood that her friend was in the wrong for overreacting to a simple greeting.
Austin smiled back and shook his head, expressing his own disappointment at the overreaction.
He would let it go, showing his goodwill.
Sammy was acquainted with Eydis because of the incident on the day they met, and Austin admitted that it was not the best first impression of him.
Sammy would have cautioned Eydis against him and likely cautioned Eydis’s roommate.
He would not be able to conquer Eydis quickly.
He needed to plan for the “long game,” to show her that whatever warnings Sammy may have spewed were baseless.
As Eydis’s opinion of him improved, he would plant seeds of frustration about her friends’ continued distrust in him.
The moment Eydis agreed to meet without either of her friends present, he would win.
Austin relaxed into his seat for the remainder of the ride to campus.

He did not have class today, so mild frustration lingered from his inability to converse with Eydis, the sole reason he left early to travel to the other side of the city and catch a bus he never rode.
He exited the bus at the same stop as Eydis and was about to wave goodbye to her when Justin pulled him aside.
Eydis stood a short distance off, well within earshot.
“I know what you are doing,” he said in a stern tone.
“Stop.”
“Aren’t you overreacting a bit?
All I said was good morning.”
“Sammy told me you ran into her again yesterday.
I have never seen you take the E-14 bus to campus at this time before, so it couldn’t have been a coincidence.
I wouldn’t have a problem if you didn’t already try to rape Sammy.”
“Is that what she told you?” Austin sighed.
“I tried to give her a kiss goodbye after our date.
That’s all.”
“She said it was far more than a kiss.”
“I’ve seen how Sammy treats you.
Can you really trust what she says?
Honestly, I probably dodged a bullet with her.”
The man’s brow knotted.
“Sammy was my girlfriend for about a year.
I know her far better than you think.
She would never lie about something like that.”
“So you were the one she was complaining about during dinner,” Austin jeered.
“Justin, your work,” Eydis said from her position a couple yards away.
“I can keep you company while Justin’s at work,” Austin suggested with a smile.
“Eydis has her English class, and Sammy will be with her until I’m off work.
Give it up.”
“Aren’t you suffocating her a bit too much?
Don’t tell me you are the obsessive controlling type.” Austin grimaced ruefully at Eydis.
“You deserve better than that.”
