“We have our reasons,” Justin replied without even attempting to refute the accusation.
“Sorry, Austin.
Justin is true… correct?
Justin is correct,” Eydis said as they walked away from the bus stop.
Austin groaned once Eydis and Justin were out of earshot.
He admitted that he knew nothing about Eydis’s situation, and he was trying to learn more, but what frustrated him most was that Justin appeared to be in complete control over her.
And he was with Sammy for a whole year?
What was it about Justin that drew in that pissy rich girl and now drew in Eydis?
Both girls far outclassed him.
If Austin wanted to conquer Eydis, he would need to break Justin’s control.
He knew how difficult that would be because he had used similar tactics on Suzie and Emma in the past.
Is the effort even worth the reward, Austin thought to himself as he paced aimlessly down the sidewalk bordering the campus.
There were certainly benefits.
A girl broken by a controlling relationship can easily fall into someone’s control again.
They are groomed into that relational hierarchy and obey it out of habit or instinct or fear.
If he could pull Eydis away from Justin, she certainly could be his if he exploited that dynamic.
“But how long?” he mumbled.
The “long game” usually only lasted a few weeks, but in Eydis’s case it could be months or possibly a year before he could pull her away unless he got lucky.
Eydis was certainly the most beautiful woman he had ever seen, but that was a long time to devote to nothing more than his current infatuation.
He would grow tired of her eventually like he had all the others.
His experience with Vanessa came to mind.
“I could just make her…” he began mumbling to himself.
So long as he made Eydis feel good by the end, she wouldn’t mind how rough he was at the start.
He could even use Justin’s controlling personality against her to keep her silent about it, but he had never once seen her alone.
Either Sammy or Justin always accompanied Eydis.
And that would only work if Eydis was actually in an abusive relationship with Justin.
Eydis showed signs of mental and emotional trauma.
The signs were well hidden, but Austin was perceptive to these things.
When smiling or apologizing, the ever-present aura of authority in her eyes collapsed, shaded by some unspoken darkness.
That was leverage he could use, increasing the plausibility of the plan, but one major hurdle remained.
Even if he could keep her silent, there was still the question of if he could restrain her long enough for her to submit to his skill.
Vanessa was weak, so she was easy.
Despite Eydis’s frail appearance, she was incredibly strong.
That push she gave him the day they met was almost unnatural, and the stance she held when she pushed him was practiced.
That decided it.
“I give up,” Austin chuckled to himself.
One girl was simply not worth that much trouble.
He could admire her from a distance, and if the dynamic changed at any point, he could swoop in and take advantage of the opening, but until then there was no need to make her a priority.
There are plenty of other girls out there, he thought to himself as he eyed the university girls walking towards campus on the other side of the road.
None of them were as beautiful as Eydis, but his reward would come much quicker with them.
He noticed a pair of girls being accosted by a short, bearded man in a cloak.
They were younger, possibly freshmen.
Freshmen were always eager to see the nightlife of a city new to them, and if he played them right, perhaps he could gain twice the reward or even both girls at once.
He had never succeeded at a threesome, each attempt a horrible disaster, but it was always worth another shot.
Austin waved down an approaching car to stop and crossed the road.
The bearded man eagerly tried to converse with the two girls but was gaining no ground.
Not only was his apparel strange, but as Austin neared, he could hear the man struggling to string words together into English.
The man was most likely a refugee.
Gullivan had advertised itself as a refugee sanctuary, so the number of these types had increased in the past year.
Austin considered the possibility that Eydis was one of them, but for all he knew she could have just been an international student.
Actually, that was far more likely.
Austin shook his head.
He caught his mind lingering on Eydis instead of his new targets.
“Do you need help with something?” Austin asked as he approached from behind the girls.
“Thank God,” the brunette on the left exclaimed, exasperated.
“Can you help him?
I think he might be lost or something.
We need to get to class, or we’ll be late.”
She grabbed her friend’s hand and jogged down the sidewalk before Austin could continue any conversation.
This was not the encounter he was hoping for, but she had stared at him long enough that she should be able to recognize him if he met her later, so his minor effort was not completely wasted.
He could arrive a little earlier another day and see if he could spot her on her way to campus again.
With less urgency, he could open a conversation about what happened today and go from there.
“You,” the bearded man said with an odd intonation.
“Sorry, but I don’t have the time either.” Austin turned his back to the man, but a hand gripped his wrist with thick fingers much larger than someone of his stature should have.
“You,” the man repeated, removing what looked like a third of an English dictionary split down the binding.
Austin caught a glimpse of the clothing under the cloak.
It was crude and worn leather sewn in a shabby attempt to look like regular clothing.
He tried to pull his arm away, but the man’s grip was iron.
Austin couldn’t even move his hand an inch.
“Whatever your problem is, I’m not interested.”
The man tried to hand the torn dictionary to Austin.
He did not know English, so there was no way for him to communicate.
“No.
I go,” Austin asserted as simply as he could, but the man’s grip would not release.
He wanted Austin to take the dictionary.
With no other option available to him besides shouting and causing a scene, Austin retrieved the dictionary with his free hand.
“You.” The man pointed at the dictionary and then himself.
Give it back?
What’s this guy’s deal?
Austin tried to hand the dictionary back, but the man would not accept it.
“You,” he repeated and brought his fingers to his mouth.
He then lowered them forward as if he was blowing a kiss.
You,” he pointed to the dictionary, repeated the hand motion, and again finished again by saying, “I.”
“You want me to teach you English?” The man could not understand, so Austin tucked the torn book under his armpit.

He pointed at the man, “you,” then himself, “want me,” and then extended his four fingers, thumb curled and hand vertical, touching his forefinger to his chin before tilting his hand forward in the sign language for speak, “to teach you English?” Austin knew very little sign language and doubted this man knew any either, but he was at a loss for what else he could do.
The man smiled within his thick beard.
Conversation had been made, surprising Austin.
He reached into his cloak once again and removed a thick ring just as golden as Eydis’s hair.
He offered the ring to Austin who accepted it quickly.
The intricate engravings suggested exquisite craftsmanship and high value.

Austin did not have the means to test the purity of the gold, but compared to the quality of the jewelry he had seen before, he did not doubt this ring was worth thousands of dollars due to the intricate craftsmanship alone.
“You.” The man repeated the sign language motions for speak, pointed to the dictionary, and then pointed to himself.
“I.” He pointed to himself again, “I,” pointed to the ring in Austin’s hand, and then pointed to Austin.
“You.”
Austin relaxed his arm in the man’s grip.
The ring was payment for teaching the man English, an offer certainly worth investigating.
The ring was quite the payment.
Thinking of no other way to confirm the offer, Austin slipped the ring over his thumb, the only digit thick enough to fit.
The man smiled and released his grip, beckoning Austin to follow.
He led Austin across the city, and over time, three more men joined.
They did not wear cloaks like the short, bearded man.
They dressed in regular clothing of odd fit as if retrieved for free from a donation bin.
The similar brown hair and lightly tanned skin suggested they were associated with the bearded man.
What worried Austin was the daggers sheathed at their hips; not knives but daggers one would see in a medieval drama or fantasy movie.
They crossed the river and headed north.
Austin’s nerves reached a breaking point when they left the city proper.
His palms sweated heavily in the chilled air.
Something was very wrong with this situation.
He stopped.
“Where are we going?”
One of the daggers pointed at his back.
The man stood close enough that anyone driving down the nearly deserted road through private fields would not notice.
Austin no longer had the option to refuse.
He already accepted the payment for teaching English, if learning English was even their goal.
His thoughts drew on the ongoing attacks in Europe commonly blamed on terrorists slipping in with the influx of refugees.
If these men were terrorists, they would have no problems killing him.
Austin had no choice but to obey.
Austin was led to a house where he was confined for two days.
He understood quickly that they did not own the house.
What could have happened to the previous owner constantly lingered in his mind, but unexpectedly the men treated Austin well.
They fed him the best food available to them despite their own apparent fasting.
They ate little and only about once a day, but Austin received 3 full meals a day with portions almost larger than he could eat.
Following his agreement, and partially out of fear, Austin taught English to the five men who lived there.
He began with the alphabet and pronunciation and then moved to basic grammar, the “to be” verbs, and conjugations.
The men were overly studious as if there was a major driving force behind their desire to learn the language.
The bearded man, Mordok, grew more and more pleased with the lessons, rewarding Austin a second ring of equivalent quality.
“This gig isn’t bad,” Austin whispered to himself atop the sole bed in the house.
He often wondered where the others slept considering he never actually saw them asleep at any time.
By Austin’s estimates, he had made five to ten thousand depending on the value of the rings in just three days of easy English lessons.
This was almost theft.
Perhaps these men did not understand the value of jewelry.
If that was true, he could continue leeching off them for a while.

His only complaint was the lack of women, but if they were so eager to reward him for his haphazard lessons, perhaps they could reward him with women too, although how they would get those women was certainly a worry.
Austin did not want to be involved in instigating any kidnappings.
“Austin, kitchen.” Mordok rapped on the door to Austin’s room.
The English lessons were finished for the day so perhaps Austin would be rewarded with a third ring.
He could only hope.
Austin walked down the hall and froze at the entrance to the kitchen.
A black void stood near the table as if a tear had opened in space.
The tip of a sword dug painfully into Austin’s back, nearly cutting his shirt.
“In,” Mordok ordered from beside the void.
“In?
In there?
You want me to enter that?”
The sword dug deeper, and Austin felt the tip prick through his skin.
He doubted he could run at this point.
He had already been paid twice.
What would happen to him if he entered that void?
The painful pressure of the sword pushed Austin forward until a kick to his back sent him stumbling into the void.
It wrapped around him, suffocating him in a nauseating, claustrophobic spiral.
He would have vomited if not for the surprise that awaited him on the other side.
He collapsed onto a marble floor and struggled at first to push himself up.
His arms shook under his own weight that felt far heavier than it should.
He feared that the strange black void weakened him but then saw the feet of Mordok and the other men easily standing upright beside him.
One of them laughed silently, and he knew it was at his expense.
Austin heard a snap, and an unfamiliar voice gave a single order in an unknown language, “Deshalu.” A small sachet was brought by Mordok and crushed beneath Austin’s nose.
The strong, herbal fumes punched him in the face.
He reeled back and stood by reflex with relative ease.
His heart raced and his body shivered uncontrollably, increasing the anxiety he already felt, but at least his feet stood strong against the immense weight of his body.
It was only now that he noticed he stood on the floor of a grand marble hall that put to shame any pictures Austin had seen of European castles or cathedrals.
The large windows were not glass but crystal and refracted rainbow light over the hall.
A lone man occupied the throne in the back center of the hall before the windows.
His apparel was simple, looking more like a robed monk than a king.
One by one, the men who occupied the house on the outskirts finished exiting the rift and saluted the robed man, their fists to the center of their chest.
The rift behind Austin vanished with a wave of the monk-king’s hand.
Only one word could describe what Austin saw: magic.
“Where am I?”
“Jethro house,” Mordok replied.
“Jethro?”
Mordok extended his hand humbly toward the throne.
The monk-king, Jethro, smiled in some simple understanding or expectation after hearing the exchange in English.
Mordok saluted before speaking in length to Jethro in a language Austin could not recognize.
However, he did pick up the mention of English no less than six times.
Was their true aim to learn English?
Who were these people?
Once the exchange between Mordok and Jethro ended, Mordok grabbed Austin by his arm and pulled him toward the throne, forcing him to kneel before Jethro.
The racing heart in Austin’s chest thundered heavier.
He would have fled in his panic if not for Mordok’s iron grip.
“You English Jethro,” Mordok ordered, somehow turning English into a verb.
He removed a third ring.
“We this you,” he finished.
Jethro gave a calm order to Mordok who quickly stepped aside.
He stood from his throne and reached into a hole in the air, his hand vanishing at the wrist.
When it reappeared, he held a large leather bag which he set on the arm of the throne.
It jingled of metal.
Jethro loosened the tie and removed a gold coin that he flicked to Austin with his thumb.
The coin was polished and beautiful, not lacking in craftsmanship compared to the two rings Mordok had given him.
Next Jethro tore a large rift in the air beside him, but unlike the black void of earlier, Austin could see inside it like a window to another room.
A surprised woman stood on the other side.
Jethro reached in and pulled her through.
Austin’s breath escaped him, and for a moment he could not feel the rapid beat of his panicked heart.
She was tall like Eydis but perhaps not quite as tall.
Her hair was not as golden as Eydis but was closer to ripe grain ready for harvest.
Her eyes were bluer than Eydis’s and her face rounder.
Her breasts were modest and slightly smaller than Eydis’s, but her slender frame allowed them to build the feminine curve of her body.
Her quivering hips were perfectly smooth leading down to her long slender legs and dainty feet.
She was naked except for a transparent blue shawl draped over her shoulders.
Where Eydis emitted an aura of authority like a queen, this woman who could be her older sister emitted the aura of a humble countryside mother, far more endearing.
It was then that Austin noticed her thin, pointed ears and a slender tail extending down behind her between her legs to her knees.
She was not human.
Jethro extended one hand toward the bag of gold, retracted it, and then extended his other to the naked woman.
He was presenting Austin a choice of reward.
Jethro stepped away from the throne after a stern word to the woman that made her shrink.
Mordok lifted Austin to his feet and stood him before the selection.
Austin’s mind grew blank.
He could not estimate the value of the gold in the bag.
If he chose the woman, she would be his, or so he assumed.
No effort would be needed to control her.
The herbal fumes buzzed in his brain, and his intoxication-heightened fear would not let him weigh the decision as he usually would.
One hand acted without knowledge of the other.
Before Austin realized what he had done, his left hand gripped the sack of gold and his right hand held firm the woman’s wrist.
Angry shouts and the unsheathing of swords returned Austin’s senses.
He shrunk in fear, yanking the woman into him and nearly collapsing with her to the ground, but then Jethro’s laughter quickly calmed both Austin’s rapidly growing fear and the anger of the men.
A few quick words silenced the hall.
Jethro tore another rift in the air and beckoned Austin to follow with both gold and woman in hand.
Unlike the black void, Austin was less fearful of the destination he could see clearly on the other side.
Although, he knew he had no other choice but to follow.
He entered with Mordok close behind.
The rift exited to what looked like a lounge with exquisite furnishings no lesser than the grandeur of the throne room.
Jethro grabbed the woman from Austin and pushed her down a narrow hallway.
Austin could see an enormous bed in the room at the end.
“Is… Is this where I’m going to live?” Austin asked, nearly choking on his words, and knowing well that no one would be able to answer.
If his assumption was true, this was certainly a far better deal than he could have imagined.
Jethro led Austin and Mordok to another adjacent room lined with bookshelves and with a desk in the back.
He sat Austin in the leather chair and removed a stack of what appeared to be parchment with an inkwell and quill.
Austin was too mentally exhausted to keep up with everything he had witnessed.
Who were these people?
Where was he taken?
Was that really magic?
Would he ever be able to return?
Did he even want to return?
All Austin knew was that if he taught Jethro and whoever else English, perhaps this place and that woman would be his.
Perhaps he could earn more riches and even more women.
Austin’s hand shook from both his anxiety and that strange herb.
His voice cracked and stuttered as he taught the alphabet and pronunciation.
Jethro’s amiable demeaner, his patience and kindness and apparent understanding of Austin’s fears, slowly calmed Austin’s nerves.
By the end of the first lesson, Austin began to feel that his life was not in any danger, so long as he did what they asked.
If these people, if Jethro the monk king, wanted to learn English so bad that they were willing to reward him with such regality, nothing in Gullivan could compare.
None of the girls he was pursuing could balance that scale.
After Austin’s first night with the payment Jethro had given him, even Eydis vanished from his mind.

Chapter 11
“Finding a Home.”
Eydis
Eydis found herself standing in the central courtyard of the palace.
It was a familiar memory, one of her earliest training sessions under Symra.
Her father, Emperor Yuro, stood afar off with a judgmental glare.
This was not long after Eydis had begun training, and he wanted to see her progress.
Her opponent, arranged by Symra for the demonstration, was a fresh recruit of the palace guard.
Although he was a recruit, all palace guard recruits were hand-selected High Elves who showed exceptional abilities among the empires seasoned soldiers.
This man who stood before her was no trainee.
“Begin!” Symra called.
Eydis did not have time to blink before the man was in front of her with his fist embedded in her stomach.
The impact knocked her back tumbling over the paved court in the center of the courtyard.
“Get up!” Symra ordered.
Eydis rolled to her arms and knees, but she couldn’t stand.
She couldn’t breathe.
“Get up!” Symra ordered again.
Eydis looked over to the disappointed face of her father.
She was not expected to win.
She was only expected to do something.
Anything.
Her opponent grabbed Eydis by the arm and lifted her only high enough to hammer a second strong blow into her stomach.
Eydis doubled over onto her back, and a weak cry escaped her lips.
She kept wondering why she had to do this, why she had to endure all this pain.
She was only a child not even two years old, and yet her father forced her to fight a seasoned soldier she could not hope in her wildest fantasies to defeat.
And above everything, she hated hurting anyone.
She despised pain, so why would she ever want to inflict it on others?
“Stand up!” Another order.
Eydis looked again over to her father who did not meet her eyes.
He turned and walked away in utter disappointment at the poor spectacle.
“Stand and fight or you will die,” Symra warned.
Out of the corner of Eydis’s eye, she saw her opponent’s foot raised, ready to crush her head with his heel.
A guard of the palace would never kill the first princess, but the terrified mind of a child did not know any better.
In panic, Eydis threw a thin spike of wind at him.
Her opponent’s heel stopped as intended right before it made contact with her cheekbone, but by that time the damage had already been done.
The man faltered back and fell.
Eydis rose to her elbow to see that her thin spike had penetrated under the man’s chin into his head, and the small burst of wind created when it dissipated had killed him instantly.
In this demonstration match orchestrated to show her father that she could indeed fight back, she killed for the first time.
In Eydis’s memory, she became inconsolable and cried for days afterwards.
Symra tried to comfort her by explaining that the greatest honor for a guard was to use his life for the betterment of the royal family.
“Again!” Symra ordered.
Something was not right.
Eydis looked back at Symra who ordered another opponent to stand before her.
No…
Eydis lost control of her actions.
She stood against her will, and the next match began.
Her new opponent was only a little taller than her.
He was not shorter.
Eydis realized that she was now older, an adult.
The match was one-sided again, but this time in her favor.
Her opponent could not land a hit.
Not a minute later, his dead body hit the ground.
“Again!” Symra ordered.
Another dead body.
“Again!”
Dead bodies grew around Eydis, and no matter how hard she tried, she could not stop herself from killing each and every one of them.
Next, her two younger brothers stood before her, their thin rapiers drawn against her, but their form was poor.
They never had to go through the same grueling training she had, only enough for sport and self-defense.
“No!” Eydis cried, but she could not stop herself from releasing a wide blade of wind with the swipe of her hand before they could defend or retaliate.
The severed bodies of her brothers fell to the ground, more real than all of the fighting she had done previous.
Their bodies lying in their own gore was burned into her memories.
“Again,” spoke another, male voice.
She recognized it immediately.
She turned her head to see the assassin standing in Symra’s place with a pleased grin on his face.
This time her father stood before her and died.
Next her mother, then Ceil who cried and begged Eydis to stop.
By the end, Eydis stood on the bodies of her family and people.
“You brought this upon yourself,” the assassin said.
“How does it feel to have everyone you love taken away from you?”
Eydis turned to face him, unable to move.
He swiped his arm to behead her with his strange barrier magic, and she woke up.
Eydis’s heart raced, and she fought back the cry that almost escaped, muffling it into a soft squeal.
She didn’t want to wake Sean who was in the next room over.
Tears streamed from her eyes.
The air was harder to breathe than normal.
She quickly realized she was hyperventilating but could not calm enough to stop.
The assassin’s words, “You brought this upon yourself,” kept repeating in her mind.
She wanted to curl up into a ball and disappear.
Never had her trauma overcome her so powerfully.
Eydis scrambled out of bed to her phone sitting atop Justin’s desk on its charger.
She called the only person she felt she could talk to, Sammy.
Sammy quickly agreed to come, and Eydis waited by the front door for her arrival.
Justin slept peacefully on the couch, completely oblivious to the emotional strain she was under, but she could not wake him.
No matter how terrible she felt, she could not burden him further than she already was.
Although, watching him sleep so peacefully did help calm her while she waited.
Justin and Sean’s home was safe.
The assassin was not here.
There was no one here she had to fight.
The doorknob turned, and Sammy slipped inside.
“Are you okay,” she asked, seeing Eydis standing in the dark.
Eydis’s cheeks glimmered with lines of tears that had not yet dried.
Eydis worried that Sammy’s voice would wake Justin, but almost as if Sammy read her thoughts she replied, “He is a deep sleeper, so we’re fine.
Let’s go to your room.”
They sat together on the bed.
Sammy did not speak up or ask for an explanation.
She only wrapped her arm around Eydis and leaned her head against her shoulder.
“I had… I saw…” Eydis began, but her mind would not find the words she needed.
She understood the essentials of English grammar, but her vocabulary was still quite small.
“My family, I saw my family dead,” Eydis finally said.
“You had a bad dream, a nightmare?” Sammy replied.
“Yes…” Tears started falling anew.
“Come here.” Sammy pulled Eydis down to her chest and coddled her.
“You’re okay.
No one is going to hurt you.”
“I think you have post-traumatic stress disorder,” Sammy said after Eydis calmed down.
“People usually shorten it to PTSD.
It’s when something bad happened to you, and then you remember it without wanting to, and it makes you scared and sick and cry and feel all those bad feelings all over again.”
“I think this is that, yes,” Eydis replied after some thought.
“Having your family killed is sure to do that.
I’m so sorry that it happened and that you went through all that.” Sammy gave Eydis another hug.
Time passed again in silence.
Eydis understood that Sammy was giving her time to sort out her thoughts and feelings.
Sammy could do nothing to help her, so she was only there for support.
Symra held that role in the past.

As strict as Symra was during training, she cared deeply about Eydis, enough to risk the emperor’s wrath and her position as head trainer of the palace guard by demanding that Eydis’s training end before serious harm was done.
Yuro had high expectations of Eydis, so high that Eydis felt they were impossible to fulfill.
She lived constantly in the shadow of his disappointment.
Everyone expected greatness and perfection from her.
The only one who didn’t was Ceil, but Eydis could not rely on Ceil for support.
The girl was younger and had her own trauma from being sold by her parents to Yuro at such a young age.
Eydis was the only one who was willing to be Ceil’s support.
As Eydis got older, expectations grew.
Yuro further accelerated her education.
He doubled and then tripled her training hours under Symra before her training eventually stopped.
He gradually became so paranoid and afraid of something he would never tell her.
She bore the full brunt of that paranoia, even to the point that he forced her to provide blood every day leaving her weak and anemic on top of her training.
Eydis came to a realization.
That feeling or condition Sammy explained, she had felt that most of her life.
She explained to Sammy the best she could about her life in the palace and asked if PTSD could come from that.
“Oh, god…” Sammy said, appalled by what she heard.
“Of course that would cause PTSD.
God!
After everything that has happened to you, you deserve so much better.
You deserve a much better life than that.”
Sammy clasped Eydis’s shoulders.
“What happened to you was terrible.
You did not have any choice coming here, but now that you are here you should make the best of it.
Maybe this is your chance to start over.
You have me and Justin.
With our help, you can create a home for yourself here, without all that shit that you had to deal with before.”
Sammy’s words stunned Eydis.
Were such fantasies really okay for her to indulge in?
Could she really start a different life without the pressures and expectations of being an heir to the Amelian Empire?
She worried about her people, especially considering she disappeared after the assassination of her family, but she had no guarantee of returning to Whinhlem.
She might live the rest of her life on Earth.
“Can I live here?” Eydis asked, worried that there was some hidden taboo in her question.
Justin already said she could stay, but Sean gave strict terms, one of which was for her to find her own place to stay.
Sammy’s suggestion stood in direct conflict with his.
What would creating such a home take?
She did not know, but there was hope in Sammy’s words.
Unknown to Eydis, a small smile began to creep over her lips.
Sammy noticed it and beamed.
“Of course!
And while you are getting yourself situated here, I’ll spend as much time with you as I can.
I’m no psychologist, and we can’t really send you to one for your PTSD given your situation, but I can talk to you whenever you need.
I should spend the night again, too, and we can talk about something better, like,” Sammy paused to think.
“You can tell me about that girl, Ceil, that you were friends with, and I can tell you about my family.”
Sammy spoke quickly in her excitement, and Eydis had trouble understanding some of it, but she understood enough.
A genuine smile appeared on Eydis’s face.
If such a free life was possible, she would do everything she could to obtain it.
Sammy pulled Eydis to her feet and looked at the clock.
It was past seven.
“Now that we talked the night away, let’s wake up Justin and have him cook us some breakfast.”
Eydis headed for her door with a new lightness to her step.

Chapter 12
“Repay kindness in double.”
Justin
Justin ended his call with Dr. Shuman with a sigh.
While Eydis was preparing for departure in the bathroom, he had made a quick call to see if Dr. Shuman had found a way to get Eydis into one of the girl’s dormitories.
Dr. Shuman had no luck so far.
Sammy was helping Dr. Shuman at first, hopefully to get a room that she and Eydis could share, but Justin was unsure whether she was still searching.
At some point, she simply stopped bringing up the topic to him when they talked in private about Eydis.
An open bed this late in the semester was extremely rare with the limited dorm space, let alone Eydis lacking a student visa or other form of identification.

Sammy had suggested the day after she met Eydis that she could use the town’s refugee hostel or to be upfront about Eydis’s situation to the authorities to see if the city could set her up with lodging, but Eydis vehemently struck both these ideas down, arguing that the fewer people who knew about her true origins, the better.
For whatever reason, Eydis refused to change where she was staying.
“You ready to go?” Justin asked as Eydis walked into the living room.
“Yes,” she replied eagerly.
Justin led Eydis out the door and to the right to the small driveway-like parking lot of his apartment.
This was the first time Eydis had ridden in a car, so her excitement was palpable.
To add to her excitement, they were headed somewhere new for her, the grocery store.
Eydis did not eat much, but because she was living with Justin, he had the responsibility of feeding her.

He could have managed by skimming down on his own meals, which he had planned on doing before meeting Eydis in order to lose some weight, but now that Sammy was aware of Eydis’s situation, she began spending a lot of time at Justin’s apartment with Eydis.
Of course, she expected him to feed her as well whenever she visited.
After all, Sammy did buy all Eydis’s clothing, of which she frequently reminded him.
With three mouths to feed, his two weeks’ worth of food lasted only one, leading to an earlier-than-usual grocery shopping excursion.
Justin felt like a parent trying to keep his rambunctious child in line in the grocery store, but the one bouncing with excitement was not a child but an elven princess over twice his age.
Much to Justin’s relief, Sammy was not present due to her swimming class, but that left him as Eydis’s sole caretaker, not that he minded.
Eydis clung to his sleeve and pulled him around, pointing to all the packaged products with the twinkling sparkle of discovery in her eyes.
Everything was new and exciting and mysterious and brought up question after curious question about how, where, and why products were here in their various forms.
“Metal is cheap in this country, yes?” Eydis admired the label on a can of refried beans.
Eydis continually amazed Justin by how fast she learned English.
Her speech was simple and a little slow, but she had no accent.
The colloquial pronunciation of words was something she mimicked perfectly from the start.
“Much metal is used to… what is the word…?”
Eydis returned the can to the shelf and pulled out her smartphone.
Sammy installed a dictionary app which Eydis immediately mastered despite being unable to do anything else on the phone yet but make and receive calls and texts.
The only downside was her tendency to become sidetracked looking up reference after reference.
Watching Eydis select links to new words one after another, Justin knew this would be another long episode and decided to continue shopping, leaving Eydis where she stood in the isle.
About twenty minutes later, Justin returned to check up on Eydis only to find her still glued to her phone.
She had not even moved a millimeter.
He sighed in bewilderment but also felt this habit was rather cute.
He couldn’t help but smile.
Shaking his head, he pushed the now full cart next to her and tapped her on the shoulder.
“This!” Eydis thrust the smartphone an inch from his nose and quickly retracted it.
“Preserve.
Much metal is used to preserve food, yes?
Should be expensive but is very cheap.”

Many of Eydis’s questions were simple inquiries, some of which Justin had never really thought about or felt the need to investigate, such as what plastic was and how was it created or why so many products seemed half prepared, being created from raw ingredients but never refined into a completed dish.
The refried beans were one such example.
“You could do more with just beans,” she had said before inquiring about its cylindrical metal packaging.
“Well, after we eat the food, the cans get sent back to be melted down into new cans to store more food, so they’ll just end up back on the store shelf again.
It’s called recycling.”
Eydis’s eyes opened wide.
“You do not throw away the metal, but you send metal back so stores can put more food in to sell again?
Recycling is smart.
My world can learn much from this world.”
A few steps were missing in the process, but Justin decided to keep quiet about it.
Once finished with her recycling revelation, Eydis continued bouncing around the isles.
Justin had already gathered the items on his shopping list and decided to humor Eydis for a little while longer.
“What is this?”
Justin almost fell back from the box of gummy fruit snacks thrust in his face as he turned into the isle after Eydis.
“This does not look like fruit.”
Eydis eyed the picture of small and colorful bite-sized gummies with suspicion.
She then turned to the back of the box to read the ingredients, which proved futile due to the complicated words, many of which Justin didn’t know.
Justin explained the simplest way he could.
“They are sweets.
They use fruit for flavor.
We can buy a box for you to try.
Pick one you like.”
Much to Justin’s surprise, Eydis selected a box immediately.
She ignored all the cartoon- or movie-themed boxes and chose one that had big words stating “Natural” where the gummies looked like the fruit that matched the flavor.
It was the most expensive of the boxes, but Justin reasoned that it would be better for Eydis to try a quality version first.
She was a princess after all.
However, he was curious about her reasoning.
“Why did you pick this one?”
Eydis’s expression froze.
She was not expecting her selection to be scrutinized.
This was also the first time Justin had asked her a question since entering the store.
She stood in thought as gears visibly turned in her head, but after a while she made little progress.
Justin felt bad that she troubled herself over a relatively pointless question.
“It’s no big deal.”
Eydis smiled and shook her head.
“I have a reason, but I cannot explain well.
It felt… clean?”
“Felt?”
Eydis thought to herself again and then grabbed one of the cheapest boxes from the shelf.
“This one feels dirty.
Not bad.
It is safe to eat, but not good.”
Justin took the box from Eydis and compared the ingredients with the organic fruit snacks.
The cheap box contained artificial sweeteners and flavoring as well as other chemicals the organic fruit snacks lacked.
Realizing that Eydis might have a keen sense for healthy food, Justin pulled a carton of eggs from his cart and handed them to her.
“What about these eggs?”
“Bad.” Eydis responded immediately.
“You must cook.
You cannot eat not cooked.”
Justin lowered his voice so others could not hear.
“Is this an elf ability?”
Eydis shook her head lightly.
“No, it is life magic.
I was taught it to save from poison.
It is easy for me because I am a High Elf.
I do not need to try.
I can just… feel?”
Eydis pulled out her phone to look for the right word to describe how she knew, but Justin stopped her.
He did not want to wait another twenty minutes.
“I understand.
Want to help me choose better food then?”
Justin decided that this was as good of an opportunity as ever to start eating healthy.
He took Eydis back around every isle of the store.
Now with a mission, Eydis did not jump from product to product swelling with curiosity but seemed overly eager to focus on her task, which surprised Justin.
But what surprised Justin most was what he noticed as Eydis added and removed food from his cart with fervor.
The healthiest food was not always the most expensive, completely counterintuitive to what he had thought.
The cheap bread he had chosen was better than the more expensive loaves according to Eydis, although the best was the fresh bakery bread that would have placed Justin well over budget.
Eydis was displeased with all the eggs and decided on picking the carton that was the freshest, even swapping out two eggs from another carton.
Justin had to wonder if there was something wrong with how the providers process their eggs for sale that would make them unsafe.
As their shopping continued, Justin did notice some limits to Eydis’s ability.
She had a much harder time determining the quality of products in cans or completely dried products like pasta or spices.
Likewise, the opposite was true for fresh produce.
Eydis didn’t even need to be near the vegetables in order to tell which ones were the freshest or lacked pesticides.
He made a mental note to let Eydis check the refrigerator to point out the food that may have gone bad.
The contents of Justin’s cart were swapped out with haste, and the resulting cart looked nothing like it had before.
Eydis appeared like a picky spouse or girlfriend who knew exactly what products and brands she wanted but her partner had chosen all wrong while she was preoccupied elsewhere.
Men and women who watched them nodded and smiled sympathetically at Justin as if telling him they felt his pain.
Some of them had seen him shopping on his own earlier only adding validation to the false assumption.
Justin could only smile back at their ignorance and wasted sympathy.
Once the groceries were in the trunk of Sean’s car, Justin opened the passenger side door for Eydis.
He entered the driver seat and was about to start the car.
“Justin?”
Hearing his name called in a soft tone, Justin turned to Eydis with his hand still on the key in the ignition.
He thought he saw a mild worry on her face.
He let go of the key, and his mind raced to try and find what the reason might be.
His shopping list became thirty dollars more expensive than what he had planned.
She might have been worried about that, but spending a little more was the price for eating healthy.
Although, he was also feeding her, and so maybe she felt bad that he was spending more to provide for her.
Or it could be something worse, like she somehow realized or noticed something dangerous.
Did she have some way of telling if the assassin appeared?
“Was I useful to you?”
Eydis’s question froze Justin’s spiraling thoughts.
He sat silent, unsure what to say.
Why was she worried about being of use to him?
Scouring his mind for an answer led nowhere, and the longer her question remained unanswered, the more prominent the worry on her face grew.
Her eyes were like a child’s trying to offer a hand-drawn picture as an apology to her parents for accidently breaking an expensive vase.
“Hold on a sec.”
Justin left the car and opened the trunk.
He searched the bags for a specific item and returned to the driver’s seat.
He opened the box of fruit snacks and handed a packet to Eydis.
“As a thank you for today.
You were a great help.”
He had already planned to give her the snacks once they returned to his apartment, but hopefully giving them now would alleviate her concerns.
Much to his relief, the worry slowly melted from Eydis’s face, changing to excitement.
She took the packet but was unsure how to open it.
Justin grabbed a packet for himself and demonstrated how to use the tear seam.
Eydis removed an apple-shaped gummy and was immediately amused by its squishy-yet-firm texture.
Seeing Justin toss one in his mouth, Eydis ate hers as well.
“HmmmmMMMM!”
The corners of Eydis’s mouth curled upwards.
She shook her fists and tapped her feet, and when she had chewed and swallowed it, she faced Justin with a joyful, beaming smile.
“What is this?
This is, this is… I do not know…!”
Instead of taking out her phone to look for the words she needed to express her feelings, Eydis placed a grape gummy in her mouth.
A repeat of the same excited shaking and tapping ensued accompanied by her blushing face.
Watching Eydis’s pleased expression made Justin’s face heat up.
He could get used to seeing this side of Eydis.
Not wanting to stare, he faced forward to start the car.
“Glad you like them,” he said with a smile.
Justin and Eydis returned to their apartment to find Sean looking up at them from the sofa, glasses on and book in hand.
Eydis managed a light bow while carrying bags in both hands.
She always made an effort to be as polite to Sean as possible.
He was still opposed to her staying in the apartment, and she had yet to find a job to help pay for her living expenses as agreed upon.
Sean often chastised Justin for doting on Eydis, but he was oblivious to Eydis’s circumstances.
Justin feared that if he told Sean, Sean would contact the police.
For now, the explanation Justin gave Sean was that Eydis was homeless after escaping an abusive relationship.
The formerly planned explanation that was told to the school would only give Sean further reason to get the authorities involved, regardless of how Eydis felt.
Sammy was in on the deception, so she was always careful in her conversations with Eydis when Sean was around.
After Eydis placed her bags on the table, she removed a packet of fruit snacks and handed it to Sean with the biggest smile she could muster.
It was forced, but Sean understood her goodwill and accepted the packet.
“Thanks.”
Eydis flashed a genuine smile at his gratitude and pranced back to help Justin put the groceries away.
And toss out half the leftovers in the fridge.

* * *
In the afternoon, Justin worked on his homework and left Eydis to her own devices, which often resulted in meditation or English studies.
He found himself having difficulty concentrating.
He felt tired, but the exhaustion was not from lack of sleep or overwork nor was it mental or emotional.
There was something different, uniquely distinct, about it.
He was familiar with this kind, and it would repeat every couple of months like clockwork, but alone it was no reason for concern.
It was only the first sign.

Once finished with his homework, after taking three hours instead of his planned one hour on something that was no more than simple review and mind-numbingly monotonous busy-work that professors seemed to be overly obsessed with, he looked up at the kitchen light.
He could feel a pressure in his eyes like thumbs were pressed forcefully on them.
The light almost had the faint line of a halo around it.
The second sign and now a reason for Justin to worry.
Medicine and the conviction to not exert himself for the rest of the day might be all he needed.
Justin hoped it was all he needed.
He did not want the alternative.
He trudged to the couch next to Eydis who was deep into meditation, but the moment Justin sat down she grew attentive, which was odd.
Normally Justin needed to speak to her or tap her on the shoulder to break her out of her trance.
Eydis noticed something was off.
She grabbed the side of his sleeve lightly, but before she could voice her concern, the front door opened.
“Hey, Eydis!” It was Sammy.
“You could knock,” Justin said, leaning his head back.
“You know how you said that there was something strange about that person who got hit by a truck outside of town two weeks ago?”
If the one who got hit was what Eydis called a minum, it would be cause for concern, but rumors were just rumors.
Tiny people did exist on earth, after all.
They increased their caution for a week, but no other signs or odd occurrences followed.
“Well, nothing happened, but there might still be a chance of someone showing up, right?
I talked with one of my friends, Chloe.” Sammy waved her hands as if she interpreted Justin’s listless stare as accusatory.
“I didn’t tell her the truth, so don’t worry.
She’s attending a self-defense class.
It’s being held in a half-hour, and I thought we should go.”
“Have fun,” Justin said while slouching deeper into the couch.
“No, you are coming too.” Sammy grabbed both Eydis and Justin’s wrists.
“This is for me and you more than her.
Eydis already knows how to fight.
And god knows you would be worthless if something happens.”
The last thing Justin wanted right now was to get involved in heavy physical activity, but Sammy was not one to listen to reason, so he wearily stood from the couch.
“I’ll watch.”
The class was held in a room of the health and fitness building on the north side of campus.
The room was a simple exercise studio with four long windows along its breadth looking out to the hallway on one side.
The entryway sat in the middle, two windows on each side.
Perhaps it was used for other martial arts or wrestling, because several large rolls of thick foam mats lined the back walls.
Only three were unrolled for the class.
A storage room sat off in the back corner with one door ajar revealing both exercise and combat equipment such as pads, focus mitts, and sandbags.
Sammy switched Eydis’s woven cap for a wide exercise headband to cover her ears and tied Eydis’s hair into a ponytail.
Once inside the room, Justin noticed something Sammy had neglected to mention.
When probing Sammy for an answer, she was also surprised.
“I didn’t realize this was a girl’s self-defense class.”
Justin shrugged and took a seat against the wall on the left side of the room.
He was not the only guy there.
Two others to his right sat conversing near the corner of the room below the windows to the hallway.
Perhaps their girlfriends or otherwise were taking the class.
He doubted they were there just to spectate.
“I wasn’t planning on participating anyway,” he said, mostly to himself.
Eydis continued looking back at Justin while Sammy pulled her to the group of eight women and introduced her to a long-haired, redheaded girl Justin recognized as Sammy’s former roommate, Chloe.
Other than her name, he never had much opportunity to get to know her while he was dating Sammy because men were not allowed in the women’s dorms, and Chloe rarely left her room back then.
Once the instructor arrived, Dr. Madison Calliby--her more familiar students greeted her as Maddi--the class began.
After warmups and ten minutes of instruction, the students paired up for practice.
Sammy paired with Eydis to help hide Eydis’s strangely light body weight.
From the start, Justin saw that Eydis was clearly far more skilled than any of the students.
Sammy was right.
Eydis could fight.
By the halfway point, everyone was positive that Eydis had received martial training, but when asked, Eydis could not name the art she knew, only that it was taught within her family.
Sammy explained that Eydis was a foreigner who was still learning English, which appeased most of the curiosity.
At the end of the session, there was still some time remaining, so the students begged Eydis to show them something from her martial art.
Dr. Calliby gave permission for a simple demonstration if Eydis was willing.
Eydis thought for a moment, and then decided on a grapple escape, given that this was a self-defense class.
Dr. Calliby volunteered to be the assailant because the height difference between Sammy and Eydis would not prove well for demonstration.
She was half a head shorter than Eydis, about six feet tall.
Eydis was reluctant, but after Sammy whispered something into the instructor’s ear, she gave the okay.
At Eydis’s request, Dr. Calliby held Eydis around the waist from behind.
Dr. Calliby was on her back with Eydis only holding her wrist.
Justin could not tell what happened.
Neither could anyone else, especially the instructor.
Through Justin’s eyes, once Eydis grabbed Dr. Calliby’s wrist and shifted slightly, Dr. Calliby’s posture buckled, and she fell without a chance for resistance.
It almost looked like an act, and she fell on purpose.
She stayed motionless for a long time, staring up at Eydis purely dumbfounded.
Sammy ran over and helped Dr. Calliby to her feet so that Eydis did not have to.
Eydis’s skill piqued the instructor’s curiosity.
“How long have you been practicing?”
“About two, so… Maybe eighteen, no, nineteen years?”
Justin understood that Eydis had to convert the years, but Dr. Calliby took her first statement directly.
“You’ve been training since you were two?
It definitely shows.” She patted Eydis on the shoulder.
“Would you be willing to help here as an instructor?”
“That’s perfect!” Sammy grabbed Eydis by both arms.
“You’ve been wanting a job, and you’re definitely qualified!”
Once all the other students left, Eydis and Sammy stayed behind to discuss terms of employment.

Sammy’s help was vital given that Eydis knew nothing about the hiring process or appropriate hourly wages or anything the average job hunter would investigate before submitting a resume or applying for a job.
The university sponsored the class, and the instructor was a professor.
She explained that she was free to request an aid and that the university would pay, but she had not done so in the past because the class was always small.
Pay for teacher assistant positions were decided by affiliated credit hours taken, but Eydis was not a student.
With about nineteen Earth-years’ worth of martial training, Eydis was certainly qualified as Sammy had stated.

Justin was sure that Eydis could open her own studio, gym, or dojo and earn far more than the university was willing to offer, but Eydis was against any job capable of advertising herself to that degree.
Dr. Calliby agreed to argue on Eydis’s behalf for the maximum pay an assistant could be given, $18.50 an hour and usually reserved for assistants to graduate-level classes.
That included hours spent on lesson planning and preparation, not just time spent instructing.
Sammy still thought the rate was cheap, but it was more than she was making as a librarian and over twice what Justin made at the help desk.
The only remaining issue for Eydis was identification.
Sammy mentioned the university recently enacted policies for temporary refugee employment that did not require identification or a work visa so long as one or the other were in process.

The refugee jobs were usually grounds work or janitorial, but there were no provisions restricting which university job the refugee employment policy could apply, a loophole Sammy was more than happy to abuse.
Sammy’s investigations on behalf of Eydis finally bore fruit.
Contact information was exchanged with an agreement to continue the hiring process once Eydis applied for a refugee ID.
Sammy and Eydis returned to Justin who had sat silently against the wall the entire class.
Sammy extended a helping hand to Justin who was not steady on his feet.
His first foot was solid, but his second sent him awry and forced him to place his hand on Sammy’s shoulder for balance.
Sammy’s abrasive front vanished in an instant and was replaced by a nostalgic expression of care he had not seen since the months they were dating.
“You doing okay?” she asked.
Justin rubbed his temples with the thumb and middle finger of his free hand.
“The usual.”
“Ah!
You should have said something!”
“I’ll be fine.
I took medicine.
I’ll just go to bed early tonight.”
“Is Justin sick?” Eydis’s voice was seeped in concern.
“Not sick.
He just has bad headaches frequently.”
“Headache?” Eydis was not familiar with the word.
Sammy explained what a headache was to the best of her ability as they walked back to the bus and assured her that Justin would be fine after some rest.
Sammy parted at the bus stop to head to her dorm, and Justin and Eydis took the bus back to the river.
Justin changed into something comfortable and bundled up in blankets on the couch.
He could already feel it coming like a heavy hand pressing his head into the pillow.
He took more medicine and tried not to focus on it, and in time, he managed to fall asleep.

* * *
Justin woke to a thunderous pain.
He rolled to his right side, but the soft pillow became a vice that gripped his head and threatened to squeeze his brain out through his right eye.
“Ahhu…” A weak moan was all his voice had strength to cry.
Even supporting himself on his shaking elbow to keep pressure off his right side only caused the vice to grip down on the left as well.
His head felt like it was being split in two between the jaws of the vice.
The medicine Justin had taken that afternoon either wore off or was not enough.
The clock on the wall read half past midnight.
So much for 8-hour relief.
Only half that had passed.
He slid his left leg and then his right off the couch taking care to set them down softly on the hardwood floor so that any impact would not travel up his leg and to his head.
Once on his knees, he attempted to stand, but the slight motion caused extreme nausea.
The room spun, and the vice on his head spun along with it.
He fell to his elbows, and the impact caused the pain in his head to spread down his neck and to his shoulders.
His stomach bubbled.
Justin scrambled to the hall and into the bathroom, barely making it to the toilet before vomiting.
The contracting of his stomach forced pressure to his head and face.
This increased the pain which further increased the nausea, causing more vomiting.
The torturous cycle repeated a second, third, and then fourth time until his stomach had nothing left to give.
The dry heaving was worse than his vomiting, and the agonizing pressure made his vision grow white.
This was his worst migraine in years.
There was nothing he could do at this point but endure it.
If he was lucky, he would pass out like the last time he had a migraine this bad.
Was he 19 or 20?
Justin couldn’t remember.
He just hoped he would wake up in the hospital on enough drugs that this night would only feel like a terrible dream, just like that time.
Justin rested his cheek on the toilet seat once he had a break in heaving.
Two shifting, blurry legs stood in the bathroom doorway.
He looked up and saw Eydis staring at him with wide, terrified eyes.
Justin attempted a self-depreciating grimace from showing Eydis his miserable state but gave up when moving his cheeks worsened the ache.
Eydis grabbed Justin without speaking a word.
He could feel wind pressure beneath him lift him up as she carried him over to the couch.
Aside from the light pressure of her arms on his back and legs, he felt as if he was riding a cloud.
She did not lay him on the couch but instead sat on it herself and situated him on the floor so that he could lean back against her.
Unable to hold back the ensuing nausea from his movements, Justin vomited again, but having already emptied his stomach, only thin bile ran down his chin onto his shirt.
Unfazed, Eydis leaned Justin forward to help the bile leave his mouth.
The motion almost made him retch again.
She then pulled him back against the couch between her legs and leaned forward.
After tilting Justin’s head back, she placed her forehead against his and her hands on the sides of his head.
Justin felt a warm pulse starting from his forehead and continuing down through his body.
After a moment, Eydis wrapped her legs around him to hold him close and then spoke.
“Sorry, this will hurt.”
What followed after Eydis’s warning made Justin’s migraine feel like nothing more than a benign paper cut.
The vice that was crushing his head was replaced by hooks digging in and yanking out hundreds of barbed spikes, pulling everything inside him out with them.
The pain quickly spread through his entire body.
He writhed and screamed, but his voice made no more sound than a raspy exhale.
Eydis continued holding him tight with strength beyond what should have been possible for her light frame.
Justin wished with all his heart to die, to stop the pain, but when he felt that his body was about to give in to his wish, the pain weakened.
The spikes became pins, and the pins became an itch.
With the ebbing of the pain, his migraine ebbed with it.
Relief washed over him, and he began to sob but was soon assaulted by shivers of exhaustion greater than any he had ever felt before.
This cold tiredness left him feeling like he was a moment from death’s door, or perhaps that he did die, and that was the reason the pain went away.
But the exhaustion was not death.
Justin felt an illness accompanying it.
He tried turning to face Eydis, but she held his head firm.
“Do not move.
I am not done.”
A soothing sensation swirled inside Justin’s head starting from where her forehead touched and spread to his neck, shoulders, back, and then extremities, just as the pain had before.
The shivers ceased and Justin felt warm.
The deathlike exhaustion changed to physical exhaustion as his body relaxed, losing the will to support itself.
Justin sat completely limp in Eydis’s grasp for a few more minutes before she released him.
“I am done.”
Eydis rested Justin’s limp body against the couch.
She pulled off his soiled shirt and walked to his room to retrieve another.
He watched as with each small step, the next step carried a little more urgency, and she returned in a trot with a mildly pained expression.
He looked into her anguished face as she wiped his and placed a clean shirt on him.
He tried to tell her that he felt fine now and that his pain was gone, but he found that he had no voice.
Eydis struggled to lift him onto the couch, and after a few minutes of strenuous effort, Justin was comfortably laying down.
Eydis knelt down to grab the blanket to spread over him, but her body trembled when she tried to stand.
Unable to lift even the blanket, she fell to her side.
Her face was pale, and she was sweating profusely.
If Justin could have felt his heart, he knew it would have been racing in panic.
He tried calling out to Eydis, but his voice remained mute.
His mouth would not move.
His arms, legs, even his fingers did not obey.
What he assumed was his body relaxing after such a traumatizing experience was something far worse.
He was paralyzed.
Justin tried to move, but no matter his mental struggle, his body would not listen.
Fear and confusion circled his mind.
What did Eydis do to him?
Why did she collapse immediately after?
With his body paralyzed, how could he help the woman on the floor before him?
Sean.
Justin took the deepest breath he could to call for his roommate, but the breath was far too shallow.
Air left his mouth, but no sound followed.
He tried once more with as much force as he could muster.
His voice was small and would not carry down the hall.
Justin repeatedly called Sean and soon found that control returned to his lips and tongue.
With each breath he could breathe deeper, his voice grew louder, and his pronunciation improved.
A door down the hall opened and Sean rushed to the bathroom, having smelled the vomit.
“Justin?”
“Living room.”
Sean hurried to Justin and saw Eydis collapsed in front of the couch.
“What happened?”
Eydis lay unconscious, her pointed ears in full view.
Sean knelt next to Eydis and touched her shoulder.
“She’s burning up.
I thought it was you who threw up.”
“It was.
I’ll explain after.
I can’t move, so please, take her to her bed and do something about her fever.”
Sean looked at her ears and reached down almost to touch them.
“Is our medicine okay for her to take?”
“…I don’t know.”
“Wet socks and towel then.”
Sean lifted Eydis in a bridal carry and froze.
His eyes narrowed as he scanned Eydis’s body from head to toe.
Justin knew the cause of Sean’s confusion.
He was surprised by her weight.
Sean carried her down the hallway and returned with a hand towel and a pair of wool socks.
He soaked both in cold water in the sink, wrung them out, and returned down the hall.
Justin cursed himself for his inability to help Eydis.
He could not even begin to understand what happened or why Eydis collapsed, but he knew he was the cause.
It happened after whatever it was that she did to him to remove his migraine.
Sean cleaned the bathroom and placed the soiled shirt into Justin’s laundry after lightly rinsing it.
He then returned and pulled up a chair next to Justin.
“So, what happened?”
Justin knew that he could no longer hide everything from Sean.
The only question was how much he needed to tell.
Justin told Sammy everything because having a fellow woman with whom Eydis could openly communicate was beneficial.
He had refrained from telling Sean the truth out of fear that Sean would contact the authorities, but now he had little choice.
There were parts of Eydis’s background that Justin still felt should be withheld, but Sean at least deserved to know Eydis’s true origins.
Justin began his explanation with his migraine and how whatever Eydis did to him placed them both in their respective conditions.
He then brought up Eydis’s otherworldly elven origins, but he decided to leave out the assassination attempt that brought her to their world.
“I assume Sammy knows everything as well?
I knew something was up between you and Eydis that you weren’t telling me.
The walls of this apartment are not exactly soundproof.
I heard jumbled bits and pieces whenever you talked in private, but I could never piece it together.
I never thought it would be this bizarre.”
“Just don’t tell anyone.
Dr. Shuman and Sammy are the only others who know the truth.”
Sean bopped his fist on Justin’s forehead.
“Who do you take me for?”
“You know, I am recovering from a migraine.”
Sean smiled and bopped Justin again.
“I thought she cured you.”
“As you can see, I’m still not in perfect condition.”
Sean sat back in his chair and folded his arms.
“How long until you can move again?”
“Eydis collapsed before she could say anything, but I can move my fingers a little now, so I might be able to move by morning.
I hope…”
“Then that just leaves one question, should I get you an empty bottle or would you rather me pick you up a diaper?”
There was no grin on his face.
Sean’s statement held the same austere aura that radiated from him at all times.

He appeared as if at Justin’s request, he would head to the nearest 24-hour mart to pick up an adult diaper, but having lived with Sean for two years, Justin could easily recognize Sean’s dry form of sarcasm.
“Very funny.”
Sean stood and returned the chair to the table.
“I’ll keep an eye on Eydis, so get some sleep.”
Of all the men that Justin knew, Sean was the only one he would trust completely to not lay his hands on Eydis.
Thinking back to when he was sexualizing Eydis’s trauma before knowing the truth, Justin trusted Sean more than he would trust himself.
Laughing silently, Justin closed his eyes and found it easy to drift off to sleep.
Justin woke before sunrise and found that he could move, albeit sluggishly.
He felt like his body was reacting a full second after he attempted to move it.
The second hand on the clock in the living room also moved far slower than it should.
Clearly his body had not fully recovered, so Justin decided to close his eyes and sleep for another hour or two, or however long his body would let it.
When Justin woke again, faint morning light peaked through the cracks in the horizontal blinds.
Unlike the dreamlike state he woke in a few hours earlier, his body moved normally.
After pulling off the blankets, Justin stood on his feet and found that his legs supported him but were very weak.
This was no different than the weakness he usually felt after a bad migraine, so he was not alarmed.
He made his way down the hall to his room where he found Eydis sleeping soundly.
Sean slept in the desk chair set beside the bed.
He held a hand towel that he had likely placed on Eydis’s forehead to help drop her fever.
Justin tapped Sean on the shoulder.
Sean looked up with groggy eyes at Justin.
“I’ll take it from here.
Go to bed.”
Sean nodded and hobbled out of the room.
Eydis continued sleeping through the morning and did not stir until the early afternoon but only to shift positions and continue sleeping.
Her fever dropped, although she still felt warm.
Sean returned after his afternoon classes to check up on her and left once he saw she was recovering.
The only words he spoke were to ask Justin not to tell Eydis that he had helped her.
Justin smiled to himself seeing the contrast between Sean’s serious front and his kindness.
Sean was a hard worker, and so he held strong opinions against freeloading and handouts.
He always pushed Eydis to situate herself and earn her way solely because he did care and felt it best for her.
Whatever happened to her in the past, Sean wanted Eydis to grow past it and become stronger for it.
Eydis opened her eyes shortly after the sun set.
After locating Justin sitting beside her, her lips slowly parted.
“Are you feeling better now?”
Justin felt anger well up in him.
It took him by surprise.
He could not tell if his anger was directed at Eydis, himself, or anyone at all.
The whole situation was preposterous.

He had a migraine, something he was used to and could endure as he had many times in the past, and then without his consent, Eydis healed him but ended up with a high fever that kept her bedridden all day in his stead.
It was like she took his illness upon herself.
What was the purpose of all this?
“Why’d you do that?”
Justin voiced his thoughts without thinking, the words sounding in his ears as if someone else had spoken them.
He knew he sounded ungrateful, but he could not take them back.
Eydis sat up in the bed with a stern face that leaned on the side of anger.
“You saved me from the cold.
You gave me a place to live.
You are hiding me from people who want to kill me.
You protect my secret.
You feed me.
And I, what have I done for you?
Pick out food?
Elves have a saying.” Eydis paused for a moment to think about the translation.
“When shown kindness, pay it back twice.
I have much to pay back.”
“I didn’t do any of that expecting you to repay me.
You did not have to harm yourself to help me.”
Eydis smiled.
“Then think this way .
If you do not get better or die, I lose place to live.
I lose place to hide.
I lose you who knows my secret.
I lose you who feeds me.
If you do not like me paying back kindness, then I did it for me, not you.”
Eydis folded her arms to add the final punctuation to her argument.
Justin had no ammo to refute what she said and raised his hands in defeat.
“Then thank you,” Justin  replied with an exasperated smile.
“How about this?
You can also pay me back by telling me what on earth you did.”
Eydis sat in thought for a few minutes.
“I cannot explain well.
You were sick… No, not sick.
You were poisoned.” Her eyes looked above her as if visualizing the question mark hanging over her head.
Justin’s mind ran circles around everything he did the previous day, everything he ate.
If there was poison in any of the food, Justin thought that Eydis would have noticed with her keen ability to detect both quality and safety.
Or perhaps there was food that Justin ate periodically that is safe for most people but his body reacts aversely to, causing his migraines.
An intolerance or allergy?
Following this train of thought, Justin began recalling what he had eaten over the past few days.
Eydis noticed his internal contemplation and placed her hand on his wrist to pull him out.
She followed with an explanation.
“Ven, the energy used for magic, is everywhere.
Bodies take in ven, turn it into something we can use.
It is very rare, but sometimes a person’s body is not good at this.
Some ven is changed wrong, becomes poison.
When your body is full of ven, extra ven your body takes in escapes.
Poison ven makes escape hard or stops it.
When full of only poison ven, poison must escape and causes pain and sickness.”
“Ven?
Is that like mana from video games?
Mana poisoning?”
Justin could not use magic, but from Eydis’s explanation, his body must still absorb ven like hers but is poor at it, making it toxic.
His periodic migraines could be explained if every two to three months, the ven poisoning backup peaked.
“Sorry for hurting you.
Normally when poison ven grows too much, your body expels it, like vomit, and the pain goes away.
Your poison ven was not escaping.
It was very dangerous.
If bad, you could die.
I pushed it out, all your ven, gone.
Having no ven is also bad.
Bodies need ven.
Without ven, your body weakens and also might die.
With no poison ven, you were empty, so I gave you all of mine.”
Justin recalled how Eydis was breathing heavier than normal and was sweating and shivering when she changed his shirt and lifted him onto the couch.
“All…?
Didn’t you just say being out of ven was bad, that you could die?”
Eydis’s eyes fell to her lap.
“Normally I would be fine.
I have trained my body to survive no ven.
I take in ven fast, but it is hard in this world.
Ven here is strange.
I must change it different than ven in my world, so it is slow.
With no ven, my body got weak, made me sleep to focus on getting more ven.”
Eydis looked down at her lap with her cheeks puffed in a childish pout that looked to Justin as if she had lost a contest she knew she would win.
“I was not going to give you all my ven, just enough to help you.
But your container is large, very large.
I felt it… It was…” Eydis bit her lower lip.
“No, four or five of me, maybe more.”
After a small shake of her head, she continued.
“With full container, magic is easy.
Less in container makes magic hard.
One fourth of container and magic stops without forcing it.
Body is in danger at one sixth of container or less.
I kept giving you ven, but you were still in danger.
You needed all my ven.
Even with all, I was worried.
It was not enough… Not even close… Your container is too large.”
“I can’t use magic.
How is my capacity bigger than yours?”
“Your… capacity?” Eydis’s eyes lit up at the discovery of a new word.
“Your capacity is big maybe because of poison ven.
Ven your body takes in cannot escape because of poison, and it stretches capacity until it must escape.
We train capacity by stopping escape the same way, but we do not let it become bad like with poison ven, so it takes a long time.
For you, poison ven always grows, stops escape, and stretches capacity.”
“Is there any way to stop my body from converting the ven wrong?”
“There is no cure.
Bring your head close.”
Eydis beckoned with her hand for Justin to come near.
She then placed her hands on his cheeks and pulled his head towards hers until their foreheads touched.
Justin could feel blood rushing to his face.
He could feel the tickle from the breath of the beautiful woman.
He then felt a brief tinge of pressure in his head, but it was not enough that he would call it painful.
Eydis released her grasp on Justin’s face, and they both sat back in their respective positions.
“Poison ven was there, but very small amount.
Could you feel how I push it out?”
Justin shook his head.
“I just felt a little pain, that’s it.”
“Poison ven is bad, so you must learn to push it out yourself.
A body full of good ven is healthy.
If you use magic, good ven is used first.
If you take in more ven and some becomes poison, poison ven grows.
If you have no good ven, then poison ven is used for magic and is very, very painful.
Removing poison ven without using it is much less painful.
I will help you learn to remove poison ven.”
“Help me learn?
How?
I can’t use magic.”
“Not magic.
Your body.
I will push out poison ven for you each day so your body can feel how.
And you do not know if you cannot do magic.
You did not know about ven, what ven feels like, how to use it.
I will show you too, but first you need to know what magic you can use.
I can only use wind magic, life magic, and…”
Eydis looked around her bed, and Justin knew what she was searching for.
He walked over to his desk to retrieve Eydis’s smartphone.
He sat silent for a few minutes as Eydis searched.
Like usual, Eydis became oblivious to the passage of time, so Justin left the room to cook dinner.
Twenty minutes later, he returned with both his and Eydis’s plates, and yet Eydis still had not found the word she was looking for.
“Transport.
Portal.
Barrier.
Wall.
No word for all this.”
Eydis voiced her frustration before tossing a piece of popcorn chicken into her mouth, ignoring the homemade barbecue sauce Justin had prepared with it.
“Hold on.
You can make portals?
You can teleport?” Justin could not believe what he was hearing.
“If that’s the case, how are you stuck in this world?
Shouldn’t you be able to go back?”
Eydis looked at Justin with a blank stare and mouth agape.
She grew angry.
“I am new to this magic.
I was not born with it.
It came when I grew to a woman.
My teacher who sent me here was the best at portal magic!
I do not know magic to move to other worlds!
That magic is much more than me!”
Justin scrambled to keep both his and Eydis’s plates from falling to the floor from her outburst.
“I get it, I get it.
As for what to call it… use the word spatial.”
Eydis’s eyes lit up again at the new word she could not find, her excitement erasing any trace of her outburst.
“Yes, spatial magic.
I can use wind magic, life magic, and spatial magic.
Give me your hand.”
Already holding his plate in one hand, Justin tossed the two pieces of popcorn chicken in his other hand into his mouth and extended it.
Eydis adjusted the position so that his palm faced upwards.
She moved her hand, palm downward, about an inch above his.
“Do you feel something?”
“What am I supposed to feel?” Justin asked after swallowing.
“Now do you feel something?”
Justin felt nothing more than the faint radiant heat of Eydis’s hand.
A third time Eydis asked, and again Justin felt nothing.
“I sent life ven, wind ven, and spatial ven below my hand.
If you feel nothing, then maybe you cannot use same magic as me.
There are other magic, like fire magic, water magic, and earth magic, but I cannot test if you can use them.
I cannot make ven for those magic.
You must learn yourself.
Or maybe you can use no magic… That is common for humans…”
Eydis tossed another piece of popcorn chicken into her mouth and pouted again.
“But that wastes large capacity.”

Chapter 13
“Hands-on Learning”
Eydis

Eydis woke not to the sunlight through the windows of her large guest room in the west wing of the imperial palace but to the sounds of scraping and gargled whimpers coming from the metal crate against the far wall from her bed.
Jethro had instructed her to raise a peculiar little creature in her room by feeding it blood each day, and this was the morning of the fifth day.
The light filtering through the parts in the blue curtains showed that the sun would soon peak over the horizon.
Eydis pulled the large blankets of her bed back over her head to muffle the noise from the crate.
It was only yesterday that the creature had begun making any sound.
A loud yip-like bark pierced through the blankets and into Eydis’s sharp ears.
She wanted to continue sleeping, but a pungent metallic odor crept into Eydis’s nose as the light of the morning sun scattered rainbow sparks through the crystalline windows.
Like the four days previous, as soon as the sun rose, a cup of blood appeared on the small table beside her bed.
The smell was musty, not unlike mold, and made her nose itch and threaten to sneeze.
The yips from the creature inside the crate grew louder and more aggressive the longer Eydis stalled.
It learned the time it got fed, or it could smell the blood.
Either way, if Eydis wanted any peace, she had to eliminate the smell and silence the creature.
Eydis removed the blankets and turned to place her feet on the cold woolen carpet.
After stretching her arms behind her back and breathing a great yawn, she retrieved the cup with one hand covering her nose.
The closer she got to the crate, the louder the creature became.
When she slowly poured the blood into the funnel on the corner, the noises of the creature ceased.
All that could be heard was the lapping of a small tongue that had not been there previously.
Over the next few days, the high-pitched yips became deep barks and howls.
To Eydis’s keen ears, it sounded no different than the hounds that she used to hear around the palace.
The creature stopped crying for the blood that Eydis gave it each morning and instead waited patiently.
Her days of seclusion in her room would have been peaceful if not for the howling at night that prevented any deep sleep.
On the fifteenth day, the smell of the blood changed.
It assaulted her nose with a rotten odor that jolted her awake before the sun had the chance.

Eydis rushed out of bed, grabbed the cup, and poured its contents into the crate, but try as she might, Eydis could not rid her sinuses of the smell of rotten food and spoiled milk that squeezed tears from the corners of her eyes.
She was grateful the cup disappeared as soon as she returned it to the bedside table, but the smell still lingered in her sinuses for most of the morning.
For the next four days, Eydis was woken by the rotten odor.
The hound-like howls ceased, and the barks grew high in pitch back to the yips they once were and then closer to a squeal.
The silencing of the howls did not improve Eydis’s sleep.
The creature slept during the day and was awake and scratching at the walls of the crate each night.
The effects of Eydis’s lack of sleep over the past fifteen days began to show.
Try as she might, she could not get her body to change its sleep schedule and let her sleep during the day.
Hours were spent lying in bed staring up at the canopy.
She used simple life magic to keep the shadows under her eyes from showing and to keep her skin on her face from sagging, but with each day she grew more and more tired, more and more frustrated.
Why has Jethro not appeared?
What am I to learn from raising this thing in a metal box?
