How long am I to continue this?
Eydis grabbed a piece of parchment from the desk in the corner of the room, wrote her questions, and placed it on the table.
The parchment disappeared immediately, seemingly falling through the polished wood into the table, and was replaced with a reply appearing in a flash of light like a spark.
“We are entering the final stages.
Only a few more days.”
Eydis tore the tough parchment in her hand and let it drift to the floor.
She was too tired to be angry, too tired to think.
She spent the rest of the day in a daze, letting her mind draw her into whatever action took its fancy, which only amounted to pacing around the room, playing with her tail, or lying in bed.
The next day the blood changed once again.
This time the smell was benign compared to the other two but still unsettling.
Eydis breathed a sigh of relief and prayed that this time the creature would become more tolerable.
She was unsure, but the actions of the creature seemed to change with the blood she gave it, and because the blood was not pungent, perhaps the creature would mellow out.
Eydis’s dazed mind found herself staring at the blood in the cup as she carried it over.
She wondered what it came from.
The smell of iron still hung thick in her nose, but at the same time, she was not averse to it.
Compared to the moldy scent of the first and the rotten odor of the second, the blood in the cup smelled of herbs.
When she brought it over to the crate, she found herself hesitating to pour it in.
She stared at it with blank eyes as red slowly filled her vision.
A sudden clang from inside the crate returned Eydis to her senses.
She realized what she was doing.
In fear, she quickly dumped it into the funnel, nearly spilling it over the edges.
Something was wrong with her.
She did not want to give it to the creature.
She wanted it instead.
This alien thought combined with her lack of sleep dropped Eydis to her knees.
Her ears could hear the creature drink the blood inside the crate.
The sound was deafening.
She covered her ears quickly with twitching, anxious fingers, but her mind could still hear the sound.
She screamed out.
“What is wrong with me!?”
Eydis ran to the desk and pulled out the drawer containing the parchment, snapping off the handle in her haste.
She penned out a complaint of the torturous treatment she had been receiving and demanded it to end.
When she placed her message on the table, the only reply she received was, “Keep feeding it.”
This was an order.
This had to be some long-term torture Jethro devised to break her mentally.
The Amelian Empire lost the war.
It was no more.
She was the sole survivor of the royal family, and she was in the hands of the enemy’s general.
Was he toying with her for his amusement?
For what purpose was she being subjected to this torture?
What was so important that she had to suffer this in order to learn?
Was it only to show his dominance over her?
Was it because of her defiance during their former daily meetings?
If that was his purpose, Eydis refused to give in.
She would not become Jethro’s broken pet.
In protest, the next morning Eydis did not feed the creature.
She left the cup on the table and sat in the furthest corner from both the crate and the cup of blood.
The aroma of the blood attacked her senses.
She found it unpleasant, but her heart still raced.
She bit the inside of her cheek until it bled to keep her mind off the smell, masking it in the taste of her own blood.
When steam no longer rose from the cup, it was replaced by another fresh cup.
After the cup was replaced for the third time, the unfed creature began to whimper, but the sound was unlike any noise the creature had previously made.
The cries had tonal changes to them and were more babble than the shrill cries of the past days.
They were otherworldly and only grew in intensity as time went by.
Eydis cried in her corner but did not want to give in.
The longer she held off feeding the creature, the louder it became.
I will not give in.
I will not!
A shrill screech from the creature sent chills through her body.
She ran and jumped completely over her large bed to the table.
Cup in hand, she cleared the long distance from her bed to the crate in only three strides, spilling drops of blood onto the pristine white carpet.
Once the blood was poured into the crate, the horrid sounding cries ceased and were replaced by the wet slurping of the creature drinking its meal.
Eydis walked slowly back to the table.
She watched the cup vanish as all the others had, but this time, the vanishing cup was agonizing rather than relieving.
She curled up against the side of her bed and cried.
She had given in.
She didn’t want to, but she had succumbed to her own weakness.
She stayed in that position for the remainder of the day and through the night wondering what more Jethro would make her do now that he knew she would become obedient if pressured enough.
She held the tip of her tail at her side like a safety blanket and waited out the torturous night.
The next morning before the cup appeared, Eydis heard mumbling from the crate.
It was high pitched and mixed with coughs and snarls.
When the sun peaked over the purple horizon, the cup appeared, and immediately the creature screamed.
It thrashed inside the crate, and from the sound, there was little room for the creature to move.
This further infuriated it.
With a deep breath and another shrill cry, a bulge grew on the crate from an impact within.
Eydis rushed the cup over to the crate and poured in the blood.
She no longer had the will to resist Jethro’s demands.
She would feed the creature as ordered.
The cries ceased, but the creature continued hitting the walls of the crate, although without the same force or ferocity.
To prevent a repeat of the previous day’s drama, Eydis waited at the table for the appearance of the cup.
The moment it appeared, Eydis rushed it to the crate and poured it in.
The cries stopped and the room fell silent, but later that day the creature began speaking.
It babbled nonsensical sounds, but they were distinctly sapient.
As the incoherent speech continued, it grew angrier and angrier until the creature assaulted the walls of its small enclosure.
The next day the assault did not stop once the creature was fed.
The number of bulges in the crate grew.
Eydis did everything within her power to appease the creature.
She tried talking to it.
She tried singing to it.
But it was not enough.
It only grew angrier.
“What more do you want?!”
Eydis screamed.
The creature responded by hitting the very center of the side of the crate facing her.
The bulge it created was far larger than any previous impact, buckling the seam in the center of both the top and bottom edge.
Eydis immediately went silent.
A second impact created a similarly large bulge on the top of the crate.
The former opening that had been welded shut grew a small crack.
Eydis held her breath.
Much to her relief, the creature did not notice.
How long will the crate hold?
What happens if it breaks?
Only a monster of terrible power could bend and stretch metal with so little room for movement.
Eydis huddled back in the furthest corner of the room and watched with wide, sleep-deprived eyes through the night.
She could not find the courage to blink for fear of something happening when her eyes closed.
Her eyes burned from lack of moisture, but still she watched.
By morning, the cries had not stopped nor had the internal attack on the crate.
When the cup appeared, Eydis ran with all haste to give it to the creature, but when she reached the crate, the creature hit the corner with the funnel.
The funnel snapped off, bouncing once on the white carpet.
The corner seam split open where the funnel attached.
This did not go unnoticed by the creature.
It hit the same location again, and the tear in the seam grew.
Fingers shot out the opening, long, slender, hairy fingers with knotted knuckles.
Eydis dropped the cup, spilling the creature’s meal on the floor.
The smell from the inside of the crate was so foul it made Eydis gag.
She staggered back.
The fingers spasmed and thrashed at the opening in the metal amidst shrill rambling cries, and the tear slowly grew.
Eydis ran panicked to the desk for the quill.
The parchment tore in her hand as she penned a plea for help so hard that the quill split and marred the polished finish of the desk.
She placed it on the table, her eyes glued to the hand protruding from the metal.
The message disappeared, but no reply came.
Another strong impact, and the corner of the crate bent further.
A long slender arm with matted hair on the outer side extended through the opening.
The odor of the arm that swung wildly and clawed at the air stung her eyes and nose.
Eydis hid in the small gap between her bed and side table.
She could not control her shaking body and pulled a blanket off her bed for what meager cover or comfort--she was not sure which she wanted more--it might provide.
In its swinging, the arm struck the wall behind the crate.
The creature jammed its claws into the marble with impossible strength, chipping off part of the wall.
This created a hold that the creature used to pull up that side of the crate.
With enough leverage, the crate tipped on its end, standing vertical.
A push off the wall sent the crate careening forward onto the ground.
The stain of blood on the carpet was now near the opening.
Eydis shrieked.
A face appeared in the opening.
It had clearly elven features but was hairy with fangs and a long tongue.
Its tongue lashed out of the opening, but despite its length it could not reach the bloodstained carpet.
This infuriated the creature.
The monster thrashed, clawed, and kicked at the opening amid shrill, angry cries.
Slowly the opening widened, and the monster stuck its head out of the crate.
A matted mane ran from the top of its head down its neck.
Its pointed ears sitting high on the sides of its head could belong to an elf, but there was something distinctly rodent about them.
The monster extended itself as far as possible out of the opening but was stopped by its shoulders.
Its long tongue could just barely touch the bloodstain.
Instead of growing angry, the creature grabbed the opening with its hand and pushed.
Little by little the metal bent outwards.
Its arm and shoulder slid through.
Grabbing the other side with its other hand, it bent the metal further.
Eydis could not speak.
She could not breathe.
Any action she took she feared would make the creature notice her.
The only sound was the rapid beating of her terrified heart.
Tears grew in her eyes, and she even feared their fall would attract its attention.
Someone… please…
The monster bent the metal enough to pull its other arm and shoulder out.
It shifted its body back and forth, sliding out the opening until it was free.
There stood a man, naked and covered in patches of matted, light-brown fur on his back from his head to his long, slender tail.
He had the gruesome appearance of an elf fused with a hound, but his hands, feet, and tail were like a rodent.
Fecal matter was smeared on his body.
Not only did her eyes sting, but she could also taste it in the air.
Free from his prison, the monster attacked the blood on the carpet with his teeth and tongue, sucking up what it could.
Eydis watched in fearful silence as the hair on his arms and legs lessened and the digits on his hands and feet shrunk slightly.
Light flashed beside Eydis.
The tears Eydis had been struggling to hold back fell at the sight of Jethro.
She pleaded in silence for him to save her.
“He grew nice and big,” Jethro said, glancing down at Eydis, completely unfazed by Eydis’s distress and the smell in the room.
Seeing that Jethro’s voice did not draw the monster’s attention, Eydis found the courage to speak.
“What… what is th-that thing?”
“An Alukah, or as close as I could get to making one.
Looks similar to a lycon, does it not?”
“Did that w-w-worm… that th-thing… it turned in-into th-this?” Eydis’s jaw shook uncontrollably.
“The peculiar little creature is called a Lurr.
I had you feed it blood from the hounds in the palace, a rodent of unusual size found in the northern highland swamps of the Tolmyur Kingdom, and some High Elves.
Of course, I was also placing food in the crate.
It could not have gotten that big on blood alone.” Jethro chuckled.
“Although, I was rather busy of late playing with the fairies, so I neglected to feed it over the past few days.”
Eydis stared at Jethro in horror.
The anger the Alukah had exhibited was from starvation.
She looked back at the monster that was licking the carpet but could no longer find any blood, or at least enough to satisfy it.
It turned to Jethro and Eydis, now noticing their presence, and charged.
Eydis screamed and climbed over the bed as the Alukah dove at Jethro.
Jethro waved his hand, and the beast was hurled back into the crate which buckled from the impact.
Unfazed, the Alukah charged again.
This time, the beast could not get close.
An invisible wall blocked its way.
The Alukah snarled and screamed in a futile attempt to claw away the barrier.
Jethro peered down at Eydis peaking from behind the far side of the bed.
“Your lesson starts now.”
The Alukah clawed at the barrier but quickly lost interest.
Looking around, it spotted Eydis hiding behind the bed.
It found a new target and lunged.
Eydis expected Jethro’s barrier to stop it, but the Alukah approached unhindered.
It slid on the bed, got caught on a blanket, and rolled off on top of Eydis.
Eydis screamed and pushed the beast away.
She ran to the other side of the room and pleaded to Jethro.
“Do something!”
The Alukah scrambled to right itself, but its erratic movements only served to further entangle it in the blanket.
Jethro flashed a crooked, dimpled smile.
“The palace hounds are highly aggressive, and it takes a lot of training to curb their violent tendencies.
Elves are highly intelligent.
The rodents… I simply used them to help attain the look I was hoping for.
And to be honest, I did not want it to look too much like a lycon.
Personal reasons.
I hope you understand.”
Understand what?!
Eydis wanted to scream.
With the sound of tearing, the beast reduced the blanket to scraps of fabric.
“When Lurr evolve, more than just their appearance changes.
They not only take on the natures of what they feed on, but those natures are also enhanced.”
Now free of the blanket, the Alukah ran towards Eydis.
She tried to flee, but it caught her arms and pinned her on the ground.
Its mouth watered, dripping saliva on her neck.
Jethro sat cross-legged on the bedside table and chuckled wryly.
“He looks hungry.”
Why is he doing this?
What would he gain?
Is this just crude entertainment for him?
Jethro’s statement when he first gave Eydis the creature came to mind like a wraith whispering in her ear.
“The real entertainment is yet to come.”
Eydis wrenched her right arm free and pushed against the Alukah’s face.
In frustration, the Alukah glared at Eydis with its blood-red eyes and bit down on her wrist.
She channeled wind magic into her hand in the jaws of the beast and expelled it with all the force she could.
The blades of wind lacerated the side of the beast’s head.
It released its hold and staggered back.
Now free, Eydis scrambled to her feet, her legs weak and shaking from fear.
Jethro chuckled.
“Realized now that you could fight?
Your flight instincts are far too strong.”
The Alukah wiped his hand down the side of his face, and the bleeding stopped.
“Oh, and Lurr can instinctively use the magic of the species from which it feeds.”
“And life magic is common to High Elves,” Eydis mumbled.
She channeled life ven into her left hand and rubbed her wrist to stop the bleeding and kill any infection that might have come from the bite.
The Alukah charged with a snarl.
Eydis rushed to erect a makeshift barrier in front of her.
The force of the Alukah’s impact into the barrier pushed Eydis, and she stumbled and fell to her back.
The Alukah tried to pin her again, but Eydis had wind ven ready and thrust a wind spear through the beast’s side.
She then used a barrier to push the beast off her and scrambled back to her feet.
Eydis was breathing heavily.
She was exhausted from lack of sleep and could feel her ven levels running low.
Again, the Alukah stopped the bleeding in its side.
He stared at Eydis with bloodshot, red eyes and bellowed an earsplitting, almost elven scream.
He picked up the heavy wooden chair at the desk and hurled it with all his strength.
Eydis barely managed to erect a barrier in time, and the one she created with the little ven she had was insufficient to stop the chair.
The impact knocked Eydis back against the wall, but she was unharmed.
Seeing the chair have no effect, the Alukah picked up the entire desk and hurled it next.
Eydis dove to the side and threw another wind spear at the beast.
The spear hit its mark but did no more than create a minor puncture in the Alukah’s stomach.
It lacked any force.
She was out of usable ven.
Eydis could not draw upon enough for another spell.
She had not trained to use ven below dangerous levels.
Panic rose in Eydis’s chest, but the feeling was interrupted by a familiar, unpleasant metallic aroma.
In Jethro’s hand was another cup of blood.
“If you want some ven back, feel free.”
Eydis’s heart raced with a new sensation different than panic.
Biting her cheek, she ignored the feeling and faced the Alukah.
The Alukah took notice of the cup but continued to focus on the larger prey.
It knew that Eydis could no longer cast any magic.
It charged.
Eydis dodged to the side, but the beast was faster.
It swung its arm and hit Eydis in the stomach.
The impact threw her back against the far wall.
The marble cracked from the force.
Eydis retched air and blood as she fell to the ground.
Very shaken with her lower ribs broken, she stood back on her feet.
“That hit alone probably would have killed me instantly, let alone the impact on the wall.” Jethro poured himself a cup of the bitter brown tea.
“You are fairly resilient.
I am rather jealous.
Oh!
Did I mention that Lurr also have superior physical ability compared to the prey they feed on?
You probably do not want to get hit like that…”
The Alukah ran at Eydis and kicked her back into the wall, splitting cracks across the wall’s full length.
“…again…” Jethro sighed.
The Alukah grabbed Eydis by the neck and lifted her.
He slammed her into the wall.
Small chunks of marble fell from the widening cracks.
The Alukah’s face twisted from the frustration that the wall was breaking faster than his prey.
Eydis could not breathe, and in her shaken mind, she knew that she would not survive another impact or two.
She grabbed the beast’s arm with both hands and dug her fingers in as tight as she could.
Her fingers penetrated its skin and dug into flesh with relative ease.
Eydis gripped harder and twisted.
With two cracks, the Alukah’s arm broke, releasing his grip on Eydis’s throat.
Eydis dropped to the ground and dove into the beast while screaming in anger.
They both tumbled backwards to the ground.
Eydis balled her fists and pummeled the Alukah’s face with a flurry of ill-formed punches.
Her fingers grew rigid, and she scraped and clawed in frantic motions.
The Alukah grabbed Eydis by her hair and threw her off.
She landed on her back next to the large metal crate.
The beast staggered to his feet, his jaw shattered and bent into itself.
Most of the flesh was missing from his face.
He turned to Eydis to retaliate, but his gaze slowly rose above her.
She held the crate high by the torn opening in the corner.
Screaming with all her might, she swung the crate down.
The impact flattened the Alukah to the ground.
When the Alukah tried to stand, Eydis swung the crate down with all her strength.
She swung it down again and again.
Again.
Again.
Again.
Eydis continued until the sky outside the windows grew red from the sunset and she had no more strength to lift the heavy metal.
The flattened crate fell to the floor with a clang.
She still held onto it with one hand, her fingers having gripped so tight that they bent the metal to match their form.
She was panting and shaking, staring at the remains of the beast.
In place of the monster was mangled, bloody gore.
No part of the splattered mound resembled the creature it once was.
Coming to her senses, she remembered Jethro.
She found him sitting cross-legged on her bed enjoying his dinner of steak with wine.
“GAAAAAHHHHH!” Anger welled, and Eydis charged.
But she did not reach him.
Eydis found herself looking up at the ceiling of a different room.
Her chest burned, and she vomited blood.
Around her, broken marble scattered from the remains of a wall.
“The control is much better than expected now.” Jethro examined the destroyed wall as he stepped through.
“I should reward Emer for explaining the trick to stabilize the force.
If I had this when fighting the first princess, my job would have been finished that night.”
Jethro stood over Eydis.
His face expressed honest concern, which struck Eydis as odd given the harrowing experience he had just put her through.
“There is something I want you to see.”
Jethro created a portal that opened to itself above Eydis.
When she looked into it, she could see herself.
Eydis began to hyperventilate.
Tears ran down her face.
What she saw had to be a lie.
That was not her face.
Those were not her eyes.
The watery eyes that looked back at her no longer resembled a polished blue-green sapphire.
They glowed a deep blood-red, the same blood-red she had seen in that monster.
“So, what did we learn from this lesson?
Take your time.”
In a raspy, winded voice that bubbled from the blood in her lungs, Eydis mustered a few words.
“Am I… What am I?”
“You certainly are not a High Elf.”
Truth.
Eydis’s eyes slowly returned to their natural color as she watched her reflection.
Jethro waved his hand over her, and with the mild pain of being squeezed, the filth of the monster that clung to her body and clothes was pulled away leaving her far cleaner than after a long bath.
He then lifted her broken frame with utmost care and carried her to a chair in the center of an adjacent room where an enslaved High Elf was waiting to administer first-aid.
The worst pain subsided as Eydis felt her ruptured organs mend.
“But, I am the first princess.
How… how can this be?”
Jethro began his explanation after taking a seat across from her.
“With the resistance holding onto the hope that the royal bloodline lives, did you truly think that I would leave First Princess Eydis FeAmel of the Amelian Empire alive?”
Eydis looked at him in disbelief, so he elaborated.
“Lurr are creatures that mutate into what they prey on.
You are a special kind of Lurr called a doppelganger.”
Truth.
“They are the exact duplicates created by feeding solely on a single individual over a long period of time, and in your case, you were fed the princess’s blood.”
Truth.
Eydis still did not want to believe Jethro.
She wanted to doubt her ability to tell truth from lies, but from what she had seen and experienced, even without her ability, she knew Jethro was not lying.
“Why did you not just tell me?” Eydis spoke through the tears running down from her dead eyes.
“Did I have to go through all that?”
“Even if I was upfront about your identity, do you honestly think that someone who was raised to believe she was the princess would believe an enemy who claimed she was some monster instead?
Doppelgangers are a dangerous type of Lurr, mainly because they believe they are the original.
If they learn about the original, they become hostile towards it, claiming the original is the fake.
Given the chance, a doppelganger will kill and replace the original by instinct once their evolution matures.
With how much stronger the Lurr is, this creates quite the problem, you see.
To create a safe doppelganger, they must raise it without knowledge of the source.
This is why you were restricted to a very specific location in the palace and were not permitted to show yourself.
If others besides your caretakers were in contact with you, you would likely find out about the true princess.”
Eydis recalled the reaction of the elderly maid on the day of the invasion.
“But… but if I am a fake, why did they create me?”
“To sacrifice you.
My guess is that you are the body double for the true princess, a tool to discard in emergencies in order to save her life.
Although, I will say that your existence is quite surprising.
Doppelgangers are highly dangerous; very few make use of them.
There have been cases in the past, but only for rulers who were extremely paranoid about their own safety.
For some reason, Emperor Yuro ordered one to be created for his daughter.
I am sure his retainers thought him mad.
He wanted to protect her by all means, I am sure.
I would find it amusing if he caught wind of my plans and created you in preparation, but I doubt that was the case given your age.
It must have been for some other reason.”
“Are there others… like me, here in the palace?”
“Keeping too many doppelgangers would only multiply the danger.
Emperor Yuro might have had one, but I assassinated him before the Namie could make the swap.
With the original gone, I’m sure the doppelganger was disposed of, if there was one at all.
You survived because they believed the princess escaped, but they very well could have disposed of you, too.
Instead, they chose to use you as a decoy when we assaulted the palace.
For a race that lives as long as they do, spending a year or so to create another is trivial.
If you died, they could just create another once they recovered the princess.”
The conversation of her guards the night of the assassination finally made sense.
Eydis felt betrayed.
She had thought of Afen as a friend.
Instead, she was just a tool, a monster he was ordered to guard.
“This does not mean you have no value.” Jethro continued.
“The princess must supply blood each day or two until your completion, and doing that for years is quite the commitment on her part.
Lurr grow quickly the more diverse their prey.
I may have only given you three types of blood to feed the Alukah, but each cup came from a different individual to accelerate the growth.
You see, the more a Lurr mutates into an individual, the less that individual’s blood has any effect on its mutation.

The process of creating you would have taken far less time if they used blood from different elves that looked like the princess, but there are races with extremely keen eyes who could spot the differences, spriggans and Melian dryads for example.”
“What is to come of me now?
Am I too… going to be…?” Now that Eydis knew she was not the true princess, she realized she no longer had any political use.
She feared that she would be disposed of as Jethro had mentioned.
“I want to make a deal with you.” Jethro replied calmly.
“A deal?”
Jethro straightened his usually relaxed posture.
“I assume that you have realized from the day I found you that I seek your cooperation.
I offer you the opportunity to become the original princess, to be free of your job as her sacrificial double.
All we need to do is kill the princess.
Only then can you take her place.”
“If I replace the princess, would that not still hinder your desire to silence the resistance?”
“This is where I need your help.
I am stuck here trying to track down the surviving wife of the emperor.
She escaped to the fairies in Vallen, but I can still search.
The princess, however, is in a location that I cannot freely move to.
She is hiding in another world.
If you can capture her in secret and return her to me, you can live freely in her place in that world, and I will have a body to show the resistance in this one.”
Red color crept into Eydis’s eyes.
Why would she ever agree to cooperate with Jethro after what he and his soldiers did to the palace and her people?
Then again, they were not truly her people, were they?
Of course, they did not know that either.
After a deep and painful breath, Eydis calmed herself.
“Why didn’t you just kill me and hand me over to the resistance as proof?
Am I not her double?”
“Do you want me to kill you?”
Eydis tensed, realizing the foolishness of her question.
“You are incomplete and will not be complete for another half a year, maybe?
I already mentioned there are those who could spot the subtle differences.
Also, any specialist in life magic who inspects your corpse would discover you are a Lurr, and this empire has both dryads and elves.
Lucky for us, those in the other world cannot use magic from what I hear.
There is no risk of you being discovered there.”
Red returned to Eydis’s eyes.
She felt the deal was well in her favor, but after the pain Jethro put her and her people through, she did not want him to have his victory.
She would not become his submissive pet.
For now, she decided to play along.
A grin spread across her face.
“I am the true First Princess of the Amelian Empire.
I will help you find that imposter.”
“Perfect!” Jethro exclaimed with a single loud clap of his hands.
“I will teach you everything we know about the other world as well as your nature as a Lurr.
I will continue your spatial magic lessons from where we left off.
I also have someone who can teach you the language.
You are free to keep him in line, and you will probably be required to, to some degree, but do not kill him.”

Chapter 14
“The Spoils and the Spoiled”
Eydis
Eydis lay on her stomach atop a long, slender table.
The leather coating of the table repelled any moisture or oil, and the thick woolen padding underneath made the table so comfortable that Eydis nearly fell asleep.
Slender yet firm hands pressed hard into her back, and the warm oil generously applied to them helped those hands slide over her skin to ease her tense muscles.
Eydis had never before had a massage.

She did not know if the High Elf slave Jethro gave her was any skilled at it, but the forceful hands pressing deep into knotted tissue squeezed out moans of pleasure from Eydis’s lips, so the slave’s methods could not have been too far wrong.
The hands reached Eydis’s ankle and lifted her leg.
The pressure on her ankle was painful, and with a small twist and push into the ball of her foot, her ankle popped.

Due to the thick and heavy chains that were locked around Eydis’s wrists and ankles while she recovered from the damage Jethro had done to her, she was unable to move her feet, and the release of that painful locking pressure sent chills through Eydis’s entire body.
Another moan serenated the room.
Eydis had been chained to a table for eight days.
She knew Jethro injured her so severely to show his superiority, but she also felt that he went overboard and had no reason to cripple her.
She did not doubt he could have easily restrained her in her rage but chose instead to attack.

It was like he gave her that experience to say, “Choose how you want to be treated.” At least he had prepared a highly capable medic to heal her and mend her broken bones, something that was incredibly difficult even for skilled life mages.
That same medic was now dipping her hands in oil again and heating them over glowing coals to continue the massage.
She was Eydis’s property, a present from Jethro out of gratitude for her cooperation.
“The reason he kept me chained to a table was to make me all the more grateful for my treatment now,” Eydis mumbled, knowing well that was a lie.
Jethro had not made the order to chain her, at least not directly.

He ordered her medic to do all within her power for Eydis to make a full recovery, and her medic made the decision that Eydis’s injuries were too severe, and so she needed to remain completely immobile until treatment finished.
Aside from the orchestrated fight with that monster and the magic that injured her, magic he only cast because she attacked him, Jethro had treated her well.
He visited her every day of her recovery with honest, heartfelt concern, which aggravated her to no end.
Eydis would have preferred to heal herself and have as little contact with Jethro as possible, but she was unable.
The ven she used in her fight during the invasion and against the Alukah never recovered.
This was the topic of the first lesson on the Lurr that Jethro gave on his daily visits during Eydis’s recovery.
The Lurr do not recover ven naturally like other species.
They must drain it from others.
This was one of the benefits of Eydis’s massage.

Not only was the slave working out the tension in Eydis’s body, but physical contact also drained ven from the victim at a rate proportional to the amount of contact; however, the drain was no greater than the victim’s natural ven regeneration.
It was the slowest method and the only one available to Eydis because she refused the next two.
The second most efficient method to drain ven was intercourse.
Using sex to recover ven was not unique to Lurr.
During intercourse, the ven of both partners slowly equalized.
If one partner had excess and the other had a shortage, the excess would flow into the lacking partner.
The difference for Lurr was that the flow did not stop when equal.
A Lurr would take all the ven it could until their partner was empty and unconscious from ven exhaustion.
The strongest form of drain was predation, or in a lighter form, drinking the blood of their prey.
Drinking directly from the source was best, but even drawn blood worked so long as it was fresh and had not sat long enough for the ven inside to disperse.
Fresh blood or predation also had the effect of mutating the Lurr to resemble their prey, which Eydis shuddered to remember having raised the Alukah herself.
This option was not possible because her prey was the princess.
If she wanted to drink the princess’s blood, she had to find her first.
Any other prey would cause drastic changes to Eydis’s appearance because of the purity of her evolution as a doppelganger.
Jethro’s lecture on Lurr only encompassed the first day of her recovery.

The remaining seven involved instruction in spatial magic from hardening her barriers and honing them to an edge to a strange new form of instantaneous teleportation called transmission that used less ven than traditional teleportation.
Its benefits did come with a few weaknesses.
It could only be used on single targets and was rather conspicuous.
It could only send a nearby target to a location, never from some distant location to the caster.
The transmission formulas were incredibly complicated, so much so that Eydis couldn’t even understand the most basic concepts at first.
Most of her recovery time was devoted to learning them.
Any practice had to wait until she recovered her ven.
At the rate her ven was recovering from the massage, she would have replenished about an eighth of her supply by the time the large bowl of oil ran out, and that would take the majority of the day.
It was far too slow.
Large beads of sweat dripped from the slave’s chin by the end of the massage, and her arms quivered in exhaustion from the strenuous work.
What little strength remained in those arms bathed Eydis as their final labor for the night.
Eydis stretched on a thick rug in front of the fireplace in her new room to dry.
She was no longer imprisoned and could now leave her room at her leisure.
She could call for any servant or service she desired.
This was better treatment than her false father had ever given her.
The room was far grander than her two past imprisonments by the emperor and Jethro.
The walls were engraved with mountain scenery and overlaid with silver accents.
The curtains of the two crystalline windows were likewise woven from silver thread.
The color pallet was rather dull compared to the west wing guest room, but that was perhaps due to the tastes of its former owner.
Apparently, it had belonged to one of the wives of the emperor, not that Eydis cared.
Her indoctrination as the false princess had been tossed away now that she knew what she was.
She also questioned whether she should keep the name “Eydis” now that she knew she was not the true First Princess of the Amelian Empire.
Names one after the other tumbled around in her mind: Galeiv, Rulen, Sermil, Eyden… Each one felt wrong, but the last felt the least wrong, perhaps due to the similarity to her current name.
When voicing “Eyden” to herself in no more than a whisper, the wrong feeling became physical nausea.
Something deep within her was telling her that “Eyden” was not her.
She was “Eydis,” and she could not be called by any other name.
Giving up on renaming herself, or at least postponing the thought until some unknown time in the future, she called her slave.

At Eydis’s order, the slave retrieved the three reports Jethro had prepared for her: information on the missing princess, the current state of the Amelian Empire, and what knowledge they had of the other world.
Eydis sat cross-legged by the fireplace and ordered the slave to sit beside her and hold her so she could recover ven as she read.
The Amelian Empire’s court magician and the princess’s instructor, Emer, was drugged and in captivity in northern Tolmyur to extract information on the empire and share his knowledge of magic.
Ceil, the emperor’s surviving wife, was still missing but was last located among the fairies in Vallen.
Genocide of the fairies hiding the wife continued, and an estimated third of the population was expected dead.
Eydis felt ill reading the reports on Vallen.
Even though her life until now had been a lie, deep within her she still felt the fairies were her people.
Over half the races in the Empire had sworn non-aggression pacts with the Tolmyur Kingdom and were providing all information requested of them with additional sovereign states following by the day.
Resistance groups in Amel were growing due to the lack of government control and leadership, leading to increased crime and poor living conditions.
Eydis skimmed through the information only looking at what she could use against the princess.

The state of the Amelian Empire should mean little to her now that she planned to stay in the other world, but she still felt remorse over what had become of the empire she was raised to believe was hers.
The documents on the other world were a confusing mess of assumptions, poor descriptions, and pure fantasy.
Large, metal, automated carriages.
Moving paintings.
Eydis found what was written difficult to believe, especially when the report said that magic did not exist.
The city in which the princess was believed to be hiding was populated solely by sotnum, which Eydis did not understand at first.
Thinking back on her education on the races and peoples of her world, she recalled that the sotnum were humans.
If these reports were written for her, Eydis felt they should have used the Amelian names for the races instead of Tolmyurin.
In any case, a land of humans made finding the princess difficult due to human similarity to High Elves.
The population of the city was large, rivaling Amel if not larger, but the city had no walls or military.
No armed city guards patrolled at any time of the day or night.
It was completely defenseless.
The only reason an invasion had not been planned was due to the fear of an unknown technology or entity powerful enough to remove the need for walls, military, and guards.
Eydis leaned back into her slave and set the documents aside.
“I am going to live in such a bizarre world?
No amount of reading will prepare me for this.”
In addition to practicing her spatial magic, Eydis had to put all her efforts into learning the language of the city, English, because the princess would likely be fluent by the time Eydis arrived.
Eydis stood and pulled her slave to her bed.
She ordered the slave to disrobe so she could hold her in full body contact throughout the night to recover ven while she slept.
Her English lessons would begin the following morning.

* * *
Eydis climbed the white-marble steps to the top floor of the palace with no shortage of unease.
Jethro’s brief description of the human from another world who would teach her English, Austin, left the impression of one who was dangerous or otherwise hard to control.
She steeled herself in preparation for their meeting.
She had no idea what to expect from a man from a world with such bizarre magical technology, what he could be capable of.

She stood in wonder before the large and extravagant doors of the former emperor’s chambers, carved from a single massive tree of dark red wood without a single crease or fracture in the woods grain from being cut or fused together.
The door depicted the emperors and empresses of the past, but Eydis did not know their names.
This brought the realization that her education as the fake princess was truly lacking.
Her retainers only taught her what was needed to be a double, not act in any real position of power where the history of her people or the knowledge of governance might be required.
The two giants at the door announced her arrival, or so she assumed.
The words they used belonged to none of the fourteen political languages she had learned.
A voice on the inside called back, and the two massive guards pulled the doors open with ease as if the heavy wood glided on air.
Eydis had thought her new room regal, but it could not be compared to the grandeur of the emperor’s lounge.
Carved marble inlaid with rare metals fashioned images of lords and lands, mountains and forests.
Thick columns rose along the walls merging into intricate carvings of spiraling biological geometry across the high ceiling.
How many lifetimes had been spent in the creation of a single room?
Without a doubt, no room in all the world could compare, and yet Jethro had not claimed it for himself.
Why would he allow another to stay in such grandeur that should have been his right as spoils of war?
Did Jethro not care for wealth and luxury?
What other purpose would he have to conquer the Amelian Empire if not for the wealth it possessed that the Kingdom of Tolmyur lacked?
The pale-faced human named Austin sat at the center of the lounge on a masterfully embroidered, padded sofa with a woman embracing him on each side.
Before she approached, she caught a whiff of deshalu, a horrid and addicting herb that had lost her the first maid of her memory.
Or perhaps, she was given a maid the palace knew was an addict because she was not the true princess but some double instead.
The thought soured Eydis’s mood, but she kept a calm expression as she approached.
Sure enough, his eyes are dilated, Eydis thought to herself.
At least the herb was not debilitating, so hopefully the man retained his reason.
Austin was tall for a human, close to Eydis in height.
He had short, dark brown hair, brown eyes, and a short, unkempt beard.
Had he not been so pale, Eydis would have expected him to be Tolmyurin.

He wore clothing of tight fit and high quality: pants of thick blue fabric and a long-sleeved shirt decorated with black and red vertical stripes with small black buttons running down the red placket.
Eydis had never seen their like before, and she could not imagine such clothing originating from Amel and especially not from Tolmyur.
He must have come from the other world as Jethro claimed.
Both women embracing him wore nothing more than a thin, transparent blue shawl about their shoulders.
No fire burned in the fireplace, so Eydis wondered if they clung to the man to ward off the chill in the room rather than out of obligation.
Winter was only half spent, so Eydis certainly found the lack of fire odd.
Perhaps this man preferred the warmth of women over the heat of a flame.
She found the thought unsettling that he might have given them no other choice but to hold him or remain cold in their underdress.
The woman on his left had short, thick brown hair that stuck out in all directions and long, drooping, pointed ears with a line of fine brown hair along the top edge.
Her nose and cheekbones were highly freckled as were her shoulders and upper arms.
Her chest was more endowed than other races of elfkind, and her thick, medium length tail had a small tuft of brown hair at the tip.
The troll, or Mountain Elf, looked at Eydis with surprise and then shame in her deep-orange eyes.
On Austin’s right sat a spriggan, a Forest Elf.
Her smaller stature was common among women of her race.
She had fair skin and faded brown hair.
Her ears were far shorter than other elfkind, similar to humans but narrowing upwards to a sharp point.
What set Forest Elves apart most from other elfkind were their horns and legs.
Two thin horns like single-point antlers grew from the corners of her forehead.
Their digitigrade legs had a more pronounced tarsal joint, looking far more bestial in nature.
Her slender body was completely hairless and sported one of the longest tails of the elfkind, meant for keeping balance in trees and while sprinting over uneven forest terrain.
The Forest Elf clung to the human with distressed white knuckles as he played with and wrapped her long and elegant tail around in his hand.
Eydis’s stomach knotted in disgust.
Austin stopped toying with the woman’s tail when Eydis stood before him.
His eyes gradually widened the longer he stared at Eydis until he pushed the two women aside and stood for a better look.
The Mountain Elf scowled at Austin from behind while coddling the panting Forest Elf.
He spoke a few words in that unknown language Eydis assumed was English.
She felt him touch her hair from behind and turned to swat his hand away.
When he was about to touch her again, Eydis grabbed him by the placket of his shirt, lifted him with ease, and threw him into the ground in front of the sofa.
The Mountain Elf watched the treatment smiling through a sneer.
Eydis swiped her hand at the chair to his left.
The intricate carving and exquisite embroidery blew apart in a diagonal line.
The chair buckled inward and collapsed to the floor.
Eydis’s barrier was not sharp enough to cut completely through objects yet, more bludgeon them, but the man gasping for breath on the floor understood her message.
“I am not another plaything given you by Jethro.
You are to teach me English.”
Austin gleaned one word in his confusion.
“English?”
His actions struck Eydis as odd, and she doubted it was because it was from the effects of the deshalu grass.
He was surprised and elated when he saw her.
He was confused when he heard her mention English.
As she was now, Eydis could not communicate with him.

She had no means to question him about the sprouting epiphany that struggled to break the surface in the back of her mind, so she grabbed the man by his shirt and drug him across the lounge into the study, setting him by the desk.
“English,” she ordered again, sitting down in the padded leather chair behind the desk.
The man quickly complied.
The English language was peculiar but not altogether difficult to learn, and despite Austin’s loathsome personality, he was quite the competent instructor.
If only he kept his distance instead of purposefully leaning close into Eydis when inspecting her writing drills, pronouncing each symbol directly into her ear.
Eydis pushed him away for the third time, now with enough force to knock him prone.
About the time Eydis began feeling hungry, the guards called from the door in their deep, reverberating voices.
Austin’s demeanor immediately perked up.
A Forrest Elf girl appeared in the entryway to the study.
She was younger than Austin’s Forest Elf slave; an adolescent with stretched and irritated skin encasing her horns.
The skin was not yet peeling, suggesting she was about two and a half years old.
Full adults nearing three years of age had no skin on their horns.
Her hair was more wheat-colored and shimmered with mesmerizing flecks of silver.
She carried a carafe and platter piled with food on a silver tray and set it where Austin patted the desk.
Eydis was grateful for the perfect timing of the meal and was about to thank the silent server girl, but Justin called for her first before the girl could walk away.
“Rynn.” He patted on his lap.
Rynn turned back towards him and sat on his lap.
Eydis watched in disgust as she broke apart the bread and meat and fed Austin.
All the while he fondled the girl, but her eyes remained dead of emotion.
When Austin reached under her skirt for her tail, Eydis lost her appetite.
She pulled the girl off Austin and handed her the tray.
“I think he has had enough if he would rather play,” she said, irritated.
She leaned down and whispered into Rynn’s ear, “Share the rest with his slaves,” before patting her back to send her out of the study.
Eydis turned to Austin and saw irritation staring back at her.
She grabbed the stack of parchment and slammed it on the table where the platter once sat.
“English,” she demanded.
The next day, Austin kept his High Elf slave with him in the study throughout the lesson.

Unlike the first day, Austin found little interest in Eydis and instead kept his submissive slave close, casting glances at Eydis as if saying, “This is how you should act in front of me.” At least Eydis was rid of his unwanted advances, but the scene before her was no less distracting.
As the lesson continued, Austin grew less interested in instruction and more interested in his slave until he led the High Elf out of the study.
“Symra,” he called as he pulled the Elf out of sight down the long, suspended corridor to the bed chamber.
Eydis gripped the edge of the desk in frustration.
The force of her grip split the polished wood and shattered it into splinters in her hand.
Jethro ordered her to learn English from this man.
He must have known Austin would react adversely to her recalcitrance and refuse to instruct her.
Eydis could not bear the thought of submitting to this human filth to fulfill her agreement with Jethro.
In Austin’s place, the Mountain Elf entered the study.
She stood beside Eydis and bowed low.
“I apologize for my master.
When the commanders come for lessons, he is far more amenable.”
“No matter,” Eydis spat.
“I am not here to control him.
I only need to learn.
Can you teach me?”
“Yes.” Symra picked up quickly from where Austin left off, and due to her ability to speak both English and Elven, Eydis felt Symra’s instruction was far more effective.
A thought crossed Eydis’s mind that Austin knew Symra would be better suited to instruct her initially but chose instead to teach her hoping to molest her like one of his slaves.
Now that he realized Eydis would not submit, he left the work to Symra.
A call from the doors announced Rynn’s arrival.
Like the previous day, she carried Austin’s meal.
He ate an absurd amount, two times during Eydis’s lesson the previous day.
If he ate so regularly, he would have four to six meals a day.
This kept the servant girl busy running back and forth between preparing food in the kitchen on the bottom floor of the palace and carrying it to the emperor’s chambers on the fourth floor.
Eydis called to Rynn as she was about to turn down the corridor to the bed chamber.
“He will not be wanting his meal right now.”
Rynn only glanced back at Eydis with weary eyes and continued into the corridor.
Eydis stood to retrieve her out of fear for the girl, but Symra gripped Eydis’s wrist.
“This is not her first time witnessing such acts of cruelty,” Symra spoke with ire.
“It is better for her to appease Austin and stay in his service where Dyas, Wian, and I can watch over her than for her to be unprotected elsewhere.”
“You surely cannot mean that,” Eydis said, but she sensed that Symra believed it, as the words rang with truth.
“I am the one who brought her to Austin’s attention.
She is safer here.
The alternative is far worse.”
Eydis kept a closer eye on Rynn over the following days, arriving earlier in the morning, staying longer for lessons, and then leaving later in the evening.
Austin grew irritated that Eydis spent so much time in his chambers, especially because she forcefully intervened whenever his actions grew too intimate with anyone.
As expected, Symra continued teaching every lesson until Eydis caught up to her ability in English, far faster than both Symra and Austin anticipated.
Much to both Eydis and Austin’s displeasure, he had to continue the lessons from then on, but Eydis set strict rules.
“You will not touch Symra, Dyas, or Wian.
You will not touch Rynn.
You eat.
You sleep.
You teach.
Nothing else!”
Eydis would keep him so occupied teaching her English that he would not have the time to satisfy his lust.
She even sacrificed the time she needed to practice the spatial magic Jethro taught her.
Austin wanted to control her, but she would not be controlled.
He grew more tired and more irritated as the lessons continued.
The more troubled Eydis saw Austin, the happier she became.
She realized that just as she had been ordered by Jethro to learn English, Austin had been ordered to teach it.
She held that order against Austin like a knife to his throat.
She was confident in her ability to win this power struggle, at least until Austin found the one weakness Eydis had no control over.

On the morning of the seventh day after Austin was forced to personally instruct Eydis in English, Eydis arrived to find Symra and Dyas huddled almost out of sight near the lit fireplace on the far side of the lounge.
Austin and his third slave, Wian the Forest Elf, were nowhere to be seen.
Eydis thought to call out to Austin to begin the lesson, but Symra waved Eydis over.
Eydis thought they knelt near the fire for warmth, but she had been horribly mistaken.
Symra held Rynn in her lap while Dyas ran her hands over the girl to heal the numerous bruises on Rynn’s face, breasts, and stomach.
The dried blood on Rynn’s chin showed that either her lip had split and was mended by Dyas, or the abuse was severe enough that she spat up blood.
Eydis reached down in horror.
Her fingers clasped a small garment discarded on the floor beside them.
It was a bloodstained blue shawl, the same that Austin’s slaves wore.
“When did this happen,” Eydis asked, gripping the loathsome fabric close to her chest.
“She was no more than a servant girl yesterday.”
“Austin made the request to Jethro after you left,” Symra spoke softly with a growl deep in her throat.
“I did not realize.
We were asleep when Rynn arrived.
She never cried out.
I woke to the beating and stopped Austin before worse could happen.”
“Where is he,” Eydis demanded, her eyes blazing red.
“Wian is keeping him occupied so we can treat Rynn,” Dyas answered.
“I thought things would be better for her here…”
Eydis wanted to scream, to berate Symra for promising that Rynn would be safe so long as she and Dyas could watch over her, but she also felt she was not blameless in this.
In her attempt to keep Austin too occupied to spend time with his slaves, she had instead made him more violent towards the weakest of those within his grasp.
The more Eydis asserted her control, the more his slaves, the more this innocent Forest Elf girl, would suffer.
She realized her folly.
Control over Austin was not important.
She could tolerate him.
He could do nothing more than annoy her or inconvenience her.
This young girl on the other hand was completely at the mercy of Austin’s whims, his violence and abuse.
With one word, he could have her killed or even kill her himself without any repercussions.
Neither Symra, Dyas, nor Wian could act against him.
Eydis was not the true princess of the Amelian Empire, but that did not make Rynn or Wian or Symra or anyone else under Tolmyur’s oppression any less her people.
She could not save everyone.
She could not defeat the whole of Tolmyur’s armies.
However, there was something she could do within her power.
If nothing else, she was the only one here who could save Rynn.
“Where is he,” Eydis demanded again.
She stood to head for the most likely location, the bed chamber down the long corridor connected to the lounge, but a hand clasped her ankle.
Rynn looked up at Eydis with swollen eyes that could open no more than a slit.
“Please… no… I’m fine… I’m fine… I have to… I have to…”
Eydis’s heart collapsed in her chest hearing Rynn’s plea not to be saved.
Her fingers grew rigid like talons ready to claw Austin apart if she could find him, but Symra also clasped Eydis’s hand.
“Confronting Austin will not help.”
Eydis understood.
She needed to confront the source.
“I will speak with Jethro.”
She tried to teleport directly to the grand council chamber, but a teleportation barrier blocked her entry.
She dashed out of the emperor’s chambers and down the many stairways to the large doors of the council chamber.
A dwarf guard blocked her path.
“Jethro is in an important meeting.
He cannot be bothered.”
The dwarf grabbed Eydis’s arm to turn her away.
Eydis hooked her fingers under the dwarf’s breastplate and tossed him across the hall.
The man landed twenty yards away with a metallic thud.
Two human guards drew their swords.
Eydis released an offensive barrier with a wave of her hand.
Both swords split in half, and the sharp barrier cut deep through the soldiers’ armor.
Blood spilled onto the white marble floors.
A backhand that dented each of their helmets knocked the soldiers unconscious to the floor.
The final human soldier about drew his sword but thought better of further antagonizing a Lurr and stepped out of Eydis’s way.
Eydis pushed open the doors after he announced her arrival.
Jethro sat cross-legged on the throne conversing with a group of armed humans.
Four fairy corpses sprawled before him in pools of blood.
A fifth fairy shouted praise to Eydis seeing the bloodied guards behind her but was immediately ran through by a sword and tossed next to the other bodies.
“To what do I owe the honor of your uninvited visit?” Jethro asked.
Eydis approached the throne with her eyes blazing red.
The men in front of Jethro aimed their blades against her, but Jethro ordered them still and simply extended the palm of his hand.
“I do not think you want a repeat.
Are you so willing to throw away our agreement and die meaninglessly?”
Jethro’s simple warning stopped her advance.
She knew she could not defeat him.
That was not her intent in coming, but her seething anger kept her body rigid.
Eydis tried to voice her feelings through her quivering anger, but her mouth only uttered a few simple words.
“Why a child?”
Jethro’s expression grew oblivious.
Eydis did not doubt he could have made the connection after Austin’s request last night, but in case his reaction was not an act, she elaborated.
“Austin, that man you brought from the other world, why did you agree to give him a child slave?”
Jethro’s sent his men out of the council chamber with the bodies.
“I am not sure what you are so angry about.
I thought she was an adult according to your elfkind.
Something about independence defining maturity?”
“Could you not see that she is still too young?
Would you give a human child of like age to be a slave to some man who would not hesitate to…!”
Jethro held out his hand to silence Eydis.
He relaxed his posture into a slouch and grew a faint smile.
All regal demeaner vanished, same as every time he would speak with her after she agreed to help him.
“I will admit that it does please me to learn there are some people in this world who do question such appalling behavior.
Such things are far too common in this horrid, primitive world.
For your concern, you have my thanks.”
“If… if you also see it as wrong, then why do you allow it?
Can you not set her free?” Eydis could not comprehend Jethro’s response.
From what he said, he also felt Rynn was too young to be a sex slave.
Jethro’s words instilled a feeling of unease in Eydis, and when she thought more on what he said, the unease became horror.
In all her interactions with Symra, Dyas, and Wian, never once did any of them question their roles as Austin’s slaves.
No matter how much they detested it, they accepted it.
“Why?
Because she chose this herself,” Jethro replied with mild disgust.
Truth.
Eydis could not believe what she sensed in Jethro’s reply.
What?
She chose…?
Why?
Eydis mouthed the words, but her voice could not speak them.
“I hope you are not under the assumption that I simply gave the girl to Austin at his request.
I sent him away and called for her to meet with me first.
I told her of Austin’s request and warned her about exactly what it would mean to be a slave to such a man, that she would not just remain his personal chef.
She would lose all the protection inherent in working under me.
From her reaction, the girl most likely understood without me needing to explain it.
I gave her full liberty to refuse.
In the end, she agreed to the role despite my warnings.
“I want you to know I have no interest in such things.
To be honest, I find the practice barbaric, but that means little.
While my commanders follow my every instruction with exactness, the common soldier, even those here in the palace, is less… disciplined.
In all my authority, even I am limited in what I can enforce when my men are not under constant watch.
You would not believe what they do to each other…” Jethro sighed.
“A soldier’s right to spoils of war,” Jethro whispered to himself after a moment of pause, every bit of him honest in his disgust.
He looked back at Eydis, knowing her keen Lurr ears had heard him.

“You see, all the slaves you have seen thus far, including the one I gave you, worked in the palace and collectively gave themselves to the soldiers in exchange for their mercy in order to protect their friends, families, and the like from similar or worse fates.
Before I gave the first three to Austin, they were already in the hands of my men by their own will.
That girl understood that should she refuse, someone else would be given to Austin instead.”
“Then it was no choice at all!” Eydis gritted her teeth.
Everything Jethro said may have been true, but that did not make it right.
She now understood Symra’s warning, why being a server girl for Austin was better than the alternative.
Her chest constricted at the realization that Rynn may have already fallen prey to the soldiers before entering Austin’s service as a chef under Jethro’s protection.
She now understood the events that transpired last night.
Rynn accepted and justified the necessity of her self-sacrifice, but when faced with her trauma once more, she grew fearful and resisted.
She was already Austin’s slave by then, and Austin expected perfect obedience from his slaves.
Symra intervened while he was beating Rynn into submission.
Or it could very well be possible that Rynn did not resist, and Austin beat her nonetheless, the wretched human that he was.
But, no matter what Jethro professed, one of his authority should have been able to deny Austin’s request.
Even now, he should be able to correct it.
Eydis calmed herself and pleaded to Jethro.
“You are the ruler of Amel, the commander of all Tolmyur’s forces.
Releasing Rynn should not cause issue.
If my cooperation in finding the princess has earned me anything more, please give Rynn to me.
You should at least be able to do that much.”
Jethro gazed with weary eyes at Eydis’s suppliance and shook his head.
“That, I also cannot do.
When she was among the kitchen staff, I was her owner as conqueror of Amel.
I have an agreement with Austin to reward him for his services, and for instructing you he personally requested the girl as his reward.
As I mentioned, she agreed and is now the private property of Austin, not me.
I detest going back on my promises, so I will not take her back.”
A dimpled grin grew on Jethro’s face.
“It is his choice whether or not to free her or gift her to another.
This discussion is between you and him.”
That was permission to act against Austin.
Eydis was sure of it.
If Rynn could be hers, no one would be allowed to touch her.
She ran out of the council chamber, barely catching Jethro’s parting order.
“Remember not to kill him!”
Once outside the teleportation barrier, she teleported directly to Austin’s lounge.
Symra and Dyas remained by the fireplace with Rynn.
Austin was still missing, and if Wian was keeping him company, he had to be in the bedchamber.
Eydis ran down the long, suspended corridor and found Austin with Wian atop his bed.
Eydis dove onto the bed and threw Austin off.
He flew into the wall and fell to the floor with a pathetic cry.
“Leave us,” Eydis ordered Wian.
Instead of gratitude for Eydis’s intervention, Wian grew terrified of Eydis’s glowing red eyes and sprinted from the room.
“You!
You are not her!” Austin yelled at Eydis from across the room.
He struggled to stand using the wall as support.
His eyes were heavily dilated.
The wretched addict.
“You are not Eydis!
You are nothing like her!”
Eydis jumped off the bed, grabbed Austin by the neck with both hands, and pinned him against the wall.
He grabbed her arms, trying futilely to peel her off.
Her grip tightened until saliva drained from his mouth.
She wanted to squeeze.
She wanted so desperately to feel flesh tear and his neck pop in her hands, but she stopped.
Jethro ordered her not to kill him, and while she desperately wished she could, she had even more reason to stay her hand for now.
That lingering epiphany from the day she met Austin found clarity.
Eydis spoke in a subdued voice.
“You know the other Eydis.
You met her in your world.
I was going to kill you here, now.
You have luck.
Now I cannot.
Jethro wants to find the other Eydis.
He wants to kill her.
You teach English to help Jethro kill Eydis.”
Austin’s eyes grew wide.
“Gi… goulgng… gurt…”
Any attempt to speak came out as broken gargles, so Eydis eased her grip.
“I wouldn’t hurt her!
Gah… I don’t want to kill her!”
Austin saw the princess with the same lustful eyes as he saw Symra and the others.
Eydis released her grip, dropping Austin to his knees gasping for breath.
“The other me is my… sister.
You want to help her?
If you help me find her, stop Jethro from killing her, I will not kill you.”
“But if Jethro finds out, he will kill me!”
“If you say no, I kill you now.” This was no lie.
If Austin declined, Eydis was ready to crush his head into the wall with her heel like a vulgar pest.
If he was unwilling to help, his knowledge of the princess was far too dangerous to keep him in association with Jethro.
She could find an excuse to appease Jethro afterwards.
“I traded my freedom for women and luxury.
He will not let me.
He only lets me leave the room for official work.”
“Work like making Rynn one of your slaves,” Eydis howled, making Austin shrink further.
She quieted her voice once more.
“Jethro needs me to find my sister.
I will say I need you.
He will listen.
We stop Jethro and help Eydis.
Say yes or die.”
Austin hesitated, so Eydis punched the wall beside his head.
The stone fractured, sending shrapnel into the side of his face.
Small cuts dripped blood from his ear and cheek.
“Yes!
Yes!
I’ll help!”
A grin spread on Eydis’s face.
His terror pleased her.
Only one more matter needed to be addressed.
“Thank me for not killing you.”
“Thank you!
Thank you thank you thank you--”
Eydis crouched down and grabbed his mouth.
“Not words.
You give me Rynn.”
Their noses nearly touched.
A menacing grin that threatened to devour Austin grew on Eydis’s face.
Eydis pulled his face near to look into her glowing red eyes.
Her eyes radiated such a deep crimson that they almost exuded visible heat.
Tears budded in Austin’s eyes and he nodded to the best of his ability while she held his face.
Eydis slapped the side of Austin’s head, knocking him unconscious.
Hopefully that would give Symra, Dyas, and Wian a break.
She could forego lessons for the day or possibly read one of the many books brought from the other world.
She found them immensely fascinating.
Eydis tore down one of the long, gilded curtains from the bedchamber windows and returned to the fireplace of the lounge.
Wian knelt with the others next to Rynn.
Dyas no longer healed Rynn so perhaps she finished.
The swelling of Rynn’s face was noticeably less.
Rynn saw Eydis approach and opened her eyes a little wider than before.
“Is he,” Symra began, likely having heard some yelling on the other side of the long corridor.
“He is alive.
Jethro would be furious if I killed his English instructor, and I need to continue learning the language.”
Symra looked disappointed, but she must have realized that with Austin gone, they would all be back in the hands of the soldiers.
Or perhaps her disappointment came from knowing the reason Eydis needed to learn English: to pursue the true princess.
“I expect he will treat you a little better now that he fears me,” Eydis added, unable to fully address Symra’s unspoken concerns.
She knelt next to Rynn and lifted the frail girl.
She pressed their foreheads together.
“I am taking you from this place.”
Rynn showed emotion for the first time.
Tears fell silently from the corners of her eyes.
Eydis wrapped Rynn in the regal fabric and carried her down to her room on the third floor of the palace.
Jethro justified his actions by stating this was Rynn’s choice, but Eydis could not see Rynn as anything but a helpless child forced into slavery by Tolmyur.
This further fueled her anger against Jethro, Austin, and all the depraved humans who relished subjecting one so young to such suffering.
She tended to Rynn the entire day with the help of her own slave.
Dyas was not a well-practiced life mage, leaving most of Rynn’s worst injuries unfinished, so Eydis’s slave continued the treatment.
Now understanding the truth of the slaves she saw in the palace and the one given her by Jethro, Eydis apologized profusely for her ignorance and exploitation of the woman’s situation.
As much as Eydis tried to separate herself from the Amelian Empire now that she knew what she was, she couldn’t.
These were still her people.
Whether Eydis was the true princess or a Lurr, Rynn was someone she should have protected.
Rynn’s mental and emotional scars may never heal like her physical injuries, but she survived.

Eydis could not right all the wrongs of the Tolmyur Kingdom, and she doubted that she could free Rynn without her falling back into Tolmyur’s grasp, but perhaps she could keep her close and personally protect her from all the evils of the world.
Eydis wrapped Rynn in a warm blanket and held her tight through the night to comfort the girl that cried silently in her sleep.

Chapter 15
“Revival of the Old Ways”
Eydis
Eydis knelt on the floor mat with her weight resting on her ankles, her legs close together, and her hands clasped in her lap.
She was told this kneeling posture was called seiza in this world and had originated in a land far to the east.
When Eydis looked up the word on her smartphone, she noticed there were similarities, but the purposes were different.
In the land of its origin on Earth, the posture was used for respect or reverence.
In Eydis’s training on Whinhlem, it was used to make recognition of the flow of ven through the body easier by eliminating the physical sensations of the body, namely the legs where veins were large.

The confusion of its origin led Eydis’s students to believe she learned her martial skills in the eastern countries, and many of them had come to the conclusion that Eydis was what they called a spiritualist.

This led Eydis to believe that there may have been those in the past who knew about magic, which made sense considering Earth had multiple words for ven, such as mana, but now the true practice of the art was lost, only replaced by empty motions.
The thrice weekly self-defense class changed in structure under Eydis’s supervision.

A month after Eydis began teaching, the hour-long course that held a ten-minute warmup and stretch period and ended with another ten-minute cooldown and relaxation period changed to a two hour session with fifteen minutes of meditation before the initial warmup and final cooldown.

With an increase in length, a properly skilled instructor, and a curriculum created by the professor in charge with Eydis’s input, once the new year began, those who attained a two-thirds attendance in the course over a two-month period could receive one of what was called a Physical Education and Conditioning credit.
Eydis was informed that a certain number was required of the students by the university.
With university credit available for the course, the number of students attending quadrupled when courses renewed in January.
“Sammy, do not move.
The discomfort is part of the meditation.” Eydis stared sternly at her friend who shifted her legs to relieve the numbing tension.
“This is harder for some of us, you know,” Sammy whined.
“All the more reason to grow accustomed to it.
Eventually the pain will lessen, and you may begin to feel a flowing sensation different from the numbness you felt before.
It is very subtle, but that is what I want you to focus on.”
After another five minutes passed, Eydis stood and gave the position in front of the students back to the professor who in turn told everyone to lay back and relax.
A unanimous sigh of relief filled the room as the students rolled off their numb legs to their backs.
Screams and laughs erupted as friends slapped their neighbor’s legs, causing an assault of needle-like sensations.
Eydis walked to the back corner of the room to where Justin knelt in the same meditating posture beside one of the rolled-up mats.
The only difference was that he had remained in that position from the start of the class under Eydis’s orders as he had every time he brought Eydis to the class over the past month.
He only left the position when the class, namely Eydis, needed him to act as an assailant for demonstrations, which he did begrudgingly.
“What are you feeling?” Eydis sat down beside him and leaned against the wall with her arms resting atop her knees.
“Not my legs, that’s for sure.
I don’t think I could stand even if I wanted to.”
Eydis flicked Justin’s foot, causing him to wince.
“You felt the direction the sensation flowed up your leg, yes?” Justin nodded, so Eydis flicked his foot again.
“Now instead of that sensation, did you feel any other sensation flowing in a different direction?”
Justin shook his head.
Eydis sighed.
“With so much ven, you should be able to feel something, even if you cannot use it.”
For Justin to recognize the toxic ven his body produced, he needed to first be able to feel the healthy ven in his body.
He would then be able to distinguish between the two.
After a month, he made no progress even though Eydis was using the same methods Evhial had used on her as a child to help her first recognize her own ven.
He was human, so she expected him to take longer, but he should have at least felt something by now.
This was troubling.
If Evhial’s methods did not work, there was little she could do for him.

She made a promise to help him purge his body of the toxic ven to repay him for everything he was doing for her, and hopefully solidify her place in his home as Sammy suggested, but she was struggling to fulfill her promise, making her feel that her dream of starting a new life here was still far away.
Hiding her depression behind a confident smile that told Justin he could succeed, Eydis dug into the bag beside her and pulled out a novel, one of Sean’s.

Having become fluent in English after only two and a half months of conversation and studying grammar books and dictionaries, she decided that reading novels was the next best step of deepening her understanding of the language.

Justin expressed interest in learning Eydis’s native tongue, but aside from explaining simple phrases and the most basic of grammar, she told him that his own studies at the university should take priority and that he was already spending much of his free time learning to recognize and control the ven inside him.
“If you want to learn something, pick one thing and master it, then move to the next.
Elven is not important, and your ven is.
Focus on that first.”
Eydis would repeat this each time Justin asked, but a worry in the back of her mind told her that Justin might not be able to feel his ven no matter how much he practiced.
She had to wonder if there was some correlation between his toxic ven and his inability to feel healthy ven, but she had no one in this world to ask and no way to test her hypothesis.
She would have to find many people with the same condition as Justin and teach them all how to recognize and control their ven, and that was impossible in her current situation.
After an announcement from the professor, the relaxation period ended, and the students prepped to go home.
Sammy bounced over to Eydis and Justin, grabbed a water bottle from Eydis’s bag, and drank half of it in one long swig.
“Any progress for our hopeless man?” she asked.
“None yet,” Eydis replied.
“And you can stop now,” she told Justin.
Justin shifted off his legs and had to use his hands to move them out in front of him to let the circulation return.
After a few seconds, Sammy grabbed Justin’s calf, causing him to reel back and tense up.
“Could you not!”
Sammy laughed.
He tried to grab her but could do no more than lean forward.
Sammy jumped out of his reach and kept laughing.
“Excuse me.
Eydis?”
Sammy’s red-headed friend, Chloe, appeared behind Sammy.
She was half a foot taller than Sammy with a smooth and clean complexion on her round face.
She wore tight black exercise shorts and a white t-shirt that was soaked and slightly transparent from sweat, showing the black sports bra that was needed to support her well-endowed chest.
When Eydis first met Chloe, the girl was overweight, but over the course of the past month, she had done well losing a little.
Eydis still felt that Chloe should lose more, but having seen many women of this world, Chloe could be considered on the healthy side compared to others.
Eydis found that most people of this world would be considered unhealthy in the Amelian Empire, so she understood her views on what was healthy might be different.
One of Eydis’s students even expressed concern that Eydis was too skinny.
“Um, you said something about being able to feel something different when doing seiza.
I don’t know if it’s what you meant, but I think I felt something.”
Eydis closed her book and placed it back in the bag.
“Can you still feel it?”
Chloe shook her head.
Eydis stood and placed her hands just below Chloe’s ears.
“Excuse me.” She then placed her forehead against Chloe’s.
Chloe blushed in surprise.
Eydis separated and sat back down.
“Next class when we meditate, I want you to focus on that feeling and do not lose it.
After the closing meditation, see if you can continue that feeling through the rest period.
If you can, talk to me afterwards.
Can you do this?”
Chloe nodded shyly and then excused herself.
Sammy pressured Eydis for an explanation.
“Ven was in motion inside her body.
She might have natural ability,” Eydis clarified.
“Chloe can use magic?” Sammy whispered, bouncing in excitement.
“I cannot be certain yet.
Everyone has ven.
Having ven does not mean you can use magic.” Eydis looked beside her at Justin who could only grimace in reply.
“Her capacity is small and what I would expect from humans, but her ven is extraordinarily active, unlike you and Justin.
We will have to wait and see.”
The next self-defense class, Eydis performed her job as required but paid special attention to Chloe.
Once the rest period ended, Chloe approached Eydis.
“I had it, but I couldn’t hold on that long.”
Eydis sent Chloe away with the assurance that it was possible.
On the final class of the week, Chloe did not approach Eydis at the end of the rest period.
“Chloe?
Are you okay?”
“What’s wrong?”
“Are you hurt?”
A small group stood around Chloe who refused to move from her position on her back.
One of the students approached Eydis.
“Chloe wants you.”
Eydis set down her book and walked over with Justin struggling to follow on his lifeless legs.
