“I have it,” Chloe said when Eydis approached.
“I don’t want to lose it.”
Eydis crouched down and grabbed Chloe by the hand.
“Keep focused.” She pulled Chloe to her feet.
“Can you still feel it?”
“Yes!”
“Mimic my motions.”
Eydis traced a line with her right hand from her heart to her abdomen and back up the other side.
She then took a step back with her right foot and extended her left arm forward.
She continued the trace across her chest and down her left arm until the fingers on her right hand ended at her left wrist.
Eydis and Chloe repeated this motion four more times with variations in the lines traced by their fingers as if connecting key points in the body and directing them to their left hand.
“Where is the feeling now?” Eydis asked.
Chloe looked at her left arm.
“In my hand.”
“Now repeat it the other direction.”
Eydis and Chloe mirrored the movements with their left hand.
“It’s in my right hand!”
“Is this some sort of calisthenics,” one of the observing girls asked.
“I am unfamiliar with the word, so I cannot say.
Chloe, extend your right hand, palm down.”
Chloe obeyed, and Eydis placed her hand underneath.
She retracted it and then asked each of the seven observers who remained to place their hand underneath as she did, asking if they felt anything.
Each woman said they felt nothing until the last screamed out in surprise.
“It’s hot!”
“Hot?” Eydis pulled Justin inside the group and had him place his hand under.
“Feel anything?”
“Nothing,” Justin replied.
“What is this?” Chloe stood frozen in the position Eydis made her hold.
“You can relax now.
Our bodies have energy in them.
I am just showing you how to recognize it.”
“Like the Chinese chi,” one student piped in.
Was chi yet another word for ven?
“They are probably one and the same,” Eydis replied.
The first translation for ven Eydis learned from Justin, mana, came from the Pacific Islander traditions.
China was located across the Pacific.
Eydis wondered if the people of the far continent were more connected to magic than those on this side of the world.
“For now, Chloe, practice meditation and those movements over the weekend and tell me how it goes on Monday.”
“I’m going to try too!”
“Me too.”
“This is way too creepy.
Count me out.”
While the students discussed with each other in varying levels of excitement, Eydis, Justin, and Sammy left the group and began walking to the bus stop.
“What was that about?” Sammy asked for further clarification once they were outside.
“Chloe is affiliated with the fire element.
I tried to feel her ven, but I could not.
Thankfully there was one there who also has an affinity to fire.
She recognized Chloe’s ven.”
“So we can cross fire off the list of affinities Sammy and I have?” Justin asked.
Eydis nodded.
“Wait, are you doing this to find out what elements we are affiliated with?” Sammy asked.
“That is part of it.
I do not plan on teaching any of them magic.
This world does not have magic users, yes?”
“We might have had some in the past.”
Sammy confirmed Eydis’s suspicions, and Justin followed up.
“A lot of cultures have miracle workers built into their legends.
Even in this country there was something called the Witch Hunts where anyone who was accused of being able to use magic was killed.
Most of the western world has viewed magic as evil, and western influence is the strongest due to western countries conquering, colonizing, or indoctrinating most of the world.”
“And if those who could use magic were hunted, the art of magic would be hidden and lost over time.”
Eydis understood how such a history could be the reason magic did not exist.
If there was a cultural stigma associated with magic use, teaching it would only endanger others.
“But things are probably different now,” Justin continued.
“I think only the most orthodox of people would still think of it as evil.
Most of our generation would probably openly accept it.
There are many books, movies, and games that have magic in them.
The concept is quite popular, even with adults.
But people’s feelings might be different when actually confronted with the real thing.”
Sammy folded her arms.
“It’s hard to ignore hundreds of years of social indoctrination.”
“If I could learn to use magic, I wouldn’t care what others think.”
“Same.”
Eydis had already committed to teaching Sammy and Justin how to use magic if possible out of gratitude for their help and care.
If they had no concerns about it, then she decided to continue.
The only remaining question was the feelings of the students in Eydis’s class.
They did not know anything.
One had already stated that what Eydis taught was creepy.
Her class needed a change.

* * *
The next Monday, a large and loud crowd surrounded Chloe.
She was thinner, having lost at least fifteen pounds.
Such a fast weight loss would make one ill, but Chloe looked happy and healthy.
The only explanation Eydis could find was Chloe’s fire affinity.
Those with an affinity to fire have a high metabolism due to the cost of conversion from raw ven to fire ven.
Eydis did not have the time to confront Chloe before class because the prompt arrival of the professor broke up the excited babble.
She would have to wait until after.
When Eydis came to the front to begin the first meditation, she did not ask anyone to kneel on their mats.
“I am making a slight change to my meditation.”
Several whispers scattered across the room, most of them from the students who stayed behind after last Friday’s class.
“Where I come from, the body is believed to have a special energy inside of it.
Some have called it chi, as in the Chinese chi.
Where I come from, it is called ven.”

When Eydis brought up her idea to reveal the purpose of the meditation to the class, both Justin and Sammy advised against using the word mana, as it was almost directly associated with the use of magic in modern pop culture, religious and cultural history aside.
This led Eydis to use the universal term from Whinhlem.
“This energy is important for health and fitness.
The purpose of the meditation was for you to recognize it.
It was brought to my attention that such things may seem wrong depending on your upbringing.
As such, I am no longer asking you to meditate in the same form I have instructed.
If you have another form of meditation you would prefer, or if you would like to use the time as a rest period, you are free to do so.
I only ask that you do not be disruptive and show respect to those who would like to meditate.
The meditation time will now begin.”
To Eydis’s surprise, the majority of the students continued to meditate in the same manner as they had previously.
Only a few chose to meditate in another position, and the remaining laid down to use the time to rest.
At the conclusion of the class, no one else came to talk to Eydis about any strange feelings they had while meditating.
Most the students surrounded Chloe to ask about her drastic change, and all Chloe could reply was that it was due to Eydis’s meditation methods.
Chloe remained in the room until all the other students left and then approached Eydis, Sammy, and Justin.
“I know there is something going on that you are keeping secret from everyone.” Chloe’s usual timidness was nowhere to be seen.
I knew she would suspect something, Eydis thought while returning her book to her bag.
Chloe would not have had such a drastic change unless she spent a lot of time experimenting with her ven.
Eydis sighed lightly.
Unsure what to say, she looked to Justin who had always been the one to decide what should and should not be told about her origins.
Justin looked up at the inquisitive girl from his seat against the wall.
“What makes you say that?”
Chloe pulled a half-empty water bottle out of her bag and stood it on her palm.
She closed her eyes and stood silent.
The plastic fogged up on the inside.
When Chloe finished, she unscrewed the cap.
Steam wafted out.
She handed the bottle to Eydis.
It was hot.
Eydis’s suspicions were correct.

In one weekend, Chloe had not only found out how to convert raw ven well enough for her to lose so much weight, but she was also able to turn that fire ven into thermal energy strong enough to heat a water bottle.
Eydis turned to Justin and Sammy for direction.
She was not expecting anyone to be able to use magic, especially this fast.
“When I have this feeling in my hands, I can also take things out of the oven without an oven mitt.
I can touch the red-hot coils on the stove.
I lit a match under my hand and the worst that happened was my hand getting dirty.
What is going on,” Chloe asked Sammy.
Sammy looked at Eydis, and Eydis again looked at Justin.
Justin looked back at Eydis but only to ask a question, much to her relief.
“Do people normally progress this fast?”
That was not what Eydis wanted to hear.
The question Justin asked involved information from her world, and she did not want to make any decisions on what should be shared with this one.
She still felt she knew too little about Earth to make any assumptions about what was safe.
Earth’s culling of magic was one such example.
She needed to be careful how she worded her answer.
“For races with a natural affinity, yes.
I was able to as a child after only a few days.
For… For you,” Eydis could not say humans without suggesting she was something different, “learning that fast is extremely rare.”
“So you can do stuff like this too?
What about you, Sammy?
Justin?” Chloe’s eyes lit up.
Eydis looked again to Justin, and he sighed.
She knew he did not like being the one to make these decisions, and yet she kept forcing them upon him, inconveniencing him, which was counterproductive to her goal of securing her place in his home.
“Sammy and I can’t.
All I know is that I have more of that energy than Eydis does.
I just can’t do anything with it.”
“So Eydis can!
I want to see it!”
There was no calming Chloe’s excitement.
Eydis waited for Justin’s confirmation.
“Something small.”
Eydis held her palm out in front of Chloe and channeled wind through, releasing it in small amounts.
Chloe’s long hair fluttered in the light breeze.
“It’s like having a fan on you at all times.
This feels amazing after all that exercise,” Chloe said.
Sammy squeezed in and placed her face next to Chloe’s.
She closed her eyes and basked in the cool air.
“Do you want to feel it too,” Eydis asked Justin.
“I’m fine,” he replied.
Eydis stopped the flow much to the disappointment of Sammy and Chloe.
Justin continued his explanation.
“Eydis doesn’t advertise that she can do this, and it’s very rare.
We tend to keep it secret, so you should as well.”
“Yah, one of the girls in the dorm’s communal kitchen thought I had gone crazy when she caught me burning a match under my hand.
Is all I can do heat things or touch hot things without getting burned?”
Fire was the most dangerous of the natural elements.
If abused, not only could the user become malnourished, but fire once released could become impossible to control.
This was a real fear for Eydis because the ven in Chloe’s body was overactive, although that may have helped her use it as fast as she did.
The worst that could happen with wind was running out of breath and passing out.
Maybe cutting something by accident.
With water, becoming dehydrated was a risk and could potentially be lethal if severe enough.
Earth magic only caused physical exhaustion which, like wind, could lead to loss of consciousness.
To prevent Chloe from harming herself or others, Eydis felt it was her responsibility to teach Chloe how to use her newfound magic.
Thankfully, Evhial had taught Eydis the basics of each natural element even if Eydis could only use wind.
“An affinity to fire magic is dangerous if not controlled.
I can help you learn to use it safely.”
“So it is magic!”
Eydis realized she let the word slip.
Sammy looked behind her to make sure that no one else heard Chloe’s exclamation.
The room was empty.
Eydis looked down apologetically at Justin, but he looked back at her with an expression asking why she was apologizing.
Chloe had clearly made the connection and was only excited that Eydis confirmed it.
It was now Eydis’s responsibility to guide Chloe.
“I cannot teach you here, but if you have time outside of the class when Justin is also free, we can meet.”
Chloe looked back and forth between Justin and Eydis.
“Ah!”
Sammy quickly waved her hand.
“No-no-no, it’s not what you’re thinking.”
Chloe and Eydis planned to meet after each self-defense class in a smaller vacant room in the health and fitness building to continue teaching Chloe how to control her ven.
By the end of the next week, Chloe produced her first flame and Sammy first recognized the flow of her own ven from meditation.
However, Justin still could not feel the ven in his body.

Chapter 16
“A place to call home”
Mid-February approached and with it the snowiest time of the season.
Temperatures hovered at 30° Fahrenheit with an average snowfall of two to three inches a day.
Due to the constant freezing temperatures, the snow piled up day after day.
Snowplows forced the snow to the sides of the road into large banks that were sucked into an even larger vehicle to be taken outside the city.
The bus Justin and Eydis rode trailed behind one such pair of vehicles on its way to the university.
Eydis stared with excitement at the strange new machinery.
“We never get snow in Amel.
Those machines are amazing!
Do they clear all the roads?
Where do they put the snow?”
Justin looked forward to these moments of childlike excitement.
As the weeks went on, they became fewer and farther between.
The last one was earlier the previous week when Eydis discovered Sammy had an elemental affinity to water.
Eydis treated Sammy, Chloe, and Justin at a diner to celebrate.
The next day when Justin and Eydis went shopping, she also bought Sammy a value-sized box of fruit snacks as a celebratory gift.
Justin wished desperately that he could be a cause for such excitement in Eydis.
As the days pressed on, Justin felt that Eydis’s attempts to help him feel his ven left her frustrated and that the daily purging of the toxic ven his body produced was becoming a chore for her.
Eydis was now paying her share of rent and covering her portion of the food, although her food expenses amounted to very little.
She even paid her own phone bill despite Sammy’s claim that it wasn’t needed.
There was nothing Justin was doing for her anymore.
Eydis once spoke of repaying her debt to him, but by Justin’s estimation, she had already far overpaid him.
Justin and Eydis exited the bus at the usual university stop and made their way to the humanities building.
They took the elevator up and knocked on Dr. Shuman’s door.
They only came to Dr. Shuman when either he or they learned of something that might hint of others from Eydis’s world appearing.

The last time they visited, Dr. Shuman brought up the possibility that the increase in missing persons cases on the news might be tied to those who were looking for Eydis, but there was never any evidence other than the increase occurring shortly after Eydis’s arrival in Gullivan, so there was little they could do, and it might be unrelated.
Dr. Shuman agreed to investigate further.
That was the reason Justin and Eydis expected they were called, but instead, Dr. Shuman addressed another topic.
“It’s not an emergency or anything.
Is Eydis still living with you?”
“I am,” Eydis replied.
“Then I guess you did not secure a room at the change of the semester.
I don’t know if you are still interested, but there is a vacancy in a two-person room of the girl’s dormitory right now.
I was able to place it on hold for you if you want it.
You are not a student, but you are working here now, so an exception can be made.”
To Justin’s surprise, Eydis showed no excitement or any emotion at all.
“I see,” was all she said.
Justin followed up on Dr. Shuman’s announcement.
“What building?” He had completely forgotten to look for openings when the new semester came around.
There were sure to be many.
Then again, Sammy never brought it up either.
Before he had realized, Eydis living in his apartment had simply become the natural state of things.
“Four,” Dr. Shuman replied.
Building four placed Eydis on the opposite side of the complex from Sammy.
At least it was closer to campus, and having Sammy closer to Eydis would be a greater benefit to her.
Perhaps Sammy could even arrange a bed swap with the other inhabitant of the room.
“That’s pretty good news.
You should take him up on the offer.” Justin smiled at Eydis, but the look he received in return was one of shock.
Eydis’s eyes shifted from Justin, to the floor, and back to Justin.
She was about to speak but instead stood up and walked out into the hall, closing the door behind her.
Justin looked at Dr. Shuman dumbfounded, hoping for an explanation.
Dr. Shuman leaned back in his chair and stroked his chinstrap beard.
“I have an idea what just happened, but it’s between you and her.”
Eydis ran.
She did not know where to, but she had to find a place to be alone before her emotions overcame her.
Sammy’s words kept repeating in her head, that she could find a new home with Justin and Sean.
She had clung to the hope Sammy gave her after losing her family, her nation, and her very world.
She had done everything that Justin had asked of her.
She followed every single one of Sean’s terms for her to stay, every term except searching for her own place to live.
But, did she not already find her place with them in their home?
Did her desire to earn her place there not fulfill that condition?
Eydis found herself standing in a small lounge down the hall on the opposite side of the building from the elevators she normally rode.
Wide windows overlooked the campus.
In the faint reflection of her face only inches from the glass, she could see the water building in her eyes.
What did I miss?
Eydis mouthed, realizing now just how hard the rejection hit her.
She had lived all her life struggling to live up to the impossible expectations of her father and her people.
She felt crushed under that weight.
Now on Earth after losing everything, she found happiness in a life free of such a burden.
That was her mistake.
The burden did not disappear.
The source of the burden only changed.
“I was a fool to think that Justin’s welcoming nature meant his expectations of me were any less…” Eydis whispered to herself, trying to keep her lips from quivering.
She had grown lax, taken Justin’s kindness for granted, and now he wanted her gone.
Her fears were right all along.
She was an inconvenience to him.
His expectations of her were not the burden.
I am the burden…
Justin appeared from the hall, flustered, and spotted Eydis at the window.
She saw him in the window’s reflection, but she could not turn and meet his eyes.
“Eydis.”
Eydis hesitated to turn and face him, but if she did not respond, she would only inconvenience him further.
Eydis turned, not hiding the emotion in her eyes.
“Eydis?”
Her eyes drifted down to the floor between them.
“I expected it.
I knew it would happen eventually.
It is your apartment, and I have made you sleep on the couch for over three months now.”
Justin scrambled for something to say.
“I was just thinking you could live with Sammy and closer to where you work.”
“Sean told me to get a job, so I got a job.
He told me to pay for rent, so I paid for rent.
You spent more money to feed me, so I paid for my food.
You asked me to help you select healthier food, so I helped you buy food.
You asked me to help around the apartment, so I helped clean.
I did everything I could so I could stay.”
The grand Amelian Palace flashed in Eydis’s mind.
She saw the faces of her mother, Ceil, Symra, and all her servants.
A tear ran down Eydis’s cheek.
“I can sleep on the couch.
You can have your bed.
I do not need it.”
A second tear fell down the other cheek.
She saw the flare light from her window.
She heard the assassin’s words, that she brought this upon herself.
She saw the palace guards die while she fled.
She saw her brothers dead in the central courtyard.
Eydis’s speech quickened.
“I have been a bad teacher.
I will work harder to help you feel your ven.
I will work harder to help you find your element.
I will try harder so you can learn to remove your toxic ven.”
She remembered Emer’s portal, her fear of this unknown world, and the biting cold that first night that could have killed her just as easily as the assassin.
“I will do all the cleaning.
I will learn to cook.
I will pay for all the food.
I will pay for all the rent.
I will do anything…”
And then she felt again the arms supporting her, the blankets laid on her, and the warm smile under deep blue eyes telling her that everything will be okay.
“Please,” Eydis begged Justin.
“I cannot lose another home… Not again…”
Before Justin realized his own actions, he embraced Eydis.
Eydis’s breath was strained and ragged, something Justin had not seen since the first weeks Eydis lived with him.
He was reminded that Eydis had to make an active effort to even breathe in Earth’s atmosphere.
She was not from this world.
Everything new was exciting to her, but it was also foreign and terrifying all the same.
“I’m sorry.
I’m sorry.
I didn’t realize,” Justin said.
Eydis leaned down and rested her forehead on Justin’s shoulder.
“Please…” she repeated, trying to hold back her emotions as she clung tight to the sleeves of Justin’s coat.
“You don’t have to go anywhere.”
Justin walked Eydis to the sofa adjacent to the window and sat her down.
Eydis still clung to him with her head bowed as low as she could, causing flashbacks to when Eydis begged him not to call the police that morning months ago.
She was terrified then, and she was just as terrified now.
Justin hated himself.

He felt that these months he spent with Eydis had been erased and they were back to the first day he met her; all the fun, laughter, and excitement replaced by a fear of isolation and abandonment the same as when she first found herself in a strange and unfamiliar world.
No, it’s worse, he realized.
With all the effort Eydis made to secure herself a place with the people who showed her kindness and took her in…
I threw it back in her face and told her to leave.
“I’ll tell Dr. Shuman that you will be staying with me.”
After explaining the situation to Dr. Shuman, Justin returned to Eydis who had not moved from her seat.
“Dr. Shuman understood and will be releasing the hold on the bed.”
Eydis nodded.

Justin wanted to do something to make up for the pain he caused Eydis, but there was little time before he and Eydis would have to walk over to the health and fitness building to prepare for the self-defense class.
Justin held out his hand.
“Let’s go.”

* * *
The heavily salted walkways crunched under their feet.
Despite the salt, Justin could see a couple of students slip on the slick pathways as he scanned the campus grounds in thought.
Sammy would not arrive until just before the class started, so Justin was left on his own to try and find a way to make amends.
Eydis had already eaten her one light meal for the day, so treating her to dinner was out.
There was a food cart that sold hot drinks along the way.
Justin could at least give Eydis something warm, but he had done this multiple times before, so he did not feel that it would work well as an apology.
Even so, he still bought Eydis a small mint hot chocolate with cream.
When they reached the health and fitness building, Eydis excused herself and handed Justin the half-empty hot chocolate.
He thought it a waste to toss it, so he finished it off.
Eydis liked the mint flavor strong, so it was a bit overpowering for him and numbed his tongue.
Justin removed his coat and unlocked the room.
He rolled out the mats and pulled out focus mitts from storage.
The lesson for this week was practicing strikes that create openings to escape an attacker.
Although he was not being paid, he always set up the class while Eydis changed--a small gesture to make Eydis’s job easier and to fill the time while he waited.
Eydis was nearly seen with her tail and ears while changing in the early days of attending the self-defense class.
Sammy worked with Eydis to locate a changing room with personal stalls to help keep her identity hidden.
Eydis had suggested using a bathroom stall, but Sammy absolutely refused to force Eydis to change in such a dirty place.
The changing room she found on the other side of the building was seldom used due to being more separate from the exercise and other sports facilities.
It also had three private stalls.
No one would see her elven traits there.
Little by little the students showed up for the class.
Chloe walked in with a brown-haired, pixie cut, heart-shape-faced woman and walked over to greet Justin who had just sat down against the wall.
Sammy arrived with Dr. Calliby right when the class was supposed to start.

When everyone wondered where Eydis was, she came in last with a clear face that showed no signs that she had been crying, but once the class started, many of the students noticed something was bothering her.
Eydis began her class as usual with warmup and then instruction.
Justin knelt against the wall below the windows into the hall in his own meditation under her instruction, meditation that wasn’t helping him gain any deeper understanding of his ven.
The time came for the first demonstration.
Out of habit, Eydis almost called out to Justin to join her up front, but she stopped herself half-way into sounding the “J”.
Her beckoning hand hung frozen in the air, and she slowly retracted it.
Justin disliked acting as the assailant.
All this time she had been troubling him.
He even set up the class for her each day, and she could not remember ever thanking him for it.
All her life, others had taken care of such menial tasks out of duty to her as a princess, so she never thought anything of it.
But Justin wasn’t her servant--quite the opposite, he was her savior.
What have I been doing all this time?
Eydis stood silent, sending confused and worried stares bouncing between her students.
The class had to continue, but she could not ask Justin to help.
The moment Eydis was about to ask Dr. Calliby to help with the demonstration, Justin broke his meditation and opened his eyes.
He saw her staring at him.
His eyes met hers for only a moment.
In one swift motion, he pulled himself to his feet and exited the room through the door beside him, pulling his coat with him as he left.
Eydis felt the weight of all her wrongs against Justin pulling her to chase after him and apologize, but the worried stares of her students rooted her in place.
How do I make this up to him?
Eydis felt she would drown in her guilt.
Eydis was troubled, and Justin knew he was the cause.
She kept forgetting what she was going to say, and after a long pause that was far too uncomfortable for him to continue meditating, he knew he had to leave.
Her stare when he opened his eyes proved that his presence only distracted her.
He donned his coat as he left the building and walked into a small clearing around the corner from the entrance.
There he knelt in the snow to continue his meditation.
The best thing he could do for Eydis was focus hard and show her that the training she was providing worked.
He knew people walking by would look at him with questioning stares, but he did not care.
He zoned out the world around him.
When the feeling painlessly left his legs, he focused on any sensation he could detect beyond the numbness.
He tried and focused, tried and focused.
Every few minutes he pinched his leg to see if he could feel a flow different than the numb tinge of pain that wracked his nerves.
After what felt like an hour, he made no progress, the same as every other day.
Justin pulled out his phone and saw that only about twenty minutes had passed, not an hour.
His rush for results was making him lose focus.
Justin breathed deep and relaxed.
He did not pinch his leg anymore.
He stayed in the proper position with his hands clasped in his lap and concentrated only on the feelings in his legs, or lack thereof.
He continued for over an hour, letting Sammy or Eydis find him and call for him to stop.
He was out in the open and not in any hidden location.
They would find him quickly.
Another hour passed by, then another.
Justin thought that the class should have ended long ago but expected Eydis to stay behind and talk with Sammy, Chloe, and the others.
They might even be doing Chloe’s--and now also Sammy’s--magic lesson, but this thought worried him because he always kept watch to make sure no one walked in on them.
Justin opened his eyes and pulled out his phone.
Only a few minutes had passed since the end of the class.
Something didn’t feel right.
He wiped his face and shakily stood.
The circulation now returned to his legs quickly after becoming accustomed to kneeling.
“Justin!” Sammy stomped across the deep snow towards Justin, fuming.
“What did you do to Eydis?”
“Let’s go.”
The snow on the ground was dry, but the snowball that hit him in the face was wet, slushy, and stung.
“She kept staring at the door after you left, and Maddi had to take over for the rest of class.”
Sammy marched closer and tossed another snowball.
This one traveled slower than the first, so Justin avoided it with ease, but his movements were also slower.
“Wait,” Justin pleaded.
“I can explain.”
Sammy tried to grab him, not giving him a chance to speak, but she was slow in the deep snow, so Justin moved his sluggish body out of the way.
Eydis appeared from the corner of the building with Chloe and Chloe’s new friend.
She saw Sammy attacking Justin and hurried to stop them.
“Sammy, wait…”
Sammy swung her fist at Justin who dodged the slow attack.
Eydis’s face lit up in excitement, and the radiant smile of discovery that Justin had longed for grew on her face.
But Eydis’s words were not what he expected.
“Sammy!
Do not stop!
Keep going!”
“Gladly,” Sammy replied, ready to flatten Justin if only she could find the chance.
Justin could not believe what he heard.
Was Eydis that angry at him?
A small crowd of students gathered on the walkway to watch the fight.
Sammy swung at Justin.
When Justin moved to dodge, his body grew slow again, but so did Sammy’s punch.
The punch missed by a large margin.
The trade of slow swing and slow dodge continued.
Sammy grew more and more irritated from being unable to land a single hit.
She reached for Justin’s arm, but Justin batted her hand away and stepped back.
Justin’s foot caught on something beneath the snow, and he tripped backwards.
Sammy did not miss the opening and dove on top, straddling him.
Justin had nowhere to move.
He wished he had taken part in the self-defense class to learn how to escape from being pinned.
Sammy swung at Justin, and all he could do was watch the slow punch make contact with the full impact of a real one.

* * *
Justin woke to a warm feeling on his cheek.
He looked up and saw Eydis leaning over him with an apologetic smile.
She removed her hand from his cheek and greeted him.
“How do you feel?”
Justin was back inside the self-defense classroom.
Sammy sat against the wall below the window behind him with a scowl on her face, and she avoided eye contact.
Justin sat up and saw that Chloe and her friend were with them as well.
“Hold out your hand.” Chloe’s friend came over and placed her hand palm-down over his.
“Another?
I feel nothing,” he said.
Eydis smiled as if she expected the result.
“Humans have a single affinity if any at all.
Miriam has an earth affinity.
With this, we can safely say that you have no affinity to any of the natural elements.”
Justin wiped his face with his hand and exhaled a large sigh.
All Eydis’s efforts and his large ven capacity had gone to waste.
Sammy lifted her head up.
“Don’t give up just yet.”
Justin looked to Eydis for an explanation.
“What does she mean?”
Sammy pulled herself to her feet using the window’s metal frame.
“I think it would be easier to show him.
Justin, stand in the middle of the room.”
Justin complied with Sammy’s orders.
She looked at him, her face filled with disgust.
“Don’t worry.
If I hit you, Eydis will fix you right up.”
Justin had no time to prepare.
Sammy ran straight at him and swung the strongest haymaker she could.
Justin panicked at first but noticed the swing slow down as it approached.
He easily turned to the side and avoided the hit, even though his body was slow reacting to his intentions.
Sammy stumbled having missed her target but managed to find her footing.
“Were you seriously trying to punch me!?
What if it hit!
?” Justin shouted, but then he realized something.
He had thought their fight in the deep snow was what caused both Sammy’s and his movements to be so slow, but that explanation would not work here.
“I seriously wanted it to.” Sammy grabbed Justin’s shirt and pulled his face close to hers.
Her voice was quiet but saturated with anger.
“I had long given up on finding somewhere for Eydis to stay because I understood her fears and anxiety, but the first opportunity you get, you send her packing.
I hope you realize how bad that must have made her feel.
I honestly wish I could have punched you a few more times.”
Justin took a deep breath and returned with Sammy to the group.
He knew he hurt Eydis, and she had every right to be angry at him, but she was not that type of person, so Sammy was acting as Eydis’s proxy.
“Eydis, sorry about earlier,” Justin began, but Eydis cut him off and prompted him to sit in front of her.
She did not want to change the subject.
“The natural elements are all around us.
There is no easy way to tell when someone uses magic of those elements unless you see or feel the result of the spell.
Life magic is included in this for the same reason.
Life is everywhere.

If you have a life affinity, you can sense life if you are specifically looking for it, like when I assess the quality of food, but unless you know the exact life magic you are looking for, you will not notice it.
However, there are affinities outside the natural elements and life magic that force noticeable changes on the world.”
Eydis held out her hand.
“Try to touch my hand.”
Justin reached out but found a solid force blocking him from coming within a few inches of Eydis’s hand.
“Spatial magic is one of these.
Those who are sensitive to ven or have trained their sensitivity can feel when someone near them uses these rare, world-altering magics.
The three rare, world-altering affinities are space, gravity… and time.
I felt something when you were defending yourself, but it was weak.”
Eydis’s eyes fell to her lap.
“I am sorry for telling Sammy to keep fighting you, but I could not let her stop.
I had to be certain about what I felt.
I think you have an affinity for time magic.
I will make it up to you.
I promise.”
Eydis dropped her head apologetically.
Her shaking hands gripped his sleeve.
The effects of Justin’s actions earlier that afternoon still weighed heavily on Eydis’s heart, and now she was distraught for telling Sammy to hurt him.
His mind raced to find a way to make amends when the words Eydis had just spoken struck him.
“Wait, wait.
Lift your head.
You said time magic?”
Eydis raised her head with a weak, forced smile.
“Yes.
You do not have any control over it because you cannot control your ven, but your meditation might have made your body become accustomed to it, so you use it without thinking.”
“How rare is time magic?” Justin asked.
“Very rare.” Eydis spoke with a hint of jealousy growing in her shaky smile.
“Life magic is the most common of the rare affinities, but only because there are many species that can use it naturally, like High Elves.
Next is spatial magic.
Time magic is the second rarest, and it is completely unheard of for a human to possess it.
The rarest is gravity, the affinity my first instructor specialized in.
She was the only one in the entire empire who could use it with any level of skill.
Most people with this affinity can do nothing more than make small objects a little heavier or lighter.
There were maybe one or two others in recorded history who could use it anywhere near as well.”
“So that means…” Eydis nodded.
“We finally know what your affinity is, and it is incredibly rare.”
Justin was elated.
He pulled Eydis into an embrace.
He spoke softly his feelings of regret for his actions earlier that day.
“I’m sorry for what I put you through.” He hugged her a little tighter.
“And thank you.
Thank you for doing all this for me.”
A single tear fell along Eydis’s cheek, and she wrapped her arms around him.
They held this position for a moment, but because either he or Eydis began feeling self-conscious of the onlookers, they mutually parted, but Justin still held his hands on Eydis’s shoulders.
He looked into her watery eyes.
“Your place will always be with me, if you can put up with my thick-headedness.”
Eydis nodded with a bright smile and wiped a tear that was about to fall.
“Everyone thought it was a lover’s spat, and turns out that’s exactly what it was.
Keep it out of class next time, okay?” The unfamiliar voice came from the extra person in the room and was answered by Sammy.
“That is not what happened,” Sammy deflected.
Justin realized that Chloe’s friend, Miriam, was listening to their entire discussion.
Miriam’s face glowed with a vibrant, childlike smile.
He let go of Eydis and looked worriedly at Sammy and Chloe.
“Is it okay for her to hear all this?” Justin asked.
Sammy wrapped her arm around Miriam’s waist, and Miriam in turn rested her arm around Sammy’s shoulders.
“Once she found out she could use earth magic, she confronted us after class and pretty much guessed everything, including that Eydis was an elf and possibly from another dimension.
We had to give in, or she was going to pull off Eydis’s headband in front of everyone.”
“Nice to meet you, Time Lord,” Miriam said with a giggle.
“I am a witch.
Word on the wind says you are involved in something very dangerous.”

Chapter 17
“Revelry and Understanding”
Justin
“““Congratulations!””” A group of women cheered around the table of a secluded booth in the corner of Eydis’s favorite diner.
Justin’s face grew a slight shade of pink from the feminine cheer of his congratulatory party.
Eydis, Sammy, Chloe, and the new addition, Miriam, each held their respective glasses.
Justin finally knew his magic affinity, and it was not just a rare affinity; it was one of the rarest of rare affinities, time.

He had requested postponing the party due to his inability to control his ven, or to at least include Miriam in the focus of the celebration due to the discovery of her earth affinity, but his idea was shot down by both Eydis and Miriam.
“None of you really have a grasp on your magic yet.
And we held a party for Sammy once we found her affinity, yes?”
“Time is much more amazing than earth, and I kind of forced myself on all of you anyway.”
After Eydis and Miriam’s rebuttal, Justin became the sole focus of the party.
The clank of each member’s choice drink echoed lightly in the booth, and the party was under way.
Chloe and Sammy were the only two without an alcoholic beverage accompanying their dinner.
“Why couldn’t you have waited a month to find your affinity?
I would have liked to drink with you.” Sammy looked at her old-fashioned cherry cream soda with mild disappointment.
Chloe only smiled with her raspberry lemonade in hand, extra raspberries.
It was almost a smoothie.
Chloe was the youngest of the group, being only 19 years old.
Sammy was next, turning 21 at the end of March.
Eydis was the oldest by a large margin, but her refugee card stated her age as 21, the age Dr. Calliby mistook her for on Eydis’s first day in the class.
Her birthday was set for June 21st, the closest approximation they could make after Eydis said she was born on the first day of the warm season of her world.
Justin followed at the age of 23 and also had a March birthday.
Miriam was the oldest non-elf in the group but refused to divulge her age when talking about drinks.
Sammy snatched Miriam’s license when she presented it to order her drink.
Miriam had just turned 26 in January.
“We could have made it a birthday celebration for me and Justin too,” Sammy continued.
“You already had your party.
It’s Justin’s turn.
We can always have another.” The mild-mannered Chloe found enjoyment in Sammy’s sulk.
“You do not need to be mad at Justin anymore.
Everything is fine.” Eydis beamed at Sammy.
She knew that Sammy’s mood was in part due to the misunderstanding between Justin and Eydis earlier that day.
“For now, enjoy the party.
I am paying for everything, so do not feel reserved.
I have no use for the money I am saving.”
“This keeps getting better and better!”
Miriam’s excitement grew a magnitude larger.
She immediately opened the menu and began scanning it for her meal.
This prompted a small chuckle from Eydis before she took a swig of her tequila.
Justin saw it during Sammy’s party but was still surprised that Eydis never got drunk no matter how much alcohol she consumed.
He added it to his list of features that proved Eydis was an elf.
When he asked why she chose alcohol if she could not get drunk, she simply answered that she liked the taste.
Apparently elven ale was far stronger, and even tequila would almost pass as a children’s drink.
Justin smiled at Eydis before taking a sip of his own cheap lager with only a 3% ABV.
Although he hated to admit it, he was a bit of a lightweight.
Orders were made, and food was delivered.
“How the hell can you even eat that much?”
“Umm… Magic?”
“You could give any competitive eater a run for their money.”
Miriam chuckled at Sammy and Chloe’s exchange.

Chloe, who required her own body’s energy to convert her raw ven into fire ven, had an extremely high metabolism that she needed to support, but she managed to eat enough to fill out her features and keep from becoming skinny.
She ordered an entire family platter for herself.
It had a full course of meat samples as well as three sides.
“I’m starting to wish I had a fire affinity.
I just don’t have the stamina to keep up with my magic for long.” Miriam’s earth affinity was physically taxing, wearing her out rather quickly.
“But on the positive side, I’ve never had a bad night’s sleep since I found I could use it.
Been sleeping like a baby for the past two days.”
“Yah, you both have benefits, but I get nothing from mine,” Sammy moaned.
“It’s not as nice as you think… My food costs have gone through the roof.” Chloe popped a medium-well strip of steak smothered in spicy barbecue sauce into her mouth.
Her cheeks blushed from the flavor or possibly the heat of the sauce.
After swallowing, she continued speaking while cutting another slice.
“You only have to drink more water.”
Sammy looked at the three glasses next to her gourmet burger and blooming onion.
Two were for water and already had been drained once each because of how much she practiced in their magic lesson just before the party, causing a dehydration headache and a stern lecture from Eydis.
The third was for her soda which was currently on its second refill as well.
Eydis assured Sammy that the amount of her body’s water that ven conversion consumed would decrease little by little as her control over the conversion process improved.
“I guess.
But I was hoping there would be more benefits after seeing how much you changed in one weekend.”
Sammy noticed Eydis eyeing her blooming onion and broke off a petal for her.
Eydis dipped it in the special house sauce that sat in the center.
One bite sent her feet tapping with glee.
Eydis did not order a meal, having already eaten that morning.
She was waiting for everyone to finish and order desserts.
The main reason she loved this diner was their wide variety with varying portions for each dessert.
Justin had suggested it initially, knowing Eydis’s sweet tooth.
He was introduced through a girl he dated briefly in the past.
The diner had a separate menu book specifically to house their selection.
Eydis could choose any dessert in a small portion and wanted to try them all eventually.
“What about life… magic?” Miriam’s question split between bites of her chili-loaded fries and chicken strips.
“Are there any passive benefits to… a life affinity?”
Eydis reached for another petal of Sammy’s blooming onion but paused to think of an answer.
“Longer life?
I think that would be the answer you are looking for.
Many people think High Elves live longer than other elves due to a difference in their biology, but that is incorrect.
We live longer because life ven helps our bodies.
It keeps us healthy.
The few High Elves without an affinity for life magic live no longer than other elfkind.
Dryads are better at life magic, and with a different biology too, they live many times longer than High Elves.”
“Any negatives?”
Justin decided to join the conversation instead of working down his massive Philly cheese steak.
“No negatives.
But life magic is very dangerous.
In the past, life and death were thought to be different affinities.
They are actually the same.
Life magic, if used for harm or without proper skill or knowledge, can do terrible damage and even kill.
Life magic can heal a wound or prevent a wound from healing.
Also, if healed without proper control, the body’s regeneration goes out of control which can lead to sickness and eventually death if not caught.”
“What about Justin’s time affinity?” Miriam voiced the question before Justin could.
“Sorry, but I do not know.
It might not have any effect on the body, like spatial magic.”
“Hey, anyone want this?”
Sammy broke up the conversation to offer the remains of her blooming onion after taking a deep breath from filling up on her burger and drinks.
Everyone but Chloe passed, claiming they were saving room for dessert.
Eydis did claim the single petal she had reached for earlier.
Chloe happily took the remaining fourth of the onion.
She already finished her family platter.
Miriam watched Chloe in disbelief.
“Where does it all go?”
“Her boobs, of course.
Look at them!
Even though they shrunk a little when she lost weight.”
“Wha… what are you saying in front of Justin?” Chloe’s face flushed pink, and her eyes darted between Sammy and Justin.
“Come on.
Any man his age shouldn’t get flustered over boobs.”
Justin’s mind drifted to the day he had found Eydis, but there was nothing arousing about her situation back then.
He then recalled one time he had seen Sammy naked when she tried to urge him into sex.
“See!
See!
He’s blushing!
He was thinking about it!” Chloe pointed a blooming onion petal at Justin with her fully extended arm as if it was her own accusatory finger.
Justin snatched it from Chloe’s hand and ate it.
He quickly wiped the thought from his mind.
That night was the turning point in his relationship with Sammy that eventually led to the break-up.
Sammy gawked at him in disbelief.
“How much of a virgin are you?”
Justin tapped the dessert menu on the side of Sammy’s head.
“Stop picking on Chloe.
And I’m not a virgin.”
“Wait, then why…” Sammy’s eyes widened in surprise and then squinted in frustration.
“Okay, details.”
Miriam leaned forward, also wanting to hear the juicy stories of Justin’s past.
Chloe’s eyes darted from Sammy to Miriam, begging them to stop.
Eydis only admired her dessert menu, her undivided attention seemingly focused on deciding what she would get, but Justin thought he saw Eydis’s ear twitch beneath her beanie.
Justin’s mind recalled memories without his permission, but he cut them off when he felt his mood sour.
“I’d rather not.
It’s not something I like to talk about.
It would only spoil the party.
It was a long time ago anyway.”
Justin picked up another dessert menu and thrust both at Miriam and Sammy.
They each grabbed it with disappointed faces.
Chloe alone looked relieved.
He then joined Eydis as she scanned her menu.
“Any idea on what to try this time?” Justin asked.
“I have only had four of their desserts so far, but they were all rather similar.
I want to try something new.”
Eydis bought a miniature slice of pie each time they came to the diner.
The pies were the first section on the dessert menu.
She was simply going down the list.
Justin scanned the second page.
His eyes fell upon a boxed section in the bottom left corner.
Twelve ice cream flavors were listed, but it was the picture next to them that caught his eye.
Eydis had never tried ice cream before, and this would be the best introduction he could think of.
“How about this?”
Justin pointed to the tapioca deep-fried ice cream.
Thick tapioca pudding was encased in an ice cream flavor of choice and then quickly deep-fried with gram cracker breading.
It could then be topped with any of seven different sauces.
Justin had never tried it himself, but the description alone made his mouth water.
Eydis read the description.
Her eyes lit up, and she thrust the menu into Justin’s face, the picture about an inch from his nose.
“This!
I will get this!”
Eydis returned to the menu, but after some thought she deferred to Justin.
“I will let you choose the flavor.
You will know better than me what will taste best, yes?”
Justin thought that Eydis would know better than him what flavors she liked, but he agreed to her request.
Once everyone decided their respective desserts, they flagged a waiter over and placed their orders.
When the desserts arrived, the party mood picked up again.
Chloe chose a fruit parfait that stood so high from the glass that it threatened to topple over.
Sammy, who was already full from her dinner, chose only a small blackberry tart.
Miriam chose a specialty chocolate shake with chunks of chocolate truffle and a little rum mixed in.
Eydis and Justin both chose the deep-fried ice cream.
Justin’s had three scoops of dark chocolate ice cream with a salted caramel sauce.
The flavor he chose for Eydis’s single scoop was in-house mint ice cream with an apricot glaze.
Justin watched with bated breath as Eydis cut the ball of ice cream with her spoon.
She took great care to make sure her scoop contained a bit of tapioca pudding, mint ice cream, caramelized and crunchy gram cracker crust, and yellow apricot glaze.
The ice cream was soft and only slightly melted from the flash cooking in the fryer.
Eydis lifted the spoon to her mouth and bit down, pulling the spoon out slowly.
She made no reaction.
Justin worried that his choice of flavors did not sit well with Eydis, but then a smile crept over her face.
It grew wider and wider until her whole countenance glowed.
“…mmmMMMMMM!” Eydis grabbed the sleeve of Justin’s shirt and shook him while stomping her feet.
“Justin!
Justin!
Try it!”
Eydis filled her spoon again making sure that each ingredient was present.
She held it in front of Justin’s mouth, her eyes beaming with joy, eager to share what she had just experienced.
Justin felt a little embarrassed with Sammy and Chloe Staring at them.
Miriam alone focused on Eydis and chuckled.
“She’s so cute!”
Justin decided to ignore them and clamped down on Eydis’s spoon.
Eydis pulled it out slowly and watched for Justin’s reaction.
The flavors Justin chose had little reason to them other than Eydis’s love of mint.
He thought he remembered somewhere that mint paired well with pitted fruit.
This proved it.
Chills ran down his spine, and he felt a light lift in his chest.
The dessert could only be described in one word: heavenly.
Almost forgetting to breathe, Justin smiled back at Eydis.
“That was really good.”
Eydis beamed back at him again and continued eating her ice cream.
Remembering that Eydis wanted to try all the desserts the diner offered, he took a scoop of his own deep fried ice cream, making sure each ingredient was on his spoon, and offered it to Eydis.
She looked at him surprised.
“Go ahead.”
Eydis leaned over, held her hair back with one hand, and took a bite.
An exact repeat of her previous performance ensued.
Justin’s shaking arm nearly dropped his spoon.
“What is this?
They are the same dessert but taste so different.
It is nothing like the pies!”
Pleased with her cute reaction, Justin began eating his own dessert.
“He does things like this so casually but the moment you try to cuddle he pushes you away…” Sammy let out a sigh and popped the last bite of her tart in her mouth.
When desserts were finished and Eydis confirmed that everyone was satisfied, she took care of the check, and with one final congratulatory cheer, the party came to a close.

Chapter 18
“A School of Magic”
Eydis
Eydis continued in high spirits on her return to the apartment after eating her prized desserts.
When she saw Sean reading on the couch, she hurried over to him unable to contain her excitement.
“Sean!
Have you ever tried fried ice cream?”
Sean looked up from his book.
“You have quite the sweet tooth.
Sadly, I can’t eat it.”
“You do not like it?” Eydis grew confused.
How could someone not like something that tastes so good?
Sean shook his head.
“I like it, but my body doesn’t.
I am lactose intolerant.”
Eydis’s confusion deepened.
Sean closed his book without placing anything inside to mark his location and looked up at Eydis.
“Lactose is a sugar present in milk, the main ingredient for ice cream.
My body does not produce enough of an enzyme called lactase to digest it.
If I eat anything with milk, I get rather sick.”
“Could you help him with your life magic?” Justin asked.

Eydis learned a little about enzymes from joining Sammy in her biology class while Justin was working, so she understood Sean’s explanation well enough, but she did not know any life magic that could help.
Healing with life magic was done through abstraction of the healing process, letting the life ven fill the acute gap in one’s understanding of the fine details of biological processes.
Biology worked through its own natural order.
Life magic manipulated that order.
Healing a wound simply required the knowledge that healing was a natural process of life that could be controlled through life magic.
That minimum required knowledge was what Eydis lacked.
She knew nothing of the natural processes of lactose or lactase.
She shook her head.
“No.
I know what enzymes are from Sammy’s class, but I do not know anything about lactose or lactase.
I would not know where to start or what to do.
Sorry.”
“Don’t worry yourself over it.
It’s not a big deal.” Sean reopened his book to the exact page he had closed it and continued reading.
After another apology, Eydis followed Justin into her room.
Justin had accepted her into the apartment and stated that her place was with him, that this apartment was her home, but he was not the only resident.
Sean still expected her to find a place of her own as one of his requirements for her to stay--a supposedly temporary state that had lasted for months now.
Eydis was distressed when she thought Justin kicked her out and was relieved when she learned that it was all a misunderstanding, but the risk of eviction was still real with Sean.
That realization brough with it a return of her anxiety creeping up on her like a haunting shadow.
Expectations.
Obligations.
Burdens.
Eydis forced her worries from her mind.
Today had been a tumult of emotions.
She sat on the bed and beckoned Justin to join her.
“Let us take care of your ven poisoning.”
Justin removed his shirt and sat next to Eydis.
Due to his decision to eat healthier with Eydis’s help, some of his excess fat had diminished.
However, his stomach bulged slightly from the large dinner he had just eaten.
His failed attempt to suck in the bulge was amusing.
He was clearly self-conscious about it, so Eydis acted as if she did not notice.
At least the sight help uplift her spirits again, even if just a little.
It was charming in its own comical way.
Eydis placed her hand on Justin’s nearly hairless chest and used life magic to reduce any physical feeling in Justin’s body.
The feeling of ven was separate from physical senses, which was why the meditation Eydis made her students perform caused the body to numb.
Using life magic to numb Justin to all physical sensations was an extreme version of this, something she thought up after his meditation was not helping him feel his ven.
Her goal was to allow Justin to feel the expulsion of his toxic ven and nothing else.
Justin leaned forward and rested his forehead against Eydis’s, and she placed both hands on the sides of his face.
“I am starting,” she announced.
Silence.
“Did you feel anything?”
“No, same as usual,” Justin replied.
Eydis could not deny how frustrating Justin’s lack of progress was.
He should have been able to feel something by now.
But she could only smile.
She expected as much.
If she could convince Sean to let her stay here permanently, she would have all the time she needed to guide Justin, however long that would take.
She released her grip and placed her hand back on Justin’s chest.
Justin shivered as warmth spread through his body with the ebbing of the numbness.
He retrieved his shirt and stood with his back to Eydis to hide his bulging stomach once again.
“Maybe there is something about me that makes it impossible to feel my ven.
Do you think that I might have some form of ven paralysis?” he asked while pulling his shirt on.
Eydis did not like that line of thinking.
It was no different than resignation.
His question annoyed her, but then again, nothing she thought of was working, so she could not help but feel Justin’s inability to feel his ven was due to her own inadequacies.
“I have never heard of such a thing.
Paralysis only affects the physical body, yes?
Ven is separate from that.”
Even if such a paralysis did not exist on Whinhlem, that did not rule out the possibility of people having it on Earth.
Now Eydis had to chastise herself for following the same defeatist line of thinking.
She grabbed her pillow and tossed it at Justin out of mild frustration from him putting such thoughts in her mind.
Justin turned in time to see her pillow flying at his face.
He dodged it with impossible reflexes, and it bounced off the wall behind him.
Eydis felt the faint sensation of time magic use.
She knew next to nothing about time magic, which made guiding him all the more difficult.
She exhaled a defeated sigh.
“Even though you cannot feel it, your body recognizes it much better now that you are aware of it and can use it without thought on your part.”
She fell back diagonally across the bed, narrowly avoiding hitting her head on the wall on the other side.
Justin retrieved the pillow and sat down next to her.
“I wish Evhial was here.
She would have a far better idea of what to do,” Eydis groaned.
Justin dropped the pillow on Eydis’s face.
“Don’t worry yourself over it.
The problem is with me, not you.
I know you are doing everything you can.”
Eydis hugged the pillow to her face.
“Can I have your hand?”
Justin did not reply.
Perhaps he was hesitant at the request, or her voice was muffled through the pillow, so he heard wrong.
She extended her hand towards him and asked again.
She felt him grasp it gently, not unlike when he was reassuring her that everything was alright.
Perhaps he thought she was low in spirit, and that was why she asked.
Her emotional state, which was low if she wanted to be honest with herself, was not the reason, but she appreciated the gesture all the same.
She smiled, her face safely hidden under the pillow.
Eydis sent a pulse of life ven up Justin’s arm to his shoulder and then through his body.
After a few seconds, she sent another.
“Nothing is different,” she said after a pause.
“Huh?”
The pillow muffled Eydis’s voice, so she removed it and sat up still holding Justin’s hand, seeking the small comfort and assurance it offered.
“Nothing is different about your body from the last time I checked.”
“When was that?” Justin couldn’t pin a time or place to the memory he had of the pulse, which was understandable given the circumstances then.
“When you had your migraine, I had to search your body to find out what was wrong.
Nothing has changed since then.”
Again, Justin was confused, so Eydis elaborated.
“Everyone was interested in the changes that using magic does to your body.
I did not know about time magic, so I wanted to check.”
“Perhaps you were right about time not having any affect.” Eydis shook her head.
“It is still too soon to tell.
My instructor, Evhial, her constant use of gravity magic drastically shortened her life.
Using gravity magic creates very small injuries in the body that go unnoticed and build up over time.
This was completely unknown before she discovered it.
There was no one who used gravity magic as much or as well as her at any time in history.
Even with her life affinity improving her health, eventually it became too much for her body to bear.
She only lived about half as long as she should.”
“Are you worried that time magic might have a similar problem?”
Her grip on Justin’s hand tightened.
Justin’s problems with his ven were connected to an incurable condition that in the worst case could be fatal.
Now she also learned he had a powerful affinity.
The more powerful the affinity, the more dangerous it was for the user.
Life and spatial magic were dangerous because without incredible skill and practice, injury and even death could result from use.
With gravity, though incredible skill was still required, it also damaged the user just by using it.
The discussion at the party brought the realization that teaching Justin how to use time magic could potentially cause him harm.
Humans already had incredibly short lives compared to elves.

If there was any similarity between gravity and time magic, or even if time magic did not cause direct harm but was dangerous if used without learning from a proper instructor, Eydis wanted to avoid hurting Justin.
“You don’t need to worry about that,” Justin answered after Eydis explained her worries.
“It’s my decision, and I want to continue.
Miriam is right.
The fact that I can use time magic is amazing.
Who would want to stop?”
Eydis smiled, but the shadow of concern darkened her expression.
“How about this?
In the next magic lesson, you explain everything you just told me and let everyone decide if they want to risk continuing.
If someone wants to stop, they can stop.
But I honestly don’t think any of them will.”
This unwavering positivity was just like Justin.
Only now did Eydis realize that his question about ven paralysis was out of simple curiosity, not out of frustration or defeatist mentality.
She was the only one being defeatist.
After a fun dinner with her new friends at her favorite diner, she went and made herself anxious and depressed all over again with worries.
Eydis’s grip on Justin’s hand tightened again.
Assurance.
A genuine smile grew on Eydis’s face.
“Okay.”

* * *
“You worry too much.”
“We already made our choice.”
“Thank you for worrying about us, though.”
Sammy, Miriam, and Chloe each turned down Eydis’s offer to stop the lessons.
They all sat down on the couch in Miriam’s studio apartment and had listened to Eydis spill her concerns.
All Eydis’s worries that she had two evenings ago were invalidated by the simple optimism of her friends, but she couldn’t help but feel frustrated by their lack of concern for their own safety.
After all, she was the one who started their training.
They were her responsibility, and thus so was their safety.
Their eagerness simply meant that Eydis had the obligation to see their magic training through and protect them no matter the outcome.
Now that Justin was included in the lessons, he could no longer keep watch at their former vacant classroom in the health and fitness building.
Miriam lived alone and volunteered her apartment, so long as Chloe was careful not to set anything on fire.
When Miriam suggested they use her apartment, everyone was curious what a witch’s apartment would look like, but reality shattered their fantasies.
“What were you expecting?
Candles and bones everywhere?
Random effigies decorating the furniture and walls?” Miriam laughed.
The small room looked like any other college student apartment.
The blue carpet was lightly stained in places.
The furniture was cheap.
Her futon was threadbare in the corners.
The small kitchen-dining corner was slightly disorganized and a little messy.
Not a single clue that would lead one to suspect Miriam was a witch could be found.
“We’re just like anyone else.
I was raised in a normal home with normal parents and just happened to have an interest in my grandma’s hobby.
She’s the real witch in the family.
I was just an apprentice, so to speak.”
“Your parents don’t practice witchcraft,” Sammy asked.
Miriam shook her head.
“They don’t believe any of it.
I learned quickly as a kid that my grandma knew things she shouldn’t, more so than the stereotypical grandma that sees through everything.
That’s what piqued my interest.
She couldn’t use magic or anything, but she claimed to be able to speak to spirits and nature, as could her mother and grandmother.
She’s the reason I came to this school.
Said I was destined to meet the Master of Time and the Bridge between Worlds.
Doom and danger!” Miriam swung her hands dramatically and stopped abruptly with a shrug.
“That sort of thing.
It was the craziest thing I had ever heard from her, but she had never been wrong before.”
Miriam smiled at Justin and Eydis.
“Turns out she was right again.
Although I’m not sure about the danger part.”
Eydis expressed interest in meeting Miriam’s grandmother, but Miriam informed her that she passed away two years ago.
Determined to become her vision of a true witch, one who could use magic, Miriam was excited to continue her official lessons.
“Our discussion at Justin’s party made me think about the benefits of each of your elements,” Eydis began, first addressing Sammy.
“You thought that a water affinity lacked benefits when compared to a fire affinity.
You are only unaware of what a water affinity can do, so I thought I would teach you all convenient ways to use just your ven in its elemental form without the need to conjure anything from it.
A perfect example is what Chloe discovered almost immediately.
Anywhere she concentrates her fire ven, she becomes resistant to heat.”
“So, something more than making rocks?”
Miriam held a perfectly monochromatic tan stone in her hand that was not there a few seconds before.
Eydis was surprised that Miriam could already conjure rocks.
She ran before even learning how to crawl.
Chloe followed Miriam’s example by producing a small flame of her own and had it dance across the tips of her fingers.
This spurred a bit of jealousy from Sammy who was the only one unable to consciously conjure something physical with her ven.
For Sammy’s lesson, Eydis handed her a bag of cotton balls and told her to infuse one with her ven.
Infusion was no different than ven affinity assessment, because in its simplest form, what they were doing during those assessments was send their ven into another’s hand.
After that brief explanation, Sammy felt confident she could do it.
The crux of Eydis’s lesson was that Sammy needed to control her ven well enough that it didn’t accidently produce water and get the ball wet.
This proved frustrating.
While Sammy could not produce water at will, her ven often created moisture on its own, getting herself or others wet.
Still, she continued as a bowl of soggy cotton balls slowly filled up.
Miriam’s lesson involved concentrating as much of her ven as possible on a single circle drawn on the back of her hand in washable marker.

The ability to move ven willingly through the body was a prerequisite for affinity assessment and infusion, so Miriam thought that this would be easy; however, Eydis stated that the ven needed to be uniformly distributed and extremely concentrated.
Even though the process was simpler than Sammy’s, the needed precision and control was higher.
Each time Miriam thought she had it, Eydis touched her hand and told her that it was nowhere near sufficient.
Chloe was ahead of everyone else in her ability to control and use her ven.
Having already learned how to gather the ven to resist heat and agitate it to warm objects, Eydis told Chloe to slow it to a complete stop.
She had to transfer ven to her hand and then prevent it from moving.
This was a unique challenge for Chloe due to how hyperactive Chloe’s ven was.
The level of control required was much greater than both Sammy and Miriam.
Like Miriam, Eydis would touch Chloe’s hand and say Chloe’s attempts were not good enough.
Even though Justin participated in the magic lessons now that he knew his affinity, he could do nothing but continue meditating with the hope that he might eventually be able to feel his ven.
He did not have even the smallest amount of control like the others.
Eydis apologized, but she could not think of anything else, and Miriam rejected the idea of randomly throwing objects at Justin in her apartment.
While everyone practiced, Eydis quickly learned to use the web browser on her phone and then delved into the molecular biology textbook she asked Sammy to bring.
The lesson finished without anyone making any progress.
The following Monday’s lesson had the same result.
By Wednesday, Eydis gave Chloe passing marks, but barely.
Given the relative difficulty of Chloe’s lesson due to Chloe’s unique ven constitution, she felt a little leeway was needed.
She also wanted to inspire the others by showing the results.
Everyone gathered around Chloe to see the results that Eydis kept secret.
“You probably think a fire affinity is only used to produce and manipulate fire.
To be more precise, it manipulates energy.
Thermal energy is energy, yes?”
Eydis asked Chloe to hold out her hand, palm facing up, and sat a half-filled water bottle on it.
“When you first showed us your magic, it was like this.
You heated a bottle of water.
Now, do what you practiced.”
Chloe nodded and channeled fire ven into her hand but brought it to a standstill.
The water bubbled slightly but soon clouded.
Eydis grabbed the bottle and gave it one solid shake.
Frozen slush filled the bottle.
Everyone grew wide-eyed in amazement.
“You mean ice is not water magic?” Chloe asked.
“Water magic can conjure ice, but you can also produce ice with fire magic by removing thermal energy from water.”
“That’s not quite how thermal dynamics works,” Sammy quipped.
“Actually, it might be,” Justin quipped back, prompting a glare from Sammy.
“I think Chloe is just absorbing the thermal energy from the water.”
Eydis handed Chloe the bottle.
“You can now not only keep your food hot but also keep your drinks cold!”
Chloe was elated with this revelation.
For the remainder of the lesson, she continued reheating the bottle only to freeze it again.
This pleased Eydis, because more than anyone else except perhaps Justin, Chloe needed to learn control over her affinity.
This training was the most basic form of control: temperature regulation, a necessity for any fire mage to keep their magic from spiraling out of control.
Eydis worried about how Chloe’s hyperactive ven would inhibit her ability to control it.
Like Justin, Chloe’s constitution was something Eydis had never seen, and she had no one to ask about it.
Sammy and Miriam redoubled their efforts after seeing Chloe’s success, and Miriam received passing marks by the next lesson.
“Grab your sharpest knife,” Eydis ordered.
Miriam pulled a knife out of one of her kitchen drawers and returned to the group.
“Once you have your ven concentrated on the back of your hand, try to cut it with the knife.”
“Cut it?” Miriam repeated worriedly.
“Trust me.
If this fails, I can heal you.”
“You saying that doesn’t make it easier…”
With Eydis’s reassurance, Miriam slid the blade over her hand.
“Harder,” Eydis ordered.
Miriam applied more pressure and pulled the knife across.
Miriam’s mouth hung agape.
She began sawing the back of her hand with the blade.
The skin stretched and pulled with each motion, but it never cut her.
“Now make a fist to tighten the skin and try to stab it.”
Without hesitation, Miriam plunged the knife into her hand.
“Shit!” Miriam recoiled and dropped the knife.
“God damnit.” She cradled her hand and winced from the pain, but when Sammy quickly pulled her hand away to see the damage, there was no mark.
From how Miriam reacted, everyone but Eydis had thought she stabbed herself.
Eydis retrieved Miriam’s aching hand and massaged it with life magic.
“Earth ven can be used to protect the body from being cut or pierced.
It can deflect swords and arrows better than conventional armor with less strain on the body than the weight of metal armor.
But it is not perfect.
As you learned just now, you will still feel pain.”
“How much of my body can I coat with it?” Miriam asked, enjoying the life-magic-aided hand massage.
“Your entire body with enough practice.
Even your internal organs can be protected, but that is far more difficult.
Only, do not try it on your eyes unless you have no other choice.
It causes temporary blindness.”
Miriam spent the remainder of the lesson concentrating her ven on different parts of her body and then poking them with the knife to test the quality of her reinforcement magic.
Sammy was the only one unable to complete her training.
Still failing to keep the cotton dry while infusing it with ven at the end of the next lesson, she began carrying a bag of cotton balls with her everywhere.
Late Sunday evening, Justin sat shirtless next to Eydis during their daily purge of his toxic ven.
“Eydis!
Are you here?!”
Sammy walked in the front door and called out.
“Done.”
Instead of removing the ven slowly to give Justin more of a chance to feel it, Eydis rushed the purge.
She stood and trotted out the door, leaving Justin alone on the bed.
Justin worked his way in an unsteady crawl out the door and down the hall.
His numbness removed most of his motor functions.
“Eydis, you kind of left me on the bed there.”
“What?” Sammy stared at the shirtless man crawling into the kitchen from the hallway.
His slender frame with near-perfect complexion had none of the excess fat she remembered.
“On the bed?
What were you two doing before I arrived?
He would never try to make a move on you.”
Justin rolled over on his back.
“Quite the opposite.
I can barely move as it is.”
Eydis hurried over with an apology and placed her hand on Justin’s chest.
Justin stood with a helping hand from Eydis and walked with her back to Sammy.
“And you could knock for once,” Justin chastised.
“What, it’s not like I would be interrupting anything.”
“As you can see, we were in the middle of something.”
“What was Eydis doing to you?”
Justin was relieved that she had not asked what he was doing to Eydis.
“You wouldn’t do anything, so it had to be her.” Sammy looked at Eydis with suspicion.
Eydis’s explanation was short and direct.
“Removing poison from his body.”
“Poison?” Worry grew on Sammy’s face.

Sammy already knew of Justin’s large ven capacity, so he filled in the blanks about how this was due to his body’s tendency to turn the ven it absorbed into poison and that Eydis purged it every day to keep it from building and causing his migraines.
“No wonder you are having such a hard time with your ven.
Your body can’t even absorb it correctly!
The two are probably linked,” Sammy mused.
“It is possible,” Eydis agreed.
“So, why are you here,” Justin asked Sammy.
“Oh!
Yah!”
Sammy held out her hand.
A puff of mist appeared in her palm that slowly swirled and grew until it condensed into water.
With a flick of her middle finger, the small ball of water the size of a marble flew directly into Justin’s face, prompting a light chuckle from Eydis.

“I was able to channel my ven into the cotton without getting it wet when I realized that the exact opposite of what I was doing would condense the ven and turn it into water!” Sammy grabbed both Eydis’s hands with excitement.
“So what’s this special use that you were teaching me with the cotton?”
Eydis was genuinely pleased with Sammy’s progress but rejected her plea to reveal the secret.
“Conjuring water was a result I hoped would follow.
You are correct that the processes are opposites of each other, just like Chloe’s heating and cooling.
You will have to wait for tomorrow’s lesson so everyone can see.”
“Come on.
Please!”
Eydis shook her head with a playful smile, and Justin interjected.
“You should have known Eydis would not spill it early.
Or did you come all the way here just to get me wet?”
“Now that you’ve lost some weight, a damp look might actually suit you well,” Sammy laughed.
“I don’t need to go back.
It’s fine.
I’ll just stay with Eydis tonight.
Eydis doesn’t mind, right?”
Eydis shook her head.
She was excited to have another night talking with Sammy.
Justin shrugged and let Sammy do as she pleased.
The next magic lesson, everyone gathered around Sammy as she conjured a small sphere of water.
“Now I won’t fall behind,” Sammy asserted.
Amid the congratulatory praise from Miriam and Chloe, Eydis appeared carrying a large bowl filled with water and set it down on the carpet between everyone.
“Take a cotton ball and fill it with your ven.”
Sammy grabbed a cotton ball from the bag beside her and channeled her ven into it.
The first attempt was a soggy failure, but the second kept the ball dry.
“Now dip it in the water.”
Sammy submerged the cotton ball completely and pulled it out to the surprise of everyone but Eydis.
It remained dry.
She dunked it again and again, and even squeezed and massaged it under water, but the cotton ball would not get wet.
Water beaded off as if it had been sprayed with a perfect waterproofing agent, one that even prevented droplets of water from clinging to the fine fibers.
Sammy’s hand alone got wet.
“Now, instead of channeling your ven into the cotton ball, coat your hand with it.
It does not need to be uniform like with Miriam.”
Sammy did as asked, and the water on her hand beaded off into her lap.
“Shit.” She quickly moved her hand over the bowl to keep her pants dry.
“I can repel water?”
“If you were to coat your body and clothes with it, you would stay dry in even the strongest rain.”
“Waterproofing?
That’s useful.” Miriam pulled at the cuffs of her pants that had gotten soaked from the snow.
“It is more than waterproofing.
Sammy, with the ven still coating your hand, put your hand in the water.”
Sammy tried, but her hand would not enter the water.
“Hey!”
“Sammy…”
Sammy slapped the water, sending droplets at Miriam and Justin, but she could not submerge her hand.
It looked like Sammy was slapping a water balloon.
“It’s like a barrier is keeping my hand out.”
“Just like you reject the water, the water rejects you.
If you were to coat it on your feet…”
Sammy’s face bubbled with the joy of what she was about to say.
“I’d become Jesus!”
“If controlled correctly, you can even propel yourself through water at incredible speeds.”
Sammy was an avid swimmer, something that Eydis knew well.
Sammy’s body shook with unrestrained excitement.
She was unable to keep herself from laughing.
Tears of joy welled up in the corners of her eyes.
“A water affinity is useful, yes?
It does not lose to fire or any other element.”
Sammy wrapped her arms around Eydis, jumping on her knees with excitement.
She looked the happiest that Eydis had ever seen her.
Sammy’s joy alone made the magic lessons worth it.
Eydis did not want to ruin Sammy’s celebration, but she also had to continue the lesson, so while Sammy still clung to her, she announced the plan for the rest of the evening.
“For the remainder of the lesson, Sammy and I thought we should focus on Justin.
There is a small park two blocks from here.
We will continue there.”
Everyone left the apartment, and Miriam led them down the street to a small park with a playground and a single swing set.
The far corner was a small field with two metal picnic tables.
The snow was about two feet deep, and several snowmen built by the neighborhood kids populated the field.
