No one else was in the park so late in the evening, so they had it to themselves.
Once Justin followed Eydis into the field, a snowball hit the back of Justin’s head.
When he turned to find Sammy gathering another, Eydis threw one at his back.
She smiled playfully.
“Your time magic doesn’t activate if you are too distracted,” Eydis analyzed.
Justin was not an uncommon topic in Eydis’s night talks with Sammy, mostly brought up by Sammy in anecdotes.
This lesson focusing on Justin was Eydis’s idea born from their discussions.
Now aware, Justin successfully dodged a pair of snowballs fired by Sammy and Miriam.
“Four against one time mage?
Seems fair to me!” Miriam giggled maniacally and handed a snowball to Chloe.
The snowball fight erupted immediately and continued until Justin was too exhausted to fight back.
Except for the first two snowballs, no other was able to hit him.
In the end, Justin was the sole victor, although Eydis was never hit, because she used wind magic to deflect any snowball Justin threw at her.
Before returning to Miriam’s apartment for hot drinks, Eydis checked Justin’s ven levels.
Despite using time magic for nearly the full half hour of the snowball fight, Justin never ran out.
The fight didn’t even make a noticeable dent, much to her surprise.
At the end of the lesson, everyone said their goodbyes and parted ways.
At the bus stop, Eydis tugged on Justin’s sleeve.
“May we stop at the store on our way back?” she asked.
“Sure.
What do you need to get?”
“Ice cream.
Do you know what flavor Sean might like?”
Justin flashed an understanding smile.
He knew she had been absorbed in something on her smartphone but never asked what.
They picked up three personal-sized cups of ice cream and headed home.
Sean sat on the couch in his usual one-leg-over-the-other posture reading a book.
Eydis walked over to him with a nervous smile.
“Sean, if you do not mind, can you lay back and pull your shirt up?”
Sean closed his book and obeyed, albeit with suspect.
“This should not hurt, but it will probably feel hot.”
Eydis placed her hand on Sean’s abdomen.
His eyes winced a little but relaxed soon after.
When finished, Eydis pulled him back up to sit.
“What did you do?” Sean asked.
Justin brought over the bag and pulled out the three cups of ice cream.
“Normally you would ask that before someone uses magic on you.
Which one do you want?”
Sean stared at the ice cream.
His eyes narrowed in disbelief when he realized what Eydis did.
“Your body should produce sufficient lactase now,” Eydis said with a warm smile.
During every purge of Justin’s toxic ven after learning of Sean’s lactose intolerance, Eydis had scanned Justin to investigate lactase levels and activity in humans.
Using Justin’s lactase levels as a guideline, Eydis learned everything she could about lactase, where and how the body produced it, and theories about why the production levels decreased.
She used her own body as a test subject until she was sure she could reproduce the change safely in Sean.
Sean grabbed the chocolate mint ice cream and finished off the entire cup.
All Eydis’s preparation led to this moment.
She waited in deep anxiety into the night hoping that Sean would not grow ill from eating the ice cream.
Eydis knocked on Sean’s door as Justin was preparing for bed in the living room.
When Sean answered, Eydis saw that she had pulled him away from working on something on his computer.
“Sorry to bother you while you are working,” Eydis said.
“I wanted to ask if you had any problems with the ice cream.”
“None.
Your magic is amazing.
Thank you.”
Now was the time.

Eydis still felt she had more to repay for Sean letting her stay considering her inability to follow all his conditions, but if she did not ask now, she felt that she would never fully feel welcome here, that this apartment would never be her home.
Eydis took a deep breath and readied her conviction.
“You said after Justin found me that I needed to find my own place to live.
I want to know if I have done enough to earn my place here with you and Justin.
I want to know if I can call this place my home.”
Sean’s face went blank and then slowly grew frustrated.
He exhaled slowly through his nose and paced once in a circle before sitting on his bed and staring at his feet.
His actions worried Eydis, and she wondered if she had insulted him by asking.
“Have you been worrying about that all this time?” Sean took a deep breath, and his frustration melted.
“I guess this is my fault.
I never thought you would agonize over that for this long.
I gave that condition before knowing anything about your situation or who you are.” He looked up at Eydis.
“I wouldn’t have let you use magic on me if I did not trust you.
You are a good person, and that is reason enough for me to let you stay.”
Sean smiled warmly, an odd sight from his usual stone-faced expression.
“So long as Justin is okay with whatever living arrangements you two have decided on, you can stay as long as you want.
I was wrong to urge you to leave.
Sorry to make you worry for so long.”
Eydis dove to her knees in front of Sean and hugged him.
She felt an immense weight and worry lifted from her.
“Thank you,” she said while trying to hold back her tears.
This small apartment by the river was finally home.

Chapter 19
“Ignorance is bliss”
Eydis
“I think you are good enough now.
If you wait any longer, Jethro might find your sister.”
Austin sank back into the sofa and ordered his new fairy slave, Jil, to grab him a flask of ale and Dyas to massage his shoulders.
At least a large fire crackled in the fireplace to keep everyone warm in their underdress.
Symra and Wian huddled together on a rug near the fire to soak in the warmth.
Symra coddled Wian who was taking a well needed rest.
The heavy bruising on Wian’s stomach, ribs, and breasts were finally fading now that Justin’s angry beatings ceased with the new arrival, a gift from Jethro at Eydis’s request.
Once Austin came to some conclusion that Wian orchestrated a plan to distract him while Eydis could gain permission to steal Rynn, he began regularly beating her.

The poor Forest Elf may have been the sole target of his rage because she reminded him of the slave he lost and because he lacked the strength to physically harm Symra or Dyas no matter how hard he tried.
Eydis did not know if Austin’s obsession with Rynn was because of her size or age, but because fairy women were similar in stature to Elf youth, she hoped the addition would spare Wian further abuse.
Austin seemed pleased with the replacement, and the new addition lessoned the beatings over time.

Eydis felt terrible forcing another innocent woman into bondage, but considering the ongoing genocide in Vallen, the fairy’s fate was either death or slavery, and Eydis was unsure which was preferable.
At least as a slave, if by some miracle the humans lost their hold on Amel, she could be saved.
Austin disgusted Eydis by his every action, but she also understood that this was the fate of a female slave.
There was nothing she could do to stop him without monitoring him every moment of every day and night, and she could barely stand being in the same room as him for her English lessons.
The best she could do for them was to take him away.
“Seriously, though.
English is one of the hardest languages of our world to learn, and you mastered it in a couple weeks.” Austin continued speaking jovially without a care towards the mournful faces of the women.
“Then I will tell Jethro we are ready to leave for your world.”
Eydis stood from her chair and walked to the large double doors.
While waiting for the guards to open them, she glanced back at the small fairy being fondled in Austin’s lap while the fairy futilely attempted to serve him his ale.
The man laughed at the sounds and expressions he could force out of the poor woman.
“Humans are repulsive, all of them.”

* * *
The next day.
Jethro called Eydis and Austin to the grand council chamber where he met them sitting casually atop the arm of the emperor’s throne.
Two humans, a dwarf, and a giant stood beside him.
They dressed in warm clothes similar in make to Austin’s aside from the giant who wore a large cloak of crude Tolmyurin fabric.
In the otherworld city where only general humans lived, finding clothing that could fit one of his stature would be impossible.
Jethro prepared this special task force to both assist and monitor Eydis.
She knew the dwarf was a magician that had mastered his single affinity.
One if not both humans could likely use magic.

The giant, taller and larger built than any of the giants Eydis had seen in the palace, was probably weaker than her in strength, but due to his military training that Eydis lacked, she did not doubt he could overpower her and pin her down if she was weakened.
The dark eyes of the giant followed Eydis as she approached but wandered to the head poking out from behind her.
Eydis brought Rynn against Jethro’s orders.
Jethro scratched under his ear and shook his head lightly.
“I reluctantly caved to your request to allow our valuable English instructor to accompany you.
I cannot permit another.
This is no vacation.
I am sure you understand that.
I can give my word that the girl will not be harmed while you are away.”
Eydis expected resistance, so she planned what she felt was a justifiable excuse.
“I need someone to replenish my ven and I refuse to use Austin or your men.
And I cannot believe Rynn will be safe until I return.
You may give your word, but did you not tell me your men are disobedient?
There is nothing you can say on this matter that I can trust.”
“Watch your tongue,” the dwarf reprimanded calmly while the two humans drew their swords in anger.
The giant was unfazed by Eydis’s defiance and kept staring at Rynn.
“Fine, fine,” Jethro sighed.
After calming his angered men with an unamused wave of his hand, he opened a strange black portal.
He felt no need to argue against Eydis’s reasoning, much to her relief.
The dwarf entered the portal first followed by the massive giant who had to duck and carefully shift his way in to not touch the edges of the portal.
Austin moved to line up for the portal, but as he passed, Eydis caught a faint whiff.
She grabbed his arm, pulled him back, and retrieved the sachet of deshalu from his pocket.
“Are you mad?” she reprimanded.
“What if the princess smells an herb from her world?” Eydis tore the sachet and dumped the dried grass with bubbled growths onto the floor.
Jethro glared.
He had also prohibited the herb.
Austin could say nothing in his defense.
He silently entered the portal behind the taskforce.
Eydis looked into the deep void that failed to show the destination, and it filled her with trepidation.
“Thank you for noticing the deshalu,” Jethro said once everyone else had left.
“Lurr senses are better than ours.
If Austin happened to find the princess first, that would have been an immense risk.”
Eydis did not move.
She stared at the portal and tried to understand its construction, why the destination was not visible.
The destination of every portal was visible, or should be.
This portal was aberrant.
It was unnatural.
Something was horribly wrong about it.
“The portal is not dangerous despite appearances.” he assured after a pause.
“Don’t let a meager portal ruin your conviction,” he said with a dimpled smirk.
Eydis doubted Jethro would let her investigate the trace to get a better understanding of the formula.
She tightened her grip on Rynn’s hand and pulled her through the void.
The portal felt like trying to step through a thin membrane that once penetrated, became a cold and viscous fluid.
It pushed back against her like a current, but at the same time it pulled her through by some unknown force.
The sensation churned her stomach.
The other side of the portal was no better than the traumatizing passage through it.
The air of the small residence was cold and thin like the top of an exceedingly high mountain.
She found breathing painful and grew dizzy.
She had to wonder how the princess was able to survive in such a place.
Rynn also felt the effects of the atmosphere and held her head.
The petite girl’s legs grew weak, so Eydis quickly lifted her.
A simple wooden chair with a glossy polish sat next to a dark, hardwood table.
She sat Rynn down in the chair to let the dizziness pass, if it would.
Eydis worried that it would linger indefinitely, and they would be forced to grow accustomed to it.
Strange objects Eydis had never seen before filled the room around her.
The wash basin and what she assumed was a range suggested that the room was meant for preparing and eating meals.
The make and quality of the appliances was exquisite, despite the obvious wear of time.
She walked to the counter and prodded an appliance with a large metal bowl and whisk.
It had to be for mixing ingredients, but there was no way to use the whisk.
It was attached at the top to the strange appliance.
As she groped around the object out of curiosity, her hand bumped something, and the whisk immediately spun at an incredible speed.
She yelped in surprise and panicked to find a way to stop it.
The dwarf pushed a set of clothes into Eydis’s arms and deactivated the machine.
“Change,” the dwarf ordered in Elven.
“You will draw attention in that dress.”
Eydis looked around.
Certainly, they could not expect her to change here.
While wondering how she would manage to change clothes in front of all these men, a stubby dwarf hand pushed her towards a hallway.
“There is a room down the hall.
I will guarantee your privacy.
Return when you are finished.
We have much to discuss.”
Eydis carried Rynn with her to the hall but took a moment to glance back at the machine that had spun the whisk on its own.
They said this world had no magic.
The room at the end of the hallway was adorned simply with a bed, side table with a lamp, a dresser, and a vanity stand with a perfectly reflective oval mirror.
The small size of the room made it feel awfully cramped, at least compared to the large rooms of the palace.
Like the dining room before, everything inside bore the weathering of age and poor maintenance but remained of incredibly fine quality.
The former resident was either an elderly human of this world or had inherited the furniture.
Eydis asked Rynn to sit on the bed while she dressed.
Rynn found it just as soft if not softer than the bed they had in the palace.
She pressed her hands into the pillowed fabric and bounced lightly a few times.
Even though the girl showed no emotion, Eydis knew she was surprised.

“I wonder if all humans of this world live in such luxury or if the owner saved enough to afford such luxuries,” Eydis thought aloud to Rynn, hoping to elicit some emotive response, but as usual the girl neither answered nor showed any outward emotion.
Eydis sat the clothes on the bed next to Rynn.
After removing her sandals, she unfastened the back ties of her dress and sash about her waist to let the dress fall to her ankles.
The Dwarf provided her with a pair of blue pants similar in fabric to those worn by Austin, a simple white shirt, and a thick brown coat that was torn in a few places.
Upon closer inspection, there were small, thin slits in the back.
The coat formally belonged to someone Jethro’s men had killed from behind.
After inspecting the pants and finding they lacked similar markings, Eydis realized that her underskirt would not pair with the pants, so she removed it as well.
The room was not heated, so she shivered lightly while she dressed.
The blue pants hung loose on her waist, rubbing against her tail whenever she moved.
The sensation was unpleasant, but there were no ties on the waistband of the pants, leaving a single button as the sole fastener.
Eydis had to question the design of only having one button and leaving no means to loosen or tighten the waist.
There was also a large hole below the button that exposed her if she was careless in how she moved or walked.
Wouldn’t such a method of fastening be better suited on the back or side instead of the front?
Eydis felt inside the hole for any means to seal it and noticed fine metal teeth.
She ran her fingers up and down and located a small tab on the bottom where the teeth joined.
While fiddling with the tab, the teeth clamped together when it rose.
Fascinated by the fine craftsmanship, Eydis repeated the motion over and over, feeling the teeth enter the tab separate but leave the tab conjoined.
It was incredible technology that felt just as much like magic as the whisk in the kitchen but was used on something so small and seemingly insignificant.
Ties would accomplish the same task, but instead this world used a magic tab on simple clothing.
The pants still hung loose and low on her hips, but there was little she could do.
She would have to endure the rubbing on her tail.
The white shirt was also loose, and the coat was made for someone much wider than her, but at least the sleeves were long enough.
Now dressed, Eydis returned to the dining room, leaving Rynn in the bedroom.
“What’s the plan?” Austin’s eyes scrutinized Eydis’s baggy apparel.
“Do as I say.
That is all.”
Eydis ignored his gaze.
She spoke to Jethro’s men in Elven to keep Austin out of the conversation so he wouldn’t say anything unnecessary.
She did not trust him to keep silent nor did she know who of Jethro’s men spoke any English.
The dwarf briefed Eydis on their current coverage of the city, but she paid little attention.
All reports Jethro received from this world he forwarded to her, including the city coverage.
Jethro’s men followed a high level of secrecy, so she doubted the thoroughness of their search.
If Austin’s supposed leads came up empty, she would likely have to begin her own search from the beginning anyway.
Eydis returned her attention to the briefing when the dwarf began mention of a public transportation system that was not included in the reports.
She could use a large, automated carriage called a bus to move around the city quickly to prevent the princess from being alerted to any use of spatial magic.
He handed her a small card with the explanation that it should give her free access if she tapped it on the pedestal inside the carriage.
His final orders were to return at sundown and gave Eydis freedom to investigate as she pleased so long as she did not confront the princess should she locate her.

* * *
Austin followed a few steps behind Eydis as they walked off the large property.
Eydis left Rynn behind in the bedroom with a warning to the humans that if any of them so much as looked at her, she would slaughter them all.
The dwarf’s assurance that he had no interest in children only slightly eased her worry.
She gave Rynn a knife from the kitchen to defend herself in an emergency because she did not think the girl knew offensive magic.
Eydis did not even know if Rynn could use magic.
Being a Forest Elf, she should at least have an affinity to wind or water, maybe earth, but that was far rarer.
“Anything important I should know?” Austin called from five full paces behind Eydis.
“Nothing.
They are useless.
We will work without them.
Anything I need to know about this world I can hear from you.”
After an hour of walking, Eydis and Austin arrived at the edge of the city proper.
Eydis breathed heavy due to the thin air and had to take a break.
She pulled Austin away from the road and asked him to fill her in on everything he knew about her sister.
“Not much to be honest.
She is living with a man who is awfully controlling of her.
She has another friend, Sammy, who she frequently hangs out with.
I know Sammy and should be able to find her again if we go to the university.
We can find your sister that way, or--”
Eydis sensed that everything Austin said was true, at least to his knowledge, so that was enough.
“You said you can find her friend at this university place?
Go there, and say nothing of me to anyone.
I will search the city.
We will meet back here before sunset.
Do you have access to the bus?”
“That bus pass you have was mine from back when they first took me from Gullivan.”
Eydis returned Austin his bus pass.
Austin was relieved that he would not have to stay with Eydis the entire time, and Eydis was just as relieved to be rid of him.
At the nearest bus stop, he happily boarded the first bus that arrived after Eydis confirmed one last time he had no more deshalu on him.
Eydis worried that Austin might run but thought better of it.
He would not abandon the slaves Jethro provided for him.
And the deshalu; all Austin’s favorite vices were on Whinhlem.
Eydis wanted a better look at the city now that she was alone but noticed many people casting strange looks her direction.
“Mommy!
It’s an elf!” A mother pulled her daughter along, and the young child’s inquisitive eyes stared at Eydis’s ears.
These humans knew about elves.
The documents stated that only humans lived in this city, but perhaps elves existed elsewhere in the world.
Or maybe they were rare?
The reports lacked any explanation of how the populace treated foreign races, and her ears were a banner announcing her as an outsider.
There was even a possibility that the man with whom the princess was staying hid her race and identity.
If humans of this world were anything like those in hers, walking alone on the streets was dangerous for an elf.
While Eydis feared nothing from weak humans, attracting unneeded attention, especially hostility, was a problem.
Eydis walked between two buildings into a secluded alleyway.
She lacked the means to hide her ears, so she chose instead to avoid people where possible.
This also meant she could not use the public transportation of this world, especially in the busier inner city, but she never planned on using it anyway.
Eydis looked up at the tops of the two-story, red-brick buildings sandwiching the alleyway and gauged the distance to the roof.
Lurr are far stronger than elves.
This should be possible.
Eydis crouched down.
Looking at the edge of the roof, she jumped.
Biting cold struck her face in her upward climb.
She overestimated her strength, but something else felt off.
Once she reached the apex of her jump, about the height of a third floor had there been one, her descent felt slow.
She did not accelerate as fast as she felt she should.
She was much lighter in this world than in Whinhlem.
The sensation was bizarre and unnerving.
Eydis landed on the flat roof with little impact.
Most the buildings near her had one or two floors.
There were no nearby towers she could use as a vantage point.
A city without walls or towers.
Was this world a peaceful place that had no need of such things?
Or were these humans so powerful that they feared nothing?
Eydis ran and jumped to the next building.
When she landed, her pants slipped down.
She grabbed them and quickly pulled them back up.
Her loose pants drastically hindered her movement, but she had no means to fasten them.
She searched the roof and found a thin wire connected to what looked like a metal sculpture that poorly resembled a tree or perhaps a feather.
She tore up the wire that attached to the base of the sculpture like a root, wrapped it around her hands, and with a swift tug snapped it with a pop.
She uprooted more of it along the roof until she felt it was long enough to tie a knot and broke it from the rest of the wire with another swift tug.
She slipped the wire a few times through two loops on the waistline of the side of her pants.
After tying a knot that pulled the loops as close together as they could reach, the pants hugged snugly against her waist.
Perhaps this was the purpose of the loops, although she had never seen Austin use them this way, but Austin’s pants fit him perfectly without ties.
Eydis ran and jumped to the next building.
Using the rooftops, she avoided the streets until she reached a wide road she would have to cross on the ground.
Her breath shot out in heavy white puffs from her lung’s fight for air.
The lightness of her body meant that she was not even the slightest bit exhausted from jumping across the buildings, but the air was far too thin.
Her already light head felt like it was drifting away in the wind, so she sat down and took the opportunity to inspect what she could see of the city.
In the distance, there were larger buildings of multiple floors, but reaching them would be difficult without drawing attention either on the ground or jumping along the rooftops.
A tree-lined river bisected the city, dividing the larger buildings on the far side from the smaller homes and businesses on this side.
Eydis understood why finding the princess would be so difficult in such a place.
The city was twice the size of Amel.
Capturing Austin who had met the princess was quite the stroke of luck.
Jethro had found the link to the princess without even knowing.
Eydis laughed to herself.
His ignorance was her blessing.
The dwarf warned Eydis not to use her spatial magic, but seeing the size of the city, she felt she could risk it.
The chances of the princess being close enough to her at this moment to sense her spatial magic were low.
The chances the princess would be near her destination would be even less.
Very few people were sensitive enough to detect magic from a great distance.
Eydis did not have that ability, and although she was not yet a perfect duplicate of the princess, she doubted the princess was highly sensitive either.
Eydis worked out the formula to Jethro’s complicated but lower-cost transmission spell.
She was still unfamiliar with it, so this took time, but Eydis’s inability to regenerate ven naturally meant she had to reserve ven as much as possible.
She had Rynn, but Rynn’s ven regeneration rate was slow, and Eydis felt bad using her for that reason even though Rynn was willing.

Transmission used a quarter the cost of regular teleportation, which made it indisputably beneficial for her, but when thinking over the formula, she felt there was an excessive amount of meaningless bloat that increased the ven cost, and she did not know enough about spatial magic to determine if the excess was needed.
Eydis disappeared with a loud crack, and with a flash of light, strong wind blew in her face.
The view from the tallest building of the city was grand.
Flat fields surrounded the city on three sides with hills or mountains far in the distance.
Many of the fields had single residences for the landowners, just like the house Jethro’s men occupied.
The fields on the final side of the city ran up along a hill that quickly grew into mountains.
A large highway left the city in three directions, one of which led up the hills and into a valley between the mountains.
As far as Eydis could see, the highways did not immediately connect to another city or village.
This city was isolated.
Perhaps it was a sovereignty of its own.
Her ven was limited, so she could not teleport around the city.
By her estimates, holding Rynn throughout the night would only recover enough ven for three uses.
To prevent a net negative, Eydis figured she could only check one section of the city each day.
She began to wish she brought her slave along with Rynn.
The High Elf’s ven regeneration was about five times Rynn’s, but there was nothing she could do about that now.
The question then became where to start her search.
Far to the southwest bordering a light forest, many of the structures appeared older or slightly dilapidated, but she could not see perfectly from her distance.
If the buildings were older, finding one unused was possible.
Starting her search there was as good of a location as any.
Eydis worked out a transmission formula while shivering in the frigid wind.
She appeared in a small, wooded grove near an old residential district on the southwest edge of the city.
No one walked the streets in the snow.
None of the automated metal carriages traveled the roads, and only a few wheel tracks drew lines in the wet powder.
Although the houses looked old and the neighborhood abandoned or at least scarcely populated compared to the rest of the city, there was plenty of life within the structures.
Her sensitive ears picked up light conversations, arguments, and people making noise while going about their daily lives.
Eydis gritted her teeth in frustration.
This was only the poor district, and she wasted precious ven to teleport here.
Eydis wondered if finding an abandoned house was not possible in such a populated city.

To not waste the ven she expended, Eydis continued walking alongside the road inspecting every house from a distance, listening to every minute noise, and peering into every window where possible with the hope that fate might shine on her and provide her what she was searching for.
The sun moved fast in the sky, and Eydis knew that the day would soon be spent.
She read in the reports that days were far shorter in this world, but experiencing it herself felt surreal.
She was about to head back to meet Austin when a small, isolated home at the dead end of a street caught her eye.
It was on the edge of the residential district, and a large, wooded land sat at its back.
Unlike many of the other houses, this one appeared unkempt.
Some form of dead ivy grew up the walls in various places, and the shrubs surrounding the back perimeter of the small property stood tall and overgrown.
Eydis walked through the untouched snow of the yard and peered between the auburn curtains of the front window.
She saw and heard no one, but the furniture and décor gave the house a pulse.
It was lived in, but there were no tracks in the snow leading to or from the door.
Either the owner was traveling or never left.
Deciding to take the risk, Eydis walked to the front step and tried the door handle.
It was unlocked.
The inside of the house was dusty and not all too dissimilar from the house that Jethro’s men had secured.
Many absurdly realistic paintings of people lined the walls of the entryway, and small decorations and trinkets sat on every shelf, table, and mantle of the living space.
Whoever owned the home had lived here for a time and had gathered many relics in their long life.
“Ara, who is this?”
A sudden hoarse voice called from down the hallway.
Like a specter, a short and smiling elderly lady hobbled over to Eydis.
Her light feet moved in perfect silence over the thick carpeted floor.
She had wispy hair that had thinned enough to show her scalp.
Brown patches peppered her wrinkled skin.
The sunken eyes on her heavily creased face smiled through the thin slits of her eyelids.
This woman looked to Eydis to be seven years old if not older, quite a ripe age for a human.
“My, you are beautiful.
It’s so nice having visitors.
Make yourself at home.
I’ll make something warm.” The elderly lady weaved past Eydis to the range and put on a kettle of water with shaking hands.
“Go on, dear.
Take a seat.”
“I apologize for entering.
I will leave.”
“No, no.
I do not care if you came here to steal something or for any other reason.
Your eyes show desperation, not malice.
You are my guest now.
Stay a while.
I never get visitors.” The lady flashed a toothy smile that had a gap in the top row just off from the center.
“Never?” Eydis sat on the cushion of a threadbare chair in the living room.
“How long ago was your last visitor?”
“Oh, two years ago just after my husband died.
God bless him.”
“How do you live?
Do you have family to watch over you?” Eydis thought it impossible for such a feeble old woman to survive on her own for such a length of time.
In the empire, she would be in the care of the community.
Humans were truly despicable if they left their elderly to survive their withered years alone.
“Oh, I never had children.
My late husband was infertile, you see.
If it’s food, I can call the market, and they deliver it to my door.
I still have money from my husband, so you don’t have to worry about me.”
A high-pitched squeal spat from the kettle.
The lady poured two pristine porcelain cups with shaking hands and mixed a spoonful of brown powder into both.
She walked the cups over and handed one to Eydis.
After taking a seat on the couch across from her, she took a sip.
The sweet fumes of the cup wafted into Eydis’s face.
A cup filled with blood flashed in Eydis’s eyes and the pungent memory assaulted her nose.
Her hands shook.
The cup fell to the floor and shattered before she realized what happened.
“I…” Eydis stared at the ruined drink.
“Do not worry yourself.”
The lady sat her cup down beside a lamp on the side table and struggled to her feet.
She returned to the kettle to pour another.
Eydis accepted it with a bowed head and handed the lady the shards of porcelain.
The lady walked with the shards back to the couch and set them aside.
She did not seem to mind the broken cup or the brown stain on her carpet.
“Do you want to talk about what is troubling you, dear?”
“I am not troubled.”
“Your eyes betray you, sweetie.
My husband was in the service for most his young life.
He always tried to hide from me the darkness that chased him, but eyes show everything.
The pain I saw in your eyes when you looked at the cup was the same.
Please, talk to me.
I cannot offer much, but my ears work well.”
Eydis sat silent looking at the brown liquid in her cup.
She smelled it once more to erase the pungent memory of blood clogging her nose.
Her hands shook, but she forced a sip, half expecting the brown liquid to be bitter like the beverage Jethro offered.
It had a smooth and sweet texture unlike anything she had ever tasted.
Shivers ran down her spine and a smile grew on her face.
Unknown to her, her feet tapped lightly on the carpet.
“What is this?”
“You have never had hot chocolate before?
Poor thing.
Drink as much as you like.”
Eydis downed her cup, and the lady refilled it.
She was about to take a sip out of courtesy but stopped and moved the cup away, subconsciously thinking for a moment that there would be blood in it this time like there had been once before.
Eydis could not stop the shaking of her hands, so she set the cup down on the mantelshelf beside her before she dropped it again.
“Don’t force it, dear.
What happened?”
Eydis bit the inside of her cheek.
“He is in my head, and I cannot remove him.”
“Who?
A father?
Brother?
Husband or boyfriend?”
“An enemy.
He imprisoned me.” Eydis’s eyes shifted to the cup beside her.
“He made me fight for his amusement.
When I tried to fight back, he almost killed me.
He forced me to work with a man who thinks of nothing but assaulting women and children…”
Eydis’s words caught in her mouth.
Her face contorted in anger and disgust.
“Children!
Jethro did nothing to help her!”
Eydis’s fists balled tight and quivered with the thoughts of all that her people had suffered at the hands of the soldiers, all that Symra, Dyas, Wian, Jil, and Rynn had suffered.
If Eydis had not been there to take Rynn away…
Eydis’s hands clenched so tight her nails pierced the skin of her palms, dripping blood onto the floor.
The elderly woman looked upon Eydis with watering eyes.
Her mouth quivered, unable to speak.
She knelt in front of Eydis in the wet of the spilled drink and clasped her hands gently over Eydis’s.
“I’m… I’m so, so sorry.
I’m so sorry…” The elderly lady’s tears fell on Eydis’s hands.
“You have been through hell as great as any war.
What of that man?
Have the police found him?
Are you free of him?”
“No, not yet, but I will be.
I will make him pay for all he has done.” Eydis clasped the lady’s hands and looked into her eyes.
“I took the girl away.
We need somewhere to hide.
We need somewhere no one will find us, where no one will visit.
No one can know where we are, not him, not even the people of this city.”
The lady brought Eydis’s hands to her cheek and rested it against them.
“You can stay here.
No one will find you.
You will be safe.
Please, let me help you.”
The woman’s voice resonated with an honest, eager truth.
Life magic channeled through Eydis’s hands into the soft grasp of the elderly woman.
She convulsed once, twice, and then fell to the floor with blank eyes.
Eydis breathed heavy.
Her heart thundered with an empty and painful pulse as she looked down at the body of the woman who sympathized with her and offered help.
She knew she betrayed that kindness, but Rynn was not human.
Even though the woman’s offer of help was genuine, there was no way of knowing how this woman would react to seeing Rynn, and she could not risk anyone knowing about her or her situation.
Eydis closed the lady’s eyes, placed her hand on the woman’s forehead, and recited simple words of parting.
“May you find rest with your husband.
Thank you for your help.”
Her words did not remove the ache, so she pushed it to the back of her mind.
Eydis picked up the cup she set down and tried to take another drink, but her hands resisted bringing the cup near her lips.
“I am not his to control.”
Not wanting to be defeated by Jethro, she forced the sweet liquid into her mouth and set the cup on the table.
Aside from the living and the dining room, there were only three other rooms in the small house.
The largest was a bed chamber containing less furniture than the house Jethro’s men occupied: only a bed, dresser, and small bedside table.
She searched the room and found nothing more than clothing and accessories.
The room’s closet contained several dresses and other clothing that might fit Rynn.
The next room contained a tub, wash basin, mirror, and a strange looking white seat.
The seat had a metal handle on it that when raised or lowered flushed water and refilled the bowl.
The lingering odor suggested it was a self-rinsing chamber pot, or so she assumed.
She could think of no other purpose for it in the small washroom, and no chamber pot was found in the other room.
Eydis had to wonder why no one in the palace had thought of such a mechanism.
One last door stood at the end of the hallway.
Given the orientations of the rooms and the size of the house, there was not enough space for another room.
Opening the door revealed a closet of hanging coats and a few boxes, but to the side a second door led to a downward stairway.
From the dark, Eydis could hear a faint humming.
She walked down but could not see any source of light nor did she have any means to produce light herself.
She could see in the dark to some extent with her Lurr eyes, but the darkness was still inconvenient, so she turned back to look in the other rooms for anything that could help.
On the way back up the dark steps, Eydis ran her hand along the wall to keep her orientation when her hand slid across a tiny lever.
The lever flipped upwards, and a dull yellow light illuminated the room.
“Some kind of cellar?
Perfect.”
Dust covered the stone floor, and jars of preserved food, tools, or miscellaneous old items lined the shelves, most of which Eydis could not even hope to identify.
A small black tank with a pipe leading to the ceiling nestled into the corner.
Wood piled next to it suggested it was used to burn fuel, but it appeared seldom used.
Just like the flushing chamber pot, this might also be deceptively similar to something Eydis knew.

A fireplace under the home made little sense, but if its purpose was heat, perhaps it acted as the heat source to the home’s hypocaust, not unlike the large furnaces that heated the bottom floors of the palace.
It was compact and finely crafted, but it was a furnace all the same.
Eydis realized that the house had adequate heat despite having no fire in the furnace.
The owner must have had other means to heat the home, but the cellar remained rather cold, being underground.
She would need to either find the means to heat the cellar or get the furnace in working order again, something she had no experience in, but she was confident she could figure it out.
She had no servants or slaves in this world.
She needed to learn everything herself.
Having inspected the cellar, Eydis turned towards the stairs.
Underneath she noticed a pale green chest, the source of the humming.
When she released the latch, mist escaped, and cold air caressed Eydis’s face.
Frost caked the sides of the chest.
It was almost empty except for what looked like a few bundles of wrapped meat.

From the moment she first stepped into this world, to viewing the city, to the strange lighting on the ceiling, and now seeing a chest that freezes its contents, she could not deny that the humans of this world had magic, despite what the reports said.
Jethro was far less informed than he thought.
Eydis had no use for meat storage, but this frozen chest could serve a better purpose.
She ran upstairs and lifted the old lady over her shoulder.
She considered teleporting her far from the city or into the river at the outer border but was unsure how traveled the river was or where people did or did not go outside the city.
If they discovered the body, they might link her to this house, and Eydis would no longer be able to use it.
Eydis found the frozen chest a blessing.
There the body could be hidden and would not decay.
She placed the lady inside and sealed the latch.
All Eydis needed was one more item to complete her preparations in the event that the princess was uncooperative, and Jethro’s men would likely be in possession of it.
If not, she would have to search the city or find another equivalent.
Eydis returned to the lounge and saw the black sky through the window.
The day moved far too fast.
If Jethro’s men were to trust her, she needed to obey their curfew.
She worked out the formula, and with a loud crack, Eydis appeared on the roof of the building she had first jumped onto.
She hopped down into the alley and walked past the people searching with wobbling heads for the origin of the flash of light.
Austin waited at their arranged location brimming with confidence.

* * *
Early the next morning before sunup, Austin took Eydis to the river.
They crouched down in the bushes to watch the opposite side.
Austin could barely see, but Eydis could pick out details on the other side of the river in the dim ambient light from the city.
After waiting for a half hour, a gate on the far side opened, and two figures walked onto the path.
A woman with long golden hair walked beside a shorter man.
Their conversation was quiet, but occasionally a small laugh came from the woman.
Before they walked too far for Eydis to see them well, she saw the woman grasp the man’s hand and draw closer.
“That was your sister, right?”
Eydis continued staring, ignoring the whisper from Austin.
There was a pull, a feeling unlike anything Eydis had ever felt before, one that forced her eyes to follow.
If she was not making an active effort to stay hidden, Eydis knew that she would subconsciously follow them, stalk them, hunt them like a predator hunting her prey.
In the dark, that woman could have easily been any tall woman with blond hair, but Eydis knew.
There was no doubt in her mind.
Something inside her that Eydis could not explain told her that this was the princess, Eydis FeAmel.
She turned to Austin and grabbed the front of his coat.
“Where are they going?”
“To the university.
The guy she is with, Justin, has morning classes today.
She follows him everywhere.”
Eydis gawked at Austin in disbelief.
She thought he only knew rumors or secondhand information, maybe from the princess’s acquaintance he knew.
She thought him wholly incompetent, but his ability to gather information was startling.
“How did you learn this much in one day?” Eydis asked.
“I knew where she lived before I was taken to your world.
I… sort of followed her around for a while.
Yesterday I just checked if she was still with him and if they still lived here.”
If Jethro knew who he had!
Eydis screamed in her mind.
“Give me one of those food bars,” she ordered.
Austen removed a small, wrapped energy bar from his bag and handed it to Eydis.
“This will last me for the day.
I will watch from the top of the buildings.
You go to the university and find what she does there.
We must find a time she is alone.
No one else can know I am here.
And do not tell her of me.
Understand?”
“Why not just go to her?”
Eydis pulled Austin closer.
“Understand?” Meeting the princess personally and explaining the situation was certainly an option and one that she was not completely opposed to, but this world was still foreign.
She had to be sure of what kind of situation the princess was in first, both for her own safety and especially for Rynn.
She could not tell how long that house in the poor district would remain safe.
She may eventually have to introduce Rynn to the princess’s associates.
Doing so without proper investigation first was foolishness.
They also needed to find a time when the princess was alone.
Whether she makes the final decision to replace the princess or join her, the initial encounter could not involve anyone other than the princess.
Austin’s frightful nod sufficed Eydis’s demand for secrecy.

After checking that the princess was out of sight and far enough away that she would not detect the use of spatial magic, Eydis disappeared with a loud crack that startled Austin, making him trip backwards.
Eydis appeared on the tallest building in the city.
The frozen morning wind stabbed her deep through her coat.
She shivered uncontrollably while locating the university from the dwarf’s explanation of the city’s layout and then formulated another transmission spell.
The transmission landed her on the tallest building on the campus.
She searched the surrounding roads for the markings of a stopping point for the transportation machine called a bus.
Eydis frowned.
“I should have asked Austin at which terminal this bus would stop.”
There were three bus stops in view from the top of the building.
Eydis resigned herself to let fate decide if she would see them exit the bus and prayed that in the time she took to create the transmission formula to the campus she had not missed them.
The same strange pull Eydis felt at the river guided her eyes to one of the bus stops.
There she spotted a familiar golden-haired woman step off the bus behind the man she accompanied.
The two no longer held hands.
The princess walked beside him with a dignified air.
A few of the humans who also arrived early waved to the princess, and the princess greeted them back in turn.
She seemed rather acquainted with, if not popular among, those at the university.
“Perhaps finding a human who knew the princess was easier than I thought.”
Or perhaps she only knew those who arrived with her in the early hours of the morning.
Austin was clearly not the only one who knew her.
Whatever the case, Eydis found it odd that Jethro’s men had not located her yet.
How incompetent were they?
The princess and the man continued along the campus path until they entered one of the structures.
Even though Eydis could no longer see the princess, because she had noticed her, she felt the princess’s location as if her very soul was drawn to her.
She could feel the moment before the princess exited the structure.
Her body recognized her prey and would not let it escape, and that feeling was terrifying.
Such heightened perception was not natural, but when Eydis remembered that she was not a High Elf but a monster called a Lurr, her surprise became disgust.
It wasn’t natural--nothing about it was--and it churned her stomach, but she understood that she had little choice but to abuse these bestial impulses to track her prey.
The pair walked to the other side of the campus and entered another building.
Again Eydis waited, and again she knew when they would exit.
The sun rose high in the midday sky.
The couple meandered around the campus cheerfully talking and greeting others.
One orange-haired woman they greeted ran over, talked with them for a long while, and then remained with them as they walked.
It was then that Austin approached the group.
He ignored the princess completely and addressed the orange-haired woman.
The more he talked, the more the woman denied his advances until displeasure grew on both the princess’s and the man’s faces.
The woman’s face grew so red that Eydis could see clearly the change in color even from her distance.
She latched herself onto the man’s arm and shouted something back at Austin.
Austin shook his head and pointed at the princess and then her partner, denying whatever she said.
The princess stood in front of Austin, blocking him from pressuring her further.
Austin left after a few pushes from the princess.
This man, Justin, had another woman besides the princess.
From the way the princess interacted with the man, Eydis was sure they were intimate and perhaps lovers.
The realization that Justin had the princess but still decided on having a second woman caused disgust to worm around in the pit of Eydis’s stomach.
Was a princess not good enough for him?
Was the princess content with this?
The princess talked to the woman to calm her down.
Her gesticulation suggested that she thought the woman could have fought him off.
Giving up on her lecture, the princess led Justin and the woman to the bus stop, and they left campus together.

Once Eydis could no longer feel the princess’s presence, she teleported to the river thinking that they would return to their home; however, the princes and her man did not appear until evening right before Eydis had to leave to meet Austin.
The orange-haired woman was not with them.

* * *
The next day, the princess did not leave with Justin until later that morning.
They rode the bus to the campus as usual, but when they arrived, they met up with a rather short, brown haired woman who could have passed as a dwarf if she had a thicker build, perhaps half-dwarf.
The man left the princess in her care and entered the largest building on campus.
The new woman and the princess talked happily as they disappeared inside a different building.
The princess stayed with this woman long past noon until Justin returned.
The woman then parted ways, and the princess remained with Justin for the afternoon.
Meet.
Handoff.
Meet.
Handoff.
The boredom of Eydis’s observations grew unbearable, but she had nothing else to occupy herself aside from fighting back the incessant urge to attack the princess.
This was nothing more than self-inflicted psychological torture.
She wondered if cooperating with the princess was even possible with such urges.
She had to resist, but she couldn’t look away.
She did not want to miss any part of the princess’s routine.
She needed to find an opening.
There had to be one, but after the tenth time swallowing the hungry saliva pooling in her mouth, Eydis wondered how long she could keep this up before the bestial urges won over.
I am not a monster!
Eydis reminded herself that she was not the Alukah, a beast that acted on pure instinct.
She was an elf, a person with thoughts of her own and control over her actions and emotions.
I am not a monster.
Little daylight remained.
The couple walked to the far side of campus out of eyesight of Eydis.

She did not want to lose them, and so she risked teleporting to another building that would give her a better vantage, trusting that the distance would still be far enough from the princess to prevent her from noticing the use of spatial magic.
The unnerving, soul-rooted pull immediately helped Eydis find her prey.
The princess continued talking happily with Justin, this time holding his hand and carrying some sort of beverage in the other.
Thankfully, the princess had not noticed the spatial magic or the flash of light that transmission produced upon arrival.
The princess and her man entered a spacious building and remained inside past sundown.
Eydis had to return, but she wanted to see when they would leave.
“The curfew is a baseless restriction.
What if the princess only left outside at night because she was in hiding?” Eydis continued talking to herself, staving her boredom and distracting herself from her predatory hunger.
She needed a valid excuse for her tardiness that did not involve informing the dwarf captain that she had found the princess.
Feeling the pull, Eydis’s eyes focused on the large glass doors of the building.
The princess appeared with Justin but was also accompanied by three other women.
The short one from earlier that day walked on the left side of Justin.
Between her and Justin was a new woman with short brown hair.
Her arms wrapped around Justin and the short woman’s shoulders.
The princess stood smiling next to Justin on his right with the former orange-hair beside her on her left, her hands clasped firmly in theirs.
Such physical association only happened between intimate partners.
It would be uncouth to appear as such in public otherwise.
Eydis’s hands gripped the masonry of the building tighter and tighter until it cracked.
Her heart thundered hard enough that it pulsed in her ears.
The bestial urges were not at fault this time.
An even stronger sense of disgust overpowered them as she watched the laughing group walk through the frigid night.
“I am going to join the princess in such a situation?” Eydis’s teeth ground together in her anger.
Or worse, replace her, she thought.
This man is no better than Austin!

Now that she had a chance at freedom by replacing the true princess in this new world, she would only become one woman among many for some human male with no attractive qualities, with no combat physique, and who lived in a poor tenement by the river.

And the princess was living happily, somehow completely accepting of being some add-on for this man and in complete ignorant bliss of everything that was happening in Whinhlem, to the Amelian Empire, to her people, and especially to those who were being preyed upon by the wretched human soldiers.
Eydis fought back the cry of fury that bubbled up in her throat, choosing instead to watch the small group with her burning crimson eyes.
Over the next six days, Eydis continued to observe the princess from afar while constantly fighting back her anger at the princess’s carefree life and suppressing the urges of her Lurr nature.
Austin tailed them close to discover the specific details of their methodic routine.
They needed an opening where the princess was alone, and Austin found one.

Chapter 20
“Tears”
Eydis
“Seriously, that bitch,” Austin groaned again.
He was spotted leaving a room restricted to women and was slapped for his efforts.
Proper treatment for a lecher.
Eydis walked a few paces in front of Austin on the roadside.
The sun had set, and the dark road was only lit by the lights of the city behind it and the few vehicles that passed.
Austin’s hands shook, and he constantly rubbed his arms.
He was clearly going through withdrawals, but surprisingly he endured them well by appearance.
Personality was another matter.
“This is the fourth time I have been hit for helping you save your sister.
Women never treated me like this before.
I am tired of being here.
The women of your world are much kinder.”
Eydis’s hands balled to a fist.
She wanted to punch Austin with her full Lurr strength.
The entire trek back, she had been trying to avoid speaking to him, but she could no longer stay silent in the face of Austin’s willful ignorance.
“Those women do not have a choice.
They are slaves!”
“That’s not true.
They can use magic, right?
I’m sure the freckled one, Symra, can fight.
She has a really toned body with a lot of muscle.
She has chiseled abs, a ton of endurance, and damn can she clamp down…”
Eydis could almost feel the slimy grin across his face.
“If they wanted me to stop, they could make me, but they say they like it.
Dyas even uses magic to make me last longer.
Quite the nympho.”
Eydis reached back and grabbed the front of Austin’s coat.
Her eyes burned red, glowing faintly in the dark.
“You think they like being attacked by a worthless animal?
Do you even know why they became slaves?”
Austin stared back without fear in his eyes.
“Because they lost the war?”
“They gave their bodies to protect their families.
They are scared that if they hurt you, hurt any human, if they do not do what you ask, if they do not do what you want, say what you want to hear, you will tell the soldiers to kill those they love.”
Austin’s eyes grew wide.
“That’s… I wouldn’t…”
A weak lie hidden behind nervous hesitation.
“You would not do that?
After how much you beat Wian?” Eydis tossed Austin into the gravel on the side of the road.
“Do not lie!
You know they can do nothing against you!
You are no different than the humans that kill my people!”
Eydis endured Austin’s presence only long enough to create a transmission formula and teleport away, leaving Austin behind on the roadside.

She was relieved that the impenetrable watch of the princess’s associates had a hole, but this did not change the fact that every day she returned to the base furious because of something Austin said or did.
“Austin knows full well that his actions anger me.”
This confrontation was only one of many.

The stronger Austin’s withdrawal symptoms showed, the more he pushed Eydis to her emotional limits when she was already mentally and emotionally exhausted from suppressing her anger and enduring her urges while observing the princess.
She suspected that the withdrawals made him less cautious, but her greater worry was that he knew she needed his help, and if she hurt him, her progress would slow drastically.
He clung onto the only weak form of control he had over her.
His withdrawals were simply emboldening him.
It was almost as if he exploited her restraint to get revenge for forcing him to do everything she wanted, possibly because she saved Rynn from him.
Whether this was his true motive or not, Eydis did not know, and she did not care.
Something needed to be done.
“He is growing too dangerous.”
The worse Austin became, the less she could trust him to do his part and not reveal her hidden actions.
Eydis opened the door of the house and found the dead body of a middle-aged, balding man in the hallway.
Another had the ill fortune of visiting.
No vehicle was parked in front of the house, so one of Jethro’s men must have driven it to abandon at some far away location as they had the others.
Eydis stepped over the body and continued to the hallway.
Jethro’s men would eventually dispose of the body as well.

When Eydis found out that they had the means to hide bodies, she considered bringing over the frozen corpse of the elderly woman she kept in the cellar, but then questions would arise about where the woman came from and why she was frozen, and Eydis did not want to deal with the trouble.
In the kitchen, only the dwarf was present.
He watched Eydis with some form of meat in his hand.
His gaze lacked his usual impartial stare.
There was a hint of distrust in his eyes.
“I thought I told you not to use spatial magic.”
Eydis acted as if she did not notice him and continued down the hall.
At the end, the door to the bedroom was closed and locked.
Eydis knocked.
“Rynn?
I have returned.”
Quiet footsteps walked to the door and unlatched it.
Rynn opened the door with faint relief.
This surprised Eydis, because Rynn never showed any emotion.
The girl wrapped her arms around Eydis’s waist and buried her face in Eydis’s stomach.
“I am sorry that I have been gone later and later.”
Eydis looked back down the hall.
Seeing that the dwarf had not followed to continue his rebuke, she walked Rynn inside the room and closed the door behind her.
“I am almost done.
I will take you away from here soon.
Did the humans give you any trouble?”
Rynn looked down at the floor.
She did not deny the question, which worried Eydis.
Eydis dropped down to her knees to look into Rynn’s shifting eyes.
“You do not belong to the humans any longer.
You can speak against them.”
Rynn hesitated but turned her back to Eydis and pulled on a tear on the back seem of her dress.
“Who?
Who touched you?”
Rynn lifted her hand high above her head.
“The giant?”
Rynn nodded.
Eydis flung open the door and ran into the kitchen.
She grabbed the dwarf by his shirt and thrust him against the cupboards.
The wooden doors cracked and then buckled inward under the force.
“I warned you and your men not to touch Rynn!” Eydis’s eyes flared.
The dwarf was not alarmed, nor did he react to the pain of the impact.
“You see that my men are gone.
I sent them away because I overheard them talking about how to take the girl from you.
Be assured that nothing happened to her.
Leaving her here alone with soldiers who are starved for a woman’s comfort is foolishness.
I am sure you realize this.”
Eydis dropped the dwarf on the floor.
His words skillfully defused her anger.
He threw the responsibility for Rynn’s safety back at her.
She understood the dangers and still chose to bring Rynn against Jethro’s wishes.
“What else can I do?
I could not leave her behind in Whinhlem without my protection, and I cannot take her with while running all over the city.
I look enough like you humans, but she is different.”
The dwarf picked himself up off the floor and sat back at the table to continue his meal.
“If you have somewhere else you could take her, I suggest you do so.”
Something was off in how the dwarf spoke.
His words were not suggestive.
It was an accusation.
Did he know?
Eydis had thought of moving Rynn to the house she found but knew it would raise suspicion against her and limit her freedom to make her own plans and preparation.
She also needed Rynn to recover ven overnight, and these humans expected her to be here.
She would not have been able to spend each night at that house on the other side of the city.
“I know you have found her.”
Eydis’s fears had been realized.
She stepped back and was about to deny it, but the dwarf spoke first.
“You have been hiding this from us, and I can only assume that you are planning to take her away and hide her somewhere.
She attends the large school, does she not?”
Eydis’s eyes grew red.
Her hands moved unconsciously towards the dwarf.
“Killing me will do you no benefit.
My men are moving into position.
We will secure her when she arrives in the morning.”
The morning classes.
How much did he know?
Somehow, they were observing Eydis, or perhaps Austin.
Eydis was backed into a corner, but she lacked the means to retaliate.
She had little choice but to reveal her hand.
Eydis never returned to the house she procured since she left the first day.
She was confident that in the least he did not know its location.
So long as that remained a secret, there was little point hiding that she had been monitoring the princess.
Her plan might still work.
She only needed to convince him not to act without her.
“You must call your men back.
It is not wise for you to confront her yet.
From what I have seen, the princess is holding combat and magic lessons.
We do not know their affinities or how skilled those who follow her are.”
“You fear amateurs?” The dwarf cast a distrusting glare.
“The princess fought Jethro and survived.
She will be difficult enough on her own let alone with others protecting her.”
The dwarf’s mustache twitched.
“I realize that you want to take her place as any doppelganger would, but our mission takes priority over whatever precautions you have made to not involve those around her.”
“I am not just referring to my desires.
We still do not know what the humans of this world are capable of.
You can expect the princess to fight back.
Any delay and the humans will come to her aid.
She is well known and well liked at that school.
We need to isolate her.”
The dwarf nodded.
“Have you found such an opening?”
“I have, so I beg your restraint.
I can send the princess to you.”
The dwarf pushed his cleared plate away and turned his chair to face Eydis.
“How can I trust that you will not take her away instead of to us?”
His question silenced Eydis.
She did not know what she could offer.
He knew she had been working behind his back and kept all information from him.
Her word would not suffice.
“How about the spriggan girl?”
Eydis grabbed the dwarf and lifted him into the air.
Red fury returned to her eyes.
The dwarf, however, did not lose his composure.
“Do not mistake my intensions.
She will not come to harm.
My men will watch her until Princess Eydis is in our custody.
We will then release her to you.” A small smile grew below the dwarf’s mustache.
“Or, you could take the spriggan and leave now.
We will have the princess tomorrow with or without your help.
Your agreement with the Commanding General will be fulfilled.”
Conflicting feelings swirled inside Eydis.
The dwarf was correct.
Jethro tasked her with locating the princess so his men could capture her.
If she let Jethro’s men attack the princess at the school, some of her associates would likely die, and those who survived would know that the princess was taken away.
Eydis would lose her place in the city, but she could find somewhere else in the world to live.
It was a tempting idea, but would other humans be as accepting of her kind as the princess’s friends had?
She would also forever be an incomplete doppelganger, just a failed copy of the original princess.
And Jethro would win.
She hated Jethro for everything he put her through and especially for consigning Rynn to slavery.
He alone would be victorious, and Eydis would only obtain a shallow freedom alone with Rynn in an unfamiliar world.
Could she place Rynn in further danger for her revenge against Jethro and the hope of a better life for her and Rynn in this world?
Eydis sat the dwarf down on the floor.
“Let me talk with Rynn.”
“Take your time.
You have until we strike to make your decision.”
Eydis walked down the hallway, her mind heavy.
She entered the room and locked the door behind her.
Rynn waited on the bed.
She sat next to the girl and pulled her down so that Rynn’s head rested in her lap.
Her fingers caressed the girl’s cheek and ran through her hair.
Forest Elf women were short in stature compared to High Elves, and in Eydis’s lap, Rynn truly looked like a child, a child that should be protected from all the evils of the world.
Eydis was the one charged with that protection.
Rynn was her responsibility, and yet…
Eydis spoke after a breath that felt like swallowing a hot coal.
“Did you hear?”
The small head nodded.
“We could leave now and live together in this world.
We would be alone, but I would be happy with that so long as I have you.” This was a third option that she had not considered.
It was so obvious after the dwarf mentioned it that Eydis had to wonder why the idea never crossed her mind.
Rynn pulled Eydis’s hand away and sat up.
She looked Eydis in the eyes and shook her head.
“You do not want that?”
Rynn shook her head again and pointed at Eydis.
Eydis gripped the blankets beneath her.
She knew what Rynn was saying.
Somehow, the girl understood Eydis’s hidden feelings better than she did.
I do not want that…
“I am sorry Rynn.
I am sorry.
I just, I cannot let him beat me.
I cannot just run away.”
And, I cannot ignore the princess, not anymore.
Eydis loathed to admit it, but after her days of monitoring the princess, her Lurr urges continually dominated her thoughts.
The only respite she found was in the presence of Rynn who alone seemed to be able to calm the beast inside.
Rynn slid behind Eydis.
Two slender arms wrapped around Eydis’s slouched body, and a small head rested on her shoulder blade.
“They already tried to lay their hands on you, and the dwarf stopped them, right?
He gave me his word that his men will not touch you while I go after the princess, but he will not be there to stop them.
I will not be there to stop them.
I am putting you in danger.”
Rynn tightened her embrace.
“I am so sorry…” Tears welled up in Eydis’s eyes.
She chose her own revenge over Rynn’s safety.
Rynn was completely selfless.
She gave of herself without ever thinking of her own wellbeing.
She surrendered herself to slavery to protect another from the same terrible fate.
And now, she was willing to place herself in the hands of the humans once more so that Eydis could take the princess away from them.
Eydis pulled Rynn around to stand in front of her.
“If you are willing to go this far for my revenge, then I will make certain you have yours.
Do you still have your knife?”
Rynn pointed to the bedside table.
Eydis grabbed the knife and tucked it into the sash on the back of Rynn’s dress.
After thinking of how much time had passed since she arrived at the house, she created a regular teleportation formula and tore open the portal.
With Rynn’s hand clasped in hers, she pulled the girl through.
They appeared on the side of the road on the outskirts of the city.
Rynn shivered from the frigid evening wind blowing over the fields.
Eydis searched down the barren road in both directions looking for her target.
Her estimations were not far off.
She spotted Austin about half a quarter mile further down walking away from them in the direction of the house.
Eydis followed at a distance while she created two teleportation formulas, one traditional and one transmission.
When finished, she lifted Rynn in her arms and ran after Austin.
Austin heard hastened footsteps and turned around.
“What are you doing here?”
He was startled to see Eydis, but his eyes located Rynn in Eydis’s arms.
Eydis set her down, and Rynn quickly hid behind Eydis.
She could not look at Austin, and her grip on Eydis’s hand tightened the longer Austin stared.
“Jethro’s men know we found my sister.
They will attack her tomorrow.”
Eydis’s announcement immediately returned Austin’s focus.
Panic rose.
“Then we need to tell her!
You can teleport to her apartment, right?”
“No.
I convinced them to let me meet her alone, so we will follow my plan, but I do not know if I can do a part of it.
I have never used Jethro’s magic on another person.
You will help me as agreed.”
Austin vanished with a loud crack.
It seemed transmission could be used on others.
Eydis used the second teleportation formula to open a portal and pull Rynn through.
They exited in a snow-covered field far from the city.
The city glowed in the distance like a glimmering gem.
The only light in the snowy field came from the stars and full moon in the frigid, cloudless sky.
Eydis felt the nighttime scene beautiful, even more so because of the screams of the man beside them serenading the dark.
“What… Gah!
Why did you…!
HaaAAHH!”
Austin’s ankle twisted back, and the calf attached to it bent at a right angle.
The other leg fared no better.
The knee hyperextended and twisted to the side.
Eydis’ transmission teleported him about fifty feet above ground into a freefall.
“Why did I hurt you?
Do you truly not know?
All the more reason to kill you.”
The color drained from Austin’s face.
“Wait!
You said… you said you wouldn’t kill me… if I helped you!”
“Do not insult me.
I did not lie.
I will not kill you.”
Eydis walked to the writhing man and stomped down on his left arm just below the shoulder.
It buckled inward with a loud pop.
Austin cried out.
His screams were like the sweet songs of morning birds in Eydis’s ears.
When they died to whimpers, Eydis stomped on his left arm in the same manner to continue the beautiful song.
Both arms and legs were broken.
Austin writhed on his back but was unable to move away.
The pain was so intense that his body entered shock.
He stopped screaming, but Eydis was content with her own retribution.
Austin looked up at her with terrified, bloodshot eyes.
“Do not look at me.”
Eydis presented Rynn.
Austin stared in horror at the knife in the girl’s hands.
“This child will end your life.”
“Ch… child? Child…?
That’s not… isn’t she older… than me?
I didn’t--”
“Do not lie!
How could you not know this was a child?
You had Wian!
You knew and still touched her!
You still hurt her!”
Eydis ran her finger down the blade of the knife in Rynn’s hands.
It surged with swirling wind energy.
“Now you will pay.”
Rynn looked up at Eydis, and Eydis nodded back.
“Wait… Please!
I… I didn’t know!”
Lies.
Rynn took slow steps over the snow and straddled Austin’s stomach, her face emotionless.
There was no joy or anger.
She was like a stone, only doing what she was ordered.
“How does it feel?
You are hurt, you cannot move, and now that someone wants to thrust something painful inside you, you cannot run away,” Eydis said with a sneer.
Rynn plunged the knife into Austin’s chest.
The wind energy coating the blade allowed the knife to cut clean and unobstructed.
Air from the knife bubbled up from the wound, spraying blood into the air.
“Keep stabbing him.
Make him suffer for what he did.
Just avoid anywhere that will be immediately lethal.”
Rynn continually drove the knife in over and over again.
When she punctured his lungs, blood and air erupted from his mouth.
She stabbed his arms.
She turned and stabbed his legs.
“You are missing a very important area.”
Rynn looked to where Eydis pointed and plunged the knife repeatedly into Austin’s groin.
The soft tissue blew apart from the force of the wind.
Eydis reached down to touch Austin’s hand and used life magic to keep him conscious and prolong his torment.
She then moved behind Rynn so that Rynn could focus solely on the man beneath her.
“He is still alive.
Keep stabbing him for every time he touched you, for every time he struck you.
For every time he hurt you or Symra or Dyas or Wian.
For every person you know and love who you lost.
For everyone who suffered from the violence or lusts of these humans, until you are content.”
Rynn held the knife in one hand and braced the body with the other.
Her strikes grew more and more aggressive.
She stabbed both shallow and deep in a rapid and haphazard flurry.
Fifty strikes grew to one hundred.
Eydis could do nothing more to keep Austin alive.
He had long passed, but Rynn showed no signs of stopping.
Two hundred strikes grew to three hundred, and Eydis began to worry.
Rynn shook from exhaustion and cold.
Each strike fell weaker than the last.
Rynn’s breath grew heavy and ragged.
She lifted the knife in her unstable hand to force the blade down as hard as she could, but when the dull knife struck the morbid heap, it failed to penetrate and slipped from her bloody fingers.
Eydis grabbed Rynn’s wrist and turned her around.
Tears ran down the young spriggan’s blood-splattered cheeks, yet she did not blink.
“That is enough.
He is dead.”
“B…but… I’m not… done…” Rynn spoke for the first time since Eydis pulled her from Austin’s lounge.
“You said… for every time…everyone that…”
Eydis’s heart collapsed within her chest.
Her hands shook, and her knees gave out.
What am I making her do?
Her orders forced Rynn to remember and relive each and every painful experience, to count how many times she had been hurt.
Eydis pulled the girl into a strong embrace.
Rynn had a deeply rooted grief over what happened to her, her friends, and her people.
The overflowing pain spilled from the girl’s eyes.
Eydis’s order had released Rynn’s pent-up anguish, making Austin the proxy for all Tolmyur had done.
“Then cry!
Forget about those monsters and cry.
Cry until the pain goes away.
It is okay to cry…”
As if listening to her own advice, tears trickled down Eydis’s cheeks.
Rynn’s lips quivered.
The stream of tears became a torrent.
Her dark crimson hands grabbed onto the sleeves of Eydis’s coat, and now with permission, Rynn wailed out the strongest cry Eydis had ever heard.
She held the small shaking body in the blood red snow under the cold moonlight until Rynn cried herself silent.

* * *
Eydis sat with Rynn in the tub of the vacant house she had prepared for her.
She found how to dispense water from the large spout, and they bathed together to remove the putrid human blood that had soaked Rynn through her dress.
Eydis did not want to bring something so filthy back to Rynn’s new home, so she left the dress with Austin’s corpse.
The blood had stained Rynn’s hair, and the human soap, though fragrant, was not strong enough to remove it.
Rynn noticed Eydis’s concern and ran her hair through her hands.
As the hair slid through, the stain vanished, sticking to Rynn’s hands where it rinsed off with ease.
This was water magic new to Eydis.
This was the first time Eydis had ever seen Rynn use magic.
She embraced the girl.
Rynn spoke, and she was using magic.
This was progress, and it helped ease some of Eydis’s worry.
She apologized again for forcing Rynn to do something so painful, but she was glad that it helped a little in its own small way.
Inside the bedroom, Eydis searched the closet for a new dress.
The elderly woman who owned the house was thin and only a little taller than Rynn.
After trying a few dresses, Rynn chose one she liked and that fit well enough.
The thick fabric was white with a yellow floral pattern, and there were small ruffles around the waist and bottom of the dress.
It was fairly worn, but the thick fabric would keep Rynn warm.
Eydis grabbed the largest knife from the kitchen to replace the one they left in the bloody field and teleported with Rynn back to the bedroom of the house on the outskirts.
She found the dwarf waiting in the living room.
He looked at the blood smears and red handprints on Eydis’s clothes and then at the new dress Rynn wore.
He reacted only with a twitch of his mustache.
Eydis breathed deep to steady her conviction.
“Tell me where your men are waiting.

I will let you keep Rynn until you have the princess, but let me warn you, should anything happen to Rynn, I will use transmission to send the princess to the other side of this world so you will never find her again.”
“Understood.
You have my word.
Are you sure you will not regret this?”
Eydis looked at Rynn who nodded back.
“Positive.”
Jethro’s men entered from the front and back doors.
Eydis stared at them in disbelief.
She never detected a lie when he said his men were heading to the university.
Eydis realized her mistake.
His words were that his men were moving into position.
He never said where or what position.
That vagueness provided an opening for deceptive truth.
His men were positioned without the house to await her decision.
The dwarf grew a complacent grin.
“Do not be so surprised.
I did not doubt you would choose to aid us.
Doppelganger tendencies are far too strong.”
Eydis realized that this was why she never considered ignoring the princess and leaving with Rynn.
Again, she was painfully reminded of what she was.
The dwarf continued.
“I will be honest and say that I had hoped you would run away with the spriggan instead of deciding to take the princess’s place.
I feel it would have been better for you, and I wanted to give you that option.
If you chose it, only then would we have moved to strike in the morning.
But now, we will follow your plan.”
The two humans and the giant joined Eydis in the living room.
“So, what is your plan?
I assume that boy Austin was not important for it.”

Chapter 21
“Eydis FeAmel”
“Good morning, my lady.”
“Hello princess.”
“That is quite the smile.”
Guards and maids greeted Eydis as she passed them down the white-marble halls of the central palace.
The quiet patter of her bare feet echoed off the stone, and the bright morning sun showered rainbow light on her through the large crystalline windows.
“You seem in a good mood.
Something nice happen?”
Eydis nodded back at the maid who walked by after her brief greeting.
She touched her cheeks and found them fixed into a large grin.
She was happy, very happy, but she could not think of why.
As she walked, she couldn’t remember the last time she felt this happy in the palace.
The large hallway was on the second floor of the central wing of the palace, and if she continued walking, she would arrive at a large crescent staircase to the first-floor west wing.
If she was in such a pleasant mood, then there was someone who lived in the west wing that Eydis wanted to share her mood with.
Eydis continued down the hallway and staircase with an increased perk to her step and excitedly greeted the guards and servants that passed her.
