Soon the marriage of the girl in the west wing to the emperor would be made public with a grand celebration.
She would then have a regal room on the third floor of the palace beside Eydis’s mother and her father’s other wives.
Ceil was probably still worried about the marriage announcement, but Eydis could not imagine her remaining sullen after Eydis spent the day with her.
The west wing was not as grand as the central palace.
The rooms were designated for royal guests who had prolonged visits to the capital, not the royal family.
This did not mean it lacked in beauty.
The marble floors were not the same pristine white as the central palace but contained swirls of silver and copper tones that glistened in the golden sunlight through the smooth crystal windows.
Pedestals bearing large vases of flowers forever in bloom lined the walls.
Above each door hung a large tapestry depicting the landscapes of the various nations that belong to the Amelian Empire.
The grandest tapestry depicted fields of wheat woven with gold thread in front of alabaster mountains and emerald forests.
A small village sat in the center where children cheerfully ran through the fields while their parents watched in a loving embrace.
It was a scene from the Filinceil Plains of the northeastern countryside bordering the Nuanae range at the edge of the empire.
The territory was the original home of the High Elves, once called Grassland Elves before the unification of the Amelian Empire.
Ceil hailed from such a village in the north.
Excitement hastened Eydis’s step.
She rushed to the door and knocked.
“Ceil, may I come in?”
“Eydis?
Yes!
Please!”
Eydis swung the door open and ran inside, but no matter where she turned, Ceil was nowhere to be seen.
“Are you hiding again?” Eydis shook her head at the girl’s childish games, but she was relieved.
This meant that Ceil was not in as poor a mood as she had thought.
The hunt began.
Ceil had a habit of hiding in her wardrobe when she was younger, but as expected, Eydis came up empty-handed.
Next, she searched under the bed, then behind the curtains.
Of course, she would think of somewhere better to hide.
Eydis sat on the bed to think.
She ran over to the sofa and looked under the skirt.
Nothing.
The chair skirts likewise revealed nothing, but Ceil was too big to fit completely under the chairs.
After all, she was now a woman of marriageable age, only a year younger than Eydis, although her father had already married Ceil in private when Ceil was but a child, something Eydis openly opposed.
A smile grew on Eydis’s face.
She knew how to draw Ceil out of her hiding place.
“I must have been mistaken.
No one is here.” Eydis walked to the door and grabbed the handle.
“I suppose I should leave.”
“But, you did leave me.”
Air caught in Eydis’s throat.
She turned and saw a body in a pool of blood on the floor.
“Ceil!” Eydis ran to the center of the room in abject horror.
The girl in a tattered purple dress had been severed in half through her stomach, her blood and viscera spilling out onto the white carpet.
Through the windows looking out to the west wing’s inner courtyard a bright purple and red flare flashed in the night sky.
“The assassination…”
Eydis ran out of the room, down the hall, and to the central courtyard where her younger twin brothers often spent the evenings dueling.
Like Ceil, both had been severed in half.
Their sabers pinned their bodies to the ground through their chest.
Eydis’s heart raced with a thunderous, terrified pulse.
“Guards!
Somebody!”
Eydis cried out, but the palace was empty.
She ran to the third floor.
Her mother’s room was empty as were the rooms of her father’s other wives.
At the top floor of the palace, Eydis ran to her father’s chambers.
“No…”
Her father and mother, her father’s other wives, they all laid dead in the lounge atop a pile of mutilated corpses of the maids, guards, and other servant she had greeted not moments earlier.
“How does it feel to have everyone you love stolen from you?
You brought this upon yourself.
Now it’s just you, princess.”
A haunting voice called to Eydis from the corridor of the bedchamber.
The human assassin waved his arm and launched a near-invisible planar projectile towards Eydis.
Eydis coated her arm in vibrating spatial ven and blocked the barrier that threatened to slice her in two.
The force knocked Eydis back into one of the chairs.
The barrier split and embedded itself into the floor and sofa behind her.
Another attack did not follow, so Eydis used the opening to run out the door.
“Somebody!
Help!”
Eydis’s futile cry echoed through the empty halls.
At the stairway to the lower floors, a portal opened in front of Eydis.
Before she could react, the assassin attacked again.
Somebody tackled Eydis from the side.
The barrier missed by a small margin and sliced through the wall behind her.
“Run!”
The familiar voice soothed Eydis’s fear.
A short human man with blond hair and the deepest blue eyes pulled Eydis to her feet and down the hall.
“Justin?”
A portal opened in front of them, and the assassin attacked.
Justin jumped in front of Eydis, and the blunt barrier knocked them both to their back across the smooth marble floor.
Eydis couldn’t move.
She could only watch as Justin struggled to his feet and stood in front of her, blocking the assassin.
The assassin lifted his hand.
“Do not hurt him!
He is not part of this!” she screamed to deaf ears.
The assassin swung his hand downward, and Justin split in half from his head to his legs.
Eydis lunged up from her bed.
Her chest dripped with cold sweat.
The fear of what she saw sent uncontrollable shivers through her body.
“Justin…”
She threw off her covers and flung her door open.
Justin slept peacefully on the couch with soft breaths matching the subtle rise and fall of his chest.
Strength left Eydis’s legs, and she dropped to her knees.
It was a dream.
It was nothing but a terrible dream.
These nightmares had repeated themselves countless times since Eydis came to Earth, but this was the first time Justin had been part of them.
It was the first time Eydis had seen Justin among those who were killed.
Eydis wiped the sweat from her face and leaned back against the arm of the couch.
She needed to calm down or Justin might wake.
The clock on the wall read 6a.m., so Justin would not rise for another two or three hours.
He did not have morning classes today, so Eydis wanted him to sleep as long as possible.
She looked beside her to his sleeping face hanging almost off the couch.
His soft breaths tickled her cheek.
She watched Justin sleep as the hands of the clock spun until the panic in her mind ebbed and her heart calmed.

So long as he was here, she would be okay, not because she was even the least bit confident in his ability to protect her--she wasn’t--but because his very presence calmed her troubled mind, although she was unsure why or how that came to be.
After sitting beside Justin for an hour, Eydis rose to her feet and returned to her room.
In the months that she had lived there, Justin’s scent that permeated the room had been replaced by hers.
The blankets and pillow on the bed were new.
Eydis bought them with her first paycheck so that Justin could have sufficient blankets in the living room to be comfortable during the cold winter nights.
Justin also bought her a thick pillow-top comforter as a gift for one of this world’s year-end holidays.
Eydis hugged her comforter, somewhat wishing that his scent was on it, but shook the foolish thought from her mind.
The nightmare had made her sweat, and there would be at least another hour before Justin woke, so Eydis decided to take a bath.
She retrieved sky-blue undergarments from the dresser and removed a set of jeggings and shirt from the closet.
She carried them to the bathroom and closed the door.
The fan in the bathroom was loud, so Eydis opted to only open the bathroom window for ventilation, letting the frigid air enter.
To prevent Justin from waking, she also opened the tub faucet only a little to let the tub fill slowly.
Long ago Eydis learned that there was little risk of suffocating when taking a bath compared to taking a shower, and baths felt far better, even if keeping herself submerged was a constant struggle.
On Whinhlem, baths in the palace were always shallow, but she was drawing her own baths now, so she made them as deep as possible.
She laughed at herself, remembering almost passing out on her first day on Earth due to a simple shower.
She was ignorant of a lot of the differences between Whinhlem and Earth, but now everything was second nature.
She could live here as easily as in her own world, if not easier.
Eydis removed her fleece sweatpants and soaked in the water.
The heat stung a bit at first, but she quickly grew accustomed and relaxed her tense muscles.
It was only a dream, she reminded herself.
A sigh of contentment escaped Eydis’s lips.
She did not need to bathe.
She had bathed just the evening before and would bathe once again after her self-defense class and magic lessons.
The cold sweat was just an excuse to relax and forget about the nightmare.
Eydis rested her cheek atop her arm on the edge of the tub.
Another content sigh escaped her lips.
Her other hand found its way to her lower back and her tail.
A light caress of her tail sent shivers up her spine.
She rubbed it and twisted it around in her fingers.
Each motion sent a numbing wave through her body.

Her maids that helped bathe her in the palace would have surely scolded her for still playing with her tail at her age, but even being able to do so was a testament to Eydis of just how comfortable she felt living here in Justin and Sean’s apartment.
She recalled the many times early on when Justin had nearly seen her tail.
Eydis sank her head under the water.
I wonder what he would have thought if he saw it…
Eydis’s face grew hot and she shook the foolish thought from her mind.
She sat up and laughed quietly to herself.
She thought back on the struggles during the early weeks after her arrival on Earth.
She never had the opportunity to mourn the loss of her family.
She suppressed her grief as much as possible, but more than once she had cried herself ragged in Sammy’s arms--weakness she felt she could never show Justin.
She struggled to be as unobtrusive as possible and worked hard to pay back Justin and Sean for their kindness in letting her stay.
Sean was always stern with her, but after she healed him of his lactose intolerance, he finally accepted her.
Justin had done much for her, and even though he could not recognize his ven, he discovered his affinity, and she was working with him daily to help him with his toxic ven.
He never blamed her for her inabilities, and he constantly thanked her for even the smallest of things she did.
After months of honest effort, this small apartment by the river truly felt like home.
After the bath, Eydis cooked breakfast.
She pulled eggs and milk from the fridge and grabbed small jars of cinnamon and nutmeg.
She mixed the milk and eggs together and seasoned the mixture with the spices.
She then removed wheat bread from the breadbox and heated a pan.
She dipped the bread in the mixture and fried it on the pan until the eggs cooked through.
French toast was Justin’s favorite breakfast.

Eydis found it rather peculiar and something that only humans would ever think up, but when topped with sweet cream and fruit preserves, she found it a very delectable food that she counted among her favorite meals of this world.
Eydis chanced a glance back at Justin and saw him watching her in silence.
“Good morning.”
“Morning…” Justin’s smile met hers, and he rolled over under his blankets to face the other way.
Eydis could not help but chuckle.
“I will be finished soon.
You should think of getting up so you can eat while it is hot.”
A muffled noise was the only reply.
When Justin had morning classes, he rose and prepared for departure rather quickly, but on his workdays when he could sleep in, getting him off the couch was a struggle.
This did not bother Eydis.
She found it charming in her own way.
Finishing the tenth slice of bread--two for her, four for Justin, and four for Sean whenever he would wake--Eydis plated them and brought her and Justin’s portions to the table.
She covered Sean’s with plastic wrap and placed it in the fridge with a note on it.
Sean would normally skip breakfast if it was not made for him.
This was another idea Eydis found to repay him.
It was small, but she knew he appreciated it.
Despite hearing the clatter of the plates and utensils, Justin did not stir.
Eydis walked over and crouched down in front of him.
“It is ready.”
She tapped him on the shoulder.
Justin stirred once more and looked at Eydis with his sleep-drunken eyes.
A few blinks later he sat up and stretched his arms.
Eydis offered her hand and pulled him off the couch.
They ate together and spent the morning in idle chatter about nothing important.
It was simple moments like this that Eydis enjoyed the most.
Sean woke up only moments before Justin and Eydis left.
Eydis pointed at the fridge, and Sean thanked her with a smile before seeing them out the door.

* * *
Eydis looked at the girl sleeping soundly in her embrace.
She ran her fingers through Rynn’s wheat-colored hair and admired the sparse strands of almost metallic-seeming silver.
She knew there was some cultural significance to silver markings among Forest Elves but could not recall what it was or if it was ever included in her limited education.
Though Rynn stirred at Eydis’s touch, she did not wake.
Her breath was heavy from the lack of air in this world, which made sleep difficult for Rynn, but she fell asleep eventually so long as Eydis was there.
Eydis held Rynn close to slowly recover as much ven as possible through contact for the monumental task later that day.
Rynn recovered ven very slowly, so they had spent the entire previous day with each other so that Eydis had enough for the battle that would likely ensue that evening.
The clock on the wall read a few minutes before 8a.m., still mid-morning in this world.
The princess would not arrive at the university until late morning, about 10 a.m. or a little after depending on which bus they caught.
Eydis could not arrive before the princess for fear of someone noticing her and unknowingly informing the princess.
This only meant that she had more time with Rynn.
Regret weighed upon Eydis.
Rynn trusted her unconditionally, and soon she would leave Rynn in the hands of the humans, the same people from which she swore to protect Rynn, but it would only be for a short time.
Eydis pulled Rynn into a tighter embrace and felt the syphoning of ven increase.

Even with all the preparation and planning, she could still fail, and in the worst case she could die, leaving Rynn alone in this strange world or worse, consign her to the hands of Jethro’s soldiers.
The house Eydis secured was for Rynn’s comfort in this world more than her own.
This was all for Rynn.

* * *
“Eydis!”
“Good morning, Sammy.”
Justin and Eydis met Sammy at the bus stop on the edge of campus.
As usual while Justin worked, Eydis accompanied Sammy to her biology and swim classes.
Justin left the two after a simple wave and headed to the student service and commons building.
“I still cannot believe that you can get paid for simply answering questions at a help desk.”
“I find it more unbelievable you thought Justin was an information broker.” Sammy laughed, and Eydis shook her head in embarrassment.
“An information broker would be even more unbelievable in our world.
With the internet, information is as free as air.
Not that there aren’t secrets or anything out there, but Justin would be the absolute LAST person who would have a job like that!”
Sammy laughed again, and Eydis bumped into her with her hip as they walked down the stone walkway.
They arrived at a single-story building on the eastern edge of campus.
It served the purpose of providing overflow classrooms for courses that could not fit in the designated college buildings.
Sammy’s molecular biology class was held in one of the underground lecture halls of this building.
The professor had a reputation for being strict and heavy on memorization of even the minutest details in his lectures.

Sammy would have chosen the second section with a different professor, but the timing of this section better allowed her and Justin to synchronize their schedules to trade off accompanying Eydis, and for that, Eydis was grateful.
Eydis also enjoyed the lectures.

The professor’s love of details proved invaluable to her understanding of the human and even her own elven body, and it was because of this class that she had enough understanding to heal Sean of his lactose intolerance.
Eydis was quickly learning that there was very little difference between a human and an elf, body density aside.
The professor reciprocated Eydis’s enjoyment of the class.
Normally, non-students needed permission to officially apply to audit the course, but after only a week of Eydis attending, the professor noticed her love of study.
Eydis’s questions were pointed and not only led to greater understanding for the students but also contributed to the flow of the lecture.
To him, she was the perfect student.
Sammy, however, did not share the sentiment.
“I’m struggling enough as it is in that class…”
The discussions often became too deep for her to follow, and much of this was because of Eydis’s questions.
“At least I can forget about all that while I swim.”
“That attitude is why you struggle,” Eydis cautioned.
Sammy bumped into Eydis with her shoulder.
The university’s pools sat inside a structure just southwest of the health and fitness building.
Sammy’s swim class was less structured than other fitness courses in that so long as the students attended and recorded their activities and progress, they received credit.
It was not a class for beginning swimmers, and a few members of the university’s swim team attended.
The professor only served as an emergency lifeguard, but she was often absent, so the swim team members with lifeguard certifications took turns filling in for her with her permission.
Normally, Eydis sat on the side of the pool and watched, but this time Sammy had other plans.
She pulled Eydis into the locker room and removed a swimsuit from her backpack.
The dark green one-piece swimsuit had a sewn-in skirt attached around the waist that would help conceal the bump from Eydis’s tail.
It came with an accompanying swim cap large enough to hold Eydis’s hair if wound tightly and came down far enough to cover the tips of her ears.
“It should fit.
Your size hasn’t changed from the last time we went shopping.”
Eydis hugged Sammy.
She never thought of joining Sammy in the pool due to concern over her elven traits being revealed.
Once again, she felt even more that she was finally fitting into human society.
There were no individual booths in the locker room, so Sammy held a towel in front of Eydis to conceal her while she changed.
The swimsuit fit perfectly.
The form of her ears showed under the swim cap, so Sammy had to wind Eydis’s hair over the tips of her ears to mask the shape.
The large room contained two Olympic-sized swimming pools and one short-course pool that was shallow at one end.
Sammy usually kept to the short-course pool while the swim team members attending the class swam laps in the larger pools.
She hopped into the shallow end, her chin barely above the four-foot-deep water.
Eydis sat on the edge and slid in.
This was her first time in deep water in this world, and as expected she could not easily keep her feet on the floor of the pool.
She immediately became buoyant and pulled her knees in to keep from floating to her back.
This caused no small amount of laughter from Sammy.
“I guess we never have to worry about you drowning.”
“It is no different than Whinhlem, so swimming should not be a problem.”
Eydis pushed off the edge of the pool and began an elementary backstroke down Sammy and her lane.
Her body never sank below the surface of the water.
Once she reached the other side she switched to a breaststroke--or what could be called a breaststroke--for the return.
Sammy fought to hold in her laughter.
“Did I look that strange?” Eydis asked.
“I can honestly say I have never seen anyone swim like that before.” Sammy swam off and skillfully repeated the strokes Eydis had done.
From what Eydis felt while swimming and what she saw Sammy do, there was a strong difference.
Their weight differed by about forty pounds in Sammy’s favor.
Their body density made all the difference.
Eydis’s form looked odd to Sammy because of Eydis’s buoyancy, but she could do nothing about that.
She could only swim how she learned in Whinhlem, which was designed for those highly buoyant like her.
After a few more laps, Sammy pulled Eydis aside to the edge of the pool.
“I want to show you something.”
Sammy placed her palms on the surface of the water and pushed up.
She rose about a foot out of the water and held herself there for a few seconds before dropping down.
“I can do it with my feet too, but keeping balance is really hard.”
Sammy then held her hands out in front of her under the water.
Without any motion on her part, she flowed backwards as if being carried away by a slow current.
“I can propel myself much faster than that too.”
“Where do you practice?” Eydis asked, astonished.
Sammy would not be able during her swim class with so many people watching, and Eydis was always with her.
She had never seen Sammy practice here.
“There is a small indoor pool at the dorms.
It’s closed in winter, but the hot tub remains open.
I practice when no one is around.”
Eydis was astonished by how far Sammy progressed.
Sammy had struggled to control her ven, but now that she learned her magic could be applied to swimming, she had an increased determination to master it.
“You’re finally in the water.”
Two men, both members of the swim team, walked over to the corner of the small pool next to Sammy and Eydis.
“I saw you swimming earlier.
If you want someone to teach you how to do a proper breaststroke, I would be happy to teach you.”
“Of all the swimming pickup lines, you choose stroking breasts?” Sammy shook her head with a playful smirk.
“We could show you proper form.
It’s just a matter of practice,” the second spoke up, completely ignoring Sammy’s attempt at turning their offer into a double entendre.
Sammy climbed the edge of the pool and stood in front of the two men.
“Eydis knows how to swim just fine.
She’s just one of those people who are more buoyant than most.
She floats without trying.”
“I am fine,” Eydis echoed in goodwill.
“Sammy is helping me well enough.”
“She can join.
We could show her a few things as well.”
Eydis sensed no malice in the two’s kind gesture.
They only wanted to help, so she considered humoring them, but Sammy shook her head.
“How about a race?
If I beat you, you leave Eydis and me alone.
Which one of you is faster?”
The two men looked at each other confused.
One pointed his thumb at the other.
“Kris, so you probably don’t want to race him.”
“Kris it is.”
Sammy walked to her bag and drank half her water bottle at once.
She then walked over to a lane in the full-length pools and stood on her pedestal.
The occupant noticed the ensuing spectacle and cleared the lane.
“Are you coming or not?” Sammy jeered.
“She can’t be serious…” Kris looked at Eydis with bewilderment.
Eydis only shook her head and hopped out of the pool to follow Sammy.
“200-meter freestyle sound good to you?” Sammy asked.
“Are you sure about racing me,” Kris asked back after mounting his pedestal.
“I wouldn’t have challenged you if I wasn’t.
Don’t hold back.
I’ve been wanting to test myself for a while now.”
Sammy nodded at the other swim team member who shook his head in disbelief but began counting down.
At his call, Kris and Sammy dove into the water.
Kris appeared above the water a full five meters past Sammy.
He continually gained distance over Sammy, but to the astonishment of Kris’s teammate, the distance did not grow very fast.
As she was, Sammy could have been considered one of the faster members of the women’s swim team.
Kris kicked off the far side of the pool and began his return.
Sammy followed, but her kick had a lot more force to it.
She not only gained a few meters on Kris, but she also no longer lost distance.
Only about a fifteen-meter gap separated them.
With the kick to begin the final lap, Sammy gained another few meters and was even gaining on Kris.
“Impossible…”
At this time most of the swimmers in the pool had stopped swimming, and a few other students around the pool watched the race.
Eydis could not have been prouder of how far her student progressed.
The gap closed to less than five meters when Kris and Sammy met the far edge of the pool.
After they kicked off, Sammy was only a meter behind.
The onlookers cheered Sammy on while the swim team watched in disbelief, shouting at their team member to stop going easy on her, but they all knew he wasn’t.
Kris swam with the same seriousness he had at meets.
At the 25-meter line, Sammy passed Kris.
The onlookers went crazy with shouts that echoed across the spacious room.
Victory was clearly Sammy’s to all who watched, but past the 15-meter mark, Sammy began to falter.
Her meter gain on Kris lessened until they fell neck in neck.
The onlookers watched with bated breath as Sammy and Kris touched the edge of the pool.
Two swim team members raised their hand in Sammy’s favor.
The spectators erupted in a deafening cheer at the impossible sight of a five-foot tall woman beating a top member of the men’s swim team.
Sammy tried to climb up the edge of the pool, but her arms shook too much from exhaustion.
Kris lifted her in the water while his friend grabbed her hand.
“That was amazing!”
“I didn’t know you could swim like that!”
“What was that?”
Sammy lay on her back and looked up at the group of people surrounding her.
“Are you okay?”
“You look pale.”
“I just ran out of juice.
That’s all.” Sammy forced the biggest smile she could.
“Can someone grab my water?”
Kris’s friend hurried over to Sammy’s bag to retrieve her water bottle.
Eydis immediately recognized what was wrong.
She knelt down, pulled Sammy to sit, and placed her forehead against hers.
Sammy only had about a tenth of her ven left.
She pushed herself far past the critical mark by sheer willpower.
Magic to control movement in water took very little ven, but Sammy currently lacked control, so much was wasted in order to attain the speed Sammy needed.
Eydis placed her hands on the side of Sammy’s head.
Sammy’s capacity was far less than Eydis’s, so she replenished all Sammy’s missing ven.
Color returned to Sammy’s face and her shivering stopped.
Sammy retrieved her water bottle from the one who fetched it and drained the rest.
“Can you fill it again?”
Sammy handed off the bottle and returned to her back.
Even though Eydis replenished her ven, the physical exhaustion from the swim remained.
Eydis could not have felt prouder of Sammy, but reprimanding her student was also her duty as a teacher.
“That was incredibly careless of you.
You pushed yourself too hard.”
Sammy smiled wryly.
“Are you doping or something?” Kris knelt next to Sammy with disbelief painted over his face.
“No way.
I’ll let you in on a secret, though.
You wanted to teach Eydis how to swim, but the truth is, Eydis is the one coaching me.
She is the reason I can swim like that.”
Kris shook his head, but then smiled.
“This is my defeat.
Ever think of joining the swim team?
With some practice, I bet you could medal in the Olympics.”
“No way.
Swimming is just a hobby for me.
I don’t want to make it my job.
That’d ruin it.
Despite how I look now, I do it to relax.”
Kris chuckled.
“That’s a serious waste of good talent, but I can respect that.”
“And don’t think of trying to pull Eydis into coaching the swim team.
She’s already got her hands full teaching a self-defense class.”
Kris looked at Eydis who shook her head lightly.
He clicked his tongue in disappointment.
“Then this is definitely a loss for me.”
Sammy spent the remainder of the class resting against the wall next to Eydis and downing bottle after bottle of water until her stomach bulged.
She chatted with the students who stuck with her but dodged any questions about what Eydis taught that helped her improve so much.
After the class, an hour remained before Justin’s shift ended, so Eydis and Sammy meandered around campus, met up with Chloe, and enjoyed each other’s company until Chloe had to leave for her class.
When Justin arrived, it was Sammy’s turn to go to work for a couple hours with the promise that she would see Eydis later that evening.

* * *
“Promise me Rynn will come to no harm,” Eydis demanded.
“You have my word, so long as you do your part.”
The dwarf extended his hand to Rynn who reluctantly extended hers.
He pulled her away from Eydis and handed her off to the two humans who accompanied them to this world.
Rynn tried to appear strong, but tears slowly collected in the corners of her eyes.

“If I hear from Rynn that you so much as looked at her with lust in your eyes, if I so much as see a single scratch or bruise or loose thread on her clothing, you will suffer a death far worse than Austin.”
When the dwarf realized that Eydis killed Austin, he was not angry.
He only asked for the location of the body and sent his men to retrieve it.
The brutality of the murder made one of the humans ill, and that same human now held Rynn’s shoulder.
His face grew pale after hearing Eydis’s threat.
Eydis glared at each human, dwarf, minum, and giant with her deep red eyes as a final warning.
She then vanished with a snap.
Eydis jumped out from behind the bushes in the back of one of the buildings on the south side of campus.
There was no walkway here, only foliage, grass, and eventually a wall marking the border of the campus.
It was the most vacant location on campus, and being on the south side, the princess would not be able to recognize Eydis’s spatial magic.
Although, from previous spatial magic use during her observation of the princess, the princess’s perception range was rather small as expected.
The students walking to and from the various buildings paid Eydis no mind.
Eydis disguised herself with a large coat and baggy pants and had a woven cap with her hair wrapped and bound tight inside.
The cap covered her ears, and a scarf was wrapped around her mouth.
Only the bridge of her nose and her eyes showed.
Judging by how the students reacted to the princess whenever they saw her, Eydis was confident in her disguise.
No one recognized her.
When Eydis looked in the mirror of the bedroom after she changed into these clothes, she could not even tell she was a woman.
The large clothing hid all her femininity.
She looked like a tall human male of this world.
Eydis picked up her pace with confidence that she would not be discovered and headed to the north side of the campus to the health and fitness building.
She withdrew the map Austin had drawn the day he died.
It was torn and bloody from Rynn’s revenge but was still legible, barely.
If she had a little more forethought, she would have taken it from him beforehand.
The princess currently accompanied her friend, Sammy, at the swimming class and would remain there for an hour.
The proximity of the class to where Eydis headed was a cause for concern, but Eydis would be able to tell if the princess moved from that location due to her doppelganger instincts.
Even if she saw the princess, Eydis felt that the princess would not be able to recognize her.
Once inside the large glass doors, Eydis followed the directions down the main hallway and turned to a smaller pathway on the right.
A door opened into a small open-air enclosure at the end.
Another door on the other side led to a wing of the building with a few smaller rooms containing desks.
There were no students here, and all the rooms were empty.
A women’s restroom sat at the end of the hall.
Eydis entered and found a door to the right with a sign that read “Changing Room.”
A large mirror and bench stretched along one side.
Three private stalls lined the wall on the other.
There was a small opening to a single shower across from the entrance.

Eydis had initially planned to confront the princess here to speak with her and probe the truth of the princess’s life in this world, hoping that she was somehow mistaken in her assumptions made from her observations.
Now that Rynn was in the hands of the soldiers, that was not an option, at least for now.
Her hand was forced.
Eydis entered the middle stall so that she could be next to the princess no matter which stall the princess used.
There she waited.

* * *
“Sammy really surprised me.
Your body naturally shuts off access to your ven when it decreases to dangerous levels.
An incredible amount of training is needed to force your body to use ven it refuses to give, and she did it like it was second nature.”
“Sounds like her.
She’s a stubborn one.”
Justin followed beside Eydis cheerfully listening to her ramblings about what she saw Sammy do at the pool.
“And how fast she was able to control water ven is astounding.
She might be more of a natural than I thought.
Sammy just needed the right motivation.”
“So Sammy, Chloe, and Miriam are all naturals?
Maybe humans of our world are far more adept at magic than those of your world.
Not that I can say anything about myself.
I still can’t feel my own ven.”
Eydis stopped walking.
The assassin who attacked her family far surpassed even Emer in spatial magic.
She could not rule out the possibility that more humans existed that could surpass elfkind in magic ability.
Justin, a human with a ven capacity so large that she was scared to inform him honestly about just how large it was, had an affinity to time magic, something unheard of in Whinhlem.

Even a spatial affinity would be considered so incredibly rare for a human to possess that Eydis was sure the number of humans that possessed it throughout the entire history of Whinhlem could be counted on one hand.
Where did that human assassin come from?
Justin held his hand out to Eydis.
He could sense something was troubling her.
She grasped it, and a smile returned to her face as they headed towards the health and fitness building to prepare for the self-defense class.
When Eydis and Justin arrived at the door to the large vacant room where the class would be held, Eydis squeezed his hand tighter before letting go and continuing down the hall.
Ever since Justin learned that Eydis still had anxiety over her situation here on Earth, he became far more sensitive to it, almost as if he was actively watching for when something worried her.
Eydis opened and closed her hand.
The gentle warmth of his grasp lingered.
He had to know that those small gestures brought her more comfort than anything else could.
He was always thinking of her.
Eydis smiled to herself as she opened the door to the small open-air enclosure but stopped in front of the adjacent door.
“I am taking him for granted.
I must make sure to thank him for always looking out for me.” Eydis opened the door with a glowing smile.
“Sammy as well.
She decreased her work hours so that I would always have someone with me.” She giggled.
“Maybe my debt has not yet been repaid.”
The friends Eydis met in this world were more than Eydis could have ever wished for.
Chloe, and even her newest friend, Miriam, did their utmost to make sure that Eydis was cared for.
It was not out of pity of her situation.
It was not because Eydis was from another world and was sent here after losing her family.
At least, she was positive that these were not the primary factors.
Everyone genuinely loved her.
She knew this and felt it every day.
“I must thank them all again.” Eydis’s feet continued with a light perk to her step.
The women’s restroom door creaked as did the door to the small changing room.
Today, the middle stall was in use--rare.
Eydis took the one on the right and removed her bag.
She emptied her pockets of her phone and apartment key setting them next to her bag on the small bench.
I will definitely thank them.
Sammy and Justin’s birthdays are coming up.
I will use that opportunity.
Eydis removed her cap and jacket and was about to unbutton her pants.
--Spatial ven--
Eydis’s mind worked at lightning speed to erect a barrier, but she found herself standing in a snowy field.
A giant, four humans, a dwarf, and two minums surrounded her at a distance.
The dwarf stared at Eydis with a pleased grin.
“Hello princess.”

* * *
That was close…
Just as Eydis thought, the princess recognized the spatial magic and almost took countermeasures.
The instantaneous nature of transmission was the only reason she had succeeded before a barrier was erected.
Now Eydis needed to hurry.
She did not doubt that the princess could defend herself, but she did not know what tricks Jethro’s men had prepared.
Eydis worked quickly to recall her memorized formula and disappeared.
The two humans startled at Eydis’s sudden appearance in the bedroom of the house on the outskirts.
Rynn knelt back against the headboard of the bed with her knife extended and pointing towards the soldier who sat lazily on the end of the bed, facing her.
Of all the places in the room, the man sat on the same bed as Rynn, somewhere he knew his proximity would trouble her.
Eydis swiped her hand, and the head of the human who sat on the bed flew from its shoulders.
His body rolled off the bed to the floor.
Color drained from the remaining man’s face as he realized that Eydis was betraying them.
He ran to the door but could not escape the barrier that split him from his left shoulder through his back.
His body buckled and crumbled onto the ground.
Eydis hurried to Rynn and pulled her off the bed into an embrace.
“I will join you shortly.
Wait for me.”
Rynn vanished with transmission’s snap.
Eydis removed her cumbersome coat and scarf and ran to the kitchen.
There she located the final piece of her preparation on the floor by the back door, preparation for if the princess was uncooperative.
The humans provided as expected.
She sent it to the cellar of the house, her transmission spell crackling from the peculiar metal’s natural resistance to magic.

* * *
“Hello princess.”
Eydis barely managed to erect a barrier before being assaulted by wind, fire, and earth magic.

She needed to escape, but her ability with spatial magic was insufficient to concurrently fight and create a teleportation formula, and even if she could, with this many opponents she doubted she would have time to use it.
Her training with Symra ended before she was proficient enough in spatial magic from Emer’s lessons to apply it in combat drills.
The barrier waned quickly, and the heat from the fire magic made her sweat.
Eydis ran in the direction of two humans and altered her barrier in front to allow wind magic to pass.
She could not see the exact location of the humans amid the barrage, so she swung her arm in a large arch to blindly launch a wide blade of wind.
A wind spear passed through the fire and grazed her shoulder, but another did not follow.
She continued running and passed the body of a human on the ground.
The explosions of fire ceased and the snow at her feet clumped up around her, tripping her.
Eydis turned on the ground to face her attackers and refreshed the barrier.
The giant stood in front of her.
His arms as thick as her torso rose together with hands clasped tight.
Eydis quickly reinforced the barrier to defend against physical attacks, but it was futile in the brunt of the giant’s strength.
The barrier could not absorb the blow.
The force of the impact into her barrier slammed Eydis to her back.
Her joints popped and creaked in protest, and the recoil of the ven used in the barrier numbed her arms.
The barrier shattered, but she survived.
The giant’s arms rose again.
Eydis rolled and kicked off the ground.
The impact into the ground blew dirt and snow in all directions, and a small crater remained.
Her barrier was not weak.
The giant was far too powerful.
Eydis sprung to her feet to run, but the humans had repositioned themselves surrounding her while she was down.
A fireball flew at her.
She tried to dodge, but the snow clumped at her feet again.
Another makeshift barrier protected Eydis from the explosion that not only enveloped her but also the giant.
Eydis sensed faint spatial magic from the nearby house.
Tolmyur reinforcements might have arrived.
When the fire cleared, the lightly singed giant charged.
His arm reeled back, ready to strike with the immense force of his momentum.
Wind gathered in Eydis’s hands.
She expelled it with enough power to blow away the snow that bound her and launch her through the air.
The impact of the giant’s strike missed Eydis by only a few feet.

The debris shot from the ground in the direction of one of the minums who attempted to shield himself with his arms, but the spray of rock and dirt blew him back into a motionless heap on the frigid ground.
“That’s why I was against bringing that seknum monster!” shouted the minum beside him who barely managed to avoid the debris.
Eydis landed in the snow twenty feet away from the impact and rolled into the feet of one of the humans.
He drew his sword and thrust it at her chest.
Eydis rolled to the side and kicked her left foot into the sword hand of the man.
The blow deflected the blade away.
She used the momentum of the kick to spin to her back and place her hands on the ground by her shoulders.
With a push, she sprung up backwards to land on her feet.
The human thrust at her again when she landed.
She hit the flat side of the blade with the palm of her left hand and deflected it to the left.
Another human encroached from behind and swung his sword upward.
Eydis barely noticed in time to arch her back out of the way.
The blade grazed her right arm near the elbow, but the cut was shallow.
The faint sensation of more spatial ven came from the house, or she thought it did.
She was now too far to tell clearly.
Eydis stepped into the first human to keep within sword range.
He drew his sword back to give room for a strike, but Eydis grabbed his free wrist.
She lifted the arm, tucked herself under, and with her body locked into the right alignment, she struck the man in the side.
Her unconverted ven pulsed through her form and into her strike, disrupting the flow of ven in the man.
He buckled and fell to the ground from the strike that would otherwise be harmless.
This was the true nature of the martial art she learned and now taught, to manipulate and control both the user’s and opponent’s ven.
Eydis conjured a small wind spear to end his life, but out of the corner of her eye, a dark projectile approached.
She tried to dodge, but the snow clumped at her feet again.
She twisted her body enough to avoid the small stone spike launched by the minum.
Before falling to her back, Eydis managed to impale the wind spear into the neck of the stunned human she grounded.
Again, Eydis felt spatial ven from the direction of the house.
If more soldiers were arriving, she needed to escape quickly.
But the soldiers barely let her breathe let alone provided her an opening to escape.
The snow around Eydis clumped at her arms and legs and pinned her to the ground.
The remaining human raised his sword and swung down at Eydis’s neck.
She was sure he could not use magic, or he would have already, so she formed an emergency physical barrier at the location the strike landed.
Unfazed, the human continued his assault while Eydis could not move.
All the while, stone spikes propelled at incredible speed by air magic flew at Eydis between sword strikes.
Eydis was forced to defend against two types of attacks from two directions.
She could not move.
She could not escape.
The humans caught her.

Chapter 22
“A Helping Hand”
Eydis
Eydis flung opened the back door.
Near the center of the snowy field, the princess defended against blow after blow with quickly formed barriers.
She had eliminated a few of the humans already, but her situation was dire.
She had no chance of retaliating, and once her ven ran out, that would be the end.
What confused Eydis was what pinned the princess.
She couldn’t see anything or anyone holding her, but the princess could not move.
The surviving minum hurled stone spike after stone spike at the princess.
A human mage stood afar while another human attacked with swift strikes from his blade.
The giant appeared ready to charge.
The dwarf leading the group knelt in the snow closer to the house.
He only observed the fight when she expected him to be at the vanguard, being a dwarf.
Instead, the dwarf buried his hands in the snow.
Eydis understood immediately that he was using the snow to bind the princess.
The giant charged, spurring Eydis to action.
If she did not intervene, she knew the princess would not survive.
She ran with all her Lurr strength toward the dwarf.
Snow and dirt blew out behind each step.
She swung her arm, targeting his neck.
A thick wall of ice shot up from the snow behind the dwarf.
He felt her approach in the snow he controlled.
The impact of Eydis’s arm blew away the ice wall and showered the dwarf in frozen shrapnel.
His concentration gone, the snow holding the princess crumbled.
The princess blew the human away from her with a great gust of wind that launched her to the side.
She barely avoided the blow from the charging giant and was now free to fight back.
Eydis breathed a sigh of relief.
“I had hoped it would not come to this.” The dwarf protected himself from the destruction of the ice wall with a shield fashioned of ice.
“You chose to protect the princess?
I must say that surprises me.
If she survives, you cannot replace her.”
Eydis swung both her arms to release two offensive barriers at the dwarf.
He was the leader and could not be taken lightly.
The snow shifted under the dwarf and moved him at an incredible speed out of the way of the barriers.
Frost coated both his arms until they froze solid.
The shield in his left hand grew in thickness and size.
In his right hand, a large war hammer formed.
Icicles covered the face of the hammer, and the back bore a single large spike.
The entire hammer radiated frost that chilled the air around it.
“I must admit that I half expected this to happen.
Jethro did warn me you might cross us.
My only question is why you sent her to us.
You could have sent her anywhere.
You even threatened as such.”
Eydis glanced in the princess’s direction.
The human with the sword lay motionless on the ground.
“Why hinder us?
You could let us kill her and then remove her,” the dwarf continued.
“I have no obligation to explain myself to you,” Eydis replied flatly.
The dwarf was clearly stalling for time, and she wouldn’t have it.
The dwarf’s mustache twitched.
“Of course… But it is a shame.
I wanted better for you who lived a lie your entire life.
Now you will never escape Jethro.
But if that is your choice, there is nothing more I can do.”
The snow at the feet of the dwarf propelled him in an S curve towards Eydis, his feet almost skidding across the surface as a tail of powder shot out behind him.
His speed was far quicker than Eydis could run, even as a Lurr.
She barely managed to dodge when the strike of the war hammer hit at her feet.
Shards of ice sprayed upward from the impact.
One grazed the left side of Eydis’s hip and another cut across her right forearm.
The wounds frosted over and numbed her skin and muscles.
Shivers ran through Eydis’s body from the sudden drop in her body temperature.
She rapidly increased her metabolic rate with life ven to heat her body, making her feverish.
The frost thawed, but doing so took a large toll on her ven.
She would not be able to keep that up for long.
She needed to avoid being hit again.
The dwarf slid on the surface of the snow in a large arch for his next approach.
He skimmed near but not over a patch of thin snow.
This did not go unnoticed by Eydis.
She readied wind magic in her hands and planted her feet solid on the ground.
She blasted a torrent of wind at the snow in front of the dwarf.
The snow blew away in all directions.
When the dwarf hit the bare patch of dead grass and dirt, he stumbled forward but caught himself on the ice shield and continued sliding towards Eydis on top of it.
He raised his hammer and slammed it on the ground.

Eydis jumped back and prepared to defend against the spray of ice shards, but a concussion wave of frost replaced the explosion of shards and coated the ground in ice, completely covering the area Eydis cleared.
Of course he would have prepared for such a strategy.
Eydis landed on the slick ice and struggled to stay standing.
The dwarf rolled off his shield back to his feet and continued sliding on the ice.
He had to have used a lot of ven to maintain his assault.
He was only a race of human.
His ven capacity should be small.
If Eydis could outlast him, forcing him into a physical battle, then she would have a chance.
In a contest of strength, a dwarf could never beat a Lurr.
In the corner of her eye, Eydis saw the princess get blown back by a strike of the giant.
Her barrier took the brunt of the hit, but the force sent her bouncing and sliding along the ground.
The minum had been killed, but the duo of the human’s explosive fire magic and the giant’s pure strength overpowered the princess in her tired and weakened state.
Eydis did not have the option of drawing out her battle with the dwarf.
The princess would be killed if she did not hurry.
But how could she beat a combat magic expert?
The reality that Eydis had never received combat training dug deep into her mind.
She figuratively shook away the worrisome thoughts that would only cause her to hesitate, but even that delayed her reaction when she needed quick thinking most.
Eydis swung an offensive barrier in panic to stop the sudden strike from the war hammer.
The dwarf’s shield caught the barrier and broke.
What little sharpness remained barely cut into his arm.
The hammer struck the ground at Eydis’s feet unobstructed as he passed, sending a spray of ice shrapnel.
She erected a quick barrier, but some of the shards already passed and powdered her body leaving cuts and punctures through her clothes.
She screamed in agony as the chill of death sent painful and uncontrollable shivers throughout her body.
Had she not created a barrier and the whole of the shards hit, the attack would have been instantly fatal.
It would have already been fatal if she was not a Lurr.
Eydis collapsed to the ground barely able to move.
Sparing a glance at the princess and the hesitation that followed had been a critical mistake.
She surged life magic through her body to heat herself but was unable to warm up in time to dodge the next hit.
In desperation, she erected a barrier in front of her.
The dwarf collided into it with enough force from his reformed shield to shatter the barrier, but his momentum was lost, and he was unable to swing his hammer.
He sped past Eydis to ready another approach.
Eydis opened and closed her hands.
Feeling started to return to her body, but her ven was running low.
Eydis struggled to her feet and faced the approaching dwarf.
She could barely stand, and every movement of her frozen joints felt like they would snap.
She had an idea, but she would have to take the full brunt of the next attack and trust her Lurr resilience to be able to absorb the blow and resist the ice.
The dwarf charged with shield forward and hammer extended backward.
He raised it for a final strike against the shivering elf.
Right as the hammer fell, Eydis dove into the shield.
A deathly chill shot straight through her body.
The dwarf’s momentum kept her pressed against the shield.
She clung on with her right arm and grabbed the dwarf’s neck through his armor with her left hand.
A contest of whether Eydis would freeze to death or the life magic would stop the dwarf’s heart began.
The dwarf realized Eydis’s intention and flung her off.
Eydis tumbled over the snow with the shield frozen to her chest.
He struggled to keep upright but collapsed.
The damage had been done.
Nothing was more lethal than the life element that included death magic.
Eydis stumbled over her frozen legs towards the fallen dwarf.
She tore the shield off her chest, taking the front of her shirt and a layer of frozen skin with it.
The dwarf looked up at Eydis with clouded eyes.
He was still alive but barely.
“Can I have your name?” Eydis asked.
“Mordok,” the dwarf barely managed to speak.
“You fought well, Mordok.
Die proud.”
Of all the human breeds, the dwarves were the most honorable.
Eydis could not find it within herself to fully hate him.
He offered her every chance to take the easy path, the safe path, and leave with Rynn.
For a human, he was caring in his own way.
Mordok smiled and then grew still.
Using what remaining ven she could spare, Eydis attempted to heat her body and prepared to help the princess.
For the rest of the fight, magic was no longer an option.
She had to save what ven remained.
Eydis charged towards the princess who was now on her back desperately trying to hold a barrier against the giant’s merciless onslaught.
The fire mage stood at a distance and sent explosive fireball after fireball without regard to the safety of the giant.
The giant’s clothes smoldered, and black burns dotted his exposed back and arms.
The human had to die first.
Eydis ran at him, forcing her frozen legs to move faster and faster.
The movement helped warm her, but she was nowhere near as fast as she had been before.
A swift strike would not be possible.
The human noticed her approach and threw a fireball.
Eydis dodged it and was propelled forward by the force of the explosion behind her.
She landed in a roll that was more a controlled tumble and continued charging.
At her distance now, an explosion would be just as harmful to him as it would be to her.
She was close enough to be safe.
Or so she thought.
The human threw a fireball at his feet when Eydis reached him.
The explosion blew her back and sent her bouncing over the ground.
Luckily, the worst of the damage was minor burns on her chest, arms, and face.
Her woven cap prevented her hair from burning, but the threads smoldered.
A human torch ran out of the explosion towards Eydis.
As the fire cleared, the human kept fire coating his hands and feet.
He was completely unharmed from his explosion.
He had full-body heat resistance.
The first strike of his fist peppered small explosions through the air.
He jabbed once and then twice.
Each time fire exploded from his knuckles.
He had only been keeping his distance from the giant.
He appeared far more comfortable in a melee.
Eydis, with her lack of any combat training, had to rely completely on her Lurr reflexes.
Each jab barely missed.
He forced Eydis into defense and was not giving her an opportunity to counterattack.
At least the heat helped her numbed body.
Strike after strike, Eydis found her body moving better and better.
Mordok’s ice magic was far more dangerous.
If anything, this human was helping her recover from her previous fight.
The human pivoted on his foot and kicked.
Eydis ducked under it and sprung at the human.
He arched backwards with his circular momentum as Eydis dove over him.
With his hands planted on the ground, he spun his legs above him and nailed Eydis with the arch of fire they expelled.
Eydis rolled in the snow to smother the flames and returned to her feet.
The human readied a fireball, so Eydis charged again.
She could not risk distancing herself.
She swung her hand full force.
The human quenched his fireball and attempted to block her, but this proved a fatal mistake.
He was not fighting a normal elf.
Her hand blew right through his forearm, shattering bone and sending a spray of blood along its path.
“GHHAAAA!”
The human reeled back in pain.
Eydis exploited the opening to punch him in the stomach, embedding her fist inside of him.
Strong heat radiated from the deep wound.
Eydis tried retracting her fist, but the human wrapped himself on her arm.
He looked at her with furious eyes and smiled with a seeping, bloody grin.
The heat increased enough to burn her hand, and soon the rest of his body began to smoke.
Panic set in.
Eydis lifted the man and slammed him into the ground, but he would not release his grip.
His skin grew red, and his clothes caught fire.
In desperation, Eydis ran and scraped him across the ground.
She jumped and slammed him once and then again.
With one final swing, the man lost consciousness and flew from her arm.
Eydis ran away as fast as she could.
A deafening explosion erupted from the body of the human sending a massive plume of fire and smoke into the air.
Had Eydis been caught in the blast, she would have died instantly.
There was no doubt in her mind.
She looked up at the plume with quivering jaw.
All her planning and all her struggle was almost reduced to a pitiful burnt husk by a human fire mage.
That was the difference of experience.
Eydis was far more powerful, but he was far more skilled.
I must hurry.
The smoke would alert those in the city, if they had not already noticed the battle.
Someone would arrive before long.
Eydis charged across the snow at full speed towards the giant.
She was no longer frozen and could make use of her speed.
Every bit of strength she could muster went into the fist she flung mid charge at the giant’s back.
The giant swung his arm wide as if he knew Eydis was there.
It collided with her side, sending her flying over fifty yards back through the air.
Eydis crumpled onto the ground, bouncing over the dirty snow, and then slid over the ice Mordok created.
She finally stopped near the house.
Her breath was gone, and she could feel acute pain in her ribs.
The blow was stronger than the Alukah’s.
Pooled blood vomited out her mouth.
Her body shook.
It screamed in writhing agony.
What magic had the giant used to become this strong?
How did the princess hold off against such strength for so long?
Even now, the princess lay on her back futilely erecting barrier after barrier to block each strike from the giant, unable to manage anything else.
Eydis rolled to her torn knees and spat out the remaining blood.
She could not target the giant.
She needed to free the princess.
Step by step, she forced her shaking legs to trudge towards the giant.
With each step, she picked up speed.
Instead of running directly at the giant’s back like before, she curved a large arch to the giant’s side and dove.
The giant’s fists swung down, but they hit nothing but earth.
Eydis rolled over the snow with the princess in her arms and collided with the wire fence bordering the back of the property.
Two of the wires snapped from the force of the impact, but the barbed metal only scraped her resilient skin.
She pulled the princess to her feet.
The giant stood in fuming anger at the loss of his target.
“EEEYYDISSSS!”
His eyes glowed deep crimson.
A Lurr.
Lurr were naturally powerful, but giants also excelled physically.
A Lurr giant would only multiply that natural strength.
“We must flee.
We cannot defeat him,” Eydis begged.
The princess struggled to stand.
She placed her hand on Eydis’s shoulder, speaking through haggard breaths.
“No… We cannot let a monster… like that… remain in this world…”
A monster.
Of course.
The princess’s words cut another deep wound in Eydis’s heart.
“I can no longer use magic, and you cannot contest it physically.
If I hold it off, can you finish it?”
“I can try, but my ven is low.
I will only get one chance,” the princess warned.
The Lurr charged, and Eydis ran to meet him.
He readied his shoulder to tackle past Eydis to reach the princess.
She slid down on the snow and caught the Lurr’s leg in her armpit.
As she thought, the Lurr was also lighter in this world.
Her momentum tripped him.
She hooked her arms around his leg and spun him three times before releasing.
The Lurr flew back and tumbled across the snow, slid over the ice, and collided with the back wall of the house.
The princess channeled wind into her hands.
It condensed and swirled so heavy that it became visible.
Seeing this, Eydis ran after the Lurr to keep him as far from the princess as possible to give her time to channel her attack.
The Lurr only had time to stand before Eydis lunged into him feet first.
She kicked out on impact and sent him crashing through the back wall into the kitchen.
The kick sent a painful shock up through Eydis’s body that wouldn’t subside.
Her body shook and her breath fell heavy.
Her lungs burned from pushing them far past what they were willing to give in the thin air, and she struggled to stand.
“Foolish woman.”
Eydis barely had time to brace herself before the hardwood table collided with her, blowing her back over the ice.
When she hit snow, friction caught her, and the force of the table knocked out what little wind remained in her lungs.
It rolled over her and left her motionless on her back.
Ice crunched under each of the Lurr’s steps.
He stood over her, completely unharmed from her attacks.
His thick fingers wrapped around her ankle and lifted her up.
She floated above him and then flew down into the ground with incredible force.
Snow and dirt blew out in every direction.
The Lurr lifted her and slammed her again into the ground.
The woven cap flew off, releasing her bound golden hair.
Eydis felt her leg dislocate.
Blood rushed to her head and seeped from her eyes.
She was going to die.
When the Lurr lifted her again, she swung her hand at his wrist.
The weak barrier was not strong enough to cut through, but it severed a tendon or two.
The surprise of the sudden injury forced the giant to release his grip on the downward swing.
Eydis flew through the air.
The world spun around her in a nauseating blur of black, white, and dark blue with thin, spiraling strings of light from the city.
The impact was not as strong as Eydis expected.
She flew high but not far.
The princess stood only a short distance away.
The small ball of wind energy had grown to a swirling torrent that engulfed the princess’s entire body, but she continued channeling.
Eydis looked behind her at the Lurr.
He noticed the princess’s magic as well and grew cautious.
The princess glanced down at Eydis.
“Do not let him run.”
What more do you expect of me!
Eydis suppressed her cry of protest and fought her body to stand.
When she thought she was steady, her dislocated leg gave in, sending her to the ground.
She bit her inner cheek until it drew blood.
Grabbing her leg, she felt the socket and forced her leg back into place with an audible pop.
Tears grew in her eyes.
She cursed the princess with every burning nerve in her body.
She would not hold out much longer.
Even Lurr had their limits.
Eydis stumbled over the snow after the Lurr giant.
He retrieved the table and split it lengthwise in half, holding a piece in each hand.
One half of the table swung horizontally at Eydis.
She barely had time to duck.
The thick wood was heavy enough that if it hit her, it would blow her head clean off.
The second half of the table swung down.
It slammed into the ground a mere hair’s width from Eydis’s face, the upheaved earth wrenching her neck to the side.
The Lurr continued swinging the halves of the table as freely as if they were twigs, using the weight of one to counterbalance the weight of the other.
The dance continued without giving Eydis a chance to breathe.
A sudden trip or slow reaction would end her life in an instant.
One half of the table swung widthwise, giving Eydis no room to duck.
It collided with her shoulder and sent her into the ground.
The next table came down.
Eydis rolled to the side.
The corner of the table dug into the ground where her head was just a moment before with enough force to fracture the thick wood and send splinters flying.
Eydis kicked the center of the table, splitting it and knocking it out of the giant’s injured hand.
The next half of the table followed immediately after.
The Lurr swung it down flat making it impossible for her to dodge out the way in what narrow window of opportunity that might have been there.
She braced against it with her arms and legs, and the impact caused the joints in her elbows and knees to pop.
The Lurr added his weight to try and crush her.
“Fool.” This world made the giant far lighter.
If Eydis was a normal High Elf, she would have been in danger, but for a Lurr, the weight of a giant and table was easy enough to bear.
The princess watched on the side of their fight.
She finished charging and only waited for Eydis to signal when to strike.
Eydis acted as if the table was crushing her to keep the attention of the Lurr and shifted her leg to the side.
Bracing the table with only one leg and arm, she placed her elbow on the ground and kicked off.
The table flew up and the Lurr to the side.
“Now!” Eydis dove away, but not fast enough.
The Lurr grabbed her leg and held her out in front.
A strong wind blew her direction.
The princess either could not or did not want to stop her attack.
Eydis’s chest pounded to bursting.
She had to escape.
The wind became painful.
She could almost feel the skin of her chest peeling.
This was no time to reserve ven.
Eydis grabbed the Lurr’s wrist and pulled all the ven she could from her tired and broken body to convert it into a weak and simple life magic spell.
The Lurr’s arm numbed and released her.
She dove to the side as a deafening roar blew past her.
The torrent of wind knocked Eydis into a tumble further away.
The Lurr stood at the center of the horizontal funnel.
The wind threatened to blow him back, so Eydis locked a barrier around his feet with the last dregs of what ven her body would give.
It was weak, but it held the Lurr’s disproportionately light body.
She held it as the fever and shivers of ven exhaustion set in, and she desperately fought to keep conscious.
The Lurr shielded his face, unable to move, but his arms were no more effective than parchment against a sword.
Hundreds of blades of wind cut into the Lurr.
The barrage chewed at his arms, legs, and torso.
Behind him, a misty spray of gore blew out as clothes, flesh, and eventually bone was torn away.
The open carcass devoid of any flesh or organs soon disintegrated along with her barrier inside the funnel leaving nothing.
Only a long trench remained following the path of the wind extending out from the princess.
Tears fell from Eydis’s eyes.
She was almost caught in that blast.
The princess did not hold back, fully ready to end her life along with the Lurr.
Unable to bear the horror and pain any longer, Eydis collapsed to the ground and cried.

Chapter 23
“The Crossroads of Happiness and Misery”
Eydis
The wind leaving Eydis’s hand ebbed as the prepared ven ran out.
She had never attempted magic of this magnitude, and it left her physically exhausted.
She gasped for breath, unable to find enough air to supplement the cost of ven conversion.
Lightheadedness dropped her to her knees.
It was then that she noticed the badly injured woman on the ground not far from her.
The High Elf exhibited incredible physical prowess.
When she called for her to attack, Eydis trusted that she would be out of the way.
The amount of wind circling her blurred her vision of anything in front save the vague silhouette of the large monster.
She feared that the woman had gotten caught in the blast, but relief washed over her seeing that the woman survived.
Eydis struggled to stand and walked to where the woman collapsed.
She was crying silently, and Eydis feared that her injuries were severe.
She lifted her to sit back and began mending the fractured bones, ruptured organs, and countless wounds all over her body.
This woman had taken far more damage than she had in her efforts to save her life.
Eydis wondered how she was still alive.
Such severe injuries would have killed Eydis.
She could never repay such a debt.
“Thank you… Thank you for saving me.”
Now that Eydis had the opportunity to look at her at length, the woman seemed very familiar.
She had blood and dirt all over her face, and her chest was badly torn from the fight, but there was no mistaking what she saw.
This woman looked identical to her.
The longer Eydis’s hands touched the woman, the more she felt a weak syphon of ven, different from the drain of the life magic she was using.
This explained the woman’s strength.
As Eydis traced her hand over the woman’s chest to repair the damage and regrow the skin, she mustered up the courage to speak the question in her mind.
“You… you are a Lurr.
Who are you?”
The woman’s shaking hands grabbed Eydis’s arm.
She looked into her eyes and fought to stifle her tears.
“I am Eydis FeAmel.
I am sure you know what I mean.”
For the past year, Eydis had supplied blood at the command of her father for the creation of her first body double.
Although she provided for its growth, she never met it personally.
Her father forbade it, citing the dangers should they ever meet.
“You are my double, the doppelganger I created.”
The doppelganger nodded.
“Why are you here?”
“To find you.”
The doppelganger placed her hand on Eydis’s shoulder and pulled herself to her feet before Eydis could finish healing the surface wounds.
In Eydis’s lack of usable ven, she was unable to heal the more delicate internal wounds.
“You shouldn’t move.
Your injuries will worsen.”
The doppelganger’s gait was unstable.
Eydis braced her until she finished wiping her tears and found footing.
Sirens blared in the distance, and Eydis looked in the sound’s direction.
“The police are coming.”
“Before these police arrive, we must set fire to the house.
We need to prevent Jethro from using it again.”
“Burning the house down will not stop a portal from forming,” Eydis tried to explain.
“No, but drawing as much attention to this place as possible will prevent him from using it.
He wants to stay hidden.”
The doppelganger grabbed Eydis’s wrist and pulled her over to the house, nearly tripping in the snow several times due to her trembling legs.
They entered from the collapsed wall.
“I do not know much about the humans of this world.
If there is something you can use to set the house ablaze, do it.
I will try to find the trace of their portal back to Whinhlem.
I have no means to send you back to Amel otherwise.”
Eydis’s heart sank in her chest.
“Go back?” The shock of that simple phrase completely overshadowed all else her doppelganger had said.

It spun in her mind, forcing away any emerging thoughts on how a portal trace was left at the source, not the destination, meaning that the doppelganger had no means to even bring her back to Whinhlem, or if the doppelganger even knew this about portal traces.
She gazed back out the large hole in the kitchen wall.
Smoke rose from burnt soil at the center of the explosion’s crater in the field.
Her own attack left a deep and long scar in the ground.
The snow across the field was died red and shimmered in the moonlight and umber glow of the crater.
And the many bodies of her enemies littered the ground.
The assassin who sought her life, Jethro, knew where she was.
She was fortunate this time, but if Tolmyur attacked her with Justin or Sammy present, she could not bear the thought of them getting hurt or worse.
Memories of her nightmare early that morning sent shivers down her spine.
She could not bear Chloe getting hurt, or Miriam, or Sean, or any of the other humans of this world.
They were not part of this conflict.
They lived peaceful lives in this peaceful city.
Could she bring war to Gullivan?
Could she willingly endanger this world?
She would only bring them harm if she stayed.
Eydis did as her doppelganger asked.
She grabbed a cushion from the living room and brought it to the stove to light on the gas flames.
She caught the cupboards of the kitchen on fire.
Back in the living room, she set the upholstery on fire, then the curtains.
The fire alarm cried out an ear-splitting howl.
Next, she carried the cushion down the hall to the study and set the bookshelf ablaze.
The room filled with black smoke.
Another fire alarm joined the chorus.
Eydis felt this sufficient to burn the house down.
Eydis used weak wind magic to keep the air near her mouth clear and moved down the hall to the single bedroom where two dead soldiers lay.
They were severed cleanly in half, far too clean to be the work of a blade.
The memory of Eydis’s twin brothers laying in their own gore returned and dominated her thoughts.
A sharp pain pierced her heart, and the drowning sensations of anxiety sank the nauseating ache into her stomach.
Eydis felt sick.
She felt worse than the entire preceding fight against Tolmyur’s assassins.
Go back?
The doppelganger’s words repeated over and over in Eydis’s head.
Go back?
What awaited her back on Whinhlem, back in Amel?
Her family was dead.
Everyone she loved was dead.
Only turmoil awaited her there.
Surely the Royal Council was preparing for war with Tolmyur, and she alone would be left to lead it as Empress Eydis Amel.
Duty, impossible expectations--she wanted none of that, not after tasting the happiness that Justin and Sammy had provided for her here.
This was her home now, not Whinhlem, not Amel, but a humble apartment along the river in Gullivan.
What about Tolmyur?
They now knew she was in Gullivan.
Her presence was a danger to everyone.
However, this world had technology that Tolmyur could never match.
Dr. Shuman was ready to contact the police at the first sure evidence of a Tolmyurin threat, and was this not such a case?
Now that she knew Tolmyur had access to this world, her returning to Whinhlem did not guarantee the safety of those here in Gullivan.
She could stop hiding and be upfront about who she was.
The police, and possibly the military, could help.
Surely, Tolmyur had no chance against them.
The Royal Council could handle the Amelian Empire.
Even without the royal family, the Amelian Empire could still function as a confederation.
She could still do her part without losing her new life with Justin and Sammy by fighting Tolmyur should they inevitably appear here again.
Eydis’s anxiety slowly started to ebb as she justified her reasons to stay.
Regret and guilt still gripped her heart, but she felt that after tasting such happiness here, she would break before ever being of use back in Amel should she return.
She fought through the smoke to look for her doppelganger to tell her the plan.
Something felt off.
Eydis had been all through the small house but did not see the doppelganger.
“E… Eydis?” she called, feeling slightly awkward calling her own name.
A blow to the back of her head brought blackness.
Eydis fell limp into the arms of Eydis.
Eydis lifted a small knife she retrieved from the kitchen and stabbed it into the shoulder of the unconscious elf.
Crimson blood flowed freely from the wound.
The attack was unintended.
She had not planned to prey on the princess, especially not before having a heart-to-heart discussion with her.
But the princess was unguarded, vulnerable, and weak from the fight.
She had lied about searching for the nonexistant portal trace.
She had to separate from the princess, to hide and resist.
In Eydis’s ven-starved and injured state, the Lurr urges she had been suppressing for many days broke through.
Eydis placed her mouth over the puncture and sucked.
A feeling unlike anything she had ever felt filled her body.
A nostalgic flavor that caused an uncontrollable high danced in her mouth.
It was succulent.
It was energizing.
In the smoke-clouded bedroom mirror, she saw the faint pink tint of her skin fade to a lighter, natural elven color.
Her body felt full, free.
It was as if she had been sick all this time.
She had unknowingly been going through withdrawals and only now began feeling normal again.
She could feel her ven returning at a staggering pace.
She could feel her body changing.
The pure euphoria made her want to laugh.
It made her want to cry.
At long last, Eydis had her prey.
Eydis’s conditioning snapped her back to consciousness.
Her training took over, fueled by the life-threatening encounter against the Tolmyur soldiers just moments before.
Her doppelganger was on the ground in less than a second.
However, her opponent was no simple elf.
Her doppelganger dodged the wind spear Eydis had subconsciously conjured to impale the imminent threat to the floor.
Eydis ran out the gaping hole in the wall.
The sudden exertion left her light-headed, and she almost collapsed to the ground.
She felt deathly cold.
Her shoulder bled, so she stemmed the bleeding with life magic.
She was foolish, so foolish.
She had ignored her father’s warnings about the danger of a doppelganger because her doppelganger saved her from her assassins.
But that thought was wrong.
She wasn’t being saved.
The doppelganger was a Lurr, a monster, and she was its sole prey.
The doppelganger was merely taking back its prey.
Eydis created a quick teleportation formula and tore open the portal the moment her doppelganger appeared from the smoking hole in the back wall.
The portal had a simple destination, the mountains further from the city that she first saw from Dr. Shuman’s office window that day months ago.
She threw herself in as the police sirens blaring down the gravel road reached her ears.
She never heard her doppelgangers apology and plea for her to wait.
The portal collapsed the moment Eydis exited, lacking the ven to keep it stable.
She landed hard on a rocky slope and tumbled over the rough stone until she landed in the cushioning snow drift beneath a pine tree.
The light of the city was not visible from her location.
She could barely see from what little light filtered through the boughs of the towering pines in the clear night.
Eydis quickly readied life magic to regulate her body temperature, already dangerously low from her blood loss, but a quick flash of light appeared at the location her portal had collapsed.
There stood her doppelganger.
Eydis had only seen a teleportation formula trace read so quickly once before.
She made the connection to the two soldiers who were killed so cleanly back in the house.
Only one person was capable of these feats and could teach her doppelganger.
“You… you sided with Jethro, with the humans.”
Her doppelganger’s once apologetic eyes now glowed red, faintly tinting the dark.
What chance of understanding that might have remained vanished, replaced with fury.
“Who are you to judge what I had to do to survive!” She dove at Eydis.

Eydis drew enough ven from her body’s critical reserves to expel a torrent of wind that blew her out of the snow drift and into shallower snow, but taking the ven her body needed to sustain itself worsened the sickening cold she felt.
Her body weakened further.
Her doppelganger was quick to respond and blew through the deep drift without effort.
Before Eydis could recover, her doppelganger pounced on her, pinning her.
Eydis disrupted her opponent’s balance with her legs and swapped positions, but that did not last for even a moment.
The difference in power was too great.
She could never hope to compete against a Lurr, even an injured Lurr, as weakened as she was now.
The doppelganger was on top once again pinning her even tighter.
“I sided with the humans?” the doppelganger roared.
“What about you?
Were you not living with them?
Did you not find yourself a man among them, living in such ignorant bliss of the horrors that are happening to your own people?!”
The doppelganger grabbed Eydis’s neck and squeezed.
“Yes, I sided with them.
I did everything I could to earn their trust so I could find you, so I could meet you.
I wanted to help you.
I wanted to work with you against them!
But after what I saw as I observed you… You never spared a thought to your own people’s suffering,” the doppelganger growled.
You’re wrong!
Eydis wanted to scream, but the powerful grip on her neck sealed her voice.
The doppelganger’s glowing eyes bored down on Eydis piercing her to her moral center.
Shock grew on the doppelganger’s face, and her eyes slowly widened into a pained stare.
Her grip eased slightly on Eydis’s neck.
“You do not want to return.
You want to stay here…”
“No, you are wrong!” Eydis pleaded with the little air she could glean, but the guilt of her decision back at the house gripped her heart tight.
The doppelganger’s eyes burned the deepest of red in unrestrained fury, almost blinding in the dark.
Her grip tightened on Eydis’s neck once again.
“LIES!
You just lied!
You want to abandon your people?
For these HUMANS?!”
Angry tears budded in the corners of the doppelganger’s eyes.
“Are you not the heir of Amel?
Your duty is to lead your people.
To PROTECT them!”
The doppelganger’s jaw quivered.
The budding tears dripped onto Eydis’s face.
“I did not have to save you.
Jethro wants your body to present to your people.
I could give you to him.
But, you do not deserve a martyr’s death.
You are not their princess.
You are NOT their empress!”
The doppelganger licked her lips.
“Just as you created me to be a tool for your survival, your only use now will be a tool for my evolution.
You should be grateful that the people of your empire who suffer from Tolmyur’s occupation will never know of your cowardice… your betrayal.”
Eydis wrenched her prey’s neck to the side and bit into her shoulder.
She sucked the wound until no more blood followed.
She then bit again beside it to draw more.
Instead of the euphoria she had felt when she first fed on her prey, now she only felt anger.
She wanted to kill this fake princess who would have easily abandoned Rynn to suffering at the hands of Jethro and his men, but she forced herself to stop when she felt the body grow cold.
If she continued, the fake princess would surely die.
She used her replenished ven to heal the wounds she inflicted and to stabilize the weakened body.
After one last curse at Jethro and a promise that he would never win, she tore open a portal to the house where Rynn awaited her, the new Eydis FeAmel’s, triumphant return.
